For this re-published version, the prior versions of the IPR Policy will apply, except that the previous
requirement for Adopters (as defined in the earlier IPR Policy) to agree to an O-RAN Adopter License
Agreement to access and use Final Specifications shall no longer apply or be required for these Final
Specifications after 1st July 2022.
The copying or incorporation into any other work of part or all of the material available in this
specification in any form without the prior written permission of O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.  is prohibited,
save that you may print or download extracts of the material on this site for your personal use, or copy
the material on this site for the purpose of sending to individual third parties for their information
provided that you acknowledge O-RAN ALLIANCE as the source of the material and that you inform
the third party that these conditions apply to them and that they must comply with them.

1 Introductory Material 1
1.1 Foreword 2
This Technical Specification has been produced by the O-RAN Alliance. 3
The contents of the present document are subject to continuing work within O-RAN and may change following formal 4
O-RAN approval. Should the O-RAN Alliance modify the contents of the present document, it will be re-released by O-5
RAN with an identifying change of release date and an increase in version number as follows: 6
Release x.y.z 7
where: 8
x the first digit is incremented for all changes of substance, i.e. technical enhancements, corrections, updates, 9
etc. (the initial approved document will have x=01). 10
y the second digit is incremented when editorial only changes have been incorporated in the document.  11
z the third digit included only in working versions of the document indicating incremental changes during the 12
editing process. 13
1.2 Scope 14
1.2.1 General 15
The present document defines tests that validate the conformance to the protocols defined in [2] for the Lower Layer 16
Split Option 7.2x interface between the O-RU and the O-DU.  A guiding principle for these conformance tests is to use 17
only standard interfaces that are defined by the specification [2] or relevant 3GPP specifications.  The construction of 18
these tests avoids the requirement for a device to include any special interfaces used solely for the purpose of these 19
tests. 20
While these tests are not written to evaluate the performance of an O-DU or O-RU device, some tests require obtaining 21
measurements and evaluating the success or failure of the device to process sample data correctly based on portion of 22
the protocol being tested at the time.     23
In general, unless otherwise stated, the tests cover LTE (Stand-Alone), NR Non-Stand-Alone (NSA) and NR Stand-24
Alone (SA).  25
In the main body of this specification (in any “chapter”) the information contained therein is normative meaning 26
binding on any compliant system, unless explicitly described as informative ( a capability described as “optional” may 27
or may not be included in a compliant system but if it is included it must comply with the optional capability 28
description).  Information contained in an “Annex” to this specification is always informative.  29
1.2.2 U-Plane and C-Plane Scope 30
This version of the Conformance Test specification defines tests which validate the conformance of an O-RU.  The tests 31
are designed to cover a large number of optional functionalities defined in [2].  Therefore, for any given O-RU 32
implementation, a subset of these tests may not be applicable.  It is the responsibility of the tester to understand the 33
applicability of each test to the feature provided by a particular O-RU.    34
Future versions of this specification may add tests which validate the conformance of the O-DU to the U-Plane and C-35
Plane and may expand on other areas not currently addressed in this version. 36
1.2.3 S-Plane  37
This version of the Conformance Test specification defines tests for time synchronization of the O -RU and O-DU.  The 38
tests defined in this version include both functional and performance tests.  Functional tests validate the ability of the O-39
RU and O-DU to achieve the proper synchronization management state based on a variety of PTP, and optionally 40
SyncE input conditions.  Performance tests validate the conformance of the recov ered clock for the O-DU or O-RU.   41

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       7
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
Concerning the scope of the S-Plane, various synchronization options have been defined in the ORAN CUS 1
Specification [2] for distributing synchronization to the O-RU (LLS-C1, LLS-C2, LLS-C3 and LLS-C4). Depending on 2
the specific ORAN deployment being considered not all of them may be relevant. When testing the S -Plane, the tester 3
shall identify which of the test cases are relevant depending on the specific deployment scenarios addressed. As a 4
general guideline the following applies: 5
1) Direct connection between O-DU and O-RU:  6
• LLS-C1 is generally the main sync option to be validated.  7
• LLS-C4 may be considered as alternative or as a complement to C1 8
2) Synchronization network between O-DU and O-RU 9
• LLS-C2 for cases where the synchronization is delivered to the O-RU via the O-DU and over the bridged 10
network. In this topology the PRTC synchronizing the O-DU may be local or remote.  11
• LLS-C3 for cases when the synchronization is distributed to the O-RU without involving the O-DU. In 12
this case one or more PRTC may be remote and may also be local. 13
• LLS-C4 may be considered as alternative or as a complement to LLS-C2/C3 14
For LLS-C1 and LLS-C2, a local PRTC is either embedded in or co-located with the O-DU. A remote PRTC is 15
located anywhere in the network (backhaul or fronthaul).    16
 17
 18
1.2.4 Test Requirement Status 19
The following table is a list of each test in this conformance specification and status of the test as REQUIRED or 20
CONDITIONAL MANDATORY.  Note that tests that are REQUIRED are for those functions of the DUT that by 21
specification are required to be supported.  Optional functionality in a DUT implies that the corresponding conformance 22
test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY and is mandatory only if the DUT supports the optional functionality.  23
The M-Plane conformance tests are applicable to both the O-RU and the O-DU.  Some of the M-Plane tests are 24
specifically targeting the protocol conformance of the O-RU and are not necessary for conformance testing of a O-DU.  25
Therefore, for M-Plane tests, the table below has two “Test Requirement” columns describing if the test is mandatory, 26
conditional mandatory or optional for testing an O-RU or a O-DU.   If a test is OPTIONAL, it does not need to be 27
included in a conformance test of the device but could be included if desired.  28
Test
Number
O-RU Test
Requirement
O-DU Test
Requirement Test Description

1.3 References 3
The following documents contain provisions which, through reference in this text, constitute provisions of the present 4
document. 5

non-specific. 7
- For a specific reference, subsequent revisions do not apply. 8
- For a non-specific reference, the latest version applies. In the case of a reference to a 3GPP document (including 9
a GSM document), a non-specific reference implicitly refers to the latest version of that document. 10

1.3.1 Definitions 10
For the purposes of the present document, the terms and definitions given in 3GPP TR 21.905, “Vocabulary for 3GPP 11
Specifications”[1]and the following apply. A term defined in the present document takes precedence over the definition 12
of the same term, if any, in [1] 13
C-Plane Control Plane: refers specifically to real-time control between O-DU and O-RU, and should not be 14
confused with the UE’s control plane 15
DL DownLink: data flow towards the radiating antenna 16
eNB eNodeB (applies to LTE) <E-UTRAN NodeB / Evolved NodeB> 17
EVM Error Vector Magnitude – see section 6.5.2 Modulation quality in 3GPP TS 38.104 18
fm-pm Fault Management, Performance Management role 19
gNB gNodeB (applies to NR) <Next Generation NodeB> 20
M-Plane Management Plane: refers to non-real-time management operations between the O-DU and the O-21
RU 22
NETCONF Network Configuration Protocol. For details see: RFC 6241, “Network Configuration Protocol 23
(NETCONF)”, IETF, June 2011 24
NSA Non-Stand-Alone network mode that supports operation of SgNB attached to MeNB 25
O-CU O-RAN Central Unit – a logical node hosting PDCP, RRC, SDAP and other control functions  26
O-DU O-RAN Distributed Unit: a logical node hosting RLC/MAC/High-PHY layers based on a lower 27
layer functional split. O-DU in addition hosts an M-Plane instance. 28
O-RU O-RAN Radio Unit <O-RAN Radio Unit: a logical node hosting Low-PHY layer and RF 29
processing based on a lower layer functional split. This is similar to 3GPP’s “TRP” or “RRH” but 30
more specific in including the Low-PHY layer (FFT/iFFT, PRACH extraction).>. O-RU in 31
addition hosts M-Plane instance. 32
PTP Precision Time Protocol (PTP) is a protocol for distributing precise time and frequency over 33
packet networks. PTP is defined in the IEEE Standard 1588. 34
PDCCH Physical Downlink Control Channel applies for LTE and NR air interface  35
PBCH Physical Broadcast Channel applies for LTE and NR air interface 36
SA Stand-Alone network mode that supports operation of gNB attached to a 5G Core Network  37
SCS OFDM Sub Carrier Spacing 38
SSB Synchronization Signal Block, in 5G PBCH and synchronization signal are packaged as a single 39
block 40
subordinate The term “subordinate” is used as a replacement for “slave” and is consistent with its use in CUS 41
specification. When consensus emerges on how to eliminate the use of the term “slave” in the 42
referenced standards organization, that approach will be applied to this specification  43
sudo Super-User Do role 44
S-Plane Synchronization Plane: Data flow for synchronization and timing information between nodes 45

                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
SyncE Synchronous Ethernet, is an ITU-T standard for computer networking that facilitates distribution 1
of clock signals over the Ethernet physical layer 2
T-BC Telecom Boundary Clock 3
TWAMP Two-Way Active Measurement Protocol 4
UDP User Datagram Protocol 5
UE User Equipment terminology for a mobile device in LTE and NR 6
UL UpLink: data flow from the UE towards the core network, that is from the O -RU towards in the O-7
DU in a Fronthaul context. 8
1.3.2 Abbreviations 9
For the purposes of the present document, the following abbreviations apply.  10
 11
C-Plane Control Plane: refers specifically to real-time control between O-DU and O-RU, and should not be 12
confused with the UE’s control plane 13
CUSM-E C-Plane, U-Plane, S-Plane and M-plane emulator – test equipment capable of sending and 14
receiving required messages for all of these protocol planes when the Radio Unit is the device 15
under test 16
DL DownLink: data flow towards the radiating antenna 17
DUT Device Under Test 18
eNB e NodeB (applies to LTE)  <E-UTRAN NodeB / Evolved NodeB> 19
gNB g NodeB (applies to NR)  <Next Generation NodeB> 20

RU 22

(NETCONF)”, IETF, June 2011 24
NMS A Network Management System 25

PDCP/RLC/MAC/High-PHY layers based on a lower layer functional split.> 27
O-RU O-RAN Radio Unit  <O-RAN Radio Unit: a logical node hosting Low-PHY layer and RF 28
processing based on a lower layer functional split.  This is similar to 3GPP’s “TRP” or “RRH” but 29
more specific in including the Low-PHY layer (FFT/iFFT, PRACH extraction).> 30
S-Plane Synchronization Plane: refers to traffic between the O-RU or O-DU to a synchronization controller 31
which is generally an IEEE-1588 Grand Master (however, Grand Master functionality may be 32
embedded in the O-DU). 33
TED Test Equipment, O-DU – test equipment used to validate the O-DU 34
TER Test Equipment, O-RU – test equipment used to validate the O-RU 35
UL UpLink: data flow away from the radiating antenna 36
U-Plane User Plane: refers to IQ sample data transferred between O-DU and O-RU 37

2 Test Configuration 1
The conformance tests described in this document require test equipment with specific capabilities to support the testing 2
of each protocol including the M-Plane, U-Plane, C-Plane and S-Plane. In addition, the tests define a specific 3
connectivity between the test equipment and the device under test.  This section describes the test equipment 4
requirements at a high level.  Details are included in each test.   5
As noted in the introduction in the Scope paragraphs, the initial focus of the M-Plane, C-Plane and U-Plane 6
conformance tests is the O-RU.  Version 2.00 and later include S-Plane tests for the O-DU in addition to the S-Plane 7
tests for the O-RU.  The initial test configuration description below is focused on the test equipment and configuration 8
required to test the O-RU. O-DU test configuration descriptions for the S-Plane are covered in the S-Plane section of 9
this document. 10
2.1 Test Configuration for O-RU as the Device Under Test 11
When testing the O-RU, it is connected to test equipment called Test Equipment O-RU (TER).  The TER is shown in  12
Figure 2.1-1 below.   TER surrounds the DUT and connects to both the fronthaul interface itself and the radio interface. 13
At the radio interface, the TER collects RF signals from the DUT (downlink) and sends RF signals to the DUT receiver 14
(uplink).  Thus, the TER is made up of three main components, a CUSM-Plane Emulator (CUSM-E), a signal analyzer 15
and a signal generator as shown in Figure 2.1-1. The RF test interface is described in TS 36.141 for LTE, TS 38.141-1 16
for NR conducted, and TS 38.141-2 for non-conducted tests.  The fronthaul interface is standard Ethernet as described 17
above.  In this case, the DL data flow is evaluated based on what is received by the signal analyzer in the RF domain as 18
radiated by the O-RU, and the UL data flow is evaluated based on what is emitted by the signal generator in the RF 19
domain and received by the CUSM-E.   20
When the O-RU is the Device Under Test (DUT), there is Test Equipment, RU (“TER”) that is used to connect to the DUT, run the test
and evaluate the test result.
fronthaul connection
DUT = O-RU
RF connection or
antenna array(s)
Test
Equipment, RU
(TER)
CUSM-Plane
Emulator
Signal
Generator
The Test Equipment, RU (“TER”) provides everything needed
to operate the test, including:
▪ M-Plane commands to collect O-RU capabilities and
configure the O-RU
▪ Synchronization via G.8275.1 (Mandatory for O-RU)
▪ C-Plane and U-Plane data flow to the O-RU
▪ Collection of RF energy to determine if the O-RU reacted
correctly to the DL C-Plane and U-Plane data
▪ Radiation of RF energy to be received by the O-RU (note:
this could be actually radiated, or conveyed through
multiple RF cabled connections)
▪ Collection of O-RU UL fronthaul data flows and evaluating
it for correctness based on the supplied RF energy to the
O-RU antennas or RF connectors
Signal
Analyser
 21
Figure 2.1-1 Test Setup, DUT = O-RU 22
While M-Plane conformance tests do not generally require all the functions shown for a TER in Figure 2.1-1, the intent 23
of this description is to show the general capabilities required for all tests on the O-RU as the DUT including U-Plane, 24
C-Plane and S-Plane tests.  If tests are restricted to only the M-Plane, the required test equipment configuration may be 25
simplified.   26
2.2 Test Configuration for O-DU as the Device Under Test 27
When testing the open fronthaul interface of the O-DU, it is connected to test equipment called Test Equipment O-DU 28
(TED).  The TED is shown in  below with the following two cases:  29

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       21
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
1. Stand-alone O-DU as the DUT – In this case the TED wraps around the O-DU DUT via its F1 interface 1
towards the Core + O-CU Emulator (and additionally X2 signalling emulator in NSA), the front haul interface 2
towards the O-RU+UE Emulator, and the O1 or EMS interface towards the test configuration entity.  3
2. Combined O-CU+O-DU (from the same vendor) as the DUT - In this case the TED wraps around the 4
combined O-CU + O-DU DUT via the NG (SA) or S1 and X2 (NSA) interfaces towards the Core Emulator 5
(additionally the X2 signalling emulator in NSA), the front haul interface towards the O-RU+UE Emulator, 6
and the O1 or EMS interface towards the test configuration entity.   7

 9
Figure 2.2-2 Test Setup, DUT = O-DU 10
 11
It is important to note that the tests assume production grade DUTs which should not be placed into any special test 12
modes nor require any special test ports.  At the front haul interface, th e O-RU+UE Emulator is expected to perform the 13
following functions: 14
1. Exchange of front haul data as required to exercise the feature under test.  This entails emulating the necessary 15
front haul signals as seen by the O-DU DUT as if it were connected to an actual O-RU with an actual UE (or 16
multiple UEs in the case of beamforming tests) performing an actual connection with the base station.   17
2. Detailed observation and analysis of the front haul data stream of the O-DU DUT in order to ascertain 18
compliance to the specifications.    19
Note that in addition to the C-, U-, and M-plane signals in the fronthaul, this also includes the necessary S-plane for 20
synchronizing the O-DU DUT with the O-RU+UE Emulator.   21
Since the O-DU is meant to support various classes of O-RU with different feature sets, e.g. CAT-A or CAT-B, FR1 or 22
FR2, different beamforming methods to multiple UEs, different compression schemes, etc.., it is important that the O -23
RU+UE Emulator has the flexibility to effectively emulate the various scenarios in a  robust and repeatable manner in 24
order to test the various features.   Similarly, the Core+O-CU emulator (with the addition of an X2 signalling emulator 25
for NSA mode) shall likewise emulate and observe the appropriate signals at the F1 or NG (or S1 and X2 for NSA) 26
interfaces to effectively wrap-around the O-DU or O-CU+O-DU DUT.  Note that the Core, O-CU, eNB, O-RU, and UE 27
emulator functionalities required in the TED are those that place the O-DU or O-CU+O-DU DUT into a state that 28
allows it to perform an actual connection(s) to a UE(s) to exercise the various open fronthaul features under test, and are 29
thus not required to fully emulate the full functionality of their commercial equivalents.  Conversely, this specification 30
does not preclude the use of the commercial equivalent elements instead of emulators, but must support a level of 31
configurability and repeatability to ensure that the required features in the O-DU front-haul are effectively and 32
repeatably exercised.  With use of either node emulators or commercial equivalents, the required test outcomes and 33
reports must be effectively and repeatably reproduced.         34
In order to cover the various potential optional features, section types, and section extensions for the O -DU DUT, the 35
TED should use the O1 (if available) or EMS interface to provision the O -DU or O-CU+O-DU DUT in order to place it 36
into the appropriate modes to exercise the specific features to test, which is then coordinated with the O-RU+UE 37
Emulator in order to elicit the appropriate front-haul interface behavior.   38

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       22
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
While M-Plane conformance tests do not generally require all the functions shown for a TED in Error! Reference 1
source not found.Figure 2.1-1, the intent of this description is to show the general capabilities required for all tests on 2
the O-DU as the DUT including U-Plane, C-Plane and S-Plane tests.  If tests are restricted to only the M-Plane, the 3
required test equipment configuration may be simplified. 4
3 Conformance Measurements 5
3.1 M-Plane Measurements 6
The O-RAN Fronthaul management plane (M-Plane) protocol conformance tests are described in this section.   The M-7
Plane is based on the NETCONF network element management protocol and YANG data modeling language.  The 8
NETCONF protocol uses a client and server model for all exchanges of information and execution of RPCs.  Every 9
NETCONF transaction is a 2-way exchange involving the client and the server.  The O-DU must support a NETCONF 10
client and the O-RU must support a NETCONF server.  Any test written to exercise either the O-DU (client) or O-RU 11
(server) is therefore applicable to both the O-DU and the O-RU.   12
The following sections describe Conformance Tests for the M-Plane.   While all of these M-Plane conformance tests 13
could apply to both the O-DU and the O-RU, some tests are focused primarily on the O-RU NETCONF server 14
capabilities and functions.   Therefore, each test below is identified as a conformance test for the O -DU, the O-RU or 15
both.  Table 1.2.4-1  lists all M-Plane test cases and whether they are applicable to one or both of the O-DU and O-RU 16
for conformance testing. 17
 18
 19
3.1.1 Transport and Handshake Test Scenarios 20
 Transport and Handshake in IPv4 Environment (positive case) 21
 22
A. Test Description and Applicability 23
This scenario is MANDATORY for both O-RU and O-DU Tests. 24
This scenario validates that the O-RU properly executes the session establishment procedure with VLANs and a 25
DHCPv4 server.  This test is applicable to IPv4 environments. 26
This scenario corresponds to the following chapters in [3]: 27
• 3.1 Management Plane Transport aspects  28
• 3.2 NETCONF Call Home to O-RU Controller(s) 29
 30
B. Test Entrance Criteria 31
The minimum functions of the TER described in section 2.1 that support validation of the M-Plane are operational, 32
configured and connected to the O-RU 33
 34
C. Test Methodology 35
a. Initial Conditions 36
1. The O-RU is powered on and has an ethernet connection to the DHCP-server 37
2. The configured DHCPv4 server is reachable by the O-RU NETCONF Server through the VLAN 38
configured for M-Plane. 39
3. Default SSH credentials (sudo) are used by both the O-RU NETCONF Server and the TER NETCONF 40
Client 41
4. IP details for test purposes are pre-defined and fixed (applies to the DHCP server). 42
 43
b. Procedure 44

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       23
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
1. The O-RU NETCONF Server can be preconfigured with no VLAN (known in 802.1Q as native ethernet 1
or an untagged VLAN), a VLAN ID or may optionally perform a VLAN scan by issuing DHCP Discover 2
trying to reach the DHCP Server 3
2. The O-RU NETCONF Server continues the DHCPv4 procedure on the preconfigured VLAN or first 4
VLAN where the Offer from DHCP Server / Relay is received if the scan method is used 5
3. O-RU NETCONF Server retrieves IP details and the IP address of the controlling TER NETCONF Client 6
from the DHCP Server.  Note: RFC 2131 is followed for DHCPv4 7
4. The O-RU NETCONF Server establishes TCP connection and performs a Call Home procedure towards 8
the NETCONF Client using the IP details obtained in step 3 9
5. The TER NETCONF Client establishes a SSH session with the O-RU NETCONF Server.  Proper 10
credentials are used. 11
6. The O-RU NETCONF Server accepts the SSH connection establishment from the TER NETCONF Client 12
7. The TER NETCONF Client and O-RU NETCONF Server exchange capabilities through NETCONF 13
<hello> messages.  The following is an abbreviated example of the capabilities exchange.  A typical 14
capabilities exchange will have far more parameters included. 15
Note: RFC 6241 is followed for NETCONF communication. 16
Server (O-RU) initiates Hello message . 17
<hello xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0"> 18
  <capabilities> 19
    <capability>urn:ietf:params:netconf:base:1.0</capability> 20
    <capability>urn:ietf:params:netconf:base:1.1</capability> 21
    <capability>urn:ietf:params:netconf:capability:writable-22
running:1.0</capability> 23
    24
<capability>urn:ietf:params:netconf:capability:notification:1.0</capabilit25
y> 26
    27
<capability>urn:ietf:params:netconf:capability:interleave:1.0</capability> 28
    <capability>http://org/openroadm/user-mgmt?module=org-openroadm-user-29
mgmt&amp;amp;amp;revision=2017-12-15</capability> 30
…… 31
  </capabilities> 32
  <session-id>1</session-id> 33
</hello>  34
 35
Client (DU) responds with Hello message … 36
<hello xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0"> 37
  <capabilities> 38
    <capability>urn:ietf:params:netconf:base:1.0</capability> 39
    <capability>urn:ietf:params:netconf:base:1.1</capability> 40
  </capabilities> 41
</hello> 42
 43
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  44
Test scenario step 7 is performed successfully. 45

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       24
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
 Transport and Handshake in IPv4 Environment (negative case) 1
A. Test Description and Applicability 2
This scenario is MANDATORY for both O-RU and O-DU Tests. 3
This scenario validates that the O-RU properly executes the session establishment procedure with VLANs and a 4
DHCPv4 server.  This test is applicable to IPv4 environments.  Two negative flows are included in this test: 5
• The TER NETCONF Client does not trigger a SSH session establishment in reaction to Call Home 6
initiated by THE O-RU NETCONF Server. 7
• The TER NETCONF Client uses improper credentials when trying to establish a SSH session with the O-8
RU NETCONF Server. 9
 10
This scenario corresponds to the following chapters in [3]: 11
• 3.1 Management Plane Transport aspects 12
• 3.2 NETCONF Call Home to O-RU Controller(s) 13
 14
B. Test Entrance Criteria 15
The minimum functions of the TER described in section 2.1 that support validation of the M-Plane are operational, 16
configured and connected to the O-RU. 17
 18
C. Test Methodology 19
a. Initial Conditions 20
a. O-RU is powered on and has an ethernet connection to the DHCP-server 21
b. Configured DHCPv4 server is reachable for O-RU NETCONF Server through the VLAN configured for 22
M-Plane. 23
c. Default SSH credentials (sudo) are used by both O-RU NETCONF Server and NETCONF Client 24
d. IP details for test purposes are pre-defined and fixed (applies to DHCP server). 25
e. Procedure 26
i. Flow 1 27
1. The O-RU NETCONF Server can be preconfigured with no VLAN (known in 802.1Q as native 28
ethernet or an untagged VLAN), a VLAN ID or may optionally perform a VLAN scan by issuing a 29
DHCP Discover trying to reach DHCP Server 30
2. The O-RU NETCONF Server continues the DHCPv4 procedure on the preconfigured VLAN or first 31
VLAN where the Offer from the DHCP Server / Relay is received if the scan method is used 32
3. The O-RU NETCONF Server retrieves IP details and the IP address of controlling TER NETCONF 33
Client from the DHCP Server.  Note: RFC 2131 is followed for DHCPv4 34
4. The O-RU NETCONF Server establishes TCP connection and performs Call Home procedure with 35
the TER NETCONF Client using IP details obtained in step 3 36
5. The TER NETCONF Client does not initiate the SSH session establishment procedure. 37
6. The O-RU NETCONF Server periodically repeats the Call Home towards TER NETCONF Client.  38
 39
ii. Flow 2 40
1. The O-RU NETCONF Server can be preconfigured with a VLAN ID or may optionally perform a 41
VLAN scan by issuing a DHCP Discover trying to reach the DHCP Server 42
2. The O-RU NETCONF Server continues the DHCPv4 procedure on the preconfigured VLAN or first 43
VLAN where the Offer from the DHCP Server / Relay is received if the scan method is used 44
3. The O-RU NETCONF Server retrieves IP details and the IP address of the controlling TER 45
NETCONF Client from DHCP Server.  Note: RFC 2131 is followed for DHCPv4  46
4. The O-RU NETCONF Server establishes a TCP connection and performs the Call Home procedure 47
with the TER NETCONF Client using IP details obtained in step 3 48
5. The TER NETCONF Client initiates the SSH session establishment procedure with improper 49
credentials. 50
6. Due to the incorrect SSH credentials, the O-RU NETCONF Server rejects the SSH connection 51
establishment from the TER NETCONF Client. 52
7. The O-RU NETCONF Server starts periodic Call Home procedure towards the TER NETCONF 53
Client. 54
 55

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       25
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  1
1. Flow 1: Scenario reaches step 6.  The O-RU NETCONF Server falls into Call Home procedure loop. 2
2. Flow 2: Scenario reaches step 7.  The O-RU NETCONF Server falls into Call Home procedure loop. 3
 4
 Transport and Handshake in IPv6 Stateful Configuration Environment 5
(positive case) 6
 7
A. Test Description and Applicability 8
This scenario is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY for both O-RU and O-DU Tests. 9
This scenario validates that the O-RU properly executes the session establishment procedure with VLANs and a 10
DHCP server.  This test is applicable to IPv6 environments.   11
This scenario corresponds to the following chapters in [3]: 12
• 3.1 Management Plane Transport aspects  13
• 3.2 NETCONF Call Home to O-RU Controller(s) 14
 15
B. Test Entrance Criteria 16
The minimum functions of the TER described in section 2.1 that support validation of the M-Plane are operational, 17
configured and connected to the O-RU. 18
 19
C. Test Methodology 20
a. Initial Conditions 21
1. O-RU is powered on and has an ethernet connection to the DHCPv6 server 22
2. The previously configured DHCPv6 server is reachable by the  O-RU NETCONF Server through the 23
VLAN configured for M-Plane. 24
3. Default SSH credentials (sudo) are used by both the O-RU NETCONF Server and the TER NETCONF 25
Client 26
4. IP details for test purposes are pre-defined and fixed (applies to the  DHCP server) 27
 28
b. Procedure 29
1. The O-RU NETCONF Server can be preconfigured with no VLAN (known in 802.1Q as native ethernet 30
or an untagged VLAN), a VLAN ID or may optionally perform a VLAN scan by issuing DHCP 31
Discover trying to reach DHCP Server 32
2. The O-RU NETCONF Server continues DHCPv6 procedure on the preconfigured VLAN or first VLAN 33
where the Offer from the DHCP Server / Relay is received if the scan method is used 34
3. The O-RU NETCONF Server retrieves IP details and IP address of the controlling TER NETCONF 35
Client from the DHCP Server.  Note: RFC 3315 is followed for DHCPv6 36
4. The O-RU NETCONF Server establishes a TCP connection and performs the Call Home procedure 37
with the TER NETCONF Client using IP details obtained in step 3 38
5. The TER NETCONF Client establishes a SSH session with the O-RU NETCONF Server. Proper 39
credentials are used. 40
6. The O-RU NETCONF Server accepts the SSH connection establishment from the TER NETCONF 41
Client 42
7. The TER NETCONF Client and the O-RU NETCONF Server exchange capabilities through 43
NETCONF <hello> messages. 44
 45
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  46
Test scenario step 7 is performed successfully. 47
 48

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       26
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
 Transport and handshake in IPv6 environment (negative case) 1
 2
A. Test Description and Applicability 3
This scenario is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY for both O-RU and O-DU Tests. 4
This scenario validates that the O-RU properly executes the session establishment procedure with VLANs and a 5
DHCPv4 server.  This test is applicable to IPv6 environments.  Two negative flows are included in this test: 6
• The TER NETCONF Client does not trigger a SSH session establishment in reaction to a Call Home 7
initiated by the O-RU NETCONF Server. 8
• The TER NETCONF Client uses improper credentials when trying to establish SSH session towards the 9
O-RU NETCONF Server. 10
 11
This scenario corresponds to the following chapters in [3]: 12
• 3.1 Management Plane Transport aspects  13
• 3.2 NETCONF Call Home to O-RU Controller(s) 14
 15
B. Test Entrance Criteria 16
The minimum functions of the TER described in section 2.1 that support validation of the M-Plane are operational, 17
configured and connected to the O-RU. 18
 19
C. Test Methodology 20
a. Initial Conditions 21
1. The O-RU is powered on and has an ethernet connection to the DHCP-server 22
2. The previously configured DHCPv6 server is reachable by the O-RU NETCONF Server through the 23
VLAN configured for M-Plane. 24
3. Default SSH credentials (sudo) are used by both the O-RU NETCONF Server and the TER NETCONF 25
Client 26
4. IP details for test purposes are pre-defined and fixed (applies to the DHCPv6 server) 27
 28
b.    Procedure 29
i. Flow 1 30
1. The O-RU NETCONF Server can be preconfigured with no VLAN (known in 802.1Q as native 31
ethernet or an untagged VLAN), a VLAN ID or may optionally perform a VLAN scan by issuing 32
DHCP Discover trying to reach DHCP Server 33
2. The O-RU NETCONF Server continues the DHCPv6 procedure on the preconfigured VLAN or first 34
VLAN where the Offer from DHCP Server / Relay is received if the scan method is used 35
3. The O-RU NETCONF Server retrieves IP details and the IP address of the controlling TER 36
NETCONF Client from the DHCP Server.  Note: RFC 3315 is followed for DHCPv6 37
4. The O-RU NETCONF Server establishes a TCP connection and performs the Call Home procedure to 38
the TER NETCONF Client using IP details obtained in step 3 39
5. NETCONF Client does not initiate a SSH session establishment procedure. 40
6. The O-RU NETCONF Server periodically repeats Call Home to the NETCONF Client.  41
 42
ii. Flow 2 43
1. The O-RU NETCONF Server can be preconfigured with a VLAN ID or may optionally perform a 44
VLAN scan by issuing DHCP Discover trying to reach DHCP Server 45
2. The O-RU NETCONF Server continues DHCPv6 procedure on the preconfigured VLAN or first 46
VLAN where the Offer from the DHCP Server / Relay is received if the scan method is used 47
3. The O-RU NETCONF Server retrieves IP details and the IP address of the controlling TER 48
NETCONF Client from the DHCP Server.  Note: RFC 3315 is followed for DHCPv6 49
4. The O-RU NETCONF Server establishes TCP connection and performs a Call Home procedure to the 50
TER NETCONF Client using IP details obtained in step 3 51
5. The TER NETCONF Client initiates a SSH session establishment procedure with improper 52
credentials.   53
6. Due to the incorrect SSH credentials, the O-RU NETCONF Server rejects the SSH connection 54
establishment from the TER NETCONF Client. 55
7. The O-RU NETCONF Server starts periodic Call Home procedure to the TER NETCONF Client. 56
 57

 2
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  3
1. Flow 1: Scenario reaches step 6.  The O-RU NETCONF Server falls into Call Home procedure loop. 4
2. Flow 2: Scenario reaches step 7.  The O-RU NETCONF Server falls into Call Home procedure loop. 5

3.1.2 Manage Alarm Requests 7
 Subscription to Notifications 8
A. Test Description and Applicability 9
This scenario is MANDATORY for both O-RU and O-DU Tests. 10
This test validates that the O-RU properly handles a NETCONF subscription to notifications. 11
This scenario corresponds to the following chapters in [3]: 12
• 8.2 Manage Alarm Requests 13
 14
B. Test Entrance Criteria 15
The minimum functions of the TER described in section 2.1 that support validation of the M-Plane are 16
operational, configured and connected to the O-RU 17
 18
C. Test Methodology 19
a. Initial Conditions 20
1. The test procedure described in section 3.1.1.1 or 3.1.1.3 for IPv4 and IPv6 respectively is successfully 21
completed. 22
 23
b. Procedure 24
1. The TER NETCONF Client triggers the subscription:  25
 26
<rpc><create-subscription><stream>NETCONF</stream></create-27
subscription></rpc>   28
to the O-RU NETCONF Server to subscribe to notifications related to the supervision process. Note: 29
<stream>NETCONF</stream> is intentional, meaning that the TER NETCONF Client subscribes to all 30
notifications that the O-RU NETCONF Server can generate (including alarm notifications). 31
2. The O-RU NETCONF Server responds with   32
 33
<rpc-reply><ok/></rpc-reply>   34
 35
to the TER NETCONF Client. 36
 37
Note: RFC 6241 is followed for NETCONF communication. 38
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  39
Test scenario step 2 is performed successfully. 40
 41
3.1.3 M-Plane Connection Supervision 42
 M-Plane connection supervision (positive case) 43
A. Test Description and Applicability 44

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       28
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
This scenario is MANDATORY for both O-RU and O-DU Tests. 1
This test validates that the O-RU manages the connection supervision process correctly. 2
This scenario corresponds to the following chapters in [3]: 3
• 3.6 Monitoring NETCONF connectivity 4
 5
B. Test Entrance Criteria 6
The minimum functions of the TER described in section 2.1 that support validation of the M-Plane are operational, 7
configured and connected to the O-RU 8
 9
C. Test Methodology 10
a. Initial Conditions 11
1. The test procedure described in section 3.1.1.1 or 3.1.1.3 for IPv4 and IPv6 respectively is successfully 12
completed. 13
 14
b. Procedure 15
1. The O-RU NETCONF Server supervision timer expires 16
2. The O-RU NETCONF Server sends a supervision notification message to the TER NETCONF Client .  17
Note that the time in this example is shown generically and will be the current time during this test.  18
 19
<notification xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:notification:1.0"> 20
  <eventTime>YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SS.FZ</eventTime> 21
  <supervision-notification xmlns="urn:o-ran:supervision:1.0"/> 22
</notification> 23
 24
3. The TER NETCONF Client responds with  25
<rpc xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0" message-26
id="20"> 27
  <supervision-watchdog-reset xmlns="urn:o-ran:supervision:1.0"> 28
        <supervision-notification-interval>60</supervision-29
notification-interval> 30
        <guard-timer-overhead>10</guard-timer-overhead> 31
    </supervision-watchdog-reset> 32
</rpc> 33
 34
to the O-RU NETCONF Server. 35
4. The O-RU NETCONF Server sends a reply to the TER NETCONF Client 36
<rpc-reply xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0" message-37
id="20"> 38
  <next-update-at xmlns="urn:o-ran:supervision:1.0">2020-10- YYYY-MM-39
DDTHH:MM:SS.FZ </next-update-at> 40
</rpc-reply> 41
 42
5. Note that the TER NETCONF Client can change the value of the supervision timer in the supervision 43
watchdog reset message. The O-RU NETCONF server must adjust the timer accordingly if this optional 44
test is performed. 45
6. The O-RU NETCONF Server sends a supervision notification towards the TER NETCONF Client with 46
respect to time-date sent in rpc-reply in step 3. 47
7. Steps 1 to 4 are looped for a total of 30 iterations including the first pass through steps 1 to 4. 48
Note: RFC 6241 is followed for NETCONF communication. 49
 50
D. Test Requirement (expected result) 51
Test scenario step 5 is performed successfully in all iterations. 52
 53

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       29
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
 M-Plane Connection Supervision (negative case) 1
A. Test Description and Applicability 2
This scenario is MANDATORY for both O-RU and O-DU Tests. 3
This test validates that the O-RU manages the connection supervision process correctly. 4
This scenario corresponds to the following chapters in [3]: 5
• 3.6 Monitoring NETCONF connectivity 6
 7
B. Test Entrance Criteria 8
The minimum functions of the TER described in section 2.1 that support validation of the M-Plane are 9
operational, configured and connected to the O-RU 10
 11
C. Test Methodology 12
a. Initial Conditions 13
1. The test procedure described in section 3.1.1.1 or 3.1.1.3 for IPv4 and IPv6 respectively is successfully 14
completed. 15
 16
b. Procedure 17
1. The O-RU NETCONF Server supervision timer expires 18
2. The O-RU NETCONF Server sends a supervision notification message to the TER NETCONF Client  19
3. The TER NETCONF Client responds with  20
 <rpc supervision-watchdog-reset></rpc> 21
to the O-RU NETCONF Server. 22
4. The O-RU NETCONF Server sends a reply to the TER NETCONF Client 23
<rpc-reply><next-update-at>date-time</next-update-at></rpc-reply> 24
5. Note that the TER NETCONF Client can change the value of the supervision timer in the supervision 25
watchdog reset message. The O-RU NETCONF server must adjust the timer accordingly if this optional 26
test is performed. 27
6. The O-RU NETCONF Server sends a supervision notification towards the TER NETCONF Client with 28
respect to time-date sent in rpc-reply in step 3. 29
7. The TER NETCONF Client does not issue <rpc supervision-watchdog-reset></rpc> to the O-RU 30
NETCONF Server and causes the watchdog timer to expire on the O-RU. 31
8. The O-RU NETCONF Server enters the Supervision failure scenario. For details please see O-RAN M-32
Plane Specification [3], chapter 11.1. 33
 34
D. Test Requirement (expected result) 35
Test scenario step 7 is performed successfully. 36
 37
 38
3.1.4 Retrieval of O-RU's information elements 39
 Retrieval without Filter Applied 40
 41

This scenario is MANDATORY for both O-RU and O-DU Tests. 43
This scenario validates that the O-RU NETCONF Server properly executes a general get command. 44
This is a general-purpose high-level test related to NETCONF implementation.  There is no direct relationship to a 45
specific chapter in [3]: 46
B. Test Entrance Criteria 47

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       30
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
The minimum functions of the TER described in section 2.1 that support validation of the M-Plane are operational, 1
configured and connected to the O-RU. 2
C. Test Methodology 3
a. Initial Conditions 4
1. The test procedure described in section 3.1.1.1 or 3.1.1.3 for IPv4 and IPv6 respectively is successfully 5
completed. 6
 7
b. Procedure 8
1. The TER NETCONF Client triggers <rpc><get> towards the O-RU NETCONF Server. 9
2. The O-RU NETCONF Server responds with <rpc-reply><data> where <data> contains all information 10
elements that the O-RU NETCONF Server is able to expose 11
 12
D. Test Requirement (expected result) 13
Test step 2 is performed successfully. 14
 Retrieval with filter applied 15
 16
A. Test Description and Applicability 17
This scenario is MANDATORY 18
This scenario validates that the O-RU NETCONF Server properly executes a get command with a filter applied. 19
This is a general-purpose high-level test related to NETCONF implementation.  There is no direct relationship to a 20
specific chapter in [3]: 21
B. Minimum Requirements 22
The minimum functions of the TER described in section 2.1 that support validation of the M-Plane are operational, 23
configured and connected to the O-RU. 24
C. Test Methodology 25
a. Initial Conditions 26
1. The test procedure described in section 3.1.1.1 or 3.1.1.3for IPv4 and IPv6 respectively is successfully 27
completed. 28
 29
b. Procedure 30
1. The TER NETCONF Client triggers <rpc><get><filter> towards NETCONF Server.  The <filter> 31
argument contains a regular expression that the O-RU NETCONF Server shall apply as a filter. For 32
example, a filter that filters all low-level-rx-endpoints:  33
  <rpc message-id="101" xmlns="urn:o-ran:uplane-conf:1.0" > 34
      <get> 35
          <source>running</source> 36
          <filter type = ”subtree”> 37
              <top xmlns="urn:o-ran:uplane-conf:1.0/”> 38
                  <user-plane-configuration> 39
                      <low-level-rx-endpoints> 40
                      </low-level-rx-endpoints> 41
                  </user-plane-configuration> 42
              </top> 43
          </filter> 44
      </get> 45
   </rpc> 46
2. The O-RU NETCONF Server responds with <rpc-reply><data> where <data> contains details for objects 47
as conforming to the <filter> (as per the above example filter: all low-level-rx-endpoints) 48
 49
D. Test Requirement (expected result) 50
Test step 2 is performed successfully. 51
 52

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       31
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
3.1.5 Fault Management 1
 O-RU Alarm Notification Generation  2
 3
A. Test Description and Applicability 4
This scenario is MANDATORY for both O-RU and O-DU Tests. 5
This scenario validates that the O-RU NETCONF Server properly sends and alarm notification. 6
This scenario corresponds to the following chapters in [3]: 7
• 8.1 Alarm Notification 8
 9
B. Test Entrance Criteria 10
The minimum functions of the TER described in section 2.1 that support validation of the M-Plane are operational, 11
configured and connected to the O-RU. 12
C. Test Methodology 13
a. Initial Conditions 14
The test procedure described in section 3.1.1.1 or 3.1.1.3 for IPv4 and IPv6 respectively is successfully 15
completed. 16
 17
b. Procedure 18
1. The TER NETCONF Client periodically tests O-RU’s sync-status until the LOCKED state is reached. 19
  <rpc message-id="101" xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0"> 20
      <get> 21
            <filter type = ”subtree”> 22
              <top xmlns="urn:o-ran:sync:1.0/”> 23
                  <sync><sync-status></sync-status></sync> 24
              </top> 25
          </filter> 26
      </get> 27
   </rpc> 28
2. Disable the Sync signal on the TER. 29
3. After a while (time depends on implementation) the O-RU NETCONF SERVER sends a notification for 30
an alarm related to synchronization failure, e.g. alarm 17: No external sync source” or another vendor 31
specific alarm.  The format of alarm notification follows RFC5277.   Note that the time in this example is 32
shown generically and will be the current time during this test. 33
 34
<notification xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:notification:1.0"> 35
  <eventTime> YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SS.FZ </eventTime> 36
  <alarm-notif xmlns="urn:o-ran:fm:1.0"> 37
    <fault-id>17</fault-id> 38
    <fault-source>sync</fault-source> 39
    <affected-objects> 40
      <name>syncE</name> 41
    </affected-objects> 42
    <fault-severity>MAJOR</fault-severity> 43
    <is-cleared>false</is-cleared> 44
    <fault-text>No external sync source</fault-text> 45
    <event-time> YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SS.FZ </event-time> 46
  </alarm-notif> 47
</notification> 48
 49
D. Test Requirement (expected result) 50
Test step 3 is performed successfully. 51
 52

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       32
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
 Retrieval of Active Alarm List 1
 2
A. Test Description and Applicability 3
This scenario is MANDATORY for O-RU tests and OPTIONAL for O-DU tests. 4
This scenario validates that the O-RU NETCONF Server can send an active alarms list to the TER NETCONF 5
Client. 6
This scenario corresponds to the following chapters in [3]: 7
• 8.  Fault Management 8
 9
B. Test Entrance Criteria 10
The minimum functions of the TER described in section 2.1 that support validation of the M-Plane are operational, 11
configured and connected to the O-RU. 12
C. Test Methodology 13
a. Initial Conditions 14
The test procedure described in section 3.1.1.1 or 3.1.1.3 for IPv4 and IPv6 respectively is successfully 15
completed. 16
 17
b. Procedure 18
1. The TER NETCONF Client sends the O-RU NETCONF Server a command to get the active-alarm-list. 19
  <rpc message-id="101" xmlns=" urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0" 20
> 21
      <get> 22
          <filter type = ”subtree”> 23
              <top xmlns="urn:o-ran:fm:1.0/”> 24
                  <active-alarm-list></active-alarm-list> 25
              </top> 26
          </filter> 27
      </get> 28
   </rpc> 29
2. The O-RU NETCONF Server responds with <rpc-reply><data> where <data> contains at least the same 30
alarm as reported in measurement 3.1.5.1 31
<rpc-reply xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0" message-32
id="11"> 33
  <data xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0"> 34
    <active-alarm-list xmlns="urn:o-ran:fm:1.0"> 35
      <active-alarms> 36
        <fault-id>17</fault-id> 37
        <fault-source>sync</fault-source> 38
        <affected-objects> 39
          <name>syncE</name> 40
        </affected-objects> 41
        <fault-severity>MAJOR</fault-severity> 42
        <is-cleared>false</is-cleared> 43
        <fault-text>No external sync source</fault-text> 44
        <event-time> YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SS.FZ </event-time> 45
      </active-alarms> 46
    </active-alarm-list> 47
  </data> 48
</rpc-reply> 49
 50
Note – There can be more than one Active Alarm in the reply from O-RU.  51
 52
 53
D. Test Requirement (expected result) 54
Test step 2 is performed successfully. 55

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       33
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
 1
3.1.6 O-RU Software Update 2
 O-RU Software Update and Install (positive case) 3
A. Test Description and Applicability 4
This scenario is MANDATORY for both O-RU and O-DU Tests. 5
This test validates that the O-RU can successfully perform a software download and software install procedure. 6
This scenario corresponds to the following chapters in [3]: 7
• 5. Software Management 8
 9
B. Test Entrance Criteria 10
The minimum functions of the TER described in section 2.1 that support validation of the M-Plane are operational, 11
configured and connected to the O-RU. 12
C. Test Methodology 13
a. Initial Conditions 14
1. The test procedure described in section 3.1.4.1 is successfully completed. 15
2. A correct and internally consistent SW package is available for test purposes.  16
3. The O-RU provides at least one slot available for SW update procedure.  The status of this slot is assumed 17
to be {active = False, running = False, access = READ-WRITE} 18
4. A sFTP server is available with an account for the SW update procedure on the TER  19
 20
b. Procedure 21
1. The TER NETCONF Client triggers <rpc><software-download>.  The O-RU NETCONF Server responds 22
with <rpc-reply><software-download> 23
<rpc xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0" message-id="13"> 24
  <software-download xmlns="urn:o-ran:software-management:1.0"> 25
         <remote-file-26
path>sftp://oranuser@192.168.3.13:22/Trace.zip</remote-file-path> 27
    </software-download> 28
</rpc> 29
 30
<rpc-reply xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0" message-31
id="13"> 32
  <status xmlns="urn:o-ran:software-management:1.0">STARTED</status> 33
</rpc-reply> 34
 35
2. The O-RU NETCONF Server performs a software download procedure.  When the download is 36
completed, the O-RU NETCONF Server sends <notification><download-event> with status 37
COMPLETED to TER NETCONF Client 38
<notification xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:notification:1.0"> 39
  <eventTime> YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SS.FZ </eventTime> 40
  <download-event xmlns="urn:o-ran:software-management:1.0"> 41
    <file-name>sftp://oranuser@192.168.3.13:22/Trace.zip</file-name> 42
    <status>COMPLETED</status> 43
  </download-event> 44
</notification> 45
 46
 47
3. The TER NETCONF Client triggers <rpc><software-install> informing the O-RU NETCONF Client 48
about the desired slot for installation.  This slot must have the attributes active = FALSE, running = 49
FALSE, access = READ-WRITE.  The O-RU NETCONF Server responds with <rpc-reply><software-50
install> with status STARTED. 51
<rpc xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0" message-id="14"> 52
  <software-install xmlns="urn:o-ran:software-management:1.0"> 53
         <slot-name>"SLOT0"</slot-name> 54
   <file-names>"testpkg"</file-names> 55

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       34
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
    </software-install> 1
</rpc> 2
 3
<rpc-reply xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0" message-4
id="14"> 5
  <status xmlns="urn:o-ran:software-management:1.0">STARTED</status> 6
</rpc-reply> 7
 8
4. The O-RU NETCONF Server examines the downloaded software.  The files are error free by design in 9
this test.  The O-RU NETCONF Server installs the new software files to the desired slot.  10
 11
5. The O-RU NETCONF Server sends <notification><install-event><status> to the TER NETCONF Client. 12
Field <status> contains the value COMPLETED to indicate the successful installation of software to the 13
desired slot. 14
<notification xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:notification:1.0"> 15
  <eventTime> YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SS.FZ </eventTime> 16
  <install-event xmlns="urn:o-ran:software-management:1.0"> 17
    <slot-name>"SLOT0"</slot-name> 18
    <status>COMPLETED</status> 19
  </install-event> 20
</notification> 21
 22
 23
D. Test Requirement (expected result) 24
1. Test step 5 completed with notification that indicates successful installation of  the downloaded software. 25
2. Status of SW slot used for SW installation is set to VALID.  Other parameters of software slot shall not be 26
changed. 27
 28
 O-RU Software Update (negative case) 29
A. Test Description and Applicability 30
This scenario is MANDATORY for O-RU tests and OPTIONAL for O-DU tests. 31
This scenario corresponds the following chapters in [3]: 32
• 5. Software Management 33
 34
B. Test Purpose 35
This test validates that the O-RU can successfully perform a software download procedure.  One or more files are 36
intentionally corrupted to make sure that the O-RU is able to recognize an invalid software update file and protect 37
itself from installing this file.  38
C. Test Methodology 39
a. Initial Conditions 40
The test procedure described in section 3.1.4.1 is successfully completed. 41
A modified software package is available for test purposes (proper content of manifest.xml, but fake /invalid 42
content of software files) 43
The O-RU provides at least one slot available for the software update procedure (status != INVALID, active = 44
False, running = False, access = READ-WRITE) 45
A sFTP server is available with an account dedicated for the software update procedure 46
b. Procedure 47
1. The TER NETCONF Client triggers <rpc><software-download>.  The O-RU NETCONF Server responds 48
with <rpc-reply><software-download> 49
<rpc xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0" message-50
id="13"> 51
  <software-download xmlns="urn:o-ran:software-management:1.0"> 52

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       35
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
         <remote-file-1
path>sftp://oranuser@192.168.3.13:22/Trace.zip</remote-file-path> 2
    </software-download> 3
</rpc> 4
 5
<rpc-reply xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0" message-6
id="13"> 7
  <status xmlns="urn:o-ran:software-management:1.0">STARTED</status> 8
</rpc-reply> 9
 10
2. The O-RU NETCONF Server performs the software download procedure.  When the download is 11
complete, the O-RU NETCONF Server sends <notification><download-event> with status COMPLETED 12
to the TER NETCONF Client 13
<rpc xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0" message-14
id="13"> 15
  <software-download xmlns="urn:o-ran:software-management:1.0"> 16
         <remote-file-17
path>sftp://oranuser@192.168.3.13:22/Trace.zip</remote-file-path> 18
    </software-download> 19
</rpc> 20
 21
<rpc-reply xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0" message-22
id="13"> 23
  <status xmlns="urn:o-ran:software-24
management:1.0">COMPLETED</status> 25
</rpc-reply> 26
 27
3. The TER NETCONF Client triggers <rpc><software-install> informing the O-RU NETCONF Server 28
about desired slot the software shall be installed to.  The O-RU NETCONF Server responds with <rpc-29
reply><software-install> with status STARTED. 30
<rpc xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0" message-id="14"> 31
  <software-install xmlns="urn:o-ran:software-management:1.0"> 32
         <slot-name>"SLOT0"</slot-name> 33
   <file-names>"testpkg"</file-names> 34
    </software-install> 35
</rpc> 36
 37
<rpc-reply xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0" message-38
id="14"> 39
  <status xmlns="urn:o-ran:software-management:1.0">STARTED</status> 40
</rpc-reply> 41
 42
4. The O-RU NETCONF Server determines that the software file is invalid and sends <notification><install-43
event><status> to the TER NETCONF Client.  The Field <status> is correctly updated with one of the 44
following status: FILE_ERROR or INTEGRITY_ERROR or APPLICATION_ERROR. 45
<notification xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:notification:1.0"> 46
  <eventTime> YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SS.FZ </eventTime> 47
  <install-event xmlns="urn:o-ran:software-management:1.0"> 48
    <slot-name>"SLOT0"</slot-name> 49
    <status> FILE_ERROR </status> 50
  </install-event> 51
</notification> 52
 53
D. Test Requirement (expected result) 54
1. Test step 4 completed a described. 55
2. Status of SW slot used for SW installation is set to INVALID.  Other parameters of software slot shall not be 56
changed. 57
 58

3.1.7 O-RU Software Activation 1
 Software Activation without Reset 2
 3
A. Test Description and Applicability 4
This scenario is MANDATORY for both O-RU and O-DU Tests. 5
This test validates that the O-RU can successfully activate software in a specific slot on the O-RU. 6
This scenario corresponds to the following chapters in [3]: 7
• 5. Software Management 8
 9
B. Test Entrance Criteria 10
The minimum functions of the TER described in section 2.1 that support validation of the M-Plane are operational, 11
configured and connected to the O-RU. 12
C. Test Methodology 13
a. Initial Conditions 14
1. The test procedure described in section 3.1.6.1 is successfully completed. 15
 16
b. Procedure 17
1. The TER NETCONF Client triggers <rpc><software-activate> towards the O-RU NETCONF Server.  18
The name of a slot containing a valid software installation to be activated is provided as a parameter in the 19
RPC.  20
<rpc xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0" message-id="15"> 21
  <software-activate xmlns="urn:o-ran:software-management:1.0"> 22
         <slot-name>"SLOT0"</slot-name> 23
 </software-activate> 24
</rpc> 25
 26
2. The O-RU NETCONF Server responds with <rpc-reply><software-activate><status>.  The parameter 27
"status" is set to STARTED. 28
<rpc-reply xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0" message-29
id="15"> 30
  <status xmlns="urn:o-ran:software-management:1.0">STARTED</status> 31
</rpc-reply> 32
 33
3. The O-RU NETCONF Server performs a software activation procedure. When the procedure is 34
completed, the O-RU NETCONF Server sends <notification><activation-event> with a status 35
COMPLETED and the slot-name in the activation event corresponds to the slot-name used in the 36
software-activate RPC to the TER NETCONF Client. 37
<notification xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:notification:1.0"> 38
  <eventTime> YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SS.FZ </eventTime> 39
  <activation-event xmlns="urn:o-ran:software-management:1.0"> 40
    <slot-name>"SLOT0"</slot-name> 41
    <status>COMPLETED</status> 42
  </activation-event> 43
</notification> 44
 45
 46
D. Test Requirement (expected result) 47
1. In step 3 of this test, the status of the software slot used for software activation is set to VALID and the 48
parameter "active" is set to "True".  The parameter "running" remains "False". 49
2. Status of the software slot containing the software still used by device remains VALID, the parameter 50
"active" is set to False. The parameter "running" is True. 51
Note: O-RU reset is required to complete SW activation sequence - meaning: to force device to start with the 52
software just activated.  53

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       37
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
 Supplemental Reset after Software Activation 1
 2
A. Test Description and Applicability 3
This scenario is MANDATORY for  O-RU tests and OPTIONAL for O-DU tests. 4
This test validates that the O-RU can successfully start up with activated software. 5
This scenario corresponds to the following chapters in [3]: 6
• 5. Software Management 7
 8
B. Test Entrance Criteria 9
The minimum functions of the TER described in section 2.1 that support validation of the M-Plane are operational, 10
configured and connected to the O-RU. 11
C. Test Methodology 12
a. Initial Conditions 13
1. The test procedure described in section 3.1.6.1 is successfully completed. 14
 15
b. Procedure 16
1. The TER NETCONF Client sends <rpc><reset></rpc> to the O-RU NETCONF Server.  17
<reset xmlns=”urn:o-ran:operations:1.0”> </reset> 18
 19
2. The O-RU NETCONF Server responds with rpc-reply. 20
3. <reset xmlns=”urn:o-ran:operations:1.0”> ok</reset> 21
 22
4. The O-RU restarts with a new software version running matching the version activated in test 3.1.7.1. 23
 24
D. Test Requirement (expected result) 25
1. In step 3 of this test, the status of the software slot used for software activation remains VALID (it is 26
unchanged) and the parameter "active" remains "True".  The parameter "running" is set to True. 27
2. Status of the software slot containing the previous version of software used by device remains VALID, the 28
parameter "active" remains False. The parameter "running" is set to False. 29
 30
3.1.8 Access Control 31
 Sudo on Hybrid M-plane Architecture (positive case) 32
 33
A. Test Description and Applicability 34
This scenario is MANDATORY for an O-RU and O-DU supporting the Hybrid M-plane architecture model. 35
This test validates that user management model can be used to add users to the O-RU 36
This scenario corresponds to the following chapters in [3]: 37
• 3.3 SSH Connection Establishment 38
• 3.4 NETCONF Access Control 39
 40
B. Test Entrance Criteria 41
The minimum functions of the TER described in section 2.1 that support validation of the M-Plane are operational, 42
configured and connected to the O-RU. 43
C. Test Methodology 44
a. Initial Conditions 45
1. The test procedure described in section 3.1.6.1 is successfully completed. 46
 47
b. Procedure 48
1. The TER NETCONF Client establishes a connection with the O-RU NETCONF Server 49

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       38
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
2. The TER NETCONF Client configures three new user accounts in addition to the default sudo account 1
already present and passwords for these three accounts using o-ran-user.mgmt.yang 2
<rpc xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0" message-id="16"> 3
  <edit-config xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0"> 4
  <target> 5
            <running/> 6
        </target> 7
        <default-operation>merge</default-operation> 8
        <config> 9
   <users xmlns="urn:o-ran:user-mgmt:1.0"> 10
   <user> 11
    <name>MPLANEUSER1</name> 12
    <password>1234</password> 13
    <enabled>true</enabled> 14
   </user> 15
   <user> 16
    <name>MPLANEUSER2</name> 17
    <password>1234</password> 18
    <enabled>true</enabled> 19
   </user> 20
   <user> 21
    <name>MPLANEUSER3</name> 22
    <password>1234</password> 23
    <enabled>true</enabled> 24
   </user> 25
   </users> 26
  </config> 27
    </edit-config> 28
</rpc> 29
 30
<rpc-reply xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0" message-31
id="16"> 32
  <ok/> 33
</rpc-reply> 34
 35
3. The TER NETCONF Client configures user account to group mappings for the three new accounts using 36
ietf-netconf-acm.yang respectively one with “nms”, one with “fm-pm” and one with “swm” privilege. 37
<rpc xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0" message-id="15"> 38
  <edit-config xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0"> 39
  <target> 40
            <running/> 41
        </target> 42
        <default-operation>merge</default-operation> 43
        <config> 44
 <nacm xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:yang:ietf-netconf-acm"> 45
     <groups> 46
        <group> 47
          <name>swm</name> 48
          <user-name>MPLANEUSER1</user-name> 49
        </group> 50
  <group> 51
          <name>nms</name> 52
          <user-name>MPLANEUSER2</user-name> 53
        </group> 54
  <group> 55
          <name>fm-pm</name> 56
          <user-name>MPLANEUSER3</user-name> 57
        </group> 58
      </groups> 59
    </nacm> 60
 </config> 61
    </edit-config> 62

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       39
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
</rpc> 1
 2
4. The O-RU NETCONF Server confirms the operations for the above transactions 3
5. The TER NETCONF Client retrieves a list of users from O-RU NETCONF Server. The newly created 4
user accounts and mappings are validated. 5
<rpc xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0" message-id="17"> 6
  <get xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0"> 7
        <filter xmlns:o-ran-usermgmt="urn:o-ran:user-mgmt:1.0" 8
type="xpath" select="/o-ran-usermgmt:*//."/> 9
        <with-defaults xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:yang:ietf-netconf-10
with-defaults">report-all</with-defaults> 11
    </get> 12
</rpc> 13
 14
<rpc-reply xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0" message-15
id="17"> 16
  <data xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0"> 17
    <users xmlns="urn:o-ran:user-mgmt:1.0"> 18
      <user> 19
        <name>oranuser</name> 20
        <password>userdefined</password> 21
        <enabled>true</enabled> 22
      </user> 23
      <user> 24
        <name>xranuser</name> 25
        <password>userdefined</password> 26
        <enabled>true</enabled> 27
      </user> 28
      <user> 29
        <name>MPLANEUSER1</name> 30
        <password>1234</password>  31
        <enabled>true</enabled> 32
      </user> 33
      <user> 34
        <name>MPLANEUSER2</name> 35
        <password>1234</password> 36
        <enabled>true</enabled> 37
      </user> 38
      <user> 39
        <name>MPLANEUSER3</name> 40
        <password>1234</password> 41
        <enabled>true</enabled> 42
      </user> 43
    </users> 44
  </data> 45
</rpc-reply> 46
 47
D. Test Requirement (expected result) 48
Step 5 is correctly validated 49

• 3.4 NETCONF Access Control 1
 2
B. Test Entrance Criteria 3
The minimum functions of the TER described in section 2.1 that support validation of the M-Plane are operational, 4
configured and connected to the O-RU. 5
C. Test Methodology 6
a. Initial Conditions 7
1. The test procedure described in section 3.1.8.1 is successfully completed. 8
2. Four user accounts are provisioned on the O-RU NETCONF server with the following groupings: sudo, 9
nms, fm-pm, swm. 10
 11
b. Procedure 12
1. The TER NETCONF client establishes a connection using a user account with sudo privileges. 13
2. The TER NETCONF client gets the password leaves from the user-mgmt.yang model. 14
<rpc xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0" message-id="17"> 15
  <get xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0"> 16
        <filter xmlns:o-ran-usermgmt="urn:o-ran:user-mgmt:1.0" 17
type="xpath" select="/o-ran-usermgmt:*//."/> 18
        <with-defaults xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:yang:ietf-netconf-19
with-defaults">report-all</with-defaults> 20
    </get> 21
</rpc> 22
 23
3. The O-RU NETCONF server replies by silently omitting data nodes and their descendants to which the 24
client does not have read access from the <rpc-reply> message 25
<rpc-reply xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0" message-26
id="17"> 27
  <data xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0"> 28
    <users xmlns="urn:o-ran:user-mgmt:1.0"> 29
        <name>MPLANEUSER1</name> 30
        <password>1234</password> 31
        <enabled>true</enabled> 32
      </user> 33
      <user> 34
        <name>MPLANEUSER2</name> 35
        <password>1234</password> 36
        <enabled>true</enabled> 37
      </user> 38
      <user> 39
        <name>MPLANEUSER3</name> 40
        <password>1234</password> 41
        <enabled>true</enabled> 42
      </user> 43
    </users> 44
  </data> 45
</rpc-reply> 46
 47
D. Test Requirement (expected result) 48
Test step 3 is performed successfully. 49

                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
 1
B. Test Entrance Criteria 2
The minimum functions of the TER described in section 2.1 that support validation of the M-Plane are operational, 3
configured and connected to the O-RU. 4
C. Test Methodology 5
a. Initial Conditions 6
1. The test procedure described in section 3.1.8.1 is successfully completed. 7
2. Four user accounts are provisioned on the O-RU NETCONF server with the following groupings: sudo, 8
nms, fm-pm, swm. 9
b. Procedure 10
1. The TER NETCONF Client establishes a connection.  Instead of using the default SUDO account, the 11
NETCONF Client uses a user account with NMS privileges. 12
2. The TER NETCONF client attempts to configure a new user/password account on the NETCONF server 13
using the user-mgmt.yang model 14
<rpc xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0" message-id="16"> 15
  <edit-config xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0"> 16
  <target> 17
            <running/> 18
        </target> 19
        <default-operation>merge</default-operation> 20
        <config> 21
   <users xmlns="urn:o-ran:user-mgmt:1.0"> 22
   <user> 23
    <name>MPLANEUSER4</name> 24
    <password>1234</password> 25
    <enabled>true</enabled> 26
   </user> 27
   </config> 28
    </edit-config> 29
</rpc> 30
 31
3. The NETCONF server replies rejecting the protocol operation with an "access -denied" error. 32
<rpc-reply xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0" message-33
id="16"> 34
  <rpc-error> 35
    <error-type>protocol</error-type> 36
    <error-tag>access-denied</error-tag> 37
    <error-severity>error</error-severity> 38
  </rpc-error> 39
</rpc-reply> 40
 41
D. Test Requirement (expected result) 42
Test step 3 is performed successfully. 43
 44
 Access Control FM-PM (negative case) 45

• 3.4 NETCONF Access Control 51
 52
B. Test Entrance Criteria 53

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       42
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
The minimum functions of the TER described in section 2.1 that support validation of the M-Plane are operational, 1
configured and connected to the O-RU. 2
C. Test Methodology 3
a. Initial Conditions 4
1. The test procedure described in section 3.1.8.1 is successfully completed. 5
2. Four user accounts are provisioned on the O-RU NETCONF server with the following groupings: sudo, 6
nms, fm-pm, swm. 7
b. Procedure 8
1. The TER NETCONF Client establishes a connection.  Instead of using the default SUDO account, the 9
NETCONF Client uses a user account with fm-pm privileges. 10
2. The TER NETCONF client attempts to configure a new processing-element on the NETCONF server 11
using the o-ran-processing-element yang model 12
<rpc xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0" message-id="19"> 13
  <edit-config xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0"> 14
    <target> 15
      <running/> 16
    </target> 17
    <default-operation>merge</default-operation> 18
    <config><processing-elements xmlns="urn:o-ran:processing-19
element:1.0"> 20
  <transport-session-type>ETH-INTERFACE</transport-session-type> 21
  <ru-elements> 22
    <name>HD-BDE_00000600_processing-element01</name> 23
    <transport-flow> 24
      <interface-name>HD-BDE_00000600_uc-vlan0</interface-name> 25
      <eth-flow> 26
        <ru-mac-address>00:03:A2:0A:00:00</ru-mac-address> 27
        <vlan-id>2</vlan-id> 28
        <o-du-mac-address>38:AF:D7:D5:CE:9B</o-du-mac-address> 29
      </eth-flow> 30
    </transport-flow> 31
  </ru-elements> 32
</processing-elements> 33
</config> 34
  </edit-config> 35
</rpc> 36
 37
3. The NETCONF server replies rejecting the protocol operation with an "access -denied" error. 38
<rpc-reply xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0" message-39
id="19"> 40
  <rpc-error> 41
    <error-type>protocol</error-type> 42
    <error-tag>access-denied</error-tag> 43
    <error-severity>error</error-severity> 44
  </rpc-error> 45
</rpc-reply> 46
 47
D. Test Requirement (expected result) 48
Test step 3 is performed successfully. 49
 50
 Access Control SWM (negative case) 51
A. Test Description and Applicability 52

________________________________________________________________________________________________

This scenario is MANDATORY for an O-RU supporting the Hybrid M-plane architecture model and OPTIONAL 1
for O-DU tests. 2
This test validates that the O-RU correctly implements NETCONF Access Control user privileges. 3
The scenario corresponds to the following chapters in [3]: 4
• 3.4 NETCONF Access Control 5
 6
B. Test Entrance Criteria 7
The minimum functions of the TER described in section 2.1 that support validation of the M-Plane are operational, 8
configured and connected to the O-RU. 9
C. Test Methodology 10
a. Initial Conditions 11
1. The test procedure described in section 3.1.8.1 is successfully completed. 12
2. Four user accounts are provisioned on the O-RU NETCONF server with the following groupings: sudo, 13
nms, fm-pm, swm. 14
b. Procedure 15
1. The TER NETCONF Client establishes a connection.  Instead of using the default SUDO account, the 16
NETCONF Client uses a user account with swm privileges. 17
2. The TER NETCONF client attempts to get the configuration of the o-ran-sync.yang model 18
<rpc xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0" message-id="11"> 19
  <get xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0"> 20
        <filter xmlns:o-ran-fm="urn:o-ran:fm:1.0" type="xpath" 21
select="/o-ran-fm:*//."/> 22
        <with-defaults xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:yang:ietf-netconf-23
with-defaults">report-all</with-defaults> 24
    </get> 25
</rpc> 26
 27
3. The NETCONF server replies rejecting the protocol operation with an "access-denied" error. 28
<rpc-reply xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0" message-29
id="11"> 30
  <rpc-error> 31
    <error-type>protocol</error-type> 32
    <error-tag>access-denied</error-tag> 33
    <error-severity>error</error-severity> 34
  </rpc-error> 35
</rpc-reply> 36
 37
D. Test Requirement (expected result) 38
Test step 3 is performed successfully. 39
