3.1.9  External Input / Output Ports 50
 External Input Port State Detection 51
A. Test Description and Applicability 52
This scenario is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. The test is applicable only for O-RUs supporting logical input 53
ports.  This test is OPTIONAL for O-DU tests. 54
This test validates proper handling of logical input ports. 55
This scenario corresponds to the following chapters in [3]: 56

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       46
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
• 11.4.1 External Input 1
 2
B. Test Entrance Criteria 3
• The minimum functions of the TER described in section 2.1 that support validation of the M-Plane are 4
operational, configured and connected to the O-RU. 5
• Supplementary circuitry is required to force a change of logical state of input lines belonging to an input port. 6
It is assumed that logical input ports are internally pulled to logical high state by O -RU, therefore 7
supplementary circuitry shall only allow to change the input port to a logical low. To determine a physical 8
input line for this test, one shall read the customer documentation applicable for the O-RU being tested. 9
 10
C. Test Methodology 11
a. Initial Conditions 12
1. The test procedure described in section 3.1.4.1 is successfully completed. 13
 14
b. Procedure 15
1. The External Input Ports are left in their normal, default stated.  For the purposes of this test, these input 16
ports are assumed to be a logical high.  17
2. The TER NETCONF Client retrieves state of chosen input port by issuing <rpc><get><filter 18
type="subtree"><external-io xml...><input><port-in></port-in></input></external-19
io></filter></get></rpc> 20
<rpc xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0" message-id="7"> 21
    <get xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0"> 22
    <filter type="subtree"> 23
              <external-io xmlns:o-ran-io="urn:o-ran:external-io:1.0"> 24
       <input>   <port-in/> </input> 25
          </external-io> 26
         </filter> 27
           <with-defaults xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:yang:ietf-28
netconf-with-defaults">report-all</with-defaults> 29
     </get> 30
</rpc> 31
 32
3. The O-RU NETCONF Server provides the state of every line-in belonging to the input port under test to 33
the TER NETCONF Client. For all input lines, the state is TRUE, indicating open circuit (no shortage to 34
ground is detected by input lines) 35
<rpc-reply xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0" message-36
id="7"> 37
  <data xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0"> 38
    <external-io xmlns="urn:o-ran:external-io:1.0"> 39
      <input> 40
        <name>PORT0</name> 41
        <port-in>0</port-in> 42
        <line-in>TRUE</line-in> 43
      </input> 44
    </external-io> 45
  </data> 46
</rpc-reply> 47
 48
4. The TER supplementary circuitry randomly shorts one or more input lines to the ground. Changes shall 49
occur with a periodicity greater than 30 seconds. 50
5. For every change the O-RU NETCONF Server sends notification <external-input-change> to the TER 51
NETCONF Client.   The notification contains updated states of input lines belonging to the port under test. 52
A state FALSE indicates shortage to ground detected by particular input line.  53
notification xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:notification:1.0"> 54
  <eventTime> YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SS.FZ </eventTime> 55
<external-input-change xmlns="urn:o-ran:external-io:1.0" > 56
      <current-input-notification > 57
        <external-input > 58
          <name > PORT0</name> 59
            <line-in >FALSE</line-in> 60

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       47
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
        </external-input> 1
      </current-input-notification> 2
    </external-input-change> 3
</notification> 4
 5
6. This test scenario is looped to step 4 for a total of 10 iterations including the first pass through steps 1 to 4. 6
 7
D. Test Requirement (expected result) 8
Step 5 is correctly validated for each of the total of 10 iterations of the test.  9
 10
 External Output Port State Control 11
A. Test Description and Applicability 12
This scenario is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. The test is applicable only for O-RUs supporting logical output 13
ports.  This test is OPTIONAL for O-DU tests. 14
This test validates proper handling of logical output ports. 15
This scenario corresponds to the following chapters in [3]: 16
• 11.4.2 External Output 17
 18
B. Test Entrance Criteria 19
• The minimum functions of the TER described in section 2.1 that support validation of the M-Plane are 20
operational, configured and connected to the O-RU. 21
• Supplementary circuitry is required to measure voltage of an output port signal.  To determine the mapping of 22
physical output lines to ports, one shall read customer documentation for the O-RU being tested.  The 23
definition of voltage levels served by output lines of output ports and the maximum allowed current sourced by 24
single an output line shall be validated against the TER capabilities. 25
 26
C. Test Methodology 27
a. Initial Conditions 28
1. The test procedure described in section 3.1.4.1 is successfully completed. 29
 30
b. Procedure 31
1. The TER NETCONF Client issues :<rpc><edit-config> to the O-RU NETCONF Server requesting all 32
output lines belonging to output port to be set to FALSE. 33
<rpc xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0" message-34
id="56"> 35
  <edit-config xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0"> 36
  <target><running/></target> 37
  <default-operation>merge</default-operation> 38
    <config> 39
      <external-io xmlns="urn:o-ran:external-io:1.0"> 40
        <output-setting> 41
          <name>External-Output-0</name> 42
          <line-out>false</line-out> 43
        </output-setting> 44
      </external-io> 45
    </config> 46
  </edit-config> 47
</rpc> 48
2. The O-RU NETCONF Server sets logical LOW state to output lines corresponding to step 1 and responds 49
to TER NETCONF Client with <rpc-reply> 50
<rpc-reply message-id="56" 51
 xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0"> 52
  <ok/> 53
</rpc-reply> 54
3. The TER supplementary circuitry shows that all output lines of the target output port are set to logical 55
LOW state. 56

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       48
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
4. The TER NETCONF Client issues :<rpc><edit-config> towards NETCONF Server requesting a random 1
change of states of output lines belonging to target output port.  Changes shall occur with a periodicity 2
greater than 30 seconds. 3
<rpc xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0" message-4
id="58"> 5
  <edit-config xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0"> 6
  <target><running/></target> 7
  <default-operation>merge</default-operation> 8
    <config> 9
      <external-io xmlns="urn:o-ran:external-io:1.0"> 10
        <output-setting> 11
          <name>External-Output-0</name> 12
          <line-out>true</line-out> 13
        </output-setting> 14
      </external-io> 15
    </config> 16
  </edit-config> 17
</rpc> 18
5. The O-RU NETCONF Server sets the requested states of output lines for the states defined by step 4 and 19
responds to NETCONF Client with <rpc-reply>.  The TER supplementary circuitry validates the change. 20
<rpc-reply message-id="58" 21
  xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0"> 22
  <ok/> 23
</rpc-reply> 24
6. This test scenario is looped to step 5 for a total of 10 iterations including the first pass through steps 1 to 4. 25

B. Test Entrance Criteria 1
• The minimum functions of the TER described in section 2.1 that support validation of the M-Plane are 2

3.1.11 ALD Communications 19
 ALD Communications Test 20
A. Test Description and Applicability 21
This scenario is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY for a O-RU equipped with a RET port (regardless of whether 22
this is a raw RS-485 port or OOK modem coupled internally to antenna connector (s)).  This scenario shall be 23
performed against each ALD port exposed by the O-RU.  This test is OPTIONAL for O-DU tests. 24
The purpose of the test is to validate the ALD communications protocol and operation of the O -RU. The following 25
functions are validated in this test. 26
• Proper transmission of the content if RPC <ald-communication> towards desired ALD port 27
• Proper calculation of FCS 28
• Proper application of basic transparency to content to be transmitted 29
• Proper addition of start / stop flags 30
• Proper reception of payload injected to ALD port 31
• Proper removal of start / stop flags 32
• Proper application of basic transparency to content received from ALD port 33
• Proper validation of FCS in data received from ALD port. 34
 35
This scenario corresponds to the following chapters in [3]: 36
• 11.3 Operational aspects of Antenna Line Devices 37
 38
B. Test Entrance Criteria 39
• The minimum functions of the TER described in section 2.1 that support validation of the M-Plane are 40
operational, configured and connected to the O-RU. 41
• It is assumed, that O-RU being a subject of this conformance test scenario is proven to be compliant to the 42
following specifications: 43
1. ISO/IEC 13239:2002 “High-level data link control (HDLC) procedures” 44
2. 3GPP TS 25.460 “UTRAN Iuant Interface: General aspects and principles” 45
3. 3GPP TS 25.461 ”UTRAN Iuant Interface: Layer 1” 46
4. 3GPP TS 25.462 ”UTRAN Iuant Interface: Signalling Transport” 47
5. 3GPP TS 25.466 “UTRAN Iuant Interface: Application Part” 48
• The O-RU uses a 9.6 kbps data rate on its ALD port(s) for transmission and reception, regardless of connector 49
supported by particular ALD port. 50
 51
 52

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       52
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
C. Test Methodology 1
As O-RU does not verify correctness of the payload that is exchanged between NETCONF Client and ALD (except 2
FCS for traffic coming from ALD) - any payload can be used in test vector, under condition, that test vectors are 3
compliant to referenced above set of specification documents (e.g. length is not smaller than minimum size of real 4
message). 5
RS-485 sniffer / injector is needed for this test. Such a device shall be connected either to O -RU’s RS-485 port or 6
to RS-485 port of Smart BiasT connected to O-RU with coaxial cable (depending on O-RU construction) 7
Unless not specified otherwise – RS-485 sniffer / injector shall be connected to ALD port corresponding to record 8
“port-id” used in RPC <ald-communication>. 9
In case O-RU exposes ALD port as antenna port, test environment should utilize Smart BiasT for conversion 10
between OOK modulation at antenna port and RS-485 signaling that RS-485 sniffer / injector can handle. DC 11
voltage for Smart BiasT device shall be provided by O-RU through antenna feeder. 12
If not specified otherwise, for test purposes RS-485 sniffer / injector is connected to ALD port which will be 13
addressed in RPC <ald-communication> within the scenario. 14
As this test is intended to verify O-RU functions and there will be no real ALD connected – compliance to the 15
required HDLC message structure is required, whilst the AISG payload can be artificial (unless otherwise specified 16
in test case). The O-RU does not verify if messaging is correct, hence, for test simplicity and ease of test result 17
verification, artificial test vectors can be used. 18
a. Initial Conditions 19
2. The test procedure described in section 3.1.4.1 is successfully completed. 20
 21
a. Procedure 22
i. Test Case 1: Transmission towards ALD (positive scenario) 23
Scope: CRC calculation, transparency algorithm application, start / stop flag addition, datagram  24
transmission using desired ALD port  25
1) NETCONF Client sends regular RPC <ald-communication> message containing bytes 0x7D and 26
0x7E in “ald-req-msg” record. 27
2) O-RU calculates FCS, adds it to datagram provided in record “ald-req-msg”, applies basic 28
transparency (replaces every occurrence of byte “0x7E” with two bytes “0x7D 0x5E”, respectively, 29
replace byte “0x7D” with two bytes “0x7D 0x5D”) and add start/stop flags 0x7E.  30
3) O-RU sends payload calculated in step 2 through ALD port mentioned in record “port -id” of RPC. 31
4) RS-485 sniffer / injector receives payload sent by O-RU. Received payload is subject of analysis for 32
scenario success / failure classification 33
 34
ii. Test Case 1 Test Requirement (expected result) 35
Content received by RS-485 listener / injector is compared with content of RPC <ald-communication>. 36
a) payload shall be sent by desired ALD port of O-RU 37
b) FCS shall be properly calculated 38
c) basic transparency shall be properly applied 39
d) start / stop flags shall be added to payload that has been received by RS-485 sniffer / injector 40
Test scenario is considered as completed with success in case all mentioned above conditions are satisfied. 41
Any deviation means test scenario is failed. 42
 43
iii. Test Case 2: Reception from ALD (positive case) 44
Scope: datagram reception, start / stop flag detection and removal, transparency algorithm applications, 45
CRC verification  46
Note: Test case 2 shall be performed just after Test case 1 so that content injected by RS -485 sniffer / 47
injector is considered by O-RU as ALD’s response to message sent towards ALD in Test case 1. Timing 48
between Test case 1 and Test case 2 shall follow 3GPP specifications mentioned above.  49
1) RS485 sniffer / injector sends properly formatted (start / stop flags, FCS and min / max payload s ize) 50
message containing strings “0x7D 0x5E” and “0x7D 0x5D” towards O-RU’s ALD port used in Test 51
case 1. 52

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       53
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
2) O-RU receives the content. 1
3) O-RU removes start / stop flags, performs basic transparency (replaces “0x7D 0x5E” with “0x7E” 2
and “0x7D 0x5D” with “0x7D”), makes sure if FCS is correct according content of datagram.  3
4) O-RU sends “ald-resp-msg” towards NETCONF Client. 4
 5
iv. Test Case 2 Requirement (expected result) 6
Content received by NETCONF Client is compared with content injected by RS -485 sniffer / injector. 7
a) record “ald-port” shall indicate proper O-RU’s ALD port as source of the payload 8
b) basic transparency is properly applied 9
b) counter of received octets is properly incremented 10
d) counters of frames with wrong FCS (CRC) and frames without stop  flags are not incremented 11
Test scenario is considered as completed with success in case all mentioned above conditions are satisfied. 12
Any deviation means test scenario is failed. 13
v. Test Case 3: Reception from ALD (negative case – wrong FCS) 14
Scope: datagram reception, start / stop flag detection and removal, transparency algorithm application, 15
CRC verification  16
Note: Test case 3 shall be performed just after Test case 1 so that content injected by RS -485 sniffer / 17
injector is considered by O-RU as ALD’s response to message sent towards ALD in Test case 1. Timing 18
between Test case 1 and Test case 3 shall follow 3GPP specifications mentioned above.  19
1) RS-485 sniffer / injector sends message containing wrong FCS towards O-RU’s ALD port used in Test 20
case 1. 21
2) O-RU receives the content. 22
3) O-RU removes start / stop flags, performs basic transparency (replaces “0x7D 0x5E” with “0x7E” and 23
“0x7D 0x5D” with “0x7D”) and detects, that FCS is incorrect according content of received datagram.  24
4) O-RU sends “ald-resp-msg” towards NETCONF Client. 25
 26
vi. Test Case 3 Requirement (expected result) 27
Content received by NETCONF Client is compared with content injected by RS -485 sniffer / injector. 28
a) record “ald-port” shall indicate proper O-RU’s ALD port as source of the payload 29
b) record “ald-resp-msg” is empty 30
b) counter of received octets and counter of frames without stop flags are not incremented  31
d) counters of frames with wrong FCS (CRC) is incremented 32
Test scenario is considered as completed with success in case all mentioned a bove conditions are satisfied. 33
Any deviation means test scenario is failed. 34
 35
vii. Test Case 4: Reception from ALD (negative case – no stop flag) 36
Scope: datagram reception, start / stop flag detection 37
Note: Test case 4 shall be performed just after Test case 1 so that content injected by RS-485 sniffer / 38
injector is considered by O-RU as ALD’s response to message sent towards ALD in Test case 1. Timing 39
between Test case 1 and Test case 4 shall follow 3GPP specifications mentioned above.  40
1) RS-485 sniffer / injector sends message not terminated by stop flag “0x7E” towards O-RU’s ALD port 41
used in Test case 1. 42

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       54
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
2) O-RU receives the content. 1
3) O-RU reaches the end of reception window without receiving stop flag that would terminate the 2
datagram. 3
4) O-RU sends “ald-resp-msg” towards NETCONF Client. 4
 5
viii. Test Case 4 Requirement (expected result) 6
Content received by NETCONF Client is compared with content injected by RS -485 sniffer / injector. 7
a) record “ald-port” shall indicate proper O-RU’s ALD port as source of the payload 8
b) record “ald-resp-msg” is empty 9
b) counter of received octets and counter of frames of frames with wrong FCS (CRC) are not incremented  10
d) counter of frames without stop flags is incremented 11
Test scenario is considered as completed with success in case all mentioned above conditions are satisfied. 12
Any deviation means test scenario is failed. 13
 14
ix. Test case 5: Transmission towards ALD (negative scenario – wrong ALD port) 15
Scope: CRC calculation, transparency algorithm application, start / stop flag addition, datagram 16
transmission using desired ALD port (ports are not used by the same HDLC Primary Device)  17
Scenario is applicable only in case O-RU supports more than one ALD port and under condition that ALD 18
ports do not share single modem. 19
IMPORTANT: In this scenario RS-485 sniffer / injector shall be connected to ALD port different from 20
than the one indicated in record “port-id” of RPC <ald-communication>. 21
1) NETCONF Client sends regular RPC <ald-communication> message. 22
2) O-RU performs the content processing and sends the content towards ALD port that corresponds to 23
content of record “port-id” of RPC 24
3) RS-485 sniffer / injector does not receive payload sent by O-RU.  25
 26
x. Test Requirement (expected result) 27
Test scenario is considered as completed with success in case RS-485 sniffer / injector does not receive 28
payload in step 3. Any deviation is considered as failed test case. 29
 30
xi. Test case 6: Transmission towards ALD (negative scenario – non-existing ALD port) 31
Scope: datagram reception 32
1) NETCONF Client sends regular RPC <ald-communication> message. Parameter <port-id> used in 33
RPC does not point to existing ALD port. 34
2) O-RU sends <rpc-response> to NETCONF Client. In the response parameter “status” contains value 35
“REJECTED” and parameter “error-message” informs about wrong ALD port has been used in RPC 36
<ald-communication> 37
3) NETCONF Client receives described above <rpc-response> message. 38
 39
xii. Test Requirement (expected result) 40
Test scenario is considered as completed with success in case step 3) is reached.  41
 42

3.1.12 Log Management 1
 Log Management Test 2
A. Test Description and Applicability 3
This scenario is MANDATORY for both O-RU and O-DU Tests. 4
This test validates the capability of the O-RU to upload troubleshooting logs including alarm information. 5
This scenario corresponds to the following chapters in [3]: 6
• 11.2.1 Troubleshooting 7
 8
B. Test Entrance Criteria 9
• The minimum functions of the TER described in section 2.1 that support validation of the M-Plane are 10
operational, configured and connected to the O-RU. 11
• Supplementary circuitry is required to measure voltage of an output port signal.  To determine the mapping of 12
physical output lines to ports, one shall read customer documentation for the O-RU being tested.  The 13
definition of voltage levels served by output lines of output ports and the maximum allowed current sourced by 14
single an output line shall be validated against the TER capabilities. 15
 16
C. Test Methodology 17
a. Initial Conditions 18
1. The test procedure described in section 3.1.4.1 is successfully completed. 19
 20
b. Procedure 21
1. The TER NETCONF Client sends <rpc><start-troubleshooting-logs> to the O-RU NETCONF Server.  22
The O-RU NETCONF Server responds with <rpc-reply>< troubleshooting-status-grouping >. 23
<rpc xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0" message-24
id="56"> 25
  <start-troubleshooting-logs xmlns="urn:o-26
ran:troubleshooting:1.0"/> 27
</rpc> 28
 29
<rpc-reply message-id="56" 30
  xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0"> 31
  <status xmlns="urn:o-ran:troubleshooting:1.0">SUCCESS</status> 32
</rpc-reply> 33
2. The O-RU NETCONF Server starts generating one or more file(s) containing troubleshooting logs.  When 34
the generation of the log file(s) are completed, the O-RU NETCONF Server sends 35
<notification><troubleshooting-log-generated> with a list of one or more log file names to the TER 36
NETCONF Server.  37
NOTE: It is assumed that the generated log file(s) contains troubleshooting logs related to alarm 17 38
measured in 3.1.5.2 or a  vendor specific alarm, but the content and format are not specified. 39
<notification 40
xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:notification:1.0"> 41
  <eventTime>YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SS.FZ</eventTime> 42
  <troubleshooting-log-generated xmlns="urn:o-43
ran:troubleshooting:1.0"> 44
    <log-file-name>/O-RAN/log/Troubleshootinglog.gz</log-file-name> 45
  </troubleshooting-log-generated> 46
</notification> 47
3. The TER NETCONF Client sends  <rpc><file-upload>log-file-name</file-upload></rpc> to the O-RU 48
NETCONF Server to start uploading the log file(s).  The O-RU NETCONF Server responds with <rpc-49
reply><file-upload> with status SUCCESS.  50

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       56
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
<rpc xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0" message-1
id="57"> 2
  <file-upload xmlns="urn:o-ran:file-management:1.0"> 3
    <local-logical-file-path>/O-4
RAN/log/Troubleshootinglog.gz</local-logical-file-path> 5
    <remote-file-6
path>sftp://oranuser@192.168.3.13:22/local/log</remote-file-path> 7
    <password> 8
      <password>1234</password> 9
    </password> 10
  </file-upload> 11
</rpc> 12
 13
<rpc-reply message-id="57" 14
  xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0"> 15
  <status xmlns="urn:o-ran:file-management:1.0">SUCCESS</status> 16
</rpc-reply> 17
4. The O-RU NETCONF Server uploads the log file(s) to NETCONF Client by sFTP. When file upload is 18
completed, the O-RU NETCONF Server sends <notification><upload-notification> with status 19
SUCCESS. 20
<notification 21
xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:notification:1.0"> 22
  <eventTime>YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SS.FZ</eventTime> 23
  <file-upload-notification xmlns="urn:o-ran:file-management:1.0"> 24
    <local-logical-file-path>/O-25
RAN/log/Troubleshootinglog.gz</local-logical-file-path> 26
    <remote-file-path>sftp://oranuser@192.168.3.13:22/local/log 27
</remote-file-path> 28
    <status>SUCCESS</status> 29
  </file-upload-notification> 30
</notification> 31
 32
D. Test Requirement (expected result) 33
Test step 4 is performed successfully. 34
NOTE: The O-RU vendor may check the contents of the uploaded log file in detail for the reported alarm 17, 35
but as noted, the content and format of troubleshooting logs are not defined. 36
 37
3.1.13 Connectivity Check 38
 Ethernet Connectivity Monitoring 39
A. Test Description and Applicability 40
This scenario is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY if the O-RU or O-DU supports C-Plane and U-Plane 41
connectivity over Ethernet.   42
This test validates the proper operation of LBM on the O-RU. 43
This scenario corresponds to the following chapters in [3]: 44
• 4.3 C/U Plane VLAN configuration 45
• 4.5 Definition of processing elements 46
• 4.6 Verifying C/U Plane Transport Connectivity 47
 48
B. Test Entrance Criteria 49
1. The minimum functions of the TER described in section 2.1 that support validation of the M-Plane are 50
operational, configured and connected to the O-RU. 51
2. Result validation of this test requires TER capabilities such as a network sniffer that allows for traffic analysis 52
over ETH frames between O-RU and O-DU. 53

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       57
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
 1
C. Test Methodology 2
a. Initial Conditions 3
1. The test procedure described in section 3.1.4.1 is successfully completed. 4
 5
b. Procedure 6
1. The TER NETCONF Client configures the O-RU NETCONF Server with a vlan-id for the C-Plane and 7
U-Plane interfaces. 8
2. The TER NETCONF Client configures a transport-flow in the O-RU processing element:  a combination 9
of VLAN identity, O-DU MAC address and O-RU MAC address.  10
3. The TER sends loopback message to the O-RU MAC address configured for the processing element. 11
4. The O-RU sends loopback responses to the O-DU MAC Address of the loopback message. 12
 13
D. Test Requirement (expected result) 14
Packets are sent correctly in step 3 and 4, as validated via the TER. 15
 UDP Echo Test 16
A. Test Description and Applicability 17
This scenario is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY.  The test is applicable only if the O-RU or O-DU supports C-18
Plane and U-Plane sessions over IP. 19
This test validates the proper operation UDP Echo on the O-RU for continuous verification of connectivity. 20
This scenario corresponds to the following chapters in [3]: 21
• 4.4 O-RU C/U Plane IP Address Assignment  22
• 4.5 Definition of processing elements 23
• 4.6 Verifying C/U Plane Transport Connectivity 24
 25
B. Test Entrance Criteria 26
1. The minimum functions of the TER described in section 2.1 that support validation of the M-Plane are 27
operational, configured and connected to the O-RU. 28
2. Result validation of this test requires TER capabilities such as a network sniffer that allows for traffic analysis 29
over ETH frames between O-RU and O-DU. 30
 31
C. Test Methodology 32
a. Initial Conditions 33
1. The test procedure described in section 3.1.4.1 is successfully completed. 34
 35
b. Procedure 36
1. The TER NETCONF Client configures IP information and udpip-flow in the O-RU processing element 37
for the C-Plane and U-Plane communications.  38
2. The TER NETCONF Client sends a UDP datagram to UDP port number:7 of  the O-RU NETCONF 39
Server. 40
3. The O-RU NETCONF Server sends back the UDP datagram to the TER NETCONF Client. 41
 42
D. Test Requirement (expected result) 43
Packets are sent correctly in step 2 and 3 as validated by the TER with sniffer capability.  44
  45

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.

                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
 1
3.2 UC-Plane Measurements O-RU 2
3.2.1 UC-Plane Standard Test Definitions 3
The following sections describe test scenarios for equipment implementing the U -Plane and C-Plane O-RAN option 4
7.2x protocols.    5
The initial focus of this conformance test document is validation of the O-RU as the device under test (DUT).  Future 6
versions of this specification may address conformance tests with other devices as the DUT.  7
 UC-Plane Measurements, O-RU TEST SCENARIO 8
In these sets of tests, the Device Under Test (DUT) is the O-RU.   9
This document describes conformance tests for 4 scenarios: 10
1. Conducted FDD tests for FR1 radios 11
2. Non-conducted (OTA) FDD tests for FR1 radios 12
3. Conducted TDD tests for FR1 radios 13
4. Non-conducted tests for TDD FR1 and FR2 radios 14
 15
The O-RU must only be tested for the scenarios that apply to the O-RU capabilities. The fact that there are 4 scenarios 16
defined does not imply that every O-RU must be tested for all scenarios in order to be O-RAN compliant and 17
consequently the O-RU does not have to support all the capabilities required to test all 4 scenarios (i.e. support of FR1, 18
FR2, TDD, FDD, conducted and non-conducted). In other words, depending on whether the O-RU supports capabilities 19
such as FDD, TDD, FR1 and or FR2, the corresponding scenarios that match the O -RU capabilities will apply only. For 20
example, an O-RU that does not have or cannot provide access to antenna ports (or TAB connectors), supports TDD 21
and operates at FR2 bands, the corresponding scenario that the O-RU will need to be tested to be O-RAN conformant is 22
scenario #4 only. Another example, for an O-RU that supports FDD, operates at FR1 bands and has or can provide 23
access to antenna ports (or TAB connectors), scenario #1 or #2 can apply but only one of the two possible scenarios will 24
be selected to test the O-RU for O-RAN conformance.   25
 26
For scenario #1 and #3 above the RF test setup is as described in 3GPP TS 38.141-1[NR] and TS 36.141 [LTE].  For 27
scenarios #2 and #4 the RF test setup is as described in TS 38.141-2. Note that O-RAN conformance testing is expected 28
to be “off-line” and not to be run while an O-DU and/or O-RU is operating and serving actual users.  The O-RU 29
manufacturer must also make available the same declarations described in 3GPP TS 38.141 -1, TS 38.141-2 [NR] and 30
TS 36.141 [LTE] Section 4.6.  This will determine the radio’s support for multi -carrier operation (e.g., if multi-carrier 31
operation is supported on different connectors) 32
Since the purpose of this document is to test O-RAN Fronthaul conformance and not to duplicate 3GPP RF tests, only 33
selected parts of TS 38.141-1, TS 38.141-2 [NR] and TS 36.141 [LTE] will be used for RF testing.  These selected test 34
features are only necessary to test whether the O-RU correctly interpreted and generated the O-RAN C-Plane and U-35
Plane messages correctly. There will also be some additions to the test waveforms used in TS 38.141 -1, TS 38.141-2 36
[NR] and TS 36.141 [LTE] to fully exercise the features of the O-RAN Fronthaul protocol.  These selected parts and 37
additions are summarized below: 38
 For scenario #1 (Conducted FDD tests for FR1 radios) 39
• For downlink tests for type 1-C radios (radios with antenna port connectors and passive antennas) the test 40
configuration described in TS 38.141-1 D.1.1 will be used.  Only a single antenna port will be used unless the 41
test explicitly requires more than one port and the radio supports more than one port.  RF test equipment will 42
be connected at the point described in TS 38.141-1 section 4.2.1. Note that an antenna port is an electrical 43
conducting port that is connected to an array element. 44
• For uplink tests for type 1-C radios (radios with antenna port connectors and passive antennas) the test 45
configuration described in TS 38.141-1 D.2.1 will be used.  Only a single antenna port will be used unless the 46

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       59
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
test explicitly requires more than one port and the radio supports more than one port.  RF test equipment will 1
be connected at the point described in TS 38.141-1 section 4.2.1. Note that an antenna port is an electrical 2
conducting port that is connected to an array element. 3
• For downlink tests for type 1-H radios (radios with TAB connectors and active antenna systems) the test 4
configuration described in TS 38.14138.141-1 D.3.1 will be used for conducted tests.  Only a single TAB 5
connector will be used unless the test explicitly requires more than one connector.  RF test equipment will be 6
connected at the point described in TS 38.141-1 section 4.2.2. Note that a transceiver array boundary (TAB) 7
connector is an electrical conducting port that is connected to an array element via a radio distribution network 8
(RDN). 9
• For uplink tests for type 1-H radios (radios with TAB connectors and active antenna systems) the test 10
configuration described in TS 38.14138.141-1 D.4.1 will be used for conducted tests.  Only a single TAB 11
connector will be used unless the test explicitly requires more than one connector.  RF test equipment will be 12
connected at the point described in TS 38.141-1 section 4.2.2. Note that a transceiver array boundary (TAB) 13
connector is an electrical conducting port that is connected to an array element via a radio distribution network 14
(RDN). 15
• The basic downlink test will start with the Test model described in NR-FR1-TM1.1 and E-TM1.1.  Subsequent 16
tests will adapt this model to test additional features of the O-RAN interface (e.g., Modifying the payload data, 17
blanking some symbols, etc.).  Note this test model describes the IQ data contained in the O-RAN packets not 18
the O-RAN specific parameters.  This test model will also be augmented with the following O-RAN specific 19
parameters: 20
Includes “stock” eAxC values as configured via M-Plane: 21
• DU_Port_ID: two bits, nominal value 00b 22
• BandSector: nominal 6 bits, nominal value 000000b 23
• CC_ID: nominal 4 bits, nominal value 0000b (most tests invoke only one component carrier) 24
• RU_port_ID: 4 bits, nominal values 0000b through 0011b or to whatever max value needed for a 25
specific test 26
• If the radio manufacturer declares support for multi-carrier a different eAxC will be assigned for each carrier. 27
Note that most tests described in 3GPP TS 38.141-1[NR] and TS 36.141 [LTE]  require testing at the bottom, 28
middle and top of the supported bands of the radio.  This specification r elaxes that requirement because the 29
purpose is to test the fronthaul compliance and not the radio performance. 30
• Compression: Static 16-bit fixed point IQ bitwidth in both DL and UL 31
• Beamforming: no beamforming (beamId = 0x0000), assumed to mean boresight radiation (normal to the 32
antenna surface) at some undetermined beamwidth (recall that beam weight magnitudes must be equal to 33
unity) 34
• Transport: L2 Ethernet, eCPRI with no fragmentation and no QOS 35
• Delay Parameters: The test will be executed with a direct fiber connection to the O-RU and the network delay 36
is considered negligible for the purpose of delay management.  Therefore, T12_min = T12_max = 0 and 37
T34_min = T34_max = 0. 38
The radio will report its supported values for: 39
o T2a_min/max_up 40
o Ta3_min/max_up 41
o T2a_min/max_cp_ul 42
o Tcp_adv_dl 43
These parameters will be used to calculate the delay windows needed for the delay management tests below.   44
Note that T1a_min_up = T2a_min_up and T1a_max_up = T2a_max_up due to the fixed, zero network delay.  45
Similarly, Ta4_min_up = Ta3_min_up and Ta4_max_up = Ta3_max_up.  Simi larly, T1a_min_cp_ul = 46
T2a_min_cp_ul and T1a_max_cp_ul = T2a_max_cp_ul.   47
 48
• Uplink tests will start with the basic 3GPP test signal for Fixed Reference Channels for receiver sensitivity and 49
in-channel selectivity as described in 3GPP TS 38.141-1[NR] and TS 36.141 [LTE].  All O-RAN specific 50
parameters will be the same as described above for downlink testing.  As with downlink testing subsequent 51
tests will build on this basic waveform modifying parameters as needed to exercise O-RAN specific features. 52
• Uplink tests will be conducted using power levels at least 30dB higher than the power levels used to test 3GPP 53
Receiver sensitivity described in 3GPP TS 38.141-1 Table 7.2.5-1[NR] and TS 36.141 [LTE]. This is to ensure 54

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       60
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
a clear signal is received by the O-RU so it can be accurately decoded and demodulated to ensure the correct 1
data was received by the O-DU as was sent by the signal source.  Again, the purpose of these tests is to ensure 2
correct operation of the O-RAN fronthaul not to test receiver sensitivity. 3
 4
 For scenario #2 (Non-conducted OTA FDD tests for FR1 radios) 5
• For downlink tests for type 1-H radios that elect to be tested over the air (OTA) rather than conducted, the test 6
configuration is described in TS 38.141-2 E.1.2 where the Test Antenna will be placed inside an OTA chamber 7
and measurements are referenced to the radiated characteristics defined over the air (OTA) at the Radiated 8
Interface Boundary (RIB) defined in TS 38.141-2 4.2-1. The RF analyzer test equipment is connected to the 9
Test Antenna and is located outside of the OTA chamber.  10
• For downlink test for 1-O or 2-O radios (radios with no physical antenna or TAB connectors and consequently 11
only over the air – OTA – measurements are possible) the test configuration is described in TS 38.141-2 E.1.2 12
where the Test Antenna will be placed inside an OTA chamber and measurements are referenced to the 13
radiated characteristics defined over the air (OTA) at the Radiated Interface Boundary (RIB) defined in TS 14
38.141-2 4.2-2. The RF analyzer test equipment is connected to the Test Antenna and is located outside of the 15
OTA chamber. 16
• For uplink tests for type 1-H radios that elect to be tested over the air (OTA) rather than conducted, the test 17
configuration is described in TS 38.141-2 E.2.1 where the Test Antenna will be placed inside an OTA chamber 18
and measurements are referenced to the radiated characteristics defined over the air (OT A) at the Radiated 19
Interface Boundary (RIB) defined in TS 38.141-2 4.2-1. The RF generator test equipment is connected to the 20
Test Antenna and is located outside of the OTA chamber. 21
• For uplink test for 1-O or 2-O radios (radios with no physical antenna or TAB connectors and consequently 22
only over the air (OTA) measurements are possible) the test configuration is desc ribed in TS 38.141-2 E.2.1 23
where the Test Antenna will be placed inside an OTA chamber and measurements are referenced to the 24
radiated characteristics defined over the air (OTA) at the Radiated Interface Boundary (RIB) defined in TS 25
38.141-2 4.2-2. The RF generator test equipment is connected to the Test Antenna and is located outside of the 26
OTA chamber.  27
• For downlink tests for LTE radios that elect to be tested over the air (OTA), the test configuration is described 28
in TS 38.141-2 E.1.2 where the Test Antenna will be placed inside an OTA chamber and measurements are 29
referenced to the radiated characteristics defined over the air (OTA) at the Radi ated Interface Boundary (RIB) 30
defined in TS 38.141-2 4.2-1. The RF analyzer test equipment is connected to the Test Antenna and is located 31
out of the OTA chamber. 32
• For uplink tests for LTE radios that elect to be tested over the air (OTA), the test configuration is described in 33
TS 38.141-2 E.2.1 where the Test Antenna will be placed inside an OTA chamber and measurements are 34
referenced to the radiated characteristics defined over the air (OTA) at the Radiated Interface Boundary (RIB) 35
defined in TS 38.141-2 4.2-1. The RF generator test equipment is connected to the Test Antenna and is located 36
out of the OTA chamber. 37
• Note that the chamber shown in TS 38.141-2 E1.2. and E.2.1. are generic and consequently any OTA chamber 38
could be used, i.e. far field, CATR, near field, reverberation, etc. 39
• Likewise, depending on the beamforming measurement technology the positioner in TS 38.141 -2 E.1.2 and 40
E.2.1. may or may not be needed. 41
• Furthermore, depending on the beamforming method to be measured more than one test an tenna with more 42
than one RF analyzer and/or generator ports may also be needed. 43
• The basic downlink test will start with the Test model described in NR -FR1-TM1.1 and E-TM1.1 in TS 44
38.141-1 and 36.141 for NR FR1 and LTE radios respectively.  Subsequent tests will adapt this model to test 45
additional features of the O-RAN interface (e.g., Modifying the payload data, blanking some symbols, etc.).  46
Note this test model describes the IQ data contained in the O-RAN packets not the O-RAN specific 47
parameters.  This test model will also be augmented with the following O-RAN specific parameters: 48
Includes “stock” eAxC values as configured via M-Plane: 49
• DU_Port_ID: two bits, nominal value 00b 50

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       61
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
• BandSector: nominal 6 bits, nominal value 000000b 1
• CC_ID: nominal 4 bits, nominal value 0000b (most tests invoke only one component carrier) 2
• RU_port_ID: 4 bits, nominal values 0000b through 0011b or to whatever max value needed for a 3
specific test 4
• If the radio manufacturer declares support for multi-carrier a different eAxC will be assigned for each carrier. 5
Note that most tests described in 3GPP TS 38.141-2[NR] and TS 36.141 [LTE]  require testing at the bottom, 6
middle and top of the supported bands of the radio.  This specification relaxes that requirement be cause the 7
purpose is to test the fronthaul compliance and not the radio performance. 8
• Compression: Static 16-bit fixed point IQ bitwidth in both DL and UL 9
• Beamforming: no beamforming (beamId = 0x0000), assumed to mean boresight radiation (normal to the 10
antenna surface) at some undetermined beamwidth (recall that beam weight magnitudes must be equal to 11
unity) 12
• Transport: L2 Ethernet, eCPRI with no fragmentation and no QOS 13
• Delay Parameters: The test will be executed with a direct fiber connection to the O-RU and the network delay 14
is considered negligible for the purpose of delay management.  Therefore, T12_min = T12_max = 0 and 15
T34_min = T34_max = 0. 16
The radio will report its supported values for: 17
o T2a_min/max_up 18
o Ta3_min/max_up 19
o T2a_min/max_cp_ul 20
o Tcp_adv_dl 21
These parameters will be used to calculate the delay windows needed for the delay management tests below.  22
Note that T1a_min_up = T2a_min_up and T1a_max_up = T2a_max_up due to the fixed, zero network delay.  23
Similarly, Ta4_min_up = Ta3_min_up and Ta4_max_up = Ta3_max_up.  Similarly, T1a_min_cp_ul = 24
T2a_min_cp_ul and T1a_max_cp_ul = T2a_max_cp_ul.   25
• Uplink tests will start with the basic 3GPP test signal for Fixed Reference Channels for receiver sensitivity and 26
in-channel selectivity as described in 3GPP TS 38.141-2[NR] and TS 36.141 [LTE]. All O-RAN specific 27
parameters will be the same as described above for downlink testing. As with downlink testing subsequent 28
tests will build on this basic waveform modifying parameters as needed to exercise O -RAN specific features. 29
• Uplink tests will be radiated using power levels at least 30dB higher than the reference sensitivity power levels 30
used to test 3GPP Receiver sensitivity described in 3GPP TS 38.141 -2 Table 7.3.5.2-1, Table 7.3.5.2-2 and 31
Table 7.3.5.2-3[NR FR1], Table 7.3.5.3-1 [NR FR2]  and TS 36.141 Table 7.2-1 to Table 7.2-12 [LTE]. This 32
is to ensure a clear signal is received by the O-RU so it can be accurately decoded and demodulated to ensure 33
the correct data was received by the O-DU as was sent by the signal source.  Again, the purpose of these tests 34
is to ensure correct operation of the O-RAN fronthaul not to test receiver sensitivity. 35
 36
 For scenario #3 (Conducted TDD Tests for FR1 Radios) 37

waveform as described in 3GPP TS 38.141-1. It will be NR-FR1-TM1.1 (TDD) and G-FR1-A1-5 (SCS30k_51RB) in 39
the uplink.  The TDD test model is derived based on the uplink/downlink configurations described in 3GPP TS 38.141-40

This waveform is shown below: 1
 2
Figure 3.2.1.1-1 NR-FR1-TM1.1 TDD Test Signal 3
 4
As an alternative to the default test waveform shown in Figure 3.2.1.1-1, it is optional to flexibly use other test 5
waveforms with any TDD configurations allowed by the information element TDD-UL-DL-ConfigCommon as defined 6
in TS 38.331 for 30 kHz SCS. The tester should use the 3GPP prescribed waveform as the recommended waveform but 7
has the option to use any TDD configuration in the IOT profiles defined in [25] with the above constraints. 8
This test frame consists of a PDCCH in the first two symbols of every downlink slot consisting of 3 PRBs.  All the 9
remaining PRBs in the frame consist of Physical Downlink Shared Channel data. This configuration corresponds to 10
stock data section A (Section 3.2.1.1.5 above) in all symbols that do not contain PDCCH channels. Individual tests may 11
call out other stock data sections as needed. If the radio does not support the numerology described in section 3.2.3.1 12
the stock test frames can be adapted for smaller numbers of PRBs and should still be used. Symbols number two and 13
eleven contain DMRS signals which are not used to test O-RAN Front Haul capabilities but should be sent to help test 14
equipment synchronize.  In the standard test frame, all PDSCH data is set to zeros if not otherwise described in the 15
testcase and PUSCH is set to PN23 sequences.  For all tests in this document (except the most basic resource allocation 16
test) the PN23 sequence will be used in both uplink and downlink to allow the test to determine whether test data was 17
put in the correct PRBs and whether the test data was accurately transmitted (or received) by the O-RU under test. 18
• For tests for type 1-C and 1-H the test configuration described in TS 38.141-1 for TDD testing will be used.  Only a 19
single antenna port will be used unless the test explicitly requires more than one port and the radio supports more 20
than one port.  RF test equipment will be connected at the point described in TS 38.141 -1. Note that an antenna 21
port is an electrical conducting port that is connected to an array element.  22
• The test will start with the Test model described above.  Subsequent tests will adapt this model to test additional 23
features of the O-RAN interface (e.g., Modifying the payload data, blanking some symbols, etc.).  Note this test 24
model describes the IQ data contained in the O-RAN packets not the O-RAN specific parameters.  This test model 25
will also be augmented with the following O-RAN specific parameters: 26
Includes “stock” eAxC values as configured via M-Plane: 27
• DU_Port_ID: two bits, nominal value 00b 28
• BandSector: nominal 6 bits, nominal value 000000b 29

• CC_ID: nominal 4 bits, nominal value 0000b (most tests invoke only one component carrier)  1
• RU_port_ID: 4 bits, nominal values 0000b through 0011b or to whatever max value needed for a specific test  2
• If the radio manufacturer declares support for multi-carrier a different eAxC will be assigned for each carrier. Note 3
that most tests described in 3GPP TS 38.141-1[NR] and TS 36.141 [LTE] require testing at the bottom, middle and 4
top of the supported bands of the radio.  This specification relaxes that requirement because the purpose is to test 5
the fronthaul compliance and not the radio performance. 6
• Compression: Static 16-bit fixed point IQ bitwidth in both DL and UL 7
• Beamforming: no beamforming (beamId = 0x0000), assumed to mean boresight radiation (normal to the antenna 8
surface) at some undetermined beamwidth (recall that beam weight magnitudes must be equal to unity)  9
• Transport: L2 Ethernet, eCPRI with no fragmentation and no QOS 10
• Delay Parameters: The test will be executed with a direct fiber connection to the O-RU and the network delay is 11
considered negligible for the purpose of delay management.  Therefore, T12_min = T12_max = 0 and T34_min = 12
T34_max = 0. 13
The radio will report its supported values for: 14
o T2a_min/max_up 15
o Ta3_min/max_up 16
o T2a_min/max_cp_ul 17
o Tcp_adv_dl 18
These parameters will be used to calculate the delay windows needed for the delay management tests below.  Note 19
that T1a_min_up = T2a_min_up and T1a_max_up = T2a_max_up due to the fixed, zero network delay.  Similarly, 20
Ta4_min_up = Ta3_min_up and Ta4_max_up = Ta3_max_up.  Similarly, T1a_min_cp_ul = T2a_min_cp_ul and 21
T1a_max_cp_ul = T2a_max_cp_ul.   22
• Uplink tests will start with the basic 3GPP test signal for Fixed Reference Channels for receiver sensitivity and in-23
channel selectivity as described in 3GPP TS 38.141-1[NR] and TS 36.141 [LTE] and described above.  All O-RAN 24
specific parameters will be the same as described above for downlink testing.  As with downlink testing subsequent 25
tests will build on this basic waveform modifying parameters as needed to exercise O-RAN specific features. 26
• Uplink tests will be conducted using power levels at least 30dB higher than the power levels used to test 3GPP 27
Receiver sensitivity described in 3GPP TS 38.141-1 Table 7.2.5-1[NR] and TS 36.141 [LTE]. This is to ensure a 28
clear signal is received by the O-RU so it can be accurately decoded and demodulated to ensure the correct data 29
was received by the O-DU as was sent by the signal source.  Again, the purpose of these tests is to ensure correct 30
operation of the O-RAN fronthaul not to test receiver sensitivity. 31

 For Scenario #4 (Non-conducted OTA TDD Tests for FR1 and FR2 Radios) 33
All provisions of section 3.2.1.1.2 with respect to OTA methodology will apply to this scenario, exc ept applied to TDD 34
FR1 (1-H, 1-O) and FR2 (2-O) radios.  The default test waveform for FR1 will be a TDD waveform as described in 35
Sec. 3.2.1.1.3.  The default test waveform for FR2 will be a 100 MHz bandwidth TDD waveform based on NR -FR2-36
TM1.1 for the downlink, and G-FR2-A1-3 for 120 kHz subcarrier spacing with 66 RBs in the uplink.  The TDD test 37
model is derived based on the uplink/downlink configurations described in 3GPP TS 38.141 -2 Table 4.9.2.2-1 using 38
information element TDD-UL-DL-ConfigCommon as defined in TS 38.331 as shown below: 39

As an alternative to the default test waveform shown in Figure 3.2.1.1-2, it is optional to flexibly use other test 2
waveforms with any TDD configurations allowed by the information element TDD-UL-DL-ConfigCommon as defined 3
in TS 38.331. The tester should use the 3GPP prescribed waveform as the recommended waveform but has the option to 4
use any TDD configuration in the IOT profiles defined in [25] with the above constraints. 5
This test frame consists of a PDCCH in the first two symbols of every downlink slot consisting of 3 PRBs.  All the 6
remaining PRBs in the frame consist of Physical Downlink Shared Channel data. This configuration corresponds to 7
stock data section A (Section 3.2.1.1.5 above) in all symbols that do not contain PDCCH channels. Individual tests may 8
call out other stock data sections as needed. If the radio does not support the numerology described the stock test frames 9
can be adapted for smaller numbers of PRBs and should still be used. Symbols number two and eleven contain DMRS 10
signals which are not used to test O-RAN Front Haul capabilities but should be sent to help test equipment synchronize.  11
In the standard test frame, all PDSCH data is set to zeros if not otherwise mentioned in the testcase  and PUSCH is set 12
to PN23 sequences.  For all tests in this document (except the most basic resource allocation test) the PN23 sequence 13
will be used in both uplink and downlink to allow the test to determine whether test data was  put in the correct PRBs 14
and whether the test data was accurately transmitted (or received) by the O -RU under test. 15
• For downlink tests for type 1-H radios that elect to be tested over the air (OTA) rather than conducted, the test 16
configuration is described in TS 38.141-2 E.1.2 where the Test Antenna will be placed inside an OTA chamber 17
and measurements are referenced to the radiated characteristics defined over the air (OTA) at the Radiated 18
Interface Boundary (RIB) defined in TS 38.141-2 4.2-1. The RF analyzer test equipment is connected to the 19
Test Antenna and is located outside of the OTA chamber.  20
• For downlink test for 1-O or 2-O radios (radios with no physical antenna or TAB connectors and consequently 21
only over the air – OTA – measurements are possible) the test configuration is described in TS 38.141-2 E.1.2 22
where the Test Antenna will be placed inside an OTA chamber and measurements are referenced to the 23
radiated characteristics defined over the air (OTA) at the Radiated Interface Boundary (RIB ) defined in TS 24
38.141-2 4.2-2. The RF analyzer test equipment is connected to the Test Antenna and is located outside of the 25
OTA chamber. 26
• For uplink tests for type 1-H radios that elect to be tested over the air (OTA) rather than conducted, the test 27
configuration is described in TS 38.141-2 E.2.1 where the Test Antenna will be placed inside an OTA chamber 28
and measurements are referenced to the radiated characteristics defined over the air (OTA) at the Radiated 29
Interface Boundary (RIB) defined in TS 38.141-2 4.2-1. The RF generator test equipment is connected to the 30
Test Antenna and is located outside of the OTA chamber. 31
• For uplink test for 1-O or 2-O radios (radios with no physical antenna or TAB connectors and consequently 32
only over the air (OTA) measurements are possible) the test configuration is described in TS 38.141 -2 E.2.1 33
where the Test Antenna will be placed inside an OTA chamber and measurements are referenced to the 34
radiated characteristics defined over the air (OTA) at the Radiated Interface Boundary (RIB) defined in TS 35
38.141-2 4.2-2. The RF generator test equipment is connected to the Test Antenna and is located outside of the 36
OTA chamber.  37
• For downlink tests for LTE radios that elect to be tested over the air (OTA), the test configuration is described 38
in TS 38.141-2 E.1.2 where the Test Antenna will be placed inside an OTA chamber and measurements are 39
referenced to the radiated characteristics defined over the air (OTA) at the Radiated Interface Boun dary (RIB) 40
defined in TS 38.141-2 4.2-1. The RF analyzer test equipment is connected to the Test Antenna and is located 41
out of the OTA chamber. 42
• For uplink tests for LTE radios that elect to be tested over the air (OTA), the test configuration is de scribed in 43
TS 38.141-2 E.2.1 where the Test Antenna will be placed inside an OTA chamber and measurements are 44
referenced to the radiated characteristics defined over the air (OTA) at the Radiated Interface Boundary (RIB) 45
defined in TS 38.141-2 4.2-1. The RF generator test equipment is connected to the Test Antenna and is located 46
out of the OTA chamber. 47

• Note that the chamber shown in TS 38.141-2 E1.2. and E.2.1. are generic and consequently any OTA chamber 1
could be used, i.e. far field, CATR, near field, reverberation, etc. 2

E.2.1. may or may not be needed. 4

than one RF analyzer and/or generator may also be needed. 6

38.141-1 and 36.141 for NR FR1 and LTE radios respectively, and NR-FR2-TM1.1 in TS 38.141-2 for FR2 8

 Test Configuration for the UC-Plane 1
The TER shown in Figure 2.1-1 provides M-Plane and S-Plane commands and sequences to correctly set up the O-RU 2
for testing using the fronthaul connection – meaning a criterion and prerequisite for executing all UC-Plane tests is 3
proper operation of the O-RU’s synchronization and M-Plane capabilities.  The TER provides the specific C-Plane and 4
U-Plane data flows and collects data from the radiated energy from the O-RU and evaluates based on the collected RF 5
energy whether the O-RU correctly received and interpreted the fronthaul DL data flow.  For many tests a single RF 6
detector is satisfactory to detect the radiated signal but for beamforming tests an RF pattern must be  measured to 7
validate the correct beam is being generated according to the C-Plane commands and U-Plane data flowing across the 8
fronthaul interface. 9
In addition, the TER generates RF energy using the signal generator and feeds it to the O -RU’s antennas (or antenna 10
connectors) which is expected to be used by the O-RU, in conjunction with the C-Plane UL commands sent by the TER 11
over the fronthaul connection, to generate UL data flows on the fronthaul connection which are received and evaluated 12
by the TER.  For almost all tests a single RF emitter is satisfactory to generate the radiated signal, even beamforming 13
tests wherein the received power level will validate that the beam main lobe was correctly specified across the fronthaul 14
interface, except for the case of uplink channel-information-based beamforming tests where multiple RF emitters are 15
needed to emulate multiple uplink spatial streams. 16
3GPP-specified tests will be used here to simplify the testing, because such tests will need to be supported by the O -RU 17
anyway for 3GPP conformance testing.  The specific test cases identify where this is possible and where changes must 18
be made to adequately test O-RAN features. 19
Note that when testing the O-RU for fronthaul interface conformance, much more than the front haul interface is being 20
tested, indeed the entire O-RU is under test, including digital and analog processing having nothing to do with the 21
fronthaul interface.  Therefore a “passed” test can be interpreted with some confidence as indicating a properly 22
operating fronthaul interface, but a “failed” test may indicate a problem with the fronthaul interface or with some other 23
operation within the O-RU therefore failed tests may require some troubleshooting.  While 3GPP TS 38.141-1, TS 24
38.141-2 [NR] and TS 36.141 [LTE] describes the basic waveform used in these tests it does not describe how the 25
various channels should be put into O-RAN sections.  The 3GPP TS 38.141-1 NR-FR1-TM1.1 [NR FR1], TS 38.141-2 26
NR-FR2-TM1.1 [NR FR2], and TSTS 36.141 E-TM1.1 [LTE] signals are tightly packed with data.  All tests will divide 27
that data into “stock” data sections using the sections described below.   To expedite the definition and creation of the 28
tests, a set of standard test environments and patterns is defined in this section.  This includes a “stock” arrangement of 29
data sections in DL (same is used for UL) which can be used regardless of the specific bandwidth and SCS used in the 30
test.  Specifically, there are “stock” 1-symbol, 2-symbol, and 3-symbol data section sets that shall be cited in test 31
definitions (numbered “A” through “F”) that will support various test cases.  The test cases are expected to specify the 32
data section definition of a test slot and all slots are expected to follow the same dat a section definition unless a test 33
specifically states otherwise.  In many cases only some symbols within a slot will be subject to testing; the remaining  34
symbols are expected to remain undefined for the test and may have data sections defined according to  the normal 35
operation of the O-DU (e.g. set to carry synch or reference signals consistent with LTE or NR).  In cases where a 36
specific type of data section cannot be supported by the DUT, then that data section is omitted in the symbol(s) and the 37
corresponding U-Plane data shall be set to zero in DL (and arranged to have no RF power in UL).  Figure 3.2.1.1-2 38
shows the “stock” data section definition. 39

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       67
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
“stock” data section definitions A-F:
A: 1 symbol 1 section only : simplest case
B: 1 symbol 2 sections : slightly more complex
C: 1 symbol 2 sections w/ gap : tests ability to handle data gaps
D: 1 symbol many sections : tests single-PRB section, rb bit, use of non-all-ones reMask, many data sections
E: 2 symbol 2 sections : tests multi-symbol section, symIncbit
F: 3 symbols many sections : tests data gaps, reMask, multi-symbol sections
Arrows mark end-of-symbol for
various SCS and bandwidths
