 1
Figure 3.2.3.1-14  NR-FR1-TM1.1 FDD Test Signal 2
 3
This test frame consists of a PDCCH in the first two symbols of every slot consisting of 3 PRBs.  All the remaining 4
PRBs in the frame consist of Physical Downlink Shared Channel data. This test requires non -zero data (PN23 5
Sequence)  to populate all allocated resource blocks.  This configuration corresponds to stock data section A in all 6
symbols that do not contain PDCCH channels. 7
 8
B. Test Entrance Criteria 9
The test numerology will be 30 KHz subcarrier spacing and 100 MHz Bandwidth as described in section NR-FR1-10
TM1.1.  It will be for 5G New Radio only. The radio must have conducted antenna ports (FR1) or TAB connectors.  11
 12
 13
C. Test Methodology 14
 15
a. Initial Conditions 16
Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation using 17
M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  Connect the signal analyzer to the O-RU 18
antenna port and configure the analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and 19
demodulate the transmitted signal.  This test is only applicable if the radio reports it supports coupling C and U 20
plane via time and frequency. 21
b. Procedure 22
Build an appropriate IQ signal describing the NR-FR1-TM1.1 signal described above in the O-DU emulator.  23
Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the signal. 24
Every symbol should be described by a single section (DL-SCH and DCI) using section type 1 messages. The 25
data in the sections must be a PN23 sequence using an initial seed of all ones. No section type zero messages 26
will be used for this test.  Encapsulate the IQ data in U-Plane messages. Play those messages to the O-RU 27
respecting timing windows described in section 3.2.1.1.1.  Repeat the entire frame the number of times 28
required to synch the signal analyzer and allow it to demodulate and decode the test frame. 29
 30
In this test the C-Plane messages will contain valid values in the following fields: 31
• EAxC ID 32
• Datadirection bit (Downlink) 33
• Frame ID, subframeID, slotID, startsymbolID, and NumSymbol 34
• SectionID must have a value 4095 35
• SymInc, rb reMask and section extension #6 are not used in this test 36
The U-Plane messages generated by the TER must match those values used in the C -Plane corresponding o 37
the section described in the C-plane but the value of sectionID will be 4095. 38
 39
 40
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  41
1. The signal measured by the signal analyzer should satisfy a basic 3GPP signal performance requirement for this 42
radio category (i.e., EVM). 43
2. The test frame received by the signal analyzer should be the same as the signal described above.  If it contains 44
all the same PRB assignments and data, the test passes. 45
 46
 47
 UC-Plane O-RU Base Class FDD Test UL – Coupling C and U plane via time and 48
frequency 49
A. Test Description and Applicability 50

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       97
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 1
 2
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can meet the most basic uplink requirements for O-RAN fronthaul 3
correctly interpreting C-Plane messages and correctly constructing uplink U-Plane messages from an RF signal 4
when the radio reports it supports C and U plane coupling via time and freque ncy. 5
 6
The test validates that correct uplink operation of the O-RU using 3GPP Reference Sensitivity level definition 7
(Section 7.2 TS 38.141-1) of the Conducted Receiver Characteristic Test section (Section 7 TS 38.141) and power 8
Levels at least 30 dB above Reference Sensitivity power Level described in TS 38.141-1 Table 7.2.5-1.  This is to 9
improve the likelihood that all data will be received by the radio correctly since we are not interested in testing 10
receiver sensitivity but only the O-RAN protocol compliance.  11
 12
 13
 14
Figure 3.2.3.1-15  G-FR1-A5-1 Uplink FDD Test Signal 15
 16
This signal is described by table A.1-1 in 3GPP 38.141-1 and is referred to as G-FR1-A1-5 with the power increased 17
to up to 30 dB above that described in Table 7.2.5-1.  Under those conditions, a 3GPP compliant O-RU should 18
deliver uplink U-Plane information that matches the uplink signal.  19
 20
The TER (Test Equipment, O-RU) generates an uplink signal on the antenna connector or TAB connector, together 21
with the corresponding C-Plane messages on the Fronthaul interface. 22
 23
The TER will capture the U-Plane messages generated by the DUT and validate whether the payload matches the 24
uplink signal.  25
 26
It applies to the following CUS fronthaul specification sections 27
• Section 5.4.2 for layout of C-Plane message, in particular Section Type 1 28
• Section 6.3.2 for U-Plane message layout 29
• Section 6.3.3 for coding of applicable Information Elements 30
 31
B. Test Entrance Criteria 32
The O-RU must support the default parameters in section 3.2.1.1.1 of this document.  The O-RU must indicate it 33
supports coupling C and U plane via time and frequency. The test numerology will be 30 kHz subcarrier spacing 34
and 100 MHz Bandwidth as described in section 3GPP TS 38.141-1 section G-FR1-A-5.  It will be for 5G New 35
Radio only. The radio must have conducted antenna ports (FR1) or TAB connectors. Note this signal may be 36
changed to any of the 3GPP sensitivity test signals in table A.1-1 in 3GPP TS 38.141-1 if the radio does not 37

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       98
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
support the numerology and bandwidth used in this test.  The test signal described in this section will be used if the 1
radio supports that numerology and bandwidth. 2
C. Test Methodology 3
Leverage from the well-known payload (PN23 sequence) of the uplink signal to compare it with the payload of the 4
signal communicated on the O-RAN interface. The IQ information is extracted from the U-Plane message and 5
demodulated to retrieve payload.  6
  7
a: Initial Conditions 8
Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation using M-9
Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  Connect the signal source to the O-RU antenna 10
port and configure the source to transmit the required 3GPP test signal upon receiving a trigger signal from the 11
CUSM-E.  The signal source power level should be adjusted to at least 30 dB above the setting used in the 3GPP 12
receiver sensitivity test. 13
b: Procedure 14
• Load uplink test waveform (G-FR1-A1-5 : SCS30k_51RB) on the RF Signal Source  15
• Configure Signal Source to play test waveforms on 10ms frame boundaries starting when it receives a 16
trigger signal from the O-DU emulator that C-Plane messages have been sent. 17
• Load C-Plane message sequence on Test Equipment O-RU (TER) C-Plane messages will contain valid 18
values in the following fields: 19
• EAxC ID 20
• Datadirection bit (Uplink) 21
• Frame ID, subframeID, slotID, startsymbolID, and NumSymbol 22
• SectionID must have a value 4095 23
• SymInc, rb reMask and section extension #6 are not used in this test 24
• Arm Test Equipment O-RU (TER) to capture DUT fronthaul Messages  25
• Launch test to play the RF uplink frame after the C-Plane messages have been sent honoring timing 26
windows  27
• Record U-Plane messages from DUT for a complete frame and the eAxC corresponding to the Antenna port  28
• TER will arrange U-Plane messages according to time and frequency 29
• Extract IQ information  30
• Extract Payload 31
• Compare payload binary sequences  32
  33
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  34
1. The verdict is “Test pass” if the payload binary sequences match between the uplink test frame sent to the 35
DUT and the received U-Plane data from the DUT 36
2. If any of the test conditions are not true, the verdict for the whole test is "Fail" 37
 38
 39
 UC- Plane O-RU Scenario Class Extended 3GPP DL – Resource allocation – Section 40
Description Priorities  41
A. Test Description and Applicability 42
This test is CONDITIONAL  MANDATORY. 43
 44
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can accurately interpret C-Plane resource allocation messages, 45
transfer U-Plane data into the correct resource blocks and transmit this data accurately in the downlink  when the 46
radio reports it supports the option feature of coupling C and U plane messages via  frequency and time and Section 47
Description Priorities.  This test is applicable for Category A and Category B radios (No precoding is required).  48
The test will be conducted therefore there will be no channel distortion or interference.  It is mandatory th e radio 49
pass this test if it reports it supports coupling C and U plane via time and frequency . 50
 51
Using a standard 3GPP NR-FR1-TM1.1 test frame for FDD the O-DU emulator (i.e., O-RAN interface of the TER 52
described in section 2.1) will generate C-Plane and U-Plane messages that require the O-RU to transmit on the 53
downlink the standard NR-FR1-TM1.1 signal with exceptions noted in the test procedure.  This signal is shown 54
below inFigure 3.2.3.1-16 . 55
 56
 57

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.

                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
 1
 2
 3
 4
Figure 3.2.3.1-16  NR-FR1-TM1.1 FDD Test Signal 5
 6
This test frame consists of a PDCCH in the first two symbols of every slot consisting of 3 PRBs.  All the remaining 7
PRBs in the frame consist of Physical Downlink Shared Channel data. This test requires non -zero data (PN23 8
Sequence)  to populate all allocated resource blocks.  This configuration corresponds to stock data section A in all 9
symbols that do not contain PDCCH channels. 10
 11
B. Test Entrance Criteria 12
The test numerology will be 30 KHz subcarrier spacing and 100 MHz Bandwidth as described in section NR-FR1-13
TM1.1.  It will be for 5G New Radio only. The radio must have conducted antenna ports (FR1) or TAB connectors.  14
 15
 16
C. Test Methodology 17
 18
a. Initial Conditions 19
Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation using 20
M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  Connect the signal analyzer to the O-RU 21
antenna port and configure the analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and 22
demodulate the transmitted signal.  This test is only applicable if the radio reports it supports coupling C and U 23
plane via time and frequency and Section Description Priority. 24
b. Procedure 25
Build an appropriate IQ signal describing the NR-FR1-TM1.1 signal described above and below in the O-DU 26
emulator.  Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe 27
the signal. Every symbol should be described by a single section (DL -SCH and DCI) using section type 1 28
messages. The data in the sections must be a PN23 sequence using an initial seed of all ones. No section type 29
zero messages will be used for this test.  Encapsulate the IQ data in U-Plane messages. Play those messages to 30
the O-RU respecting timing windows described in section 3.2.1.1.1.  Repeat the entire frame the number of 31
times required to synch the signal analyzer and allow it to demodulate and decode the test frame. 32

Table 3.2.3.1-3 Section Description Priorities 1
In this test the section configuration will be as shown in Table 3.2.3.1-3 above.  The 6 sections will comprise 2
one slot and this slot will be repeated continuously to synchronize the TER signal analyzer.  The six sections 3
will be sent on one C-Plane message using C and U plane coupling via time and frequency.  The 4
configuration above follows the example given in the CUSM specification. 5
The section numbers in the above table do not represent SectionID numbers but individual sections. Sections 6
#1 and #2 describe hypothetical DMRS signals sent in symbols #2 and #11 in each slot.  These signals have 7
every other subcarrier masked by reMask. This is the same as shown above in the standard NR-FR1-TM1.1 8
test signal shown above. The DMRS signals in symbol #2 have beam ID 1 and symbol #11 have beam ID 2.  9
These sections use section extension 6 and contain a higher priority than all other sections.  10
Section #3 describes PN23 data sent to hypothetical UE #1 it overlaps REs in sections #1 and #2 but has a 11
lower priority so sections #1 and #2 are valid.  Since section #3 has contiguous symbols section extension 6 12
is not needed. 13
Section #4 is for hypothetical UE #2. It occupies the same symbols as the DMRS signals but uses a different 14
reMask.  Since the symbols are not contiguous it uses sections extension 6 but the priority is set to the default 15
0. 16
Section #5 is for hypothetical UE #3 and uses a contiguous set of symbols so section extension 6 is not 17
needed.  It does not overlap any other signals.  This section is optional because it does not test Section 18
Description Priority. 19
Section #6 is a hypothetical special channel using only one symbol and does not  require section extension 6.  20
This section is also optional. 21
U-Plane messages will contain: 22
• DMRS signals for every odd resource element as described by section #1 for symbol #11  23
• DMRS signals for every odd resource element as described by section #2 for sy mbol #2 24

                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
• A new PN23 sequence in each of the first 5 symbols as described in section #3.  Note that for 1
symbol #2 the PN sequence will be pierced by the DMRS signals. 2
• A new PN23 sequence for symbol #6 as described by section #4 as well as a new PN sequence f or 3
symbol #11.  These sequences are only 32 PRBs long and start in PRB 15. The sequence in symbol 4
#11 will be pierced by DMRS signals. 5
• The user data for sections number #5 and #6 are standard PN23 sequences only for these symbols 6
and PRBs described in the table above. 7

D. Test Requirement (expected result)  10
1. The signal measured by the signal analyzer should satisfy a basic 3GPP signal performance requirement for 11
this radio category (i.e., EVM). 12
2. The test frame received by the signal analyzer should be the same PRB assignment and data as the signal 13
described above.   14
3. The beamweights or magnitude and phase relation at the antenna ports (or TAB connectors) of the test signal 15
that achieves the highest performance (i.e. best EVM, power, SNR, etc.) should match with the manufacturer’s 16
declaration of the beam under test that has been assigned to each section described above.  The procedure for 17
this beamforming test is the same as test 3.2.3.2.3 (UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – 18
Predefined-beam Beamforming). 19

A. Test Description and Applicability 23
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 24
 25
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can meet the uplink requirements for O-RAN fronthaul correctly 26
interpreting C-Plane messages and correctly constructing uplink U-Plane messages from an RF signal when the 27
radio reports it supports Section Description Priorities as well as Coupling C and U plane via tim e and frequency.. 28
 29
The test validates that correct uplink operation of the O-RU using 3GPP Reference Sensitivity level definition 30
(Section 7.2 TS 38.141-1) of the Conducted Receiver Characteristic Test section (Section 7 TS 38.141) and power 31
Levels at least 30 dB above Reference Sensitivity power Level described in TS 38.141-1 Table 7.2.5-1.  This is to 32
improve the likelihood that all data will be received by the radio correctly since we are not interested in testing 33
receiver sensitivity but only the O-RAN protocol compliance.  34

described in this section will be used if the radio supports that numerology and bandwidth.  28

 10
In this test the section configuration will be as shown in Table 3.2.3.1-4 above.  The 6 sections will comprise 11
one slot and this slot will be repeated to fill the entire frame (i.e., 20 times).  The six sections will be sent on 12
one C-Plane message using C and U plane coupling via time and frequency.  The configuration above 13
follows the example given in the CUSM specification. 14
o The section numbers in the above table do not represent SectionID numbers but individual sections. 15
Sections #1 and #2 describe hypothetical DMRS signals sent in symbols #2 and #11 in each slot.  16
These signals have every other subcarrier masked by reMask. This is the same as shown above in 17
the standard G-FR1-A1-5 test signal shown above with the exception that the DMRS signals 18
continue for all 273 RBs. The DMRS signals in symbol #2 have beam ID 1 and symbol #11 have 19
beam ID 2.  These sections use section extension 6 and contain a higher priority than all other 20
sections.  21
o Section #3 describes PN23 data sent to hypothetical UE #1 it overlaps REs in sections #1 and #2 22
but has a lower priority so sections #1 and #2 are valid.  Since section #3 has contiguous symbols 23
section extension 6 is not needed.  Note it starts in PRM 64 (RBG 4) and continues for the 24
remainder of the 273 RBs. 25
o Section #4 is for hypothetical UE #2. It occupies the same symbols as the DMRS signal s but uses a 26
different reMask.  Since the symbols are not contiguous it uses sections extension 6 but the priority 27
is set to the default 0.  It also starts in RBG 4 (RB 64) and continues to the rest of the 273 RBs.  28

1. The verdict is “Test pass” if the payload binary sequences match between the uplink test frame sent to the 35

power, SNR, etc.) should match with the manufacturer’s declaration of the beam under test.   The procedures 38
for test case 3.2.3.2.4 (UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP UL – Predefined-beam 39
Beamforming) should be used. 40

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       105
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming (BFM)  1
This section describes the beamforming conformance testing for ORAN fronthaul interface. The tests do not aim to test 2
the O-RU beamforming performance or capabilities but to test that the O-RU under test focuses the RF energy or 3
sensitivity into a specific direction and with a specific granularity following the O-DU emulator (i.e., O-RAN interface 4
of the TER described in section 2.1) C-Plane messages.  5
Unless stated otherwise in a test case, the following statements apply to all the test cases defined in this section:  6
• It is based on conducted testing with a setup such as described in Section 2.1 and it only applies to O-RU DUTs 7
that have conducted antenna ports or TAB connectors. 8
 9
• It applies to  Category A and  Category B O-RU DUTs. 10
 11
• It applies to LTE and/or 5G New Radio O-RU DUTs.  In both cases, precoding is not required in any test case.   12
 13
• If O-RU DUT supports Analog Beamforming (i.e. time domain beamforming), all the U-Plane test frames are 14
defined by segmenting the Stock Test A: 1 section per symbol.  The definition of this Stock Test A can be 15
found in Figure 3.2.1.1-2 and the description accompanying this Figure.  Each slot shall include multiple 16
sections (one per symbol within the slot) and only one beam at a time (i.e. one beamId at a time) and therefore 17
only one beam can be tested per slot. 18
 19
• If O-RU DUT supports Digital Beamforming (i.e. frequency domain beamforming), all the U-Plane test frames 20
are defined by segmenting the Stock Test B: 2 sections per symbol definition as shown in Figure 3.2.1.1-2.  21
Each slot shall include multiple sections (two per symbol within the slot) and only one beam per section at a 22
time (i.e. one beamId at a time) and therefore up to two different beams can be tested per slot. 23
 24
• If O-RU DUT supports multiple polarizations, it is up to the TER to determine if the testing is carried out for 25
each polarization separately or multiple polarizations at the same time. In any case, it is important to guarantee 26
that the correct eAxC_ID for the correct polarization (or polarizations) is exercised.  27
 28
• For O-RU DUT that support LTE:  29
o Downlink tests will use a standard 3GPP E-TM1.1 test frame for FDD (Section 6.1.1.1 TS 36.141-1) with 30
20MHz bandwidth (100 RB) as shown in Figure 3.2.3.2-1. 31
 32
Figure 3.2.3.2-1 E-TM1.1 FDD 20 MHz 100RB 33
If 20MHz is not supported by the O-RU DUT, then it will use the highest bandwidth supported by the O-34
RU DUT. 35
o Uplink test will use a standard 3GPP UL RMC Configuration definition for FDD (TS36.521 -1) and 36
power levels 30dB above Reference Sensitivity power level with 10MHz bandwidth (100 RB) as shown 37
in Figure 3.2.3.2-2. 38
 39
Figure 3.2.3.2-2 UL RMC FDD 20 MHz 100 RB 40
If 20MHz is not supported by the O-RU DUT, then it will use the highest bandwidth supported by the O-41
RU DUT. 42

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       106
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
 1
• For O-RU DUT that support 5G NR:  2
o Downlink tests will use a standard 3GPP NR-FR1-TM1.1 test frame for FDD in [19] (Section 4.9.2 3
TS138.141-1) of the Conducted Transmitter Characteristic Test section (Section 6 TS138.141-1) as 4
described in section 3.2.1.1. The test numerology will be preferably 30KHz subcarrier spacing and 100 5
MHz Bandwidth. If not supported, then it will use any other supported subcarrier spacing and the 6
highest bandwidth of the O-RU DUT. 7
  8
o Uplink tests will use a standard 3GPP Reference Sensitivity level definition (Section 7.2 and Annex A 9
TS138.141-1) of the Conducted Receiver Characteristic Test section (Section 7 TS 38.141) and power 10
levels 30dB above Reference Sensitivity power level as described in  section 3.2.1.1.  The test 11
numerology will be preferably 30kHz subcarrier spacing and 100 MHz Bandwidth, if supported. 12
Otherwise, it will use any available subcarrier space and the highest bandwidth supported by the O -RU 13
DUT. 14
  15
• The O-RU DUT must: 16
o support the default parameters in section 3.2.1.1.1 of this document. 17
o have installed current release of shipping software.  18
o have at least two conducted antenna ports (or TAB connectors) to be connected to a signal analyzer. 19
Likewise, it must have at least two conducted antenna ports or TAB connectors to be connected to a signal 20
generator. 21
o be fully calibrated up to the antenna ports or (TAB connectors) (if needed). It is expected to be calibrated 22
by O-RU vendor prior to testing.  23
 24
 25
• The TER must: 26
o be capable of carrying out any signal processing required to generate and demodulate 3GPP compliant 27
waveforms. 28
o be able to calculate or extract beamweights (or magnitude and phase relations) between antenna ports or 29
TAB connectors. Alternatively, and if the O-RU DUT manufacturer provides the list of beam directions 30
supported by the O-RU DUT, TER might calculate or extract the beam direction instead of the 31
beamweights. 32
o be able to generate and deliver signals with the required beamweights (or magnitude a nd phase relations) at 33
the antenna ports or TAB connectors.  34
o be fully calibrated up to the interfaces where is connected to the O-RU DUT antenna ports (or TAB 35
connectors). For that, a known test signal might be either injected by the TER into the O -RU DUT, or 36
internally generated by the O-RU DUT, and the O-RU DUT must not apply any digital or analog 37
beamweights to the known test signal.  One possible method to perform calibration uses injected C-Plane 38
and U-Plane signals from TER into the O-RU and using C-Plane messages with beamID=0.   39
 40
 41
• The O-DU emulator of the TER must: 42
o be capable of generating and sending U-Plane messages containing 3GPP test frames following the 43
corresponding Stock sectioning defined above, as well as be capable of capturing U-Plane messages and 44
extracting 3GPP test frames (i.e. IQ data) from the captured U-Plane messages. 45
o be capable of generating the C-Plane messages for, receiving, extracting and demodulating the 3GPP test 46
frames following the corresponding Stock sectioning defined above. 47
 48
• The TER might have less testing ports than the O-RU DUT conducted antenna ports (or TAB connectors) if 49
testing is carried out sequentially; or as many antenna ports as the number of conducted antenna ports (or TAB 50
connectors) under test if testing is carried out simultaneously. 51
 52
• It is up to the TER on how to extract the beamweights (or magnitude and phase relation) between the 53
antenna ports or TAB connectors, or the beam direction / properties, in order to match it with the 54
manufacturer’s declaration. 55
 56
• The user payload will be generated as PN23 with a seed of all ones. 57
 58
• It applies to the following CUS fronthaul specification sections: 59
• Section 5.4.2 for layout of C-Plane message, in particular Section Type 1 60

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       107
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
• Section 6.3.2 for U-Plane message layout 1
• Section 6.3.3 for coding of applicable Information Elements 2
• Section 10 for beamforming guidelines. 3
• Annex J for beamforming methods description.  4
 5
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – No Beamforming 6
A. Test Description and Applicability 7
This test is MANDATORY. 8
 9
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can transmit a basic 3GPP test frame with no beamforming 10
(beamId=0x000) and with one spatial stream (single eAxC). 11
 12
B. Test Entrance Criteria 13
• Manufacturers’ declaration that defines list of magnitude and phase relation (or beamweights) between 14
antenna ports or TAB connectors and/or beam directions with antenna array characteristics when O-RU DUT 15
is operating with no beamforming.  16
 17
C. Test Methodology 18
 19
a. Initial Conditions 20
• Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation 21
using M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  22
• Ensure that the RF connections and cables are calibrated so there is phase coherence between the antenna 23
ports (or TAB connectors) within acceptable tolerance.  24
• Connect the signal analyzer to the O-RU antenna ports or TAB connectors that belong to the beam under 25
test and configure the analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and demodulate the 26
transmitted signal.  27
• Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.  28
 29
b. Procedure 30
a. Build an appropriate IQ signal describing the NR-FR1-TM1.1 signal described above in the O-DU 31
emulator.   32
b. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the 33
signal and the beam under test. Every symbol should be described by either one or two  sections (DL-SCH 34
and DCI) using section type 1 messages. No section type zero messages will be used for this test. 35
c. Encapsulate the IQ data in U-Plane messages. Play those messages to the O-RU respecting timing 36
windows described in section3.2.1.1.1.   37
d. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the signal analyzer and allow it to 38
demodulate and decode the test frame. 39
e. Extract either the beamweights, or magnitude and phase relation, or beam direction from the measured 40
signal. 41
 42
 43
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  44
1. The signal measured by the signal analyzer should satisfy a basic 3GPP signal performance requirement for this 45
radio category (i.e., EVM). 46
2. The test frame received by the signal analyzer should be the same as the signal d escribed above and should 47
contain all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data. 48
3. The signal relation (i.e. beamweights, or magnitude and phase relation) between antenna ports or TAB 49
connectors, or the extracted beam direction, should match the expected relation, or beam direction, for the 50
expected no beamforming within a tolerance defined by the manufacturer.  51
 52
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP UL – No Beamforming 53
A. Test Description and Applicability 54
This test is MANDATORY. 55
 56
 57

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       108
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can receive a basic 3GPP test frame with no beamforming 1
(beamId=0x000) and with one spatial stream (single eAxC). 2
 3
 4
B. Test Entrance Criteria 5
• Manufacturers’ declaration that defines list of magnitude and phase relation (or beamweights) between antenna 6
ports or TAB connectors and/or beam directions with antenna array characteristics when O -RU DUT is 7
operating with no beamforming.  8
 9
C. Test Methodology 10
 11
a. Initial Conditions 12
• Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation 13
using M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1. 14
• Ensure that the RF connections and cables are calibrated so there is phase coherence between the antenna 15
ports (or TAB connectors) within acceptable tolerance.  16
• Connect the signal source to the O-RU antenna ports or TAB connectors that belong to the beam under test 17
and configure the source with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and generate the test 18
signal.  19
• Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.   20
 21
b. Procedure 22
a. Build an appropriate test signal described above in the signal source of the TER.  23
b. Inject the test signal into the O-RU with the application of an initial set of beamweights, or equivalently 24
magnitude and phase relation, between all the TER ports connected to the antenna ports (or TAB 25
connectors) to emulate the phase and magnitude difference “seen” by the antenna elements under test . For 26
example, initial beamweights could be set to be “all equal” (i.e. no beamforming).  27
c. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the 28
signal and the beam under test. Every symbol should be described by either one or two  sections (UL-29
SCH) using section type 1 messages. No section type zero messages will be used for this test.  30
d. Play the C plane messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows described in section 3.2.1.1.1. while 31
also triggering the signal source.   32
e. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the DUT, allow it to create and send the U 33
plane messages to the O-DU and for the O-DU to demodulate, decode and extract the payload. 34
f. Repeat the previous steps but now in step b apply a different set of beamweights or phase relation between 35
all the antenna ports (or TAB connectors) when injecting the test signal into the O-RU. For example, 36
repeating the process for a number of different beamweights will simulate the reception of the test signal 37
from different beam directions. This allows to determine if the O-RU is really focusing the sensitivity to 38
the correct beam direction. 39
 40
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  41
1. The test frame received by the TER/O-DU should be the same as the signal described above and should contain 42
all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data. 43
2. The beamweights or magnitude and phase relation at the antenna ports (or TAB connectors) of the test signal 44
that achieves the highest performance (i.e. best EVM, power, SNR, etc.) should match with the manufacturer’s 45
declaration of the phase relation expected for no beamforming. 46
 47
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Predefined-beam 48
Beamforming 49
A. Test Description and Applicability 50
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 51
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can transmit a basic 3GPP test frame with predefined -beams 52
beamforming (beamId≠0x000) and with one spatial stream (single eAxC). 53
The transmitted beam direction is measured for each indexed beam required in this measurement, see below. The 54
measured transmitted direction is compared to manufacturer-designated direction. Transmitted direction could be 55
defined by the phase relation between the antenna ports or TAB connectors under test, or directly by extracting the 56
beam direction. 57

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       109
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
Depending on the O-RU beamforming capabilities regarding the ability to generate “coarse”, “fin e” and/or “beam 1
groups”, as defined in [2] Section 10.4.1.1. 2
 3
The elevation θ and azimuth Φ angles are defined as in [2] Section 10.4.1.1: 4
 5
The UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Predefined-beam Beamforming conformance test 6
might include multiple tests that the O-RU must comply: 7
a. “Coarse” beamIds test:  8
If O-RU supports and reports beamIds that are defined as coarse granularity (coarse beamIds) to the O -DU 9
emulator, the test should include the following beams: 10
1. A coarse beam with 0 degrees azimuth (Φ) and elevation (θ) angles. 11
2. A coarse beam with maximum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and maximum supported elevation angle (θ). 12
3. A coarse beam with maximum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and minimum supported elevation angle (θ).  13
4. A coarse beam with minimum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and maximum supported elevation angle (θ). 14
5. A coarse beam with minimum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and minimum supported elevation angle (θ).  15
 16
If the O-RU only supports one azimuth (Φ) or elevation angle (θ), fewer than 5 beam angles will be measured.  17
 18
b.  “Fine” beamIds test:  19
If O-RU supports and reports beamIds that are defined as fine granularity (fine beamIds) to the O-DU 20
emulator, the test should include the following beams: 21
1. A fine beam with 0 degrees azimuth (Φ) and elevation (θ) angles. 22
2. A fine beam with maximum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and maximum supported elevation angle (θ). 23
3. A fine beam with maximum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and minimum supported elevation angle (θ).  24
4. A fine beam with minimum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and maximum supported elevation angle ( θ). 25
5. A fine beam with minimum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and minimum supported elevation angle (θ).  26
 27
If the O-RU only supports one azimuth or elevation angle, fewer than 5 beam angles will be measured.  28
 29
c.  “beam-group” beamIds test:  30
If O-RU supports and reports beamIds that belong to same and different beam-groups to the O-DU emulator, 31
the test should include the following beams: 32
1. All beams that belong to a beam-group with 0 degrees azimuth (Φ) or elevation (θ) angles. 33
2. All beams that belong to a beam-group with maximum supported azimuth angle (Φ). 34
3. All beams that belong to a beam-group with minimum supported azimuth angle (Φ). 35
4. All beams that belong to a beam-group with maximum supported elevation angle (θ). 36
5. All beams that belong to a beam-group with minimum supported elevation angle (θ). 37
 38
If the O-RU only supports one azimuth or elevation angle, fewer than 5 beam-groups will be measured. 39
 40
 41
B. Test Entrance Criteria 42
• Manufacturers’ defined list of beam indices and their associated magnitude and phase relation between antenna 43
ports or TAB connectors and/or beam directions with antenna array characteristics.  44
 45
C. Test Methodology 46
 47
a. Initial Conditions 48
• Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation using 49
M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  50
• Ensure that the RF connections and cables are calibrated so there is phase coherence between the antenna 51
ports (or TAB connectors) within acceptable tolerance.   52
• Connect the signal analyzer to the O-RU antenna ports or TAB connectors that belong to the beam under 53
test and configure the analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and demodulate the 54
transmitted signal.  55
• Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range. 56

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       110
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
   1
b. Procedure 2
a. Build an appropriate IQ signal describing the NR-FR1-TM1.1 signal described above in the O-DU emulator.   3
b. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the signal 4
and the beam under test. Every symbol should be described by either one or two  sections (DL-SCH and 5
DCI) using section type 1 messages. No section type zero messages will be used for this test. 6
c. Encapsulate the IQ data in U-Plane messages. Play those messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows 7
described in section 3.2.1.1.1.   8
d. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the signal analyzer and allow it to demodulate 9
and decode the test frame. 10
e. Extract either the beamweights, or magnitude and phase relation, or beam direction from the measured 11
signal. 12
 13
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  14
1. The signal measured by the signal analyzer should satisfy a basic 3GPP signal performance requirement for this 15
radio category (i.e., EVM). 16
2. The test frame received by the signal analyzer should be the same as the signal des cribed above and should 17
contain all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data. 18
3. The signal relation (i.e. beamweights, or magnitude and phase relation) between antenna ports or TAB 19
connectors, or the extracted beam direction, should match the expected relation, or beam direction, 20
corresponding to the beam under test within a tolerance defined by the manufacturer.  21
 22
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP UL – Predefined-beam 23
Beamforming 24
A. Test Description and Applicability 25
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 26
 27
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can receive a basic 3GPP test frame with predefined -beams 28
beamforming (beamId≠0x000) and with one spatial stream (single eAxC).  29
 30
The same description and criteria for selecting the beams to be tested applies as in section 3.2.3.2.3 applies, but 31
instead it is related to the uplink direction.  32
 33
B. Test Entrance Criteria 34
 35
• Manufacturers’ defined list of beam indices and their associated magnitude and phase relation between antenna 36
ports or TAB connectors and/or beam directions with antenna array characteristics.  37
  38
C. Test Methodology 39
 40
a. Initial Conditions 41
• Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation using 42
M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1. 43
• Ensure that the RF connections and cables are calibrated so there is phase coherence between the antenna 44
ports (or TAB connectors) within acceptable tolerance.    45
• Connect the signal source to the O-RU antenna ports or TAB connectors that belong to the beam under test 46
and configure the source with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and generate the test 47
signal.  48
• Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.   49
 50
b. Procedure 51
a. Build an appropriate test signal described above in the signal source of the TER. 52
b. Inject the test signal into the O-RU with the application of an initial set of beamweights, or equivalently 53
magnitude and phase relation, between all the TER ports connected to the antenna ports (or TAB 54
connectors) to emulate the phase and magnitude difference “seen” by the antenna elements under test. For 55
example, initial beamweights could be set to be “all equal” (i.e. no beamforming).    56

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       111
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
c. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the 1
signal and the beam under test. Every symbol should be described by either one or two  sections (UL-2
SCH) using section type 1 messages. No section type zero messages will be used for this test.  3
d. Play the C plane messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows described in section 3.2.1.1.1. while 4
also triggering the signal source.   5
e. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the DUT, allow it to create and send the U 6
plane messages to the O-DU and for the O-DU to demodulate, decode and extract the payload. 7
f. Repeat the previous steps but now in step b apply a different set of beamweights or phase relation between 8
all the antenna ports (or TAB connectors) when injecting the test signal into the O-RU. For example, 9
repeating the process for a number of different beamweights will simulate the reception of the test signal 10
from different beam directions. This allows to determine if the O-RU is really focusing the sensitivity to 11
the correct beam direction. 12
 13
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  14
1. The test frame received by the TER/O-DU should be the same as the signal described above and should contain 15
all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data. 16
2. The beamweights or magnitude and phase relation at the antenna ports (or TAB connectors) of the test signal 17
that achieves the highest performance (i.e. best EVM, power, SNR, etc.) should match with the manufacturer’s 18
declaration of the beam under test. 19
 20
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Weight-based Dynamic 21
Beamforming 22
A. Test Description and Applicability 23
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 24
 25
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can transmit a basic 3GPP test frame with weight -based dynamic 26
beamforming with one spatial stream (single eAxC).  27
 28
The transmitted beam direction is measured for each weighted beam required in this measureme nt, see below. The 29
measured transmitted direction is compared to manufacturer-designated direction. Transmitted direction could be 30
defined by the phase relation between the antenna ports or TAB connectors under test, or by directly extracting the 31
beam direction. 32
The elevation θ and azimuth Φ angles are defined as in [2] Section 10.4.1.1: 33
 34
 35
The UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Weight-based Dynamic Beamforming conformance 36
test should evaluate the following beams for the O-RU to comply: 37
a. A weight-based beam with 0 degrees azimuth (Φ) and elevation (θ) angles. 38
b. A weight-based beam with maximum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and maximum supported elevation angle  39
(θ). 40
c. A weight-based beam with maximum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and minimum supported elevation angle 41
(θ). 42
d. A weight-based beam with minimum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and maximum supported elevation angle 43
(θ). 44
e. A weight-based beam with minimum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and minimum supported elevation angle 45
(θ). 46
 47
If the O-RU only supports one azimuth (Φ) or elevation angle (θ), fewer than 5 beam angles will be measured.  48
 49
The UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Weight—based Dynamic Beamforming 50
conformance test should also evaluate the following compression methods for each of the supported beams 51
described above (a. to e.) for the O-RU to comply: 52
a. No compression method applied to the beamforming weights.  53
b. Block floating point compression method applied to the beamforming weights with 14 -bit mantissa. 54
c. Block scaling compression method applied to the beamforming weights with 14 -bit scaler. 55
d. μ-law compression method applied to the beamforming weights with 14-bit fixed width. 56
e. Beamspace compression method applied to the beamforming weights with 14 -bit scaler.  57

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       112
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
 1
If the O-RU does not support all the compression methods described above, fewer than 5 compression methods will 2
be measured. 3
 4
 5
B. Test Entrance Criteria 6
• Manufacturers’ defined list of frequency domain (ϕ) and or time domain (θ) weights for each supported beam, 7
or alternatively, list of gain and phase relation, or complex beam weights, between antenna ports or TAB 8
connectors for each supported beam . Also, the O-RU needs to report to the O-DU the antenna array 9
characteristics. 10
 11
C. Test Methodology 12
 13
a. Initial Conditions 14
• Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation 15
using M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1. 16
• Ensure that the RF connections and cables are calibrated so there is phase coherence between the antenna 17
ports (or TAB connectors) within acceptable tolerance.    18
• Connect the signal analyzer to the O-RU antenna ports or TAB connectors that belong to the beam under 19
test and configure the analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and demodulate the 20
transmitted signal.  21
• Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.   22
 23
b. Procedure 24
a. Build an appropriate IQ signal describing the NR-FR1-TM1.1 signal described above in the O-DU emulator.   25
b. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the signal 26
and the beam under test. Every symbol should be described by one or two sections (DL-SCH and DCI) 27
using section type 1 messages, the sections in the first symbol of the slot will contain section extension 28
extType=0x01 to convey the beam weights, it is not required that the next sections contain extension type 1 29
since the same beam IDs will not change along the slot. If O-RU does not support a field, then its value 30
should be 0x0. No section type zero messages will be used for this test. 31
c. Encapsulate the IQ data in U-Plane messages. Play those messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows 32
described in section 3.2.1.1.1.   33
d. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the signal analyzer and allow it to demodulate 34
and decode the test frame. 35
e. Extract either the beamweights, or magnitude and phase relation, or beam direction from the measured 36
signal. 37
 38
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  39
1. The signal measured by the signal analyzer should satisfy a basic 3GPP signal performance requirement for this 40
radio category (i.e., EVM). 41
2. The test frame received by the signal analyzer should be the same as the signal d escribed above and should 42
contain all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data. 43
3. The signal relation (i.e. beamweights, or magnitude and phase relation) between antenna ports or TAB 44
connectors, or the extracted beam direction, should match the expected relation, or beam direction, 45
corresponding to the beam under test within a tolerance defined by the manufacturer.  46
 47
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP UL – Weight-based Dynamic 48
Beamforming 49
A. Test Description and Applicability 50
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 51
 52
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can receive a basic 3GPP test frame with weight -based beamforming 53
and with one spatial stream (single eAxC).  54
 55
The same description and criteria for selecting the beams to be tested applies as in section 3.2.3.2.5 but applies to 56
the uplink direction.  57

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       113
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
 1
B. Test Entrance Criteria 2
• Manufacturers’ defined list of frequency domain (ϕ) and or time domain (θ) weights for each supported beam, 3
or alternatively, list of gain and phase relation, or complex beam weights, between antenna ports or TAB 4
connectors for each supported beam . Also, the O-RU needs to report to the O-DU the antenna array 5
characteristics 6
 7
C. Test Methodology 8
 9
a. Initial Conditions 10
• Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation 11
using M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  12
• Ensure that the RF connections and cables are calibrated so there is phase coherence betw een the antenna 13
ports (or TAB connectors) within acceptable tolerance.   14
• Connect the signal source to the O-RU antenna ports or TAB connectors that belong to the beam under test 15
and configure the source with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and generate the test 16
signal.  17
• Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.   18
 19
b. Procedure 20
 21
a. Build an appropriate test signal described above in the signal source of the TER.  22
b. Inject the test signal into the O-RU with the application of an initial set of beamweights, or equivalently 23
magnitude and phase relation, between all the TER ports connected to the antenna ports (or TAB 24
connectors) to emulate the phase and magnitude difference “seen” by the antenna elements under test . For 25
example, initial beamweights could be set to be “all equal” (i.e. no beamforming).   26
c. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the signal 27
and the beam under test. Every symbol should be described by one or two sections (UL-SCH) using section 28
type 1 messages, the sections in the first symbol of the slot will contain section extension extType=0x01 to 29
convey the beam weights, it is not required that the next sections contain extension type 1 since the same 30
beam IDs will not change along the slot. If O-RU does not support a field, then its value should be 0x0. No 31
section type zero messages will be used for this test. 32
d. Play the C plane messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows described in section 3.2.1.1.1. while 33
also triggering the signal source.   34
e. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the DUT, allow it to create and send the U 35
plane messages to the O-DU and for the O-DU to demodulate, decode and extract the payload. 36
f. Repeat the previous steps but now in step b apply a different set of beamweights or phase relation between 37
all the antenna ports (or TAB connectors) when injecting the test signal into the O-RU. For example, 38
repeating the process for a number of different beamweights will simulate the reception of the test signal 39
from different beam directions. This allows to determine if the O-RU is really focusing the sensitivity to the 40
correct beam direction. 41
 42
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  43
1. The test frame received by the TER/O-DU should be the same as the signal described above and should contain 44
all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data. 45
2. The beamweights or magnitude and phase relation at the antenna ports (or TAB connectors) of the test signal 46
that achieves the highest performance (i.e. best EVM, power, SNR, etc.) should match with the manufacturer’s 47
declaration of the beam under test. 48
 49
 50
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Attribute-based Dynamic 51
Beamforming 52
A. Test Description and Applicability 53
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 54
 55
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can transmit a basic 3GPP test frame with attributed -based dynamic 56
beamforming with one spatial stream (single eAxC).  57
 58

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       114
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
If the O-RU DUT supports Attribute based Dynamic Beamforming, this test is mandatory for the O -RU DUT to be 1
O-RAN conformant.   2
The transmitted beam direction and attributes are measured for each attributed beam required in this measurement, 3
see below. The measured transmitted direction and attributes, i.e. pointing azimuth and elevation angles, 4
beamwidths and sidelobe suppression, is compared to manufacturer-designated direction and attributes. 5
Transmitted direction and beam attributes are defined by the magnitude and phase relation between the antenna 6
ports or TAB connectors under test, or by directly extracting the beam propertie s. 7
The elevation θ and azimuth Φ angles are defined as in Section 10.4.1.1  of [2]. 8
 9
 10
The UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Attribute-based Dynamic Beamforming 11
conformance test should evaluate the following beams for the O-RU to comply: 12
a. An attribute-based beam with 0 degrees azimuth (Φ) and elevation (θ) angles with any beamwidth and sidelobe 13
suppression supported by the O-RU under this beam direction. 14
b. An attribute-based beam with maximum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and maximum supported elevation angle 15
(θ) with the widest beamwidth and lowest sidelobe suppression supported for this specific beam direction.  16
c. An attribute-based beam with maximum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and minimum supported elevation angle 17
(θ) with the narrowest beamwidth and highest sidelobe suppression supported for this specific beam direction.  18
d. An attribute-based beam with minimum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and maximum supported ele vation angle 19
(θ) with the widest beamwidth and lowest sidelobe suppression supported for this specific beam direction.  20
e. An attribute-based beam with minimum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and minimum supported elevation angle 21
(θ) with the narrowest beamwidth and highest sidelobe suppression supported for this specific beam direction. 22
 23
If the O-RU only supports one azimuth (Φ) or elevation angle (θ), fewer than 5 beam angles and attribute 24
configurations will be measured. 25
 26
 27
B. Test Entrance Criteria 28
• Manufacturers’ defined list of supported beam directions (azimuth ϕ and elevation θ angles) attributes that are 29
supported by the O-RU and their associated gain and phase relation, or complex weight, between antenna ports 30
or TAB connectors and/or beam directions with antenna array characteristics. 31
 32
C. Test Methodology 33
 34
a. Initial Conditions 35
• Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation 36
using M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  37
• Ensure that the RF connections and cables are calibrated so there is phase coherence betw een the antenna 38
ports (or TAB connectors) within acceptable tolerance.   39
• Connect the signal analyzer to the O-RU antenna ports or TAB connectors that belong to the beam under 40
test and configure the analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and demodulate the 41
transmitted signal.  42
• Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.   43
 44
b. Procedure 45
a. Build an appropriate IQ signal describing the NR-FR1-TM1.1 signal described above in the O-DU 46
emulator.   47
b. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the signal 48
and the beam under test. Every symbol should be described by one or two sections (DL-SCH and DCI) 49
using section type 1 messages, the sections in the first symbol of the slot will contain section extension 50
extType=0x02 to convey the beam weights, it is not required that the next sections contain extension type 2 51
since the same beam IDs will not change along the slot.  If O-RU does not support a field, then its value 52
should be 0x0. No section type zero messages will be used for this test. 53
c. Encapsulate the IQ data in U-Plane messages. Play those messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows 54
described in section 3.2.1.1.1.   55
d. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the signal analyzer and allow it to 56
demodulate and decode the test frame. 57
e. Extract either the beamweights, or magnitude and phase relation, or beam properties from the measured 58
signal. 59

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       115
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
 1
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  2
1. The signal measured by the signal analyzer should satisfy a basic 3GPP signal performance requirement for this 3
radio category (i.e., EVM). 4
2. The test frame received by the signal analyzer should be the same as the signal described above and should 5
contain all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data. 6
3. The signal relation (i.e. beamweights, or magnitude and phase relation) between antenna ports or TAB 7
connectors, or the extracted beam properties, should match the expected beam properties corresponding to the 8
beam under test within a tolerance defined by the manufacturer.  9
 10
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP UL – Attribute-based Dynamic 11
Beamforming 12
A. Test Description and Applicability 13
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 14
 15
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can receive a basic 3GPP test frame with attribute -based 16
beamforming with one spatial stream (single eAxC). 17
 18
Same description and criteria for selecting the beams to be tested applies as in section 3.2.3.2.7 but considering 19
uplink direction.  20
 21
B. Test Entrance Criteria 22
• Manufacturers’ defined list of supported beam directions (azimuth ϕ and elevation θ angles) attributes that are 23
supported by the O-RU and their associated gain and phase relation, or complex weight, between antenna ports 24
or TAB connectors and/or beam directions with antenna array characteristics 25
 26
C. Test Methodology 27
 28
a. Initial Conditions 29
• Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation using 30
M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1. 31
• Ensure that the RF connections and cables are calibrated so there is phase coherence between the antenna 32
ports (or TAB connectors) within acceptable tolerance.    33
• Connect the signal source to the O-RU antenna ports or TAB connectors that belong to the beam under test 34
and configure the source with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and generate the test 35
signal.  36
• Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.   37
 38
b. Procedure 39
a. Build an appropriate test signal described above in the signal source of the TER.  40
b. Inject the test signal into the O-RU with the application of an initial set of beamweights, or equivalently 41
magnitude and phase relation, between all the TER ports connected to the antenna ports (or TAB 42
connectors) to emulate the phase and magnitude difference “seen” by the antenna elements under test . For 43
example, initial beamweights could be set to be “all equal” (i.e. no beamforming).    44
c. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the signal 45
and the beam under test. Every symbol should be described by one or two sections (UL-SCH) using section 46
type 1 messages, the sections in the first symbol of the slot will contain section extension extType=0x02 to 47
convey the beam weights, it is not required that the next sections contain extension type 2 since the same 48
beam IDs will not change along the slot. If O-RU does not support a field, then its value should be 0x0. No 49
section type zero messages will be used for this test. 50
d. Play the C plane messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows described in section 3.2.1.1.1. while also 51
triggering the signal source.   52
e. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the DUT, allow it to create and send the U 53
plane messages to the O-DU and for the O-DU to demodulate, decode and extract the payload. 54
f. Repeat the previous steps but now in step b apply a different set of beamweights or magnitude and phase 55
relation between all the antenna ports (or TAB connectors) when injecting the test signal into the O -RU. For 56
example, repeating the process for a number of different sets of beamweights will simulate the reception of 57

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       116
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
the test signal from different beam directions. This allows to determine if the O -RU is really focusing the 1
sensitivity to the correct beam properties. 2
 3
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  4
1. The test frame received by the TER/O-DU should be the same as the signal described above and should 5
contain all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data. 6
2. The beamweights or magnitude and phase relation at the antenna ports (or TAB connectors) of the test signal 7
that achieves the highest performance (i.e. best EVM, power, SNR, etc.) should match with the 8
manufacturer’s declaration of the beam under test. 9
 10
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Channel-Information-based 11
Beamforming 12
A. Test Description and Applicability 13
This Test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 14
 15
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can transmit a basic 3GPP test frame with channel -information-based 16
beamforming with multiple spatial streams from multiple users (i.e. MU-MIMO). 17
 18
For Category A radios, the test is for each polarization separately and consequently either different or same channel 19
models can be defined for each of the polarization. For Category B, same channel might be used for both 20
polarizations and the test might measure each polarization separately. 21
The transmitted beam direction is measured for each scenario required in this measurement .  The measured 22
transmitted direction is extracted from the decoded received signal in the TER. Transmitted direction is defined by 23
properly receiving a data transmission between the O-RU and the target User Equipment while destroying or 24
heavily attenuating the data transmission between the O-RU and the other User Equipment. 25
The UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Channel-Information-based Beamforming 26
conformance test should evaluate the following scenarios for the O-RU to comply and will rely on TER Channel 27
Emulation capabilities as shown in Figure 3.2.3.2-3.  28
 29
 30
Figure 3.2.3.2-3 TER with Channel Emulation Capability 31
 32
a. A scenario where two spatial streams, or eAxC flows, are generated for two users (one layer each) with M 33
antenna ports or TAB connectors. The O-DU will report to the O-RU via C plane messages an emulated 34

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       117
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
channel estimate 𝐻 ≜  [ℎ1
1, . . . , ℎ1
𝑀, ℎ2
1, . . . , ℎ2
𝑀] ∈ ℂ2𝑥𝑀. The emulated channel  𝐻  shall model a static channel, 1
with rank not lower than the number of spatial streams, and it shall not be a block -diagonal channel. As an 2
example, a Butler channel model could be implemented as emulated channel. The O -RU will calculate and 3
apply the beamweight matrix 𝐺 ≜  [𝑔1
1, . . . , 𝑔1
𝑀, 𝑔2
1, . . . , 𝑔2
𝑀]  ∈ ℂ𝑀𝑥2 in such that the received signal at the 4
users is the same as the generated in the O-DU. It is up to the O-RU on how to calculate the beamforming 5
weights, for example Zero-forcing, regularized zero-forcing / MMSE, etc.   6
 7
If O-RU supports Analog Beamforming (Time Domain Beamforming), the test should not apply any analog 8
beamforming or time domain beamforming. In this case, M is not the number of antenna ports or TAB connecto rs 9
but the number of TRX channels supported by the O-RU. 10
 11
B. Test Entrance Criteria 12
 13
• The O-RU must have at least two TRX chains with conducted antenna ports (or TAB connectors) to be 14
connected to a signal analyzer. 15
• The TER equipment must either include a channel emulator between the O -RU antenna ports and the signal 16
analyzer or the signal analyzer be capable of applying the required channel matrix being emulated between the 17
O-RU and the users.  18
• Manufacturers’ defined list of number of TRX chains and what antenna ports or TAB connectors are 19
connected to each TRX chain.  20
 21
C. Test Methodology 22
 23
a. Initial Conditions 24
• Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation using 25
M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  26
• Ensure that the RF connections and cables are calibrated so there is phase coherence betw een the antenna 27
ports (or TAB connectors) within acceptable tolerance.   28
• Connect the signal analyzer to the O-RU antenna ports or TAB connectors that belong to the scenario under 29
test and configure the analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and demodulate the 30
transmitted signal.  31
• Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.   32
 33
b. Procedure 34
a. Build an appropriate IQ signal describing the NR-FR1-TM1.1 signal described above in the O-DU 35
emulator.   36
b. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the signal 37
and the scenario under test. Every symbol should be described by either one or two  sections (DL-SCH and 38
DCI) using section type 5 and 6 messages. No section type zero messages will be used for this test. 39
c. Encapsulate the IQ data in U-Plane messages. Play those messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows 40
described in section 3.2.1.1.1. 41
d. Capture the test signals and pass them through a channel emulator or apply the signal processing required 42
to emulate the channel under test.   43
e. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the signal a nalyzer and allow it to 44
demodulate and decode the test frame. 45
 46
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  47
1. The signal measured by the signal analyzer should satisfy a basic 3GPP signal performance requirement for this 48
radio category (i.e., EVM). 49
2. The test frame received by the signal analyzer should be the same as the signal described above and should 50
contain all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data. 51
 52
 53
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP UL – Channel-Information-based 54
Beamforming 55

This Test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 57

The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can receive a basic 3GPP test frame with channel -information-based 1
beamforming with multiple spatial streams from multiple users (i.e. MU-MIMO).  2
 3
Same description and criteria for selecting the beams to be tested applies as in section 3.2.3.2.10 but considering 4
uplink direction.  5
B. Test Entrance Criteria 6
 7
• The O-RU must have at least two TRX chains with conducted antenna ports (or TAB connectors) to be 8
connected to a signal generator. 9
• The TER equipment must either include a channel emulator between the O-RU antenna ports and the signal 10
generator or the signal generator be capable of applying the required channel matrix being emulated between 11
the users and the O-RU.  12
• Manufacturers’ defined list of number of TRX chains and what antenna ports or TAB connectors are 13
connected to each TRX chain. 14
 15
C. Test Methodology 16
 17
a. Initial Conditions 18
• Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation 19
using M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  20
• Ensure that the RF connections and cables are calibrated so there is phase coherence between the antenna 21
ports (or TAB connectors) within acceptable tolerance.   22
• Connect the signal source to the O-RU antenna ports or TAB connectors that belong to the beam under test 23
and configure the source with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and generate the test 24
signal.  25
• Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.  26
  27
b. Procedure 28
a. Build an appropriate test signal described above in the signal source of the TER. 29
b. Inject the test signals through a channel emulator or apply the required signal processing to emulate the 30
channel under test.  31
c. Inject the resulting test signals into the antenna ports (or TAB connectors). 32
d. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the signal 33
and the beam under test. Every symbol should be described by either one or two  sections (UL-SCH) using 34
section type 5 and 6. No section type zero messages will be used for this test. 35
e. Play the C plane messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows described in section 2.4. while also 36
triggering the signal source.   37
f. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the DUT, allow it to create and send the U 38
plane messages to the O-DU and for the O-DU to demodulate, decode and extract the payload. 39
 40
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  41
1. The test frame received by the TER/O-DU should be the same as the signal described above and should 42
contain all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data. 43

 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Compression (CMP) 1
Validate the correct implementation and interpretation of mandatory and optional IQ data compression formats 2
described in [2]. Also, evaluate the consistency in U-Plane signaling. 3
It applies to the following CUS fronthaul specification sections in [2]: 4
• Section 5.4.2 for layout of C-Plane message, in particular Section Type 1 5
• Section 5.4.4.10 for applicability of "udCompHdr" and "reserved" fields 6
• Section 6.3.3.13 udCompHdr (user data compression header) 7
• Section 6.3.3.15/16/17 for applicability of udCompParam 8
• Section 6.3.2 for U-Plane message layout 9
• Section 6.3.3 for coding of applicable Information Elements 10
• Table 8-2 for mandatory/optional capabilities. 11
• Annex A 12
• Annex A.6 Selective RE sending Compression 13
 14
The objective is primarily to test the protocol, prior to the compression algorithms performance. 15
Signalling: IQ Compression related fields in UC-Plane messages include:  16
• U-Plane IQ data field  17
• C-Plane udCompHdr (per section 5.4.4.10 of [2]) 18
• U-Plane udComphdr (per section 6.3.3.13 of [2]) 19
• U-Plane udCompParam (per section 6.3.3.15 of [2]) 20
 21
Compression: The current specification [2] includes 7 compression modes, including uncompressed mode (fixed 22
point).  Tests should cover each one of these modes   23
• fixed-point 24
• block floating-point 25
• block scaling 26
• mu-law 27
• modulation compression (modulation compression not included in this document) 28
• Block Floating Point + selective RE sending 29
• Modulation Compression + selective RE sending 30
 31
IQ Bit Width: IQ information can be represented using different bit width (1-16 bits). To optimize test time, tests 32
should be performed on a subset of bit widths  33
• 9 bits 34
• 14 bits  35
 Overview of Compression Test Methodology 36
A common test methodology and structure will be used across all compression test cases. Each one of the test cases will 37
be defined with specific input parameters and expected output values.  38
To minimize influence of the Radio’s RF performance to the test results, the test methodology will be based on a 39
relative comparison between modulated signal measurements performed on a test frame with uncompressed IQ (fixed 40
16 bits) and measurements on the same test frame using compressed IQ. The test will verify that the difference between 41
measurements fits within an acceptable range for the test to pass. 42
For downlink test, the modulated signal measurement is performed by a signal analyzer on the antenna port of the O-43
RU.  44
For uplink measurement, the modulated signal measurement is performed with the IQ extracted from the Uplink U-45
Plane data sent by the O-RU on the O-RAN interface.  46
The following paragraphs in this overview section outline the details of these common test methodologies.  47

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       120
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
3.2.3.3.1.1 Test Frame 1
The test frames used for compression conformance test will be referred in this document as “ NR-FR1-CMP-TST-2
FRAME-DL” Downlink Standard Compression Test frame and “NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-UL” Uplink Standard 3
Compression Test frame. They are 5G NR frames based on the de scription in section 3.2.1.1.5 with specific attributes 4
described below. 5
The Downlink UC-Plane test stimulus file includes the C-Plane and U-Plane messages that require the O-RU to 6
transmit on the downlink the NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-DL test frame.  7
The Uplink C-Plane test stimulus file includes the C-Plane messages that require the O-RU to provide the uplink U-8
Plane messages according to the NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-UL test frame received by the O-RU on its antenna port. 9
Signalling and IQ information will be based on various compression schemes  10
Stimulus File Name Description

NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-ST-UL-UNC-16B Static Uplink Uncompressed (C-plane only)
NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-ST-DL-FPF-9B Static Downlink Fixed Point 9 Bits (CU-plane)

NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-NS-UL-MLW-9B Uplink Mu-Law 9 Bits (C-plane only)
NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-NS-UL-MLW-14B Uplink Mu-Law 14 Bits (C-plane only)
NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-NS-DL-MC Non-Static Downlink Modulation Compression
NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-NS-DL-UNC-BRE-
16B
Static Downlink Uncompressed (CU-plane) with both empty
and allocated RE in the same symbol
NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-NS-UL-UNC-BRE-
16B
Static Uplink Uncompressed (C-plane only) with both empty
and allocated RE in the same symbol
NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-NS-DL-BRE-9B Downlink Block Floating Point + Selective RE 9 Bits
 (CU-plane)
NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-NS-DL-BRE-14B Downlink Block Floating Point + Selective RE 14 Bits
(CU-plane)
