(C-plane only)
NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-NS-UL-BRE-14B Uplink Block Floating Point + Selective RE 14 Bits
(C-plane only)
NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-NS-DL-MRE Downlink Modcomp + Selective RE Compression
Table 3.2.3.3-2 Stimulus Files for Non-Static Compression Test   3
 4
3.2.3.3.1.2 Test Frame Power  5
To ensure that the compressed IQ exponent value is properly tested, each symbol of the test frame wil l include 3 6
sections with different power levels.  The Power levels are relative powers to the first group of PRBs transmitted.  Any 7
valid 3GPP power level may be used for the first set of PRBs as long as the power levels of the remaining PRBs are 8
also valid.  Figure 3.2.3.3-1 below shows PRB power relative to the first set of PRBs. 9
•    0 dB for the bottom third of total PRBs in the symbol (referred as PDSCH0) 10

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       122
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
• -10 dB for the middle third of total PRBs in the symbol (referred as PDSCH1) 1
• -20 dB for the upper third of total PRBs in the symbol (referred as PDSCH2)  2
 3
The spectrum representation of the frame shown in Figure 3.2.3.3-1 below highlights the various power levels for each 4
group of PRBS within a symbol.  5
 6
Figure 3.2.3.3-1 PRB Spectrum Power Visualization 7
 8
3.2.3.3.1.3 Test Frame User data  9
To validate that user data has not been impacted by compression, the test payload for the 3 sections is based on a PN23 10
sequence that will be measured and compared by the test apparatus.   11
3.2.3.3.1.4 Test Frame Modulation Scheme 12
To maximise coverage on the compressed IQ mantissa value, the test frame will use the highest possible modulation 13
(256 QAM modulation for downlink).  An example measurement is show in Figure 3.2.3.3-2. 14
 15
Figure 3.2.3.3-2 Example User Data Modulation Validation 16
3.2.3.3.1.5 Summary of Required Measurements for Compression Tests 17
3 measurements types will be required for downlink tests and 4 measurements will be required for uplink tests.  18
• Power level:  Using the test frames (NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-DL and NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-UL) 19
sent twice with both compressed and uncompressed IQ data, power level measurements are performed to 20
validate compression algorithms influence on Exponent (udCompParam).  21
The Power level measurements are called: 22
 23
o CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH0 in dBm 24
o CMP-Compressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH0 in dBm 25
o CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH1 in dBm 26
o CMP-Compressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH1 in dBm 27
o CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH2 in dBm 28
o CMP-Compressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH2 in dBm 29
 30
For the test to pass, the difference between measurements should be within an acceptable range, called  31
o ACC_PWR_PDSCH0 = ± 1dB 32
o ACC_PWR_PDSCH1 = ± 1dB 33
o ACC_PWR_PDSCH2 = ± 1dB 34
o  35
• EVM:  Using a common test frame sent twice with both compressed and uncompressed IQ data, EVM 36
measurements comparisons between uncompressed IQ and compressed IQ will help validate acceptable 37
compression influence on signal quality.  38
 39
These 6 EVM measurements required: 40

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       123
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
o CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH0 in % 1
o CMP-Compressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH0  in % 2
o CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH1  in % 3
o CMP-Compressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH1  in % 4
o CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH2  in % 5
o CMP-Compressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH2  in % 6
 7
For the test to pass, the difference between the compressed and uncompressed measurements for the same 8
PDSCH signal must be within the following range: 9
o ACC_EVM_PDSCH0 ≤ 4 percentage points 10
o ACC_EVM_PDSCH1 ≤ 4 percentage points 11
o ACC_EVM_PDSCH2 ≤ 4 percentage points 12
 13
An example measurement showing both power and EVM is shown below in Figure 3.2.3.3-3. 14

Figure 3.2.3.3-3 Example Compression EVM Measurement 15
 16
• Payload Data Integrity:  comparing user data between the O-RAN test frame and the RF measurement to 17
validate that compression does not influence user data.  The User data measurements are called: 18
 19
o CMP-Uncompressed-BER-PDSCH0  20
o CMP-Uncompressed-BER-PDSCH1  21
o CMP-Uncompressed-BER-PDSCH2  22
o CMP-Compressed-BER-PDSCH0  23
o CMP-Compressed-BER-PDSCH1  24
o CMP-Compressed-BER-PDSCH2  25
 26
For the data integrity test to pass, the comparison between stimulus payload and the measured payload should 27
be free of any errors (i.e. BER=0).  28
 29
• Presence/Absence of U-Plane Header measurements (uplink only): to validate that in the U-Plane PRB 30
header, the udCompHeader, “reserved” and udCompParam fields are correctly absent for Static compression 31
mode or present for other compression modes.  32
 33
Table 3.2.3.3-3 describes the measurements required for each compression option in the downlink. 34
 35

3.2.3.3.1.7 Results Analysis 2
In general, for each specific Compression Test in this conformance test document, the test will pass if the following 3
conditions are met: 4
• Power measurement differences between Uncompressed and Compressed are within acceptable range  5
• EVM measurement difference between Uncompressed and Compressed are within acceptable range  6
• Data integrity measurements show no data corruption 7

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       126
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
• Uplink U-Plane Header measurements exclude fields for static compression 1
 2
These test criteria and expected results are summarized below in 3.2.3.3-6.   3

Table 3.2.3.3-5  Compression Test Acceptance Threshold Criteria 1
 2
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Compression Static Format (SF) Fixed-Point (FP)  3
A. Test Description and Applicability 4
This test is CONDITIONALMANDATORY and shall be performed if the O-RU supports this compression format. 5
 6
The purpose of this test is to: 7
• Validate correct encoding of IQ data under the following conditions.  8
o RU Static compression configurations 9
o Fixed point IQ data format 10
o Selection of 2 supported bit width: 9 bits, 14 bits  11
o Uplink / downlink 12
• Validate that in the U-Plane PRB header, the udCompHeader, “reserved” and udCompParam fields are 13
not present  14
 15
B. Test Entrance Criteria 16
 The test uses the setup and methodology described in section 3.2.1.1. 17
 18
 19
C. Test Methodology 20
a.  Initial Conditions 21
• The O-RU is started 22
• Fronthaul Ethernet interface configured for communication between TER and the DUT. 23
• O-RU synchronized with TER using S-Plane 24
• Communication established between TER and the DUT such that it is possible to exchange U-Plane and 25
C-Plane messages  26
• Signal Analyzer connected to DUT’s antenna port and setup according to DUT RF output configuration 27
• Signal Source connected to DUT’s antenna port and setup according to DUT RF input configuration  28
 29
b.  Procedure 30
For each supported bit width (9 bits, 14 bits), the following tests need to be performed:  31
  32
1. Downlink test 33
• Via the M-Plane or another suitable mechanism, put the O-RU into a static configuration with the 34
downlink configured as follows: no compression, (16 bits) 35
• Arm Signal Analyzer to capture the next Frame  36
• Send the “uncompressed” NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-ST-DL-UNC-16B test stimulus file to the 37
DUT 38
• With the Signal Analyzer, perform the 3 power measurements  39
• CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH0 in dBm 40
• CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH1 in dBm 41
• CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH2 in dBm 42
• With the Signal Analyzer, perform the 3 EVM measurements  43
• CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH0 in % 44
• CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH1 in % 45
• CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH2 in % 46
• With the Signal Analyzer, check Data integrity measurements  47
• CMP-Uncompressed-BER-PDSCH0  48
• CMP-Uncompressed-BER-PDSCH1  49
• CMP-Uncompressed-BER-PDSCH2  50

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       129
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
• Via the M-Plane or another suitable mechanism, put the O-RU into a static configuration with the 1
downlink configured as follows: Fixed point, 9-bit (then 14 bits)  2
• Send the “Compressed” NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-ST-DL-FPF-9B (then 14B) test stimulus 3
file to the DUT 4
• With the Signal Analyzer, perform the 3 power measurements  5
• CMP-Compressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH0 in dBm 6
• CMP-Compressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH1 in dBm 7
• CMP-Compressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH2 in dBm 8
• With the Signal Analyzer, perform the 3 EVM measurements  9
• CMP-Compressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH0 in % 10
• CMP-Compressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH1 in % 11
• CMP-Compressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH2 in % 12
• With the Signal Analyzer, check Data integrity measurements  13
• CMP-Compressed-BER-PDSCH0  14
• CMP-Compressed-BER-PDSCH1  15
• CMP-Compressed-BER-PDSCH2  16
• Verify the following conditions  17
• Power measurements within acceptable range  18
• Difference between CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH0 and CMP-19
Compressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH0 is within ACC_PWR_PDSCH0 range 20
• Difference between CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH1 and CMP-21
Compressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH1 is within ACC_PWR_PDSCH1 range 22
• Difference between CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH2 and CMP-23
Compressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH2 is within ACC_PWR_PDSCH2 range 24
•  25
 26
• EVM  measurements within acceptable range  27
• Difference between CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH0 and CMP-28
Compressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH0 is less than ACC_EVM_PDSCH0 29
• Difference between CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH1 and CMP-30
Compressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH1 is less than ACC_EVM_PDSCH1 31
• Difference between CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH2 and CMP-32
Compressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH2 is less than ACC_EVM_PDSCH2 33
 34
• BER Measurements show no errors  35
• CMP-Uncompressed-BER-PDSCH0 =0 36
• CMP-Uncompressed-BER-PDSCH1  =0 37
• CMP-Uncompressed-BER-PDSCH2 =0 38
• CMP-Compressed-BER-PDSCH0 =0 39
• CMP-Compressed-BER-PDSCH1 =0 40
• CMP-Compressed-BER-PDSCH2 =0 41
  42
2. Uplink test 43
• Via the M-Plane or another suitable mechanism, put the O-RU into a static configuration with the 44
uplink configured as follows: no compression, 16-bit 45
• Arm Signal Source to generate the Frame NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-UL 46
• Arm CUSM-E to send the “uncompressed” NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-ST-UL-UNC-16B test 47
stimulus file to the DUT 48
• ARM CUSM-E to capture the Uplink U-Plane Data from the DUT 49
• Launch the test 50
• Extract IQ information from Capture U-Plane trace 51
• Using the Signal Analyzer software, perform the 3 power measurements  52
• CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH0 in dBm 53
• CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH1 in dBm 54
• CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH2 in dBm 55
 56
• Using the Signal Analyzer software, perform the 3 EVM measurements  57
• CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH0 in % 58
• CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH1 in % 59

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       130
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
• CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH2 in % 1
 2
• Using the Signal Analyzer software, check Data integrity measurements  3
• CMP-Uncompressed-BER-PDSCH0  4
• CMP-Uncompressed-BER-PDSCH1  5
• CMP-Uncompressed-BER-PDSCH2  6
 7
• Via the M-Plane or another suitable mechanism, put the O-RU into a static configuration with the 8
uplink configured as follows: Fixed point, 9-bit (then 14 bits)  9
• Arm Signal Source to generate the Frame NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-UL 10
• Arm CUSM-E to send the “Compressed” NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-ST-UL-FPF-9B test stimulus 11
file to the DUT 12
• Arm CUSM-E to capture the Uplink U-Plane Data from the DUT 13
• Launch the test 14
• Extract IQ information from Capture U-Plane trace 15
• Using the Signal Analyzer software, perform the 3 power measurements  16
• CMP-Compressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH0 in dBm 17
• CMP-Compressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH1 in dBm 18
• CMP-Compressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH2 in dBm 19
 20
• Using the Signal Analyzer software, perform the 3 EVM measurements  21
• CMP-Compressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH0 in % 22
• CMP-Compressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH1 in % 23
• CMP-Compressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH2 in % 24
 25
• Using the Signal Analyzer software, check Data integrity measuremen ts  26
• CMP-Compressed-BER-PDSCH0  27
• CMP-Compressed-BER-PDSCH1  28
• CMP-Compressed-BER-PDSCH2  29
 30
• Validate correct U-Plane PRB header structure  31
• U-Plane udComphdr (per section 6.3.3.13 of [2]) 32
• U-Plane udCompParam (per section 6.3.3.15 of [2]) 33
 34
• Validate that the power measurements within acceptable range  35
• Difference between CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH0 and CMP-36
Compressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH0 is withinACC_PWR_PDSCH0 range 37
• Difference between CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH1 and CMP-38
Compressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH1 is withinACC_PWR_PDSCH1 range 39
•  40
• Difference between CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH2 and CMP-41
Compressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH2 is withinACC_PWR_PDSCH2 range 42
• EVM measurements within acceptable range  43
• Difference between CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH0 and CMP-Compressed-44
Measured-EVM-PDSCH0 is less than ACC_EVM_PDSCH0 45
• Difference between CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH1 and CMP-Compressed-46
Measured-EVM-PDSCH1 is less than ACC_EVM_PDSCH1 47
• Difference between CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH2 and CMP-Compressed-48
Measured-EVM-PDSCH2 is less than ACC_EVM_PDSCH2 49
 50
• Validate that the BER Measurements show no errors  51
• CMP-Uncompressed-BER-PDSCH0 = 0 52
• CMP-Uncompressed-BER-PDSCH1 = 0 53
• CMP-Uncompressed-BER-PDSCH2 = 0 54
• CMP-Compressed-BER-PDSCH0 = 0 55
• CMP-Compressed-BER-PDSCH1 = 0 56
• CMP-Compressed-BER-PDSCH2 = 0 57
 58

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.

                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
D.  Test Requirement (expected result)  1
1. All validation steps above are within expected ranges or correctly match the expected outcome.  2
 3
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Compression Static Format (SF) Block Floating Point 4
(BFP) 5
A. Test Description and Applicability 6
This test is CONDITIONALMANDATORY and shall be performed if the O-RU supports this compression format. 7
This static format test scenario for Block Floating Point Format will verify DL and UL correct encoding of IQ 8
information for 2 supported bit widths: 9 bits or 14 bits. 9
 10
B. Test Entrance Criteria 11
Same as 3.2.3.3.2 for Block floating point formats.  12
 13
C. Test Methodology 14
Same as 3.2.3.3.2 with Static Block Floating Point test patterns  15
• NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-ST-DL-BFP-9B  16
• NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-ST-DL-BFP-14B 17
• NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-ST-UL-BFP-9B  18
• NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-ST-UL-BFP-14B 19
 20
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  21
1. Same as 3.2.3.3.2. 22
 23
  UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Compression Static Format (SF) Block Scaling 24

 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Compression Static Format (SF) Modulation-6
Compressed Format 7
A. Test Description and Applicability 8
This test is CONDITIONALMANDATORY and shall be performed if the O-RU supports this compression format. 9
 10
This modulation compression format scenario is a static format scenario, based on 3.2.3.3.2 with some important 11
differences 12
• The purpose is to validate Radio Unit’s correct interpretation of the Modulation compression parameters 13
used in the Section Extension Type =4  14
• The test will only verify DL correct encoding of IQ information, as the Modulation Compression model is 15
not applicable for uplink 16
• As the Modulation Compression model does not require IQ bit width to be setup, there is no need to run 17
multiple compression tests for various IQ bit width.  18
 19
Stimulus File Name Description
NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-ST-DL-UNC-16B Static Downlink Uncompressed (CU-plane)
NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-ST-DL-MC Static Downlink Modulation Compression
 20
 21
B. Test Entrance Criteria 22
Same as 3.2.3.3.2. 23
 24
C. Test Methodology 25
Same as 3.2.3.3.2 with Static Modulation Compression test patterns 26
• NR-FR1-TDD-CMP-TST-ST-DL-MC 27
 28
Note that this test is only applicable to the downlink and therefore should only follow the downlink steps of the 29
referenced test case above.  Via the M-Plane or another suitable mechanism, put the O-RU into a static 30
configuration with the downlink configured as follows: Modulation Compression. 31
 32
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  33
All validation steps for the downlink referenced in 3.2.3.3.2 are within expected ranges or correctly match the 34
expected outcome. 35
 36
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Compression Non-Static (NS) Fixed-Point (FPF)  37
A. Test Description and Applicability 38
This test is CONDITIONALMANDATORY and shall be performed if the O-RU supports this compression format. 39
This Fixed-Point Format scenario is a non-static format scenario that will verify DL and UL correct encoding of IQ 40
information for 2 supported bit widths: 9 bits or 14 bits. 41
 42
B. Test Entrance Criteria 43
Same as 3.2.3.3.2. 44
 45
C. Test Methodology 46
a. Initial Conditions 47
• Same as 3.2.3.3.2  Non-Static Fixed-Point test patterns 48
• Via the M-Plane or another suitable mechanism, disable the O-RU Static IQ and compression format 49
 50

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       133
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
 1
b. Procedure 2
For each supported bit width (9 bits, 14 bits), the following tests need to be performed:  3
1. Downlink test 4
• Arm Signal Analyzer to capture the next Frame  5
• Send the uncompressed” NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-NS-DL-UNC-16B test stimulus file to the 6
DUT 7
• With the Signal Analyzer, perform the 3 power measurements  8
• CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH0in dBm 9
• CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH1 in dBm 10
• CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH2 in dBm 11
 12
• With the Signal Analyzer, perform the 3 EVM measurements  13
• CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH0 in % 14
• CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH1 in % 15
• CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH2 in % 16
 17
• With the Signal Analyzer, check Data integrity measurements  18
• CMP-Uncompressed-BER-PDSCH0  19
• CMP-Uncompressed-BER-PDSCH1  20
• CMP-Uncompressed-BER-PDSCH2  21
 22
• Send the “Compressed” NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-NS-DL-FPF-9B (then 14B) test stimulus 23
file to the DUT 24
 25
• With the Signal Analyzer, perform the 3 power measurements  26
• CMP-Compressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH0 in dBm 27
• CMP-Compressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH1 in dBm 28
• CMP-Compressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH2 in dBm 29
 30
• With the Signal Analyzer, perform the 3 EVM measurements  31
• CMP-Compressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH0 in % 32
• CMP-Compressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH1 in % 33
• CMP-Compressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH2 in % 34
 35
• With the Signal Analyzer, check Data integrity measurements  36
• CMP-Compressed-BER-PDSCH0  37
• CMP-Compressed-BER-PDSCH1  38
• CMP-Compressed-BER-PDSCH2  39
 40
• Validate that the power measurements within acceptable range  41
• Difference between CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH0 and CMP-42
Compressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH0 is within ACC_PWR_PDSCH0 range 43
• Difference between CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH1 and CMP-44
Compressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH1 is within ACC_PWR_PDSCH1 range 45
• Difference between CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH2 and CMP-46
Compressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH2 is within ACC_PWR_PDSCH2 range 47
 48
• Validate that the EVM  measurements within acceptable range  49
• Difference between CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH0 and CMP-50
Compressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH0 is within ACC_EVM_PDSCH0 range 51
• Difference between CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH1 and CMP-52
Compressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH1 is within ACC_EVM_PDSCH1 range 53
• Difference between CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH2 and CMP-54
Compressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH2 is within ACC_EVM_PDSCH2 range 55
 56
• Validate that the BER Measurements show no errors  57
• CMP-Uncompressed-BER-PDSCH0 =0 58
• CMP-Uncompressed-BER-PDSCH1 =0 59

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       134
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
• CMP-Uncompressed-BER-PDSCH2 =0 1
• CMP-Compressed-BER-PDSCH0 =0 2
• CMP-Compressed-BER-PDSCH1 =0 3
• CMP-Compressed-BER-PDSCH2 =0 4
 5
  6
2. Uplink test 7
• Arm Signal Source to generate the Frame NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-UL 8
• Arm CUSM-E to send the “uncompressed” NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-NS-UL-UNC-16B 9
test stimulus file to the DUT 10
• Arm CUSM-E to capture the Uplink U-Plane Data from the DUT 11
• Launch the test 12
• Extract IQ information from Captured U-Plane trace 13
• Using the Signal Analyzer software, perform the 3 power measurements  14
• CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH0 in dBm 15
• CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH1 in dBm 16
• CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH2 in dBm 17
 18
• Using the Signal Analyzer software, perform the 3 EVM measurements  19
• CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH0 in % 20
• CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH1 in % 21
• CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH2 in % 22
 23
• Using the Signal Analyzer software, check Data integrity measurements  24
• CMP-Uncompressed-BER-PDSCH0  25
• CMP-Uncompressed-BER-PDSCH1  26
• CMP-Uncompressed-BER-PDSCH2  27
 28
• Via the M-Plane or another suitable mechanism, put the O-RU into a Non-Static 29
configuration   30
• Arm Signal Source to generate the Frame NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-UL 31
• Arm CUSM-E to send the “Compressed” NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-NS-UL-CMP-9B 32
(then 14B) test stimulus file to the DUT 33
• ARM CUSM-E to capture the Uplink U-Plane Data from the DUT 34
• Launch the test 35
• Extract IQ information from Captured U-Plane trace 36
• Using the Signal Analyzer software, perform the 3 power measurements  37
• CMP-Compressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH0 in dBm 38
• CMP-Compressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH1 in dBm 39
• CMP-Compressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH2 in dBm 40
 41
• Using the Signal Analyzer software, perform the 3 EVM measurements  42
• CMP-Compressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH0 in % 43
• CMP-Compressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH1 in % 44
• CMP-Compressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH2 in % 45
 46
• Using the Signal Analyzer software, check Data integrity measuremen ts  47
• CMP-Compressed-BER-PDSCH0  48
• CMP-Compressed-BER-PDSCH1  49
• CMP-Compressed-BER-PDSCH2  50
 51
• Validate correct U-Plane PRB header structure  52
• U-Plane udComphdr (per section 6.3.3.13 of [2]specification) 53
• U-Plane udCompParam (per section 6.3.3.15 of [2] 54
• Validate that the power measurements within acceptable range  55
• Difference between CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH0 and CMP-56
Compressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH0 is within ACC_PWR_PDSCH0 range. 57
• Difference between CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH1 and CMP-58
Compressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH1 is within ACC_PWR_PDSCH1 range. 59

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       135
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
• Difference between CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH2 and CMP-1
Compressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH2 is within ACC_PWR_PDSCH2 range. 2
• Validate that the EVM measurements within acceptable range  3
• Difference between CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH0 and CMP-4
Compressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH0 is less than ACC_EVM_PDSCH0 value. 5
• Difference between CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH1 and CMP-6
Compressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH1 is less than ACC_EVM_PDSCH1 value. 7
• Difference between CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH2 and CMP-8
Compressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH2 is less than ACC_EVM_PDSCH2 value. 9
• Validate that the BER Measurements show no errors  10
• CMP-Uncompressed-BER-PDSCH0 = 0 11
• CMP-Uncompressed-BER-PDSCH1 = 0 12
• CMP-Uncompressed-BER-PDSCH2 = 0 13
• CMP-Compressed-BER-PDSCH0 = 0 14
• CMP-Compressed-BER-PDSCH1 = 0 15
• CMP-Compressed-BER-PDSCH2 = 0 16
 17
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  18
1. All validation steps above are within expected ranges or correctly match the expected outcome. 19

 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Compression Static Format (SF) Block Floating Point 4
+ Selective RE Format 5
A. Test Description and Applicability 6
This test is CONDITIONALMANDATORY and shall be performed if the O-RU supports this compression format. 7
 8
The Block Floating-Point+ Selective RE Format scenario is a static format scenario that will verify DL and UL 9
correct encoding of IQ information for 2 supported bit widths: 9 bits or 14 bits.  10
 11
For this test scenario, the compression test methodology will be based on the description in section 3.2.3.3.1.  12
 13
However, on top of the test frame requirements from section 3.2.3.3.1, this test scenario also requires a test frame 14
that MUST include PRBs with a combination of allocated and empty Resource Elements in the same symb ol, to 15
verify if the O-RU properly interprets the sReMask value in the udCompParam field (user data compression 16
parameter). The measurements must be performed on the symbols that include a combination of empty and 17
allocated resource elements.  18
 19
The recommended DL test frame is based on Type 2 DMRS with 2 DMRS CDM groups without data. The 20
resource mapping model for the Resource Blocks is shown Figure 3.2.3.3-4, where both symbols #2 and #11 21
include a combination of empty and allocated Resources. 22
 23
 24
Figure 3.2.3.3-4  Frame Format Compression Test Selective RE 25
 26
The uncompressed and compressed test frames are listed in Table 3.2.3.3-6  Stimulus Files for Static Compression 27
Test  28
Stimulus File Name Description
NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-ST-DL-UNC-RE-16B Static Downlink Uncompressed (CU-plane) with both
empty and allocated RE in the same symbol
NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-ST-UL-UNC-RE-16B
Static Uplink Uncompressed (C-plane only) with both
empty and allocated RE in the same symbol

NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-ST-DL-BRE-9B Static Downlink Block Floating Point + Selective RE 9
Bits (CU-plane)
NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-ST-DL-BRE-14B Static Downlink Block Floating Point + Selective 14
Bits (CU-plane)
NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-ST-UL-BRE-9B
Static Uplink Block Floating Point 9 Bits + Selective
RE
 (C-plane only)
NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-ST-UL-BRE-14B Static Uplink Block Floating Point 14 Bits + Selective
RE (C-plane only)

 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Compression Static Format (SF) mod-compr + 20
Selective RE Format 21
A. Test Description and Applicability 22
This test is CONDITIONALMANDATORY and shall be performed if the O-RU supports this compression format. 23
 24
This modulation compression + Selective format scenario is a static format scenario, based on 3.2.3.3.2 with some 25
important differences 26
• The purpose is to validate Radio Unit’s correct interpretation of the Modulation compression parameters 27
used in the Section Extension Type =4  28
• The test will only verify Downlink correct encoding of IQ information, as the Modulation Compression 29
model is not applicable for uplink 30
• As the Modulation Compression model does not require IQ bit width to be setup, there is no need to run 31
multiple compression tests for various IQ bit widths.  32
 33
On top of the test frame requirements described above , this test scenario requires a test frame that MUST include 34
PRBs with a combination of allocated and empty Resource Elements in the same symbol, to verify if the O -RU 35
properly interprets the sReMask value in the udCompParam field (user data compression parameter).  The 36
measurements must be performed on the symbols that include a combination of empty and allocated resource 37
elements.  38
 39
The recommended DL test frame is based on Type 2 DMRS with 2 DMRS CDM gro ups without data. The 40
resource mapping model for the Resource Blocks is shown on the diagram below, where both symbols #2 and #11 41
include a combination of empty and allocated Resources. 42
 43

 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Delay Management (DLM) 34
This section describes conformance test cases for O-RU Delay Management. 35
The test setup for these test cases is shown in 2.1.  36
When performing the conformance test cases for scenario class Delay Management it does not matter which timing 37
method is used. The different timing methods are described in section 2.3.2, 2.3.3, 2.3.4 and 2.3.5 in the CUS 38
Specification [2] 39
Delay Management downlink tests will test whether the O-RU can accurately transmit data when C and U plane 40
messages are received at the extreme ends of their respective reception windows. Uplink tests will test whether the O-41
RU can accurately transmit received data to the CUSM-E when the CUSM-E transmits uplink C-Plane messages within 42
the correct uplink reception window.  It also tests whether the O-RU sends its U-Plane messages within the correct 43
reception window. 44
Figure 3.2.3.4-1 shows a simplified timing relation for the C- and U-Plane messages for downlink. 45

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       142
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
The size of the control plane reception window on the O-RU will be: (T2a_max_up +Tcp_adv_dl) – (T2a_min_up 1
+Tcp_adv_dl) = C-Plane reception window.   The start-point (before t=0) will be: T2a_max_up + Tcp_adv_dl = start of 2
C-Plane transmission window. 3
The size of the reception window for the user plane will be: T2a_max_up - T2a_min_up. The start-point (before t=0) 4
will be T2a_max_up. 5
As an example, if the values are set such as T2a_max_up = 264 µs, Tcp_adv_dl = 63 µs and T2a_min_up = 53 µs, then 6
the C-Plane reception window would be 211 µs, the start of C-plane transmission window would be 327 us, the U-plane 7
reception window would 211 µs and the start of U-plane transmission window would be 264 µs. 8
 9
 10

 13
The Delay Management uplink test cases for the O-RU will test that if the C-Plane fronthaul messages are received with 14
respective reception window then the corresponding U-Plane messages will be sent in the O-RU’s transmission 15
window. 16
Figure 3.2.3.4-2 shows a simplified timing relation for the C-Plane and U-Plane messages for uplink. 17
Similar to the downlink case, the size of the control plane reception window is T2a_max_cp_ul - T2a_min_cp_ul . The 18
start-point of (before t=0) of the C-plane reception window is T2a_max_cp_ul. 19
The size of the transmission window for the user plane will be: Ta3_max_up  - Ta3_min_up. The start-point (after t=0) 20
will be Ta3_min_up. 21
If we follow the same example values as the ones set in the downlink case, the C-plane reception window would be 211 22
µs, the start-point of the C-plane reception window would be 274 µs, the U-plane transmission window would be 70 µs 23
and the start-point of the U-plane transmission window would be 20 µs.  24

 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class DLM Test #1: Downlink – Positive testing 9
A. Test Description and Applicability 10
This test is MANDATORY. 11
 12
This test case will validate that the timing on the air interface is according to requirements specified in the 13
CUS Specification when the C-Plane and the U-Plane messages are received within the O-RU’s reception 14
windows. 15
 16
Four different test cases for downlink can be performed when the expected outcome is positive, i.e. the O-RU 17
shall be able to transmit the received U-Plane-data on the air interface.  These are shown in Figure 3.2.3.4-5.  18
Note that in these tests the C-Plane reception window may be applicable to the slot or symbol boundaries 19
depending on the Radio’s capabilities.  That is, in some radios, the C-Plane reception window is at the 20
beginning of each slot and all C-Plane messages will be sent at once within this window.  Other radios will 21
require C-Plane messages to be sent in a reception window for each symbol, In all cases U-Plane messages 22
will be sent during reception windows corresponding to each symbol regardless of whether the radio has large 23
enough buffers to store U-Plane data for multiple symbols. 24
 25

                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00

 1
Figure 3.2.3.4-5 Downlink Positive Test Cases 2
 3
1st case “C-Plane Early – U-Plane Early”; the C-Plane message is received by the O-RU at the beginning of 4
the reception window for the C-Plane messages (indicated with small green box in figure 2.5). The 5
corresponding U-Plane data is received in the beginning of the reception window for the U-Plane messages 6
(indicated with small blue box in figure), i.e. Tcp_adv_dl later. 7
2nd case “C-Plane Early – U-Plane Late”; the C-Plane message is received by the O-RU at the beginning of 8
the reception window for the C-Plane messages. The corresponding U-Plane data is received earliest Tcp_adv_dl 9
after the C-Plane message i.e. in the end of the U-Plane reception window. 10
3rd case “C-Plane Late – U-Plane Early”; the C-Plane message is received by the O-RU at the end of the 11
reception window for the C-Plane messages.  The corresponding U-Plane data is received earliest Tcp_adv_dl 12
after the C-Plane message i.e. in the end of the reception window. 13
4th case “C-Plane Late – U-Plane Late”; this case is greyed out in the figure since it will in practice be the 14
same case as number 3, the U-Plane message cannot be received later than it is in case 3. 15
 16
 17
B. Test Entrance Criteria 18
The O-RU must have a conducted antenna port (or TAB connector) to be connected to a signal analyzer.  The 19
reception windows will be calculated and used by the CUSM-E based on the delay parameters reported by the 20
radio on the M-Plane. 21
 22
C. Test Methodology 23
 24
a. Initial Conditions 25
Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation 26
using M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1. Connect the RF Signal 27

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       146
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
Analyzer to the O-RU antenna port. Determine the correct reception windows the radio claims to 1
support using delay management parameters repowered by the radio, 2
b. Procedure 3
Configure the CUSM-ECUSM-E to send C-Plane and U-Plane messages so these messages are received 4
within the reception windows for respective plane according to the three cases (1..3) described in figure 5
above. NOTE: Make sure that the C-Plane message is received at least Tcp_adv_dl earlier then the 6
corresponding U-Plane message(s) by the O-RU. 7
 8
On the RF-signal-analyzer observe the received signal and compare the decoded data on the selected 9
test symbol to the send PN23 sequence for that symbol. 10
 11
D. Pass/Fail Criteria (expected result) 12
The test passes if the received data matches the transmitted data. 13
 14
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class DLM Test #2: Uplink – Positive testing 15
A. Purpose and Description  16
This test is MANDATORY. 17
 18
This test case will validate that the transmission of the U-Plane data in uplink direction are transmitted correctly by 19
the O-RU within its transmission window.  The CUSM-E will send C-Plane messages at both ends of the C-Plane 20
reception window specified by the radio using the M-Plane (Two tests).  The C-Plane messages will describe a test 21
frame as shown above.  The frame will have one designated symbol in each slot (not containing DMRS 22
information).  The C-Plane message will ask the radio to send that symbol’s data from each slot. 23
 24
After the correct C-Plane messages are sent the CUSM-E will trigger the signal generator to send a valid test signal 25
to the radio’s RF port.  This signal will contain a new, known PN23 sequence in the same symbol (per slot) 26
designated by the C-Plane messages. 27
 28
The positive test outcome for these uplink test cases is that the corresponding U-Plane data for a specific C-Plane 29
message is transmitted within the O-RU’s transmission window IF the C-Plane message was received within the O-30
RU’s reception window as shown in Figure 3.2.3.4-6 31
.  The data will be transmitted to the radio by an external signal generator and the uplink signal will be as described 32
above.  The test data sent by the signal generator will contain a known, new PN23 sequence in one symbol of each 33
slot.  The CUSM-E will expect to receive the same data for the correct symbol in each slot. 34
t=0
T2a_max_cp_ul
T2a_min_cp_ul
Ta3_max_up_dl
Ta3_min_up_dl
O-RU rec. win. C-plane
O-RU tr. win. U-plane

The O-RU must have a conducted antenna port (or TAB connector) to be connected to a signal analyzer.   11
 12
C. Test Methodology 13
a. Initial Conditions 14
Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation using 15
M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1. Connect the RF Signal Generator to the O-16
RU antenna port. 17
b. Procedure 18
Configure the CUSM-E to send C-Plane so these messages are received within the reception windows 19
according to the two cases (1..2) described in figure above.  After these messages are sent a trigger signal will 20
be sent to the signal generator instructing it to send the correct RF test frame at t=0. 21
 22
The CUSM-should receive U-Plane messages on the front haul interface during the uplink transmission 23
window described by the radio over the M-Plane. 24
 25
 26
D. Pass/Fail Criteria (expected result) 27
The test case is passed if the correct data is received at CUSM-E in the correct time window. 28

This test is MANDATORY. 32
 33
This test case will validate that the O-RU will correctly increment relevant M-Plane counters if C-Plane and/or U-34
Plane messages are not received within the respective O-RU reception windows. 35
 36

if C-Plane and/or U-Plane messages are not received within the respective O-RU reception windows.  There are 38

test cases defined for this Downlink test and are shown in Figure 3.2.3.4-9.  The titles on each diagram show the 10
message arrival time relative to the O-RU receive window for the C-Plane and the U-Plane in that order.  For 11
instance, test 1: Too Early-OK means the C-Plane message arrived early, outside the O-RU C-Plane receive 12
window and the corresponding U-Plane message arrived correctly within the O-RU U-Plane receive window. 13

Plane messages are not received within the window on the O-RU. 15

 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Transport (TRN) 1
This test is for future study. 2
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class LAA (LAA) 3
The purpose of this section is to specify LAA test cases to test the compliance of the O -RU to the O-RAN 4
specifications. Although in LAA operation, regular C-Plane and U-Plane messages (used for operation over licensed 5
spectrum as well) are transmitted over the fronthaul interface between the O-DU and O-RU, there exist additional C-6
Plane messages that are required specifically for LAA operation over unlicensed spectrum. These additional C-Plane 7
messages are based on Section type 7 and are communicated in bo th UL and DL directions between the O-DU and O-8
RU.  9
 10
The LAA test cases only focus on LAA-related messages and operations. Other testing aspects that are applicable to 11
LAA and non-LAA technologies (e.g., delay management, beamforming, compression, etc.) ar e not considered in this 12
section; Please refer to other sections in the conformance test specification document.  13
 14
LAA considered in this section is based on 3GPP Rel. 13, which only considers downlink transmission on the 15
unlicensed spectrum (i.e., uplink transmission goes on the licensed component carrier). Hence, all the test cases in this 16
section will consider downlink operation only. This includes DL U-Plane messages and DL/UL C-Plane messages. 17
Note also that UL C-Plane messages only exist in LAA technology. 18
 19
The LAA test cases for the O-RU test if the O-RU is capable of conforming with the CUSM-E instructions in terms of: 20
1) Correctly performing the listen-before-talk (LBT) procedure (i.e., managing the congestion window). 21
2) Timely data transmission based on the spectrum sensing outcome. 22
3) Timely deferring from occupying the spectrum based on the messages received from the O -DU. 23
 24
On the other hand, testing O-RU capabilities (e.g., spectrum sensing) is out of scope of this specifications since it’s not 25
directly related to the O-RAN fronthaul interface.  26
 27
 CU-DU-LAA-CWM Test #1: LBT PDSCH Configuration and Response  28
A. Test Description and Applicability 29
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY.  The test must be executed if the O-RU supports LAA. 30
This test validates that the O-RU is capable of the following functions 31
• Correctly receiving and interpreting C-Plane messages (Section Type 7 and specifically laaMsgType 0) 32
from the TER to correctly perform LBT.  33
• Correctly receiving U-Plane data from the TER and correctly processes the data (i.e., drop it or transmit 34
it) based on the LBT outcome.  35
• Correctly performing LBT and correctly generating C-Plane messages to inform the TER about the LBT 36
outcomes using Section Type 7 and specifically laaMsgType 2. 37
 38
This test assumes that the O-RU is capable of processing Section Type 1 C-plane messages and its corresponding 39
U-plane messages. 40
It applies to the following CUS fronthaul specification sections: 41
• Section 5.4.2 for layout of C-Plane messages, in particular Section Type 1 and Section Type 7. 42
• Section 5.4.5.14 for applicability of “laaMsgType” (LAA message type) 43
• Section 5.4.5.15 for applicability of “laaMsgLen” (LAA message length) 44
• Section 5.4.5.16 for applicability of “lbtHandle” (LBT Handle) 45
• Section 5.4.5.17 for applicability of “lbtDeferFactor” (listen-before-talk defer factor) 46
• Section 5.4.5.18 for applicability of “lbtBackoffCounter” (listen-before-talk backoff counter) 47
• Section 5.4.5.19 for applicability of “lbtOffset” (listen-before-talk offset) 48
• Section 5.4.5.20 for applicability of “MCOT” (maximum channel occupancy time)  49
• Section 5.4.5.21 for applicability of “lbtMode” (LBT Mode) 50
• Section 5.4.5.22 for applicability of “lbtPdschRes” (LBT PDSCH Result)  51
• Section 5.4.5.23 for applicability of “sfStatus” (subframe status) 52

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       151
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
• Section 5.4.5.25 for applicability of “initialPartialSF” (Initial partial SF) 1
• Section 5.4.5.27 for applicability of “sfnSf” (SFN/SF End) 2
• Table 8-2 for mandatory capabilities 3
 4
The purpose of this test is to: 5
• Validate that the O-RU can correctly interpret C-Plane messages by correctly performing LBT.  6
• Validate that the O-RU can correctly construct the UL C-Plane message as specified in Section Type 7, 7
laaMsgType 2 with the following specialized fields. Specifically,  8
o Verify the laaMsgLen based on the message content. 9
o Verify that the lbtHandle parameter in the DL C-Plane message with laaMsgType 0 matches the 10
corresponding lbtHandle parameter in the UL C-Plane message with laaMsgType 2.  11
o Verify the lbtPdschRes parameter value. Set: {0, 1, 2, 3}. 12
o Verify the inParSF parameter value. Set: {0, 1} 13
o Verify the sfStatus parameter value. Set: {0, 1}.  14
o Verify the sfnSf value.  15
• Validate that the O-RU can correctly interpret U-Plane data received from the TER. 16
• Validate that the O-RU can correctly interpret C-Plane messages received from the TER.  17
 18
 19
B. Test Entrance Criteria 20
• The O-RU must support LAA 21
• The O-RU has passed M-Plane conformance and S-Plane conformance testing. 22
• The O-RU has antenna ports or TAB connectors for TER connections 23
 24
C. Test Methodology 25
The test shall be executed by the TER issuing DL C-Plane messages to the O-RU DUT to cause the O-RU to 26
execute LBT. Furthermore, the TER shall issue other U-Plane and C-Plane messages required for data 27
transmission. The TER needs to emulate external interference to allow the O-RU to do LBT and send the LBT 28
outcome to the TER based on the description in Section 5.3.4 in [2] 29
 30
a. Initial Conditions 31
• TER (Test Equipment, O-RU) is initialized and configured. 32
• The O-RU is initialized, synchronized, and configured as normal, except that it shall receive and interpret 33
Test Commands. 34
• The fronthaul Ethernet interface is up. 35
•  The O-RU is running its usual software, except that it is configured to accept and execute Test 36
Commands to enable O-RU Conformance Testing. 37
• The TER needs to emulate the external interference (e.g., Wi-Fi, other LAA cells) for the O-RU to execute 38
LBT.  39
 40
b. Procedure 41
• DL C-Plane message (LBT_PDSCH_REQ): 42
o The TER sends DL C-Plane message to configure the DUT (i.e., O-RU) to execute LBT for 43
PDSCH transmission using the configuration parameters in Table 3.2.3.6-1 below.  44
o The TER needs to run 4 consecutive LBT trials starting from run index 1 until run index 4.  45
 46
Run
Index
laaMsgType laaMsgLen lbtHandle lbtOffset lbtMode lbtDeferFactor lbtBackoffCounter MCOT
1 0 2 65,534 0 0 1 2 2
2 0 2 65,535 250 0 1 4 3
3 0 2 0 500 3 3 8 8
4 0 2 1 750 3 7 16 10
Table 3.2.3.6-1: LBT_PDSCH_REQ Configuration Parameters for Different Runs 47
 48
• DL U-Plane data: 49
o TER provides U-Plane DL data to the O-RU at the correct time based on Section 5.3.4 in [2] 50
o TER evaluates the detected U-Plane data for correctness 51

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       152
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
o Note that multiple U-Plane messages are needed for every “run” (i.e., for every MCOT). Some of 1
these U-Plane messages should get dropped by the TER based on the outcome of the LBT 2
process.  3
 4
• DL C-Plane (Section type 1): 5
o TER sends DL C-Plane message to help the DUT interpret the U-Plane data.  6
 7
• UL C-Plane message (LBT_PDSCH_RSP) verification: 8
o The TER generates RF signal to emulate that the channel is busy for the durations shown in 9
Table 3.2.3.6-2 below starting from the subframe where LBT is scheduled to start: 10
 11
Run
Index
Channel busy duration
1 0
2 2 msecs
3 2.5 msec
4 lbt-timer (see Section 13.2.2 in the M-
plane specs)
Table 3.2.3.6-2  Channel Busy Duration for Different LBT Test Runs 12
 13
o TER starts Timeout-Timer “T1”; “T1” is of a suitable length to allow the O-RU to receive the C-14
Plane and U-Plane messages, process it, and act accordingly (based on the LBT outcome and the 15
description in Section 5.3.4 in [2]) such that timer expiry is a sign of test failure.  16
 17
 18
D.  Test Requirement (expected result) 19
 20
• TER detects the U-Plane data at the correct time and for the correct duration based on Table 3.2.3.6-3 below 21
and Section 5.3.4 in [2].  22
• TER correctly detects the LBT response C-Plane messages over the fronthaul interface with results that match 23
the emulated external interference.  24
• TER detects the correct operation of the DUT based on the description in Section 5.3.4 in [2] and Table 25
3.2.3.6-3 Expected O-RU Behavior in LBT Test Cases Table 3.2.3.6-3 below: 26
 27
Run
Index
Expected behavior
1 Data transmission for 2 msecs starts after finishing initial spectrum
sensing.
2 Data transmission for 3 msecs starts after finishing spectrum sensing for
a minimum duration of 2 msecs.
3 Data transmission for 8 msecs starts after finishing spectrum sensing for
a minimum duration of 2.5 msecs.
4 No Data transmission. LBT should fail.

 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class LTE (LTE) 31
This section describes applicable LTE conformance test cases for O-RAN fronthaul interface. Since there are plenty of 32
the commonalities between the NR and LTE test cases, this section makes suitable references to the NR speci fic test 33
cases sections for the LTE scenarios whenever possible, as below.   34
• LTE UC-Plane O-DU Scenario Class Beamforming (BFM) described in clause 3.2.3.2 35
• LTE UC-Plane O-DU Scenario Class Compression (CMP) described in clause 3.2.3.3 36
• LTE UC-Plane O-DU Scenario Class Delay Management (DLM) described in clause 3.2.3.4 37

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       153
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
• LTE UC-Plane O-DU Scenario Class LAA (LAA) described in clause 3.2.3.6 1
• LTE UC-Plane O-DU Scenario Class Section Type 3 described in clause 3.2.3.8 2
 3
Subsequently, LTE-only specific generic test cases are explicitly covered in the subsections below.  One of the key 4
differences applicable for LTE specific test cases as compared to NR is due to the explicit precoding behavior supported 5
by some of the transmission modes for LTE.  6
In particular, for a Category B O-RU to implement precoding for LTE TM2-TM4, specific C-Plane instructions need to 7
be provided to the O-RU from the O-DU.  This specific aspect of the O-RAN fronthaul interface is enabled by the 8
section extension = 0x3 described in the CUS Plane specification [2]. 9
For all the test cases described in this section: 10
▪ Downlink tests will use a standard 3GPP E-TM1.1 test frame for FDD (Section 6.1.1.1 TS 36.141-1) as shown in 11
Figure 3.2.3.7-1. 12
 13
Figure 3.2.3.7-1 3GPP E-TM1.1 Test Frame for FDD 14
 15
▪ Uplink tests will use a standard 3GPP UL RMC Configuration definition for FDD (TS36.521 -1) and power levels 16
30dB above Reference Sensitivity power level as shown in Figure 3.2.3.7-2 UL RMC Configuration for FDD: 17
 18
 19
Figure 3.2.3.7-2 UL RMC Configuration for FDD 20
All the downlink tests in this section use a 3GPP test wave form LTE Test Model 1.1 (E -TM1.1) with 20 MHz 21
Bandwidth as described in TS 36.141 section 6.1.1.1.   22
There are several variations on this test signal depending on the capabilities of the radio.  If for example the radio does 23
not support the bandwidth used in the example tests as reported in the M -plane it will be up to the test developer to 24
modify their tests to adapt to the radio.  The test is expected to follow the same spirit as the tests in this document may 25
have to be changed. 26
Likewise, all uplink tests in this section use a 3GPP test waveform described in 36.141 section A1.  As with downlink 27
tests if the radio does not support this signal it is up to the test developer to modify the parameters of the test without 28
changing the spirit of the test. 29
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Base 3GPP DL 30
A. Test Description and Applicability 31
This test is MANDATORY. 32
  33
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can transmit a basic 3GPP test frame using the default parameters in 34
section 3.2.1.1.1 of this document except for only one spatial stream on one antenna will be used.   35
 36
This test is applicable for  Category A and  Category B radios (No precoding is required).   37
As per E-TM1.1 all user data in this test will be zeros.  The test will be conducted.   38

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       154
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
 1
B. Test Entrance Criteria 2
• The O-RU must support the default parameters in section 3.2.1.1.1 of this document.  The test bandwidth is 20 3
MHz Bandwidth as described by E-TM1.1. 4
• The O-RU must have a conducted antenna port to be connected to a signal analyzer.   5
• The signal analyzer must have the ability to decode the downlink shared channel. 6
 7
C. Procedure 8
a. Initial Conditions 9
• Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation using 10
M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.   11
• Connect the signal analyzer to the O-RU antenna ports or TAB connectors under test and configure the 12
analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and demodulate the transmitted signal.  13
• Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.  14
 15
b. Procedure 16
• Build an appropriate IQ signal describing the E-TM1.1 signal described above in the CUSM-E.  17
• Use the CUSM-E control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the signal. 18
Every symbol should be described by a single section (DL-SCH and DCI) using section type 1 messages.  19
• The data in the sections must be all zeros.  20
• No section type zero messages will be used for this test.  21
• Encapsulate the IQ data in U-Plane messages. Play those messages to the O-RU respecting timing 22
windows described in section 3.2.1.1.1.  Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the 23
signal analyzer and allow it to demodulate and decode the test frame. 24
 25
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  26
1. The signal measured by the signal analyzer should satisfy a basic 3GPP signal performance requirement for 27
this radio category (i.e., EVM). 28
2. The test frame received by the signal analyzer should be the same as the signal described above.  If it contains 29
all the same PRB assignments and all zero data, the test passes. 30
 31
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Extended 3GPP DL – Resource Allocation 32
A. Test Description and Applicability 33
This test is MANDATORY. 34
 35
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can accurately interpret C-Plane resource allocation messages, 36
transfer U-Plane data into the correct resource blocks and transmit this data accurately in the downlink.   37
 38
This test requires non-zero data to populate all allocated resource blocks.  This data will be a PN23 sequence with a 39
seed value of all ones. 40
 41
This test is applicable for both  Category A and  Category B radios.  42
 43
B. Test Entrance Criteria 44
• The O-RU must support the default parameters in section 3.2.1 of this document.  The test bandwidth is 20 45
MHz Bandwidth as described by E-TM1.1. 46
• The O-RU must have a conducted antenna port to be connected to a signal analyzer.   47
• The signal analyzer must have the ability to decode the downlink shared channel.  48
 49
C. Test Methodology 50
 51
a. Initial Conditions 52
• Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation 53
using M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.   54
• Connect the signal analyzer to the O-RU antenna ports or TAB connectors under test and configure the 55
analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and demodulate the transmitted signal.  56
• Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.  57

 1
b. Procedure 2
• Build an appropriate IQ signal describing the E-TM1.1 signal described above in the CUSM-E.  3
• Use the CUSM-E control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the signal. 4
Every symbol should be described by a single section (DL-SCH and DCI) using section type 1 messages.  5
• The data in the sections must be a PN23 sequence using an initial seed of all ones.  6
• No section type zero messages will be used for this test.  7
• Encapsulate the IQ data in U-Plane messages. Play those messages to the O-RU respecting timing 8
windows described in section 3.2.1.1.1.  Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the 9
signal analyzer and allow it to demodulate and decode the test frame. 10

the same PRB assignments and data the test passes. 16
