 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Extended 3GPP UL – Resource Allocation 18
A. Test Description and Applicability 19
This test is MANDATORY. 20
 21
The purpose of this test is to validate correct uplink operation of the O-RU using 3GPP Reference Sensitivity 22
level definition (Section 7.2 TS 36.141) of the Conducted Receiver Characteristic Test section (Section 7 TS 23
36.104) and power Levels at least 30 dB above Reference Sensitivity power Level described in E-TM1.1.  This 24
is to improve the likelihood that all data will be received by the radio correctly since we are not interested in 25
testing receiver sensitivity but only the O-RAN protocol compliance.  26
 27
Under those conditions, 3GPP compliant O-RU should deliver uplink U-Plane information that matches with 28
the uplink signal.  29
 30
The TER (Test Equipment, O-RU) generates an uplink signal on the antenna connector or TAB connector, 31
together with the corresponding C-Plane messages on the Fronthaul interface. The TER will capture the U-32
Plane messages generated by the DUT and validate if the payload matches with the uplink signal.   33
 34
This test is applicable for both  Category A and  Category B radios. 35
 36
It applies to the following CUS fronthaul specification sections 37
• Section 5.4.2 for layout of C-Plane message, in particular Section Type 1 38
• Section 6.3.2 for U-Plane message layout 39
• Section 6.3.3 for coding of applicable Information Elements 40
 41
B. Test Entrance Criteria 42
 43
• The O-RU must support the default parameters in section 3.2.1 of this document.  The test bandwidth is 20 44
MHz Bandwidth as described by E-TM1.1. 45
• The O-RU must have a conducted antenna port to be connected to a signal analyzer.   46
• The signal analyzer must have the ability to decode the downlink shared channel.  47
• The Radio must support the reMask parameter as notified by the M-Plane.  48
 49
C. Test Methodology 50
 51
a. Initial Conditions 52
• Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for 53
operation using M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.   54
• Connect the signal analyzer to the O-RU antenna ports or TAB connectors under test and configure 55
the analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and demodulate the 56
transmitted signal.  57

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       156
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
• Configure the source to transmit the required 3GPP test signal upon receiving a trigger signal from 1
the CUSM-ECUSM-E.  The signal source power level should be adjusted to setting used in the 2
3GPP receiver sensitivity test. 3
• Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.  4
 5
b.  Procedure 6
• Load uplink test waveform (A1-1) on the RF Signal Source  7
• Configure Signal Source to play test waveforms on 10ms frame boundaries starting when it 8
receives a trigger signal from the CUSM-E that C-Plane messages have been sent. 9
• Load C-Plane message sequence on Test Equipment O-RU (TER)  10
• Arm Test Equipment O-RU (TER) to capture DUT fronthaul messages  11
• Launch test to simultaneously play RF uplink frame and C-Plane messages  12
• Record U-Plane messages from DUT for a complete frame and the eAxC corresponding to the 13
Antenna port  14
• Extract IQ information  15
• Extract Payload 16
• Compare payload binary sequences  17
 18
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  19
1. The verdict is “Test pass” if payload binary sequences match between the uplink test frame sent to the DUT 20
and the received U-Plane data from the DUT 21
2. If any of the test conditions is not true, the verdict for the whole test is "Fail" 22
3. If the DUT does not support initial conditions, the test verdict is "Inconclusive" 23
 24
 25
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Extended using reMask parameter 3GPP DL – 26
Resource allocation 27
A. Test Description and Applicability 28
This test is MANDATORY. 29
 30
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can accurately interpret C-Plane resource allocation messages 31
with the reMask parameter set, transfer U-Plane data into the correct resource elements and transmit this data 32
accurately in the downlink.  This test is applicable for  Category A and  Category B radios (No precoding is 33
required).  The test will be conducted therefore there will be no channel distortion or interference.  It is 34
mandatory the radio pass this test to be considered O-RAN conformant. 35
 36
This test requires non-zero data to populate all allocated resource blocks.  This data will be a PN23 sequence 37
with a seed value of all ones.  This test is applicable for both  Category A and  Category B radios.  38
 39
B. Test Entrance Criteria 40
 41
• The O-RU must support the default parameters in section 3.2.1 of this document.  The test bandwidth is 20 42
MHz Bandwidth as described by E-TM1.1. 43
• The O-RU must have a conducted antenna port to be connected to a signal analyzer.   44
• The signal analyzer must have the ability to decode the downlink shared channel.  45
 46
C. Test Methodology 47
 48
a. Initial Conditions 49
• Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for 50
operation using M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.   51
• Connect the signal analyzer to the O-RU antenna ports or TAB connectors under test and configure 52
the analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and demodulate the transmitted 53
signal.  54
• Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.  55
 56
b. Procedure 57

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       157
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
• Build an appropriate IQ signal described above in the CUSM-E.   1
• Use the CUSM-E control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the signal.  2
• Every symbol should be described by a single type 1 section (DL-SCH and DCI) except symbols#6 3
which will be used for the reMask test. 4
• The data in this section must be a PN23 sequence using an initial seed of all ones. The first bits of the 5
PN23 will be in PRB1 and continue in consecutive resource elements to the end of PRB5. No section 6
type zero messages will be used for this test. 7
• Symbol number #6 should be stock data section type “D” as shown above.   8
• This test will only be using PRBs 1 through 5.  The corresponding C-Plane message will contain a 9
section IDs in a single C-Plane message describing symbol #6.  10
• The startSymbolid in the application header will be symbol #6.  11
• The C-Plane message will have one section with the reMask set to only the odd number resource 12
elements.  The number of PRBs will be 4. The start PRB will be 1. 13
• The corresponding U-Plane message will be a new PN23 Sequence (initial seed is all ones) in PRBs 1 14
through 5 of symbol #6. 15
 16
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  17
1. The signal measured by the signal analyzer should satisfy a basic 3GPP signal performance requirement for 18
this radio category (i.e., EVM). 19
2. The test frame received by the signal analyzer should only contain the same PN23 signals that were sent in 20
the U-Plane but only every other odd resource element. 21
 22
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class With Precoding (WPR) TxD 23
A. Test Description and Applicability 24
This test is MANDATORY. 25
 26
The purpose of this test is to validate the correct implementation of transmit diversity of a Category B  O-RU with 27
two antenna ports.  TxD uses TM2 (transmission Mode 2).  For TxD, information for 2 layers are packed into a 28
PRB for transmission from O-DU and are unpacked at the O-RU.  TxD precoding is applied based on the C Plane 29
configuration before RF transmission.  30
 31
Using a standard E-TM1.1 test frame for FDD the CUSM-E (i.e., O-RAN interface of the TER described in section 32
3.2.2) will generate C-Plane and U-Plane messages that require the O-RU to transmit on the downlink the standard 33
E-TM1.1 signal.   34
 35
This test is applicable for  Category B radios only. 36
 37
B. Test Entrance Criteria 38
 39
• The O-RU must support the default parameters in section 3.2.1 of this document.  The test bandwidth is 20 40
MHz Bandwidth as described by E-TM1.1. 41
• The O-RU must have two conducted antenna ports to be connected to a signal analyzer.   42
• The signal analyzer must have the ability to decode the downlink shared channel.  43
• The O-RU must support the Section Extension ExtType=3 parameter as notified by the M -Plane 44
 45
C. Test Methodology 46
 47
a. Initial Conditions 48
 49
• Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation 50
using M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.   51
• Connect the signal analyzer to the O-RU antenna ports or TAB connectors under test and configure the 52
analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and demodulate the transmitted signal.  53
• Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.  54
 55
b. Procedure 56
 57

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       158
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
• Build an appropriate IQ signal describing the E-TM1.1 signal described above in the CUSM-E.   1
• Use the CUSM-E control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the signal.  2
• Every symbol should be described by a single section (DL-SCH and DCI) using section type 1 messages. 3
No section type zero messages will be used for this test. 4
• The test configures two antenna ports hence two beamIDs needed (same beamID for user data and CRS 5
REs).  For Antenna Port 0, the beamId is contained in the C-Plane data section header, while the Antenna 6
Ports 1 (“beamIdAP1”) is contained in the ExtType=3 .  7
• Configure different eAxCs are used for each layer 8
• Configure following parameters in the Section Extension ExtType=3   9
o codebookIndex - ‘00000000’ (invalid) 10
o layerID (Layer ID for DL transmission) - layer ID that are used for DL transmission 11
o txScheme (transmission scheme) - ’txD’ 12
o numLayers (number of layers used for DL transmission) - 0001 (implies 2) 13
o crsReMask (CRS resource element mask)  14
o crsSymlNum (CRS symbol number indication) 15
o crsShift (crsShift used for DL transmission) 16
• Encapsulate the IQ data in U-Plane messages. Play those messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows 17
described in section 3.2.3.4.   18
• Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the signal analyzer and allow it to demodulate 19
and decode the test frame. 20
 21
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  22
 23
1. The signal measured by the signal analyzer should satisfy a basic 3GPP signal performance requirement for 24
this radio category (i.e., EVM). 25
2. The test frame received by the signal analyzer should be the same as the signal described above and should 26
contain all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data. 27
3. The signal relation between antenna ports or TAB connectors under test should match the expected result for 28
Tx Diversity transmission as specified in 3GPP TS 36.141 Section 4.5.1.1. 29
 30
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class With Precoding (WPR) SM 31
A. Test Description and Applicability 32
This test is MANDATORY. 33
 34
The purpose of this test is to validate the correct implementation of TM3/4 Spatial Multiplexing transmission mode 35
for a Category B O-RU with two antenna ports.  For TM3/4 Spatial Multiplexing, information for 2 layers are 36
packed into a PRB for transmission from O-DU and are unpacked at the O-RU, subsequently TM3/4 based 37
precoding is applied based on the C Plane configuration before over the air transmission.  38
 39
Using a standard E-TM1.1 test frame for FDD the CUSM-E (i.e., O-RAN interface of the TER described in section 40
3.2.2) will generate C-Plane and U-Plane messages that require the O-RU to transmit on the downlink the standard 41
E-TM1.1 signal.   42
 43
This test is applicable for  Category B radios only. 44
 45
B. Test Entrance Criteria 46
 47
• The O-RU must support the default parameters in section 3.2.1 of this document.  The test bandwidth is 20 48
MHz Bandwidth as described by E-TM1.1. 49
• The signal analyzer must have the ability to decode the downlink shared channel. 50
• The O-RU must support the Section Extension ExtType=3 parameter as notified by the M -Plane 51
• The O-RU must have at least two conducted antenna ports (or TAB connectors) to be connected to a signal 52
analyzer. 53
• The TER with connections to the O-RU must be calibrated. 54
 55
C. Test Methodology 56
 57
a. Initial Conditions 58

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       159
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
• Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation using 1
M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.   2
• Connect the signal analyzer to the O-RU antenna ports or TAB connectors under test and configure the 3
analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and demodulate the transmitted signal.  4
• Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.  5
 6
b. Procedure 7
• Build an appropriate IQ signal describing the E-TM1.1 signal described above in the CUSM-E.   8
• Use the CUSM-E control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the signal.  9
• Every symbol should be described by a single section (DL-SCH and DCI) using section type 1 messages. 10
No section type zero messages will be used for this test. 11
• The test configures two antenna ports.  Therefore, two beamIDs are needed.  The same beamID is used for 12
user data and CRS REs.   13
o For Antenna Port 0, the beamId is contained in the C-Plane data section header, while the 14
Antenna Ports 1 (“beamIdAP1”) is contained in the ExtType=3   15
• Configure following parameters in the Section Extension ExtType=3 as defined in CUS Plane Specification 16
[2].  17
o codebookIndex - indices of the precoder codebook that are used for precoding 18
o layerID (Layer ID for DL transmission) - layer ID that are used for DL transmission 19
o txScheme (transmission scheme) – set to Spatial multiplexing (no CDD) 20
o numLayers (number of layers used for DL transmission) – set to 0001 (implies 2) 21
o crsReMask (CRS resource element mask)  22
o crsSymlNum (CRS symbol number indication) 23
o crsShift (crsShift used for DL transmission) 24
 25
• Encapsulate the IQ data in U-Plane messages. Play those messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows 26
described in section 3.2.3.4.   27
• Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the signal analyzer and allow it to 28
demodulate and decode the test frame. 29
 30
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  31
1. The signal measured by the signal analyzer should satisfy a basic 3GPP signal p erformance requirement for 32
this radio category (i.e., EVM). 33
2. The test frame received by the signal analyzer should be the same as the signal described above and should 34
contain all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data. 35
3. The signal relation between antenna ports or TAB connectors under test should match the expected result for 36
MIMO transmission as specified in 3GPP TS 36.141 Section 4.5.1.1.  37
 38
 39
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Section Type 3 (ST3) 40
This section will specify the test scenarios to validate the correct decoding of C-Plane messages with section type 41
3. 42
The required test setup is shown in 2.1, where only a stimulus RF signal is applied. 43
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class ST3 Test #1: NR PRACH 44
A. Test Description and Applicability {MANDATORY} 45
This test is MANDATORY. 46
This test will validate the correct decoding of C-Plane messages containing section type 3 in 5G NR scenario by 47
testing the correct detection of a PRACH signal.  48

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       160
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
TER will setup the signal generator with a PRACH test waveform according to TS 38.141 -1 section 8.4.1 and A.6. 1
The test waveform will contain the same preamble ID repeated by following the timing offset scheme specified in 2
the figures 8.4.1.4.2-2 or 8.4.1.4.2-3 TS 38.141-1 depending on the selected PRACH format. 3
This is an example for FR1 – SCS=30 KHz – BW=100MHz – Format A3, at each occasion the time offset of the 4
same preamble index (selected according to table A.6-1 TS 38.141.1) is incremented by 100nsec starting from 0 up 5
to 800nsec (9 occasions per frame). Each PRACH occasion is at the beginnin g of the first nine used sub-frames. 6
The scheme is repeated every frame. 7
 8
 9
Figure 3.2.3.8-1 FR1 SCS 30Kz 100MHz Format A3 10
 11
According to the PRACH waveform setting, the TER will generate a corresponding sequence of C-Plane messages 12
with section type 3. By the corresponding U-Plane messages in the uplink direction, the TER will try to detect the 13
presence of the corresponding preamble at the expected timing offset and calculate the probability of detection Pd 14
according to the definition in TS38.141-1 section 8.4.1.1.  15
The signal will be exercised at only one O-RU port without adding any external AWGN power level or multipath 16
fading profile and at a power level avoiding detection errors due to poor SNR (rule described in the sub -section C 17
of this scenario class). 18
B. Test Entrance Criteria 19
O-RU must have a conducted antenna port (FR1) or TAB connector. 20
By the M-plane, TER will detect all the supported SCSs, FFT sizes and carrier bandwidths by the O -RU. To test 21
the correct interpretation of section type 3, it is assumed that only one combination of the three above parameters 22
supported by the O-RU is enough to validate the test. TER shall generate C-Plane messages according to one of the 23
PRACH formats in table A.6-1 TS 38.141. TER will choose the format either according to the manufacturer 24
declaration item D.103 “PRACH format and SCS” in TS 38.141-1 or according to the format information obtained 25
by the M-plane in case O-RU implements this feature. If more formats are claimed, only one shall be selected to 26
reduce the test time, preference will be given to a format specified in Table A.6.1 TS 38.141. It is assumed that the 27
O-RU manufacturer will support at least one in that table. For the case of long preambles, it is assumed format 0 is 28
always supported since the only one shown in the table A.6-1 TS 38.141.  29
C. Test Methodology 30
a. Initial Conditions 31
The O-RU is synchronized using G.8275.1. The signal generator is connected to the antenna port under test and 32
synchronized to the same frequency reference of the O-RU. CUSM-E has completed the activation of one carrier on 33
the O-RU port and enabled one endpoint supporting section type 3. The endpoint is configured with no data 34
compression.  35

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       161
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
b. Procedure 1
1. Set signal generator power by the following method: 2
a. Select SNR from the scenario with two RX antennas and AWGN propagation condition in table 8.4.1.5 -3
1, 8.4.1.5-2 or 8.4.1.5-3 TS 38.141-1 depending on the selected SCS and PRACH format. 4
b. Select the AWGN power level according to the configured SCS and channel bandwidth in table 5
8.4.1.4.2-1 TS 38.141-1and38.141-1and multiply by the PRACH signal bandwidth.  6
c. The output power will be given by the formula (SNR+Noise power – 3dB) rounded to the first decimal 7
digit. Extra 3dB are to compensate that SNR and noise power are selected from the two RX ports test 8
case and this test procedure requires only one O-RU port. 9
 10
For example, for the FR1 – SCS=30 KHz – BW=100MHz – Format A3 SNR is -13.5dB and noise level 11
is -70.1dBm/98.28MHz. signal generator power = -13.5dB -70.1dBm/98.28MHz*(139*30 KHz)-3dB 12
=-19.5dBm.  13
2. Set signal generator frequency offset to the central carrier frequency. PRACH will be mapped over frequency 14
according to msg1-FrequencyStart ( ) parameter equal to 0. PRACH format is set according to what TER 15
has selected from the manufacturer declarations. 16
3. Start PRACH waveform generation on the signal generator. 17
4. Configure CUSM-E to generate C-Plane section type 3 messages according to the PRACH occasions 18
described in subsection A and by the following approach: 19
a. In case of a PRACH format not including preamble repetitions, only one C-Plane message with one 20
section ID is generated per PRACH occasion. O-DU emulator will set “cpLength” field according to 21
table 6.3.3.1-2 or table 6.3.3.1-1 TS 38.211 and to the format specified in section 5.4.4.14 in [2] 22
“timeOffset” field will be set according to the PRACH occasion position inside the slot and by 23
following the format value specified section 5.4.4.12 CUS plane specification.  24
b. In case of a PRACH format with preamble repetitions, the implementation can be achieved by one C-25
Plane message with one section ID or by N number of C-Plane messages with one section ID 26
corresponding to the single PRACH repetition as described in section 5.3.2 CUS plane specification. 27
TER shall exercise both approaches and perform them in two separate test sessions by repeating steps 4 28
and 5. 29
c. In both scenarios “filterIndex” field is setup based on the PRACH format and according to table 5.9 30
of [2]and “beamId” field will set to 0 (no beamforming). 31
5. TER will perform PRACH detection per each PRACH occasion and compare the result with the expected 32
preamble ID and the expected timing offset. Since the external AWGN and fading generator are not present the 33
time error tolerance should be low, TER will use the time error tolerance in table 8.4.1.1 -1 for AWGN case 34
according to the corresponding PRACH format and PRACH SCS. A counter of successful detections is 35
incremented at every matching. The probability of detection is given by the ratio between that counter and the 36
number of the expected received PRACH occasions within the test time. 37
6. Repeat the test procedure by setting msg1-FrequencyStart ( ) parameter to the right edge of the 38
configured carrier bandwidth in order to exercise a different frequency offset number in section type 3.  39
D. Pass/Fail Criteria (expected result) 40
1. Test is pass if the probability of detection is 100%. 41
 42
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class ST3 Test #2: LTE PRACH 43
A. Test Description and Applicability  44
This test is MANDATORY. 45
This test will validate the correct decoding of C-Plane messages containing section type 3 in LTE scenario by 46
testing the correct detection of a PRACH signal.  47

TER will setup the signal generator with a PRACH test waveform according to TS 36.141 section 8.4.1 and A.6. 1
The test waveform will contain the same preamble ID repeated by the timing offset scheme specified in the figure 2
8.4.1.4.2-2 and section 8.4.1.4.2 TS 36.141. 3
According to the PRACH waveform setting, TER will generate a corresponding sequence of C-Plane messages with 4
section type 3. By the corresponding U-Plane messages in the uplink direction, TER will try to detect the presence 5
of the corresponding preamble at the expected timing offset and calculate the probability of detection Pd according 6
to the definition in TS36.141 section 8.4.1.1.  7
The signal will be exercised at only one O-RU port without adding any external AWGN power level or multipath 8
fading profile and at a power level avoiding detection errors due to poor SNR (rule described in the sub -section C of 9
this scenario class). 10
B. Test Entrance Criteria 11
O-RU must have a conducted antenna port (FR1) or TAB connector. 12
By the M-plane, TER will detect all the supported SCSs, FFT sizes and carrier bandwidths by the O -RU. To test the 13
correct interpretation of section type 3, it is assumed that only one combination of the three above parameters 14
supported by the O-RU is enough to validate the test. TER will choose the PRACH format according to the 15
manufacturer declarations or according to the format information obtained by the M -plane in case O-RU implements 16
this feature. If more formats are claimed, only one shall be selected to reduce the test time.  17
C.   Test Methodology 18
a. Initial Conditions 19
O-RU is synchronized using G.8275.1. signal generator is connected to the antenna port under test and 20
synchronized to the same frequency reference of the O-RU. CUSM-E has completed the activation of one carrier 21
on the O-RU port and enabled one endpoint supporting section type 3. The endpoint is configured wi th no data 22
compression.  23
b. Procedure 24
1. Set signal generator power by the following method: 25
a. Select SNR from the scenario with two RX antennas and AWGN propagation condition in table 8.4.1.5 -26
1 TS 36.141 depending on the selected PRACH format. 27
b. Select the AWGN power level according to the configured channel bandwidth in table 8.4.1.4.2 -1 TS 28
36.141 and multiply by the PRACH signal bandwidth.  29
c. The output power will be given by the formula (SNR+Noise power – 3dB) rounded to the first decimal 30
digit. Extra 3dB are to compensate that SNR and noise power are selected from the two RX ports test 31
case and this test procedure requires only one O-RU port. 32
For example, for the LTE 20MHz – Format 0 SNR is -13.9dB and noise level is -77.4dBm/18MHz. signal 33
generator power = -13.9dB -77.4dBm/18MHz*(839*1.25kHz)-3dB =-21.5dBm.  34
2. Set signal generator frequency offset to the central carrier frequency. PRACH will be mapped over frequency 35
according to prach-FrequencyOffset (
RA
offset PRBn ) parameter equal to 0. PRACH format is set according to what 36
TER has selected from the manufacturer declarations. 37
3. Start PRACH waveform generation on the signal generator. 38
4. Configure CUSM-E to generate C-Plane section type 3 messages according to the PRACH occasions 39
described in subsection A and by the following approach: 40
a. In case of a PRACH format not including preamble repetitions, only one C-Plane message with one 41
section ID is generated per PRACH occasion. O-DU emulator will set “cpLength” field according to table 42
6.3.3.1-2 or table 6.3.3.1-1 TS 38.211 and to the format specified in section 5.4.4.14 in [2].  The 43
timeOffset” field will be set according to the PRACH occasion position inside the slot and by following 44
the format value specified section 5.4.4.12 in [2].  45
b. In case of a PRACH format with preamble repetitions, the implementation can be achieved by one C-46
Plane message with one section ID or by N number of C-Plane messages with one section ID 47

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       163
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
corresponding to the single PRACH repetition as described in section 5.3.2  in [2].  TER shall exercise 1
both approaches and perform them in two separate test sessions by repeating steps 4 and 5 2
c. In both scenarios “filterIndex” field is setup based on the PRACH format and according to table 5.9 of [2] 3
and “beamId” field will set to 0 (no beamforming). 4
5. The TER will perform PRACH detection per each PRACH occasion and compare the result with the expected 5
preamble ID and the expected timing offset. Since the external AWGN and fading generator are not present, the 6
time error tolerance should be low.  The TER will use the time error tolerance defined in section 8.4.1.1 TS 7
36.141 for AWGN (1.04usec).  On the TER, a counter is incremented for each successful preamble detection. 8
The probability of detection is given by the ratio between that counter and the number of the expected received 9
PRACH occasions within the test time. 10
6. Repeat the test procedure by setting
RA
offset PRBn  parameter of PRACH to the right edge of the configured carrier 11
bandwidth in order to exercise a different frequency offset number in section type 3.  12
D.  Pass/Fail Criteria (expected result) 13
1. Test is pass if the probability of detection is 100%. 14

3.2.4 FR1 FDD Non-conducted OTA Signal Tests 16
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class NR testing Generic (NRG) 17
The generic tests for FR1 FDD Non-conducted OTA are the same as the tests described in section 3.2.3 FR1 FDD 18
Conducted-Signal Tests.  Only the setup for the tests are different reflecting the difference between non -conductive and 19
conductive mode testing.  20
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming (BFM)  21
This section describes the beamforming conformance testing for ORAN fronthaul interface. The tests do not aim to test 22
the O-RU beamforming performance or capabilities but to test that the O-RU under test focuses the RF energy or 23
sensitivity into a specific direction and with a specific granularity following the O -DU emulator (i.e., O-RAN interface 24
of the TER described in section 2.1) C-Plane messages.  25
Unless stated otherwise in a test case, the following statements apply to all the test c ases defined in this section: 26
• It is based on Over-the-Air (OTA) testing with a setup such as described in Section 2.1 and it may be applied to 27
any O-RU DUTs, whether the O-RU DUTs have conducted antenna ports or TAB connectors or not. 28
 29
• It applies to  Category A and  Category B O-RU DUTs. 30
 31
• It applies to LTE and/or 5G New Radio O-RU DUTs.  In both cases, precoding is not required in any test case.   32
 33
• If O-RU DUT supports Analog Beamforming (i.e. time domain beamforming), all the U -Plane test frames are 34
defined by segmenting the Stock Test A: 1 section per symbol.  The definition of this Stock Test A can be 35
found in Figure 3.2.1.1-2 and the description accompanying this Figure.  Each slot shall include multiple 36
sections (one per symbol within the slot) and only one beam at a time (i.e. one beamId at a time) and therefore 37
only one beam can be tested per slot. 38
 39
• If O-RU DUT supports Digital Beamforming (i.e. frequency domain beamforming), all the U -Plane test frames 40
are defined by segmenting the Stock Test B: 2 sections per symbol definition as shown in Figure 3.2.1.1-2.  41
Each slot shall include multiple sections (two per symbol within the slot) and only one beam per section at a 42
time (i.e. one beamId at a time) and therefore up to two different beams can be tested per slot. 43
 44
• If O-RU DUT supports multiple polarizations, it is up to the TER to determine if the testing is carried out for 45
each polarization separately or multiple polarizations at the same time. In any case, it is important to guarantee 46
that the correct eAxC_ID for the correct polarization (or polarizations) is exercised.  47
 48
• For O-RU DUT that support LTE:  49

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       164
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
o Downlink tests will use a standard 3GPP E-TM1.1 test frame for FDD (Section 6.1.1.1 TS 36.141) with 1
20MHz bandwidth (100 RB) as shown in Figure 3.2.3.2-1. 2
 3
Figure 3.2.4.2-1 E-TM1.1 FDD 20 MHz 100RB 4
If 20MHz is not supported by the O-RU DUT, then it will use the highest bandwidth supported by the O-5
RU DUT. 6
o Uplink test will use a standard 3GPP UL RMC Configuration definition for FDD (TS36.521-1) and 7
power levels at least 30dB above Reference Sensitivity power level with 20MHz bandwidth (100 RB) as 8
shown in Figure 3.2.3.2-2. 9
 10
Figure 3.2.4.2-2 UL RMC FDD 20 MHz 100 RB 11
If 20MHz is not supported by the O-RU DUT, then it will use the highest bandwidth supported by the O-12
RU DUT. 13
 14
• For O-RU DUT that support 5G NR:  15
o Downlink tests will use a standard 3GPP NR-FR1-TM1.1 test frame for FDD in [19] (Section 4.9.2 16
TS138.141-1) of the Conducted Transmitter Characteristic Test section (Section 6 TS138.141 -1) as 17
described in section 3.2.1.1. The test numerology will be preferably 30KHz subcarrier spacing and 100 18
MHz Bandwidth. If not supported, then it will use any other supported subcarrier spacing and the 19
highest bandwidth of the O-RU DUT. 20
  21
o Uplink tests will use a standard 3GPP G-FR1-A1-5 Reference Sensitivity level definition (Section 7.2 22
and Annex A TS138.141-1) of the Conducted Receiver Characteristic Test section (Section 7 TS 23
38.141) and power levels at least 30dB above Reference Sensitivity power level as described in section 24
3.2.1.1.  The test numerology will be preferably 30kHz subcarrier spacing and 100 MHz Bandwi dth, if 25
supported. Otherwise, it will use any available subcarrier space and the highest bandwidth supported 26
by the O-RU DUT. 27
  28
• Radiated tests coordinate system is based on the coordinate system defined in section 10.5.1. of  [2]. 29
 30
• The O-RU DUT must: 31
o support the default parameters in section 3.2.1.1.2 of this document. 32
o have installed current release of shipping software.  33
o be fully calibrated up to Radiated Interface Boundary (RIB). It is expected to be calibrated by O -RU 34
vendor prior to testing.  35
 36
 37
• The TER must: 38
o be capable of carrying out any signal processing required to generate and demodulate 3GPP compliant 39
waveforms. 40
o be able to calculate or extract the beam direction via OTA measurements. 41
o be able to generate and deliver signals with the required beam direction at the RIB point.  42
o be fully calibrated up to the interface where it interacts with the DUT’s RIB. For that, a known test signal 43
might be either injected by the TER into the O-RU DUT, or internally generated by the O-RU DUT, and 44
the O-RU DUT must not apply any digital or analog beam direction to the known test sig nal.  One possible 45

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       165
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
method to perform calibration uses injected C-Plane and U-Plane signals from TER into the O-RU and 1
using C-Plane messages with beamID=0. Alternatively, calibration methods for radiated test setups that are 2
described in 3GPP TR37.941 can be used. 3
 4
 5
• The O-DU emulator of the TER must: 6
o be capable of generating and sending U-Plane messages containing 3GPP test frames following the 7
corresponding Stock sectioning defined above, as well as be capable of capturing U -Plane messages and 8
extracting 3GPP test frames (i.e. IQ data) from the captured U-Plane messages. 9
o be capable of generating the C-Plane messages for, receiving, extracting and demodulating the 3GPP test 10
frames following the corresponding Stock sectioning defined above. 11
 12
• The TER might have a single test antenna if a single beam direction and polarization is measured at a time, or 13
multiple test antennas if multiple beam directions and/or polarizations are measured at the same time.  14
 15
• It is up to the TER on how to extract the beam direction and beam properties at the DUT’s RIB in 16
order to match it with the manufacturer’s declaration. 17
 18
• The user payload will be generated as PN23 with a seed of all ones. 19
 20
• It applies to the following CUS fronthaul specification sections: 21
• Section 5.4.2 for layout of C-Plane message, in particular Section Type 1 22
• Section 6.3.2 for U-Plane message layout 23
• Section 6.3.3 for coding of applicable Information Elements 24
• Section 10 for beamforming guidelines. 25
• Annex J for beamforming methods description.  26

 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – No Beamforming 28
B. Test Description and Applicability 29
This test is MANDATORY. 30
 31
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can transmit a basic 3GPP test frame with no beamforming 32
(beamId=0x000) and with one spatial stream (single eAxC). 33
 34
B. Test Entrance Criteria 35
• Manufacturers’ declaration that defines list of beam directions when O-RU DUT is operating with no 36
beamforming.  37
 38
C. Test Methodology 39
 40
a. Initial Conditions 41
• Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation using 42
M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  43
• Ensure that the test antenna/s and TER equipment is calibrated within acceptable tolerance.  44
• Place the test antenna/s to a defined position within the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.2 and configure 45
the analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and demodulate the transmitted 46
signal. 47
• Place the O-RU into a test calibrated point within the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.2. 48
• Align the O-RU to a default initial position, i.e. align the O-RU to the origin of coordinates of the declared 49
coordinate reference point and orientation in the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.2.  50
• Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.  51
 52
b. Procedure 53
a. Build an appropriate IQ signal describing the NR-FR1-TM1.1 signal described above in the O-DU 54
emulator.   55
b. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the 56
signal and the beam under test. Every symbol should be described by either one or two  sections (DL -SCH 57
and DCI) using section type 1 messages. No section type zero messages will be used for this test.  58

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       166
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
c. Encapsulate the IQ data in U-Plane messages. Play those messages to the O-RU respecting timing 1
windows described in section 3.2.1.1.2.   2
d. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the signal analyzer and allow it to 3
demodulate and decode the test frame. 4
e. Measure any metric/s that allows for extracting the transmitted beam direction from a single measurement, 5
i.e. transform-based techniques, or take as many measurements of any metric/s from multiple angles, by 6
for example rotating the O-RU, that allows for extracting beam direction from multiple measurement, i.e. 7
beam scanning. 8
 9
 10
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  11
1. The signal measured by the signal analyzer at the expected transmitted beam direction should satisfy a basic 12
3GPP signal performance requirement for this radio category (i.e., EVM).  13
2. The test frame received at the expected transmitted beam direction by the signal analyzer should be t he same as 14
the signal described above and should contain all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data.  15
3. The extracted beam direction is defined as the direction where the best metric/s were measured (i.e. best EVM, 16
power, SNR, etc.) and should match the expected beam direction for the expected no beamforming within a 17
tolerance defined by the manufacturer.  18
 19
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP UL – No Beamforming 20
A. Test Description and Applicability 21
This test is MANDATORY. 22
 23
 24
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can receive a basic 3GPP test frame with no beamforming 25
(beamId=0x000) and with one spatial stream (single eAxC). 26
 27
 28
B. Test Entrance Criteria 29
• Manufacturers’ declaration that defines list of beam directions when O-RU DUT is operating with no 30
beamforming.  31
 32
C. Test Methodology 33
 34
a. Initial Conditions 35
• Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation using 36
M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  37
• Ensure that the test antenna/s and TER equipment is calibrated within acceptable toleranc e.  38
• Place the test antenna/s to a defined position within the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.2 and configure 39
the signal source with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and generate the test signal. 40
• Place the O-RU into a test calibrated point within the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.2. 41
• Align the O-RU to a default initial position, i.e. align the O-RU to the origin of coordinates of the declared 42
coordinate reference point and orientation in the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.2.  43
• Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.  44
 45
b. Procedure 46
a. Build an appropriate test signal described above in the signal source of the TER.  47
b. Inject the test signal into the O-RU with the application of an initial beam direction. This initial beam 48
direction could be the boresight direction of the receiver antenna array.  49
c. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the 50
signal and the beam under test. Every symbol should be described by either one or two  sections (UL-51
SCH) using section type 1 messages. No section type zero messages will be used for this test.  52
d. Play the C plane messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows described in section 3.2.1.1.2 while 53
also triggering the signal source.   54
e. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the DUT, allow it to create and send the U 55
plane messages to the O-DU. 56
f. Allow the O-DU to demodulate, decode and extract the payload and to measure and extract any required 57
metric/s from the received signal that will be used later to determine what is the best received direction.  58

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       167
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
g. Repeat the previous steps but now in step b apply a different beam direction when injecting the test signal 1
into the O-RU. Repeating the process for a number of different beam directions will exercise the reception 2
of the test signal from different beam directions. This allows to determine if the O -RU is really focusing 3
the sensitivity to the correct beam direction. 4
 5
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  6
1. The test frame received at the expected beam direction by the TER/O-DU should be the same as the signal 7
described above and should contain all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data.  8
2. The extracted beam direction is defined as the direction where the best metric/s were measured (i.e. best EVM, 9
power, SNR, etc.) and should match the expected beam direction for the expected no beamforming within a 10
tolerance defined by the manufacturer.  11
 12
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Predefined-beam 13
Beamforming 14
A. Test Description and Applicability 15
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 16
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can transmit a basic 3GPP test frame with predefined -beams 17
beamforming (beamId≠0x000) and with one spatial stream (single eAxC). 18
The transmitted beam direction is measured for each indexed beam required in this measurement, see below. The 19
measured transmitted direction is compared to manufacturer-designated direction. Transmitted direction is defined 20
by extracting the beam direction. 21
Depending on the O-RU beamforming capabilities regarding the ability to generate “coarse”, “fine” and/or “beam 22
groups”, as defined in [2] Section 10.4.1.1. 23
 24
The elevation θ and azimuth Φ angles are defined as in [2] Section 10.4.1.1: 25
 26
The UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Predefined-beam Beamforming conformance test 27
might include multiple test that the O-RU must comply: 28
a. “Coarse” beamIds test:  29
If O-RU supports and reports beamIds that are defined as coarse granularity (coarse beamIds) to  the O-DU 30
emulator, the test should include the following beams: 31
1. A coarse beam with 0 degrees azimuth (Φ) and elevation (θ) angles. 32
2. A coarse beam with maximum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and maximum supported elevation angle (θ).  33
3. A coarse beam with maximum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and minimum supported elevation angle (θ). 34
4. A coarse beam with minimum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and maximum supported elevation angle (θ).  35
5. A coarse beam with minimum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and minimum supported elevation  angle (θ). 36
 37
If the O-RU only supports one azimuth (Φ) or elevation angle (θ), fewer than 5 beam angles will be measured.  38
 39
b.  “Fine” beamIds test:  40
If O-RU supports and reports beamIds that are defined as fine granularity (fine beamIds) to the O -DU 41
emulator, the test should include the following beams: 42
1. A fine beam with 0 degrees azimuth (Φ) and elevation (θ) angles. 43
2. A fine beam with maximum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and maximum supported elevation angle (θ).  44
3. A fine beam with maximum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and minimum supported elevation angle (θ). 45
4. A fine beam with minimum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and maximum supported elevation angle (θ).  46
5. A fine beam with minimum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and minimum supported elevation angle (θ).  47
 48
If the O-RU only supports one azimuth or elevation angle, fewer than 5 beam angles will be measured.  49
 50
c.  “beam-group” beamIds test:  51
If O-RU supports and reports beamIds that belong to same and different beam-groups to the O-DU emulator, 52
the test should include the following beams: 53
1. All beams that belong to a beam-group with 0 degrees azimuth (Φ) or elevation (θ) angles. 54

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       168
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
2. All beams that belong to a beam-group with maximum supported azimuth angle (Φ). 1
3. All beams that belong to a beam-group with minimum supported azimuth angle (Φ). 2
4. All beams that belong to a beam-group with maximum supported elevation angle (θ). 3
5. All beams that belong to a beam-group with minimum supported elevation angle (θ). 4
 5
If the O-RU only supports one azimuth or elevation angle, fewer than 5 beam-groups will be measured. 6
 7
 8
B. Test Entrance Criteria 9
• Manufacturers’ defined list of beam indices and their associated beam directions with antenna array 10
characteristics. 11
 12
C. Test Methodology 13
 14
a. Initial Conditions 15
• Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation using 16
M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  17
• Ensure that the test antenna/s and TER equipment is calibrated within acceptable toleranc e.  18
• Place the test antenna/s to a defined position within the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.2 and configure 19
the analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and demodulate the transmitted 20
signal. 21
• Place the O-RU into a test calibrated point within the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.2. 22
• Align the O-RU to a default initial position, i.e. align the O-RU to the origin of coordinates of the declared 23
coordinate reference point and orientation in the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.2.  24
• Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.  25
   26
b. Procedure 27
a. Build an appropriate IQ signal describing the NR-FR1-TM1.1 signal described above in the O-DU 28
emulator.   29
b. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the 30
signal and the beam under test. Every symbol should be described by either one or two  sections (DL -31
SCH and DCI) using section type 1 messages. No section type zero messages will be used for this 32
test. 33
c. Encapsulate the IQ data in U-Plane messages. Play those messages to the O-RU respecting timing 34
windows described in section 3.2.1.1.2.   35
d. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the signal analyzer and allow it to 36
demodulate and decode the test frame. 37
e. Measure any metric/s that allows for extracting the transmitted beam direction from a single 38
measurement, i.e. transform-based techniques, or take as many measurements of any metric/s from 39
multiple angles, by for example rotating the O-RU, that allows for extracting beam direction from 40
multiple measurement, i.e. beam scanning. 41
 42
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  43
1. The signal measured by the signal analyzer at the expected transmitted beam direction should satisfy a basic 44
3GPP signal performance requirement for this radio category (i.e., EVM).  45
2. The test frame received at the expected transmitted beam direction by the signal analyzer should be the same as 46
the signal described above and should contain all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data. 47
3. The extracted beam direction is defined as the direction where the best metric/s were measured (i.e. best EVM, 48
power, SNR, etc.) and should match the expected beam direction for the beam under test within a tolerance 49
defined by the manufacturer.  50
 51
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP UL – Predefined-beam 52
Beamforming 53
A. Test Description and Applicability 54
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 55
 56

Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       169

The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can receive a basic 3GPP test fram e with predefined-beams 1
beamforming (beamId≠0x000) and with one spatial stream (single eAxC).  2
 3
The same description and criteria for selecting the beams to be tested applies as in section 1.1.1.1.3 applies, but 4
instead it is related to the uplink direction.  5
 6
B. Test Entrance Criteria 7
 8
• Manufacturers’ defined list of beam indices and their associated beam directions with antenna array 9
characteristics. 10
  11
C. Test Methodology 12
 13
a. Initial Conditions 14
• Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation using 15
M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  16
• Ensure that the test antenna/s and TER equipment is calibrated within acceptable toleranc e.  17
• Place the test antenna/s to a defined position within the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.2 and configure 18
the signal source with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and generate the test signal. 19
• Place the O-RU into a test calibrated point within the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.2. 20
• Align the O-RU to a default initial position, i.e. align the O-RU to the origin of coordinates of the declared 21
coordinate reference point and orientation in the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.2.  22
Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range  23
b. Procedure 24
a. Build an appropriate test signal described above in the signal source of the TER.  25
b. Inject the test signal into the O-RU with the application of an initial beam direction. This initial beam 26
direction could be the boresight direction of the receiver antenna array.  27
c. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the 28
signal and the beam under test. Every symbol should be described by either one or two  sections (UL-29
SCH) using section type 1 messages. No section type zero messages will be used for this test.  30
d. Play the C plane messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows described in section 3.2.1.1.2 while 31
also triggering the signal source.   32
e. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the DUT, allow it to create and send the U 33
plane messages to the O-DU. 34
f. Allow the O-DU to demodulate, decode and extract the payload and to measure and extract any required 35
metric/s from the received signal that will be used later to determine what is the best received direction.  36
g. Repeat the previous steps but now in step b apply a different beam direction when injecting the test signal 37
into the O-RU. Repeating the process for a number of different beam directions will exercise the reception 38
of the test signal from different beam directions. This allows to determine if the O -RU is really focusing 39
the sensitivity to the correct beam direction. 40
 41
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  42
1. The test frame received at the expected beam direction by the TER/O-DU should be the same as the signal 43
described above and should contain all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data.  44
2. The extracted beam direction is defined as the direction where the best metric/s were measured (i.e. best EVM, 45
power, SNR, etc.) and should match the expected beam direction for the beam under test within a tolerance 46
defined by the manufacturer.  47
 48
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Weight-based Dynamic 49
Beamforming 50
A. Test Description and Applicability 51
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 52
 53
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can transmit a basic 3GPP test frame with weight -based dynamic 54
beamforming with one spatial stream (single eAxC).  55
 56

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       170
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
The transmitted beam direction is measured for each weighted beam required in this measurement, see below. The 1
measured transmitted direction is compared to manufacturer-designated direction. Transmitted direction is defined 2
by extracting the beam direction. 3
The elevation θ and azimuth Φ angles are defined as in [2] Section 10.4.1.1: 4
 5
 6
The UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Weight-based Dynamic Beamforming conformance 7
test should evaluate the following beams for the O-RU to comply: 8
a. A weight-based beam with 0 degrees azimuth (Φ) and elevation (θ) angles. 9
b. A weight-based beam with maximum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and maximum supported elevation angle 10
(θ). 11
c. A weight-based beam with maximum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and minimum supported elevation angle 12
(θ). 13
d. A weight-based beam with minimum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and maximum supported elevation angle 14
(θ). 15
e. A weight-based beam with minimum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and minimum supported elevation angle 16
(θ). 17
 18
If the O-RU only supports one azimuth (Φ) or elevation angle (θ), fewer than 5 beam angles will be measured.  19
 20
The UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Weight—based Dynamic Beamforming 21
conformance test should also evaluate the following compression methods for each of the supported beams 22
described above (a. to e.) for the O-RU to comply: 23
f. No compression method applied to the beamforming weights.  24
g. Block floating point compression method applied to the beamforming weights with 14 -bit mantissa. 25
h. Block scaling compression method applied to the beamforming weights with 14 -bit scaler. 26
i. μ-law compression method applied to the beamforming weights with 14-bit fixed width. 27
j. Beamspace compression method applied to the beamforming weights with 14 -bit scaler.  28
 29
If the O-RU does not support all the compression methods described above, fewer than 5 compression methods will 30
be measured. 31
 32
 33
B. Test Entrance Criteria 34
• Manufacturers’ defined list of frequency domain (ϕ) and/or time domain (θ) weights and their associated beam 35
directions with antenna array characteristics 36
 37
C. Test Methodology 38
 39
a. Initial Conditions 40
• Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation 41
using M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1. 42
• Ensure that the test antenna/s and TER equipment is calibrated within acceptable tolerance.  43
• Place the test antenna/s to a defined position within the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.2 and configure 44
the analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and demodulate the transmitted 45
signal. 46
• Place the O-RU into a test calibrated point within the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.2. 47
• Align the O-RU to a default initial position, i.e. align the O-RU to the origin of coordinates of the declared 48
coordinate reference point and orientation in the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.2.  49
• Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.   50
 51
b. Procedure 52
a. Build an appropriate IQ signal describing the NR-FR1-TM1.1 signal described above in the O-DU 53
emulator.   54
b. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the signal 55
and the beam under test. Every symbol should be described by one or two sections (DL -SCH and DCI) 56
using section type 1 messages, the sections in the first symbol of the slot will contain section extension 57
extType=0x01 to convey the beam weights, it is not required that the next sections contain extension type 1 58

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       171
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
since the same beam IDs will not change along the slot. If O-RU does not support a field, then its value 1
should be 0x0. No section type zero messages will be used for this test. 2
c. Encapsulate the IQ data in U-Plane messages. Play those messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows 3
described in section 3.2.1.1.1.   4
d. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the signal analyzer and allow it to 5
demodulate and decode the test frame. 6
e. Measure any metric/s that allows for extracting the transmitted beam direction from a single measurement, 7
i.e. transform-based techniques, or take as many measurements of any metric/s from multiple angles, by for 8
example rotating the O-RU, that allows for extracting beam direction from multiple measurement, i.e. beam 9
scanning. 10
 11
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  12
1. The signal measured by the signal analyzer at the expected transmitted beam direction should satisfy a basic 13
3GPP signal performance requirement for this radio category (i.e., EVM).  14
2. The test frame received at the expected transmitted beam direction by the signal analyzer should be the same as 15
the signal described above and should contain all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data.  16
3. The extracted beam direction is defined as the direction where the best metric/s were measured (i.e. best EVM, 17
power, SNR, etc.) and should match the expected beam direction for the beam under test within a tolerance 18
defined by the manufacturer.  19
 20

 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Attribute-based Dynamic 21
Beamforming 22
A. Test Description and Applicability 23
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 24
 25
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can transmit a basic 3GPP test frame with attributed-based dynamic 26
beamforming with one spatial stream (single eAxC).  27
 28
If the O-RU DUT supports Attribute based Dynamic Beamforming, this test is mandatory for the O -RU DUT to be 29
O-RAN conformant.   30
The transmitted beam direction and attributes are measured for each attributed beam required in this measurement, 31
see below. The measured transmitted direction and attributes, i.e. pointing azimuth and elevation angles, 32
beamwidths and sidelobe suppression, is compared to manufacturer-designated direction and attributes. 33
Transmitted direction and beam attributes are defined extracting the beam properties. 34
The elevation θ and azimuth Φ angles are defined as in Section 10.4.1.1 of [2]. 35
 36
 37
The UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Attribute-based Dynamic Beamforming 38
conformance test should evaluate the following beams for the O-RU to comply: 39
a. An attribute-based beam with 0 degrees azimuth (Φ) and elevation (θ) angles with any beamwidth and sidelobe 40
suppression supported by the O-RU under this beam direction. 41
b. An attribute-based beam with maximum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and maximum supported elevation angle 42
(θ) with the widest beamwidth and lowest sidelobe suppression supported for this specific beam direction . 43
c. An attribute-based beam with maximum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and minimum supported elevation angle 44
(θ) with the narrowest beamwidth and highest sidelobe suppression supported for this specific beam direction.  45
d. An attribute-based beam with minimum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and maximum supported elevation angle 46
(θ) with the widest beamwidth and lowest sidelobe suppression supported for this specific beam direction.  47
e. An attribute-based beam with minimum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and minimum supported e levation angle 48
(θ) with the narrowest beamwidth and highest sidelobe suppression supported for this specific beam direction.  49
 50
If the O-RU only supports one azimuth (Φ) or elevation angle (θ), fewer than 5 beam angles and attribute 51
configurations will be measured. 52
 53
 54
B. Test Entrance Criteria 55
• Manufacturers’ defined list of supported beam attributes that are supported by the O -RU and/or their 56
associated beam directions with antenna array characteristics. 57

C. Test Methodology 2
 3
a. Initial Conditions 4
• Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation 5

signal. 10
• Place the O-RU into a test calibrated point within the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.2. 11

coordinate reference point and orientation in the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.2.  13

a. Build an appropriate IQ signal describing the NR-FR1-TM1.1 signal described above in the O-DU 17
emulator.   18

and the beam under test. Every symbol should be described by one or two sections (DL -SCH and DCI) 20

since the same beam IDs will not change along the slot.  If O-RU does not support a field, then its value 23
should be 0x0. No section type zero messages will be used for this test. 24

described in section 3.2.1.1.1.   26

1. The signal measured at the expected beam direction by the signal analyzer should satisfy a basic 3GPP signal 35
performance requirement for this radio category (i.e., EVM). 36
2. The test frame received by the signal analyzer should be the same as the signal described above and should 37
contain all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data. 38
3. The extracted beam attributes are referenced from the measured beam direction where the best metric/s were 39
measured (i.e. best EVM, power, SNR, etc.) and should match the expected beam direction and attributes for 40
the beam under test within a tolerance defined by the manufacturer.  41

C. Test Methodology 1
 2
a. Initial Conditions 3
• Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation using 4
M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1. 5
• Ensure that the test antenna/s and TER equipment is calibrated within acceptable tolerance.  6
• Place the test antenna/s to a defined position within the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.2 and configure 7
the analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and demodulate the transmitted 8
signal. 9
• Place the O-RU into a test calibrated point within the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.2. 10
• Align the O-RU to a default initial position, i.e. align the O-RU to the origin of coordinates of the declared 11
coordinate reference point and orientation in the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.2.  12
• Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.   13
 14
b. Procedure 15
a. Build an appropriate test signal described above in the signal source of the TER.  16
b. Inject the test signal into the O-RU with the application of an initial beam direction. This initial beam 17
direction could be the boresight direction of the receiver antenna array. 18
c. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the signal 19
and the beam under test. Every symbol should be described by one or two sections (UL -SCH) using section 20
type 1 messages, the sections in the first symbol of the slot will contain section extension extType=0x02 to 21
convey the beam weights, it is not required that the next sections contain extension type 2 since the same 22
beam IDs will not change along the slot. If O-RU does not support a field, then its value should be 0x0. No 23
section type zero messages will be used for this test. 24
d. Play the C plane messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows described in section 3.2.1.1.12. while 25
also triggering the signal source.   26
e. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the DUT, allow it to create and send the U 27
plane messages to the O-DU and for the O-DU to demodulate, decode and extract the payload. 28
f. Repeat the previous steps but now in step b apply a different beam direction when injecting the test signal 29
into the O-RU. Repeating the process for a number of different beam directions will exercise the reception of 30
the test signal from different beam directions. This allows to determine if the O -RU is really focusing the 31
sensitivity to the correct beam direction with the correct beam attributes. 32
 33
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  34
1. The test frame received at the expected beam direction by the TER/O-DU should be the same as the signal 35
described above and should contain all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data.  36
2. The extracted beam attributes are referenced from the measured beam direction where the best metric/s were 37
measured (i.e. best EVM, power, SNR, etc.) and should match the expected beam direction and attributes for 38
the beam under test within a tolerance defined by the manufacturer.  39
 40
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Channel-Information-based 41
Beamforming 42
A. Test Description and Applicability 43
This Test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 44
 45
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can transmit a basic 3GPP test frame wi th channel-information-based 46
beamforming with multiple spatial streams from multiple users (i.e. MU -MIMO). 47
 48
For Category A radios, the test is for each polarization separately and consequently either different or same channel 49
models can be defined for each of the polarization. For Category B, same channel might be used for both 50
polarizations and the test might measure each polarization separately. 51
The transmitted beam direction is measured for each scenario required in this measurement.  The measured 52
transmitted direction is extracted from the decoded received signal in the TER. Transmitted direction is defined by 53
properly receiving a data transmission between the O-RU and the target User Equipment while destroying or 54
heavily attenuating the data transmission between the O-RU and the other User Equipment. 55

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       175
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
The UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Channel-Information-based Beamforming 1
conformance test should evaluate the following scenarios for the O-RU to comply and will rely on TER Channel 2
Emulation capabilities as shown in Figure 3.2.4.2-3.  3
 4
 5
 6
Figure 3.2.4.2-3 TER with Channel Emulation Capability antennas representing multiple UEs 7
 8
b. A scenario where two spatial streams, or eAxC flows, are generated for two users (one layer each) with M 9
antennas ports or TAB connectors. The O-DU will report to the O-RU via C plane messages an channel 10
estimate 𝐻 ≜  [ℎ1
1, . . . , ℎ1
𝑀, ℎ2
1, . . . , ℎ2
𝑀] ∈ ℂ2𝑥𝑀, which is the effective channel as seen by the antennas 11
representing the multiple UEs, which are spaced sufficiently such that the O-RU can effectively equalize out 12
the interference between the users.. The O-RU will calculate and apply the beamweight matrix 𝐺 ≜13
 [𝑔1
1, . . . , 𝑔1
𝑀, 𝑔2
1, . . . , 𝑔2
𝑀]  ∈ ℂ𝑀𝑥2 in such that the received signal at the users is the same as the generated in the 14
O-DU. It is up to the O-RU on how to calculate the beamforming weights, for example Zero-forcing, 15
regularized zero-forcing / MMSE, etc.   16
 17
If O-RU supports Analog Beamforming (Time Domain Beamforming), the test should not apply any analog 18
beamforming or time domain beamforming. In this case, M is not the number of antenna s ports or TAB connectors 19
but the number of TRX channels supported by the O-RU. 20
 21
B. Test Entrance Criteria 22
 23
• The O-RU must have at least two TRX chains with radiating antennas. 24
• The TER equipment must include 2 antennas with sufficient separation to emulate the 2 users such that the O-25
RU can equalize out the mutual interference of the users due to the effective MU-MIMO channel. 26
• Manufacturers’ defined list of number of TRX chains and what antennas are connected to each TRX chain.   27
 28
C. Test Methodology 29
 30
a. Initial Conditions 31
• Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation using 32
M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  33
• Ensure that the test antennas and TER equipment are calibrated within acceptable tolerance.  34
• Place the test antennas within the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.2 with sufficient separation for 35
effective MU-MIMO beamforming and configure the analyzer ports with any setup information needed to 36
synch and demodulate the MU-MIMO transmitted signal 37
• Place the O-RU into a test calibrated point within the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.2. 38

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       176
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
• Align the O-RU to a default initial position, i.e. align the O-RU to the origin of coordinates of the declared 1
coordinate reference point and orientation in the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.2.  2
• Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.   3
 4
b. Procedure 5
a. Build an appropriate IQ signal describing the NR-FR1-TM1.1 signal described above in the O-DU 6
emulator, with the data symbols for user 1 and user 2 fully overlapping in time and frequency, but with user 7
data initialized using different seeds for the PN23 sequence.  .   8
b. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the signal 9
and the scenario under test. Every symbol should be described by either one or two  sections (DL -SCH and 10
DCI) using section type 5 and 6 messages. No section type zero messages will be used for this test. 11
c. Encapsulate the IQ data in U-Plane messages. Play those messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows 12
described in section 3.2.1.1.1. 13
d. Capture the test signals and pass them through a channel emulator or apply the signal processing required 14
to emulate the channel under test using the 2 test antennas.   15
e. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the signal analyzer and allow it to 16
demodulate and decode the test frames for the 2 users. 17
 18
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  19
1. The signal measured by the signal analyzer for each of the expected UE – layer - should satisfy a basic 3GPP 20
signal performance requirement for this radio category (i.e., EVM). 21
2. The test frame received by the signal analyzer for each of the expected UE – layer - should be the same as the 22
signal described above and should contain all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data. 23
 24
 25
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP UL – Channel-Information-based 26
Beamforming 27
A. Test Description and Applicability 28
This Test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 29
 30
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can receive a basic 3GPP test frame with channel -information-based 31
beamforming with multiple spatial streams from multiple users (i.e. MU -MIMO).  32
 33
Same description and criteria for selecting the beams to be tested applies as in section 3.2.3.2.10 but considering 34
the uplink direction.  35
B. Test Entrance Criteria 36
 37
• The O-RU must have at least two TRX chains with radiating sensing antennas. 38
• The TER equipment must include 2 antennas with sufficient separation to emulate the 2 users such that the O -39
RU can equalize out the mutual interference of the users due to the effe ctive MU-MIMO channel. 40
• The TER equipment must have at least two probe transmitting antennas to radiate the test signals to the O -RU. 41
• The TER equipment must either include a channel emulator between the signal generator and the probe 42
transmitting antennas or the signal generator be capable of applying the required channel matrix being 43
emulated between the users and the O-RU.  44
• Manufacturers’ defined list of number of TRX chains and what antennas are connected to each TRX chain.   45
 46
C. Test Methodology 47
 48
a. Initial Conditions 49
• Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation 50
using M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  51
• Ensure that the test antenna/s and TER equipment is calibrated within acceptable tolerance.  52
• Place the test antenna/s to a defined position within the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.2  with sufficient 53
separation for effective MU-MIMO beamforming and configure the generator with any set-up information 54
needed to transmit the signals from the 2 UEs. 55
• Place the O-RU into a test calibrated point within the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.2. 56
• Align the O-RU to a default initial position, i.e. align the O-RU to the origin of coordinates of the declared 57
coordinate reference point and orientation in the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.2.  58

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       177
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
• Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.  1
  2
b. Procedure 3
a. Build an appropriate test signals for each of the 2 users as described above in the signal sources of the TER 4
using a different seed to initialize the PN23 data for each user. 5
b. Inject the test signals through a channel emulator or apply the required signal processing to emulate the 6
channel under test.  7
c. Radiate the resulting test signals over the air into the antennas of the O-RU. 8
d. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the signal 9
and the beam under test. Every symbol should be described by either one or two  sections (UL-SCH) using 10
section type 5 and 6. No section type zero messages will be used for this test. 11
e. Play the C plane messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows described in section 2.4. while also 12
triggering the signal source.   13
f. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the DUT, allow it to create and send the U 14
plane messages to the O-DU and for the O-DU to demodulate, decode and extract the payload for each of 15
the users. 16
 17
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  18
The test frame received by the TER/O-DU for each of the expected User – layer - should be the same as the signal 19
described above and should contain all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data.  20

A. Test Description and Applicability 15
This test is MANDATORY. 16
  17

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
