D. Test Requirement (expected result)  1
1. The signal measured by the signal analyzer should satisfy a basic 3GPP signal performance requirement for 2
this radio category (i.e., EVM). 3
2. The test frame received by the signal analyzer must be the same as the signal described above.  It must contain 4
all the same PRB assignments and PN23 sequences. 5
3. The data received from the O-RU on the uplink U-Plane must match the uplink signal sent to the DUT 6
including all the same PRB assignments and PN23 sequences. 7
4. The beamweights or magnitude and phase relation at the antenna ports (or TAB connectors) of the test signal 8
that achieves the highest performance (i.e. best EVM, power, SNR, etc.) should match with the manufacturer’s 9
declaration of the beam under test.  The procedures for test case 3.2.3.2.4 (UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class 10
Beamforming 3GPP UL – Predefined-beam Beamforming) and test case 3.2.3.2.3 (UC-Plane O-RU Scenario 11
Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Predefined-beam Beamforming) should be used. 12
5. If all of the above results are observed the test passes. 13
 14
A. Test Description and Applicability 15
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 16
 17
The purpose of this test is to ensure the O-RU can support static PRACH configuration through the M-Plane.  This 18
is an uplink only test so there is no corresponding downlink test for downlink slots.  The O-RU must report through 19
the M-Plane that it supports static configuration of PRACH.  The concept is to repeat the spirit of test 3.2.3.8.1 20
(5GNR  PRACH test) without sending any C-Plane type 3 messages and configuring the O-RU using only the M-21
Plane. 22
 23
TER will setup the signal generator with a PRACH test waveform according to TS 38.141 -1 section 8.4.1 and A.6. 24
The test waveform will contain the same preamble ID repeated by following the timi ng offset scheme specified in 25
the figures 8.4.1.4.2-2 or 8.4.1.4.2-3 TS 38.141-1 depending on the selected PRACH format. 26
This is an example for FR1 – SCS=30 KHz – BW=100MHz – Format A3 configuration index 132 (From Table 27
6.3.3.2-3, unpaired spectrum), at each occasion the time offset of the same preamble index (selected according to 28
table A.6-1 TS 38.141.1) is incremented by 100nsec starting from 0 up to 800nsec (9 occasions per frame). Each 29
PRACH occasion is at the beginning of the first nine used sub-frames. The scheme is repeated every frame. The test 30
must be conducted using a PRACH format and configuration index the radio has reported it s upports 31
 32
 33
Figure 3.2.5.1-1 FR1 SCS 30Kz 100MHz Format A3, Unpaired spectrum, configuration index 132  34
 35
According to the PRACH waveform setting, the TER will generate a corresponding sequence of M -Plane messages 36
which include the following parameters (According to the M-Plane specification and the PRACH configuration index 37
supported): 38
grouping static-prach-configuration  39
• leaf pattern-period - "Period after which static PRACH patterns are repeated. Unit: number of 40
frames." 41
• leaf guard-tone-low-re - "Number of REs occupied by the low guard tones." 42

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       205
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
• leaf num-prach-re - "Number of contiguous PRBs per data section description“ 1
• leaf guard-tone-high-re - "Number of REs occupied by the high guard tones.“ 2
• leaf sequence-duration - "Duration of single sequence of the PRACH. Sequence may be considered as 3
'single PRACH symbol’” 4
• list prach-patterns - key prach-pattern-id - "Provides a PRACH pattern. Each record in the list 5
represents a single PRACH occasion. Number of list entries cannot exceed max -prach-patterns“ 6
• leaf prach-pattern-id - "Supplementary parameter acting as key for prach-pattern list.“ 7
• leaf number-of-repetitions - "This parameter defines number of PRACH repetitions in 8
PRACH occasion, to which the section control is applicable 9
• leaf number-of-occasions - "This parameter informs how many consecutive PRACH 10
occasions is described by the PRACH Pattern” 11
• leaf re-offset – “Offset between the start of the lowest-frequency RE of the lowest frequency 12
PRB and the start of the lowest frequency RE belonging to the PRACH occasion.  The re -13
offset is configured as number of PRACH REs. 14
• list occasion-parameters – “list of cp-lengths, gp-lengths and beam-ids applicable per each 15
PRACH occasion in PRACH pattern. Note: the number of records in this list MUST be equal 16
to value of parameter number-of-occasions.“ 17
• leaf occasion-id - "Supplementary parameter acting as key in 'occasion-parameters' 18
list“ 19
• leaf cp-length - "Cyclic prefix length. See CUS-plane specification for detailed 20
description.“ 21
• leaf gp-length - "Guard period length.“ 22
• leaf beam-id  - "This parameter defines the beam pattern to be applied to the U-23
Plane data. beamId = 0 means no beamforming operation will be performed." 24
• leaf frame-number - "This parameter is an index inside the pattern-length, such that PRACH 25
occasion is happening for SFN which fulfills following equation: [SFN mod pattern-length = 26
frame-id]“ 27
• leaf sub-frame-id - "Identifier of sub-frame of the PRACH occasion. Value is interpreted in 28
the same way as subframeId field in a section description of a C-Plane message.“ 29
• leaf time-offset - "This parameter defines the time-offset from the start of the sub-frame to 30
the start of the first Cyclic Prefix of PRACH pattern" 31
 32
By the corresponding U-Plane messages in the uplink direction, the TER will try to detect the presence of the 33
corresponding preamble at the expected timing offset and calculate the probability of detection Pd according to the 34
definition in TS38.141-1 section 8.4.1.1.  35
The signal will be exercised at only one O-RU port without adding any external AWGN power level or multipath 36
fading profile and at a power level avoiding detection errors due to poor SNR (rule described in the sub -section C of 37
this scenario class). 38
The test will have the CUSM emulator configure the O-RU, through the M-Plane, with a section of time/frequency 39
resources reserved for static uplink PRACH.  The default is the PRACH configuration described in 3GPP and above but 40
the test may be conducted with changes if the radio does not support those exact configurations.  The signal source will 41
be programmed to send simulated PRACH signals in those resources.  The O -RU should receive this PRACH signal 42
and pass them through to the CUSM emulator using U-Plane messages.  Note, there will be no C-Plane messages sent 43
from the CUSM emulator and the O-RU. 44
 45
 46
B. Test Entrance Criteria 47
O-RU must have a conducted antenna port (FR1) or TAB connector. 48
By the M-plane or by manufacturer declaration, TER will detect all the supported SCSs, FFT sizes and carrier 49
bandwidths by the O-RU. It is assumed that only one combination of the three above parameters supported by the O-50
RU is enough to validate the test. TER shall generate M-Plane messages according to one of the PRACH formats in 51
table A.6-1 TS 38.141. TER will choose the format either according to the manufacturer declaration item D.103 52
“PRACH format and SCS” in TS 38.141-1 or according to the format information obtained by the M-plane in case O-53
RU implements this feature. If more formats are claimed, only one shall be selected to reduce the test time, preference 54
will be given to a format specified in Table A.6.1 TS 38.141. It is assumed that the O -RU manufacturer will support at 55
least one in that table. For the case of long preambles, it is assumed format 0 is always supported since the only one 56
shown in the table A.6-1 TS 38.141. 57
 58

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       206
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
C. Test Methodology 1
  2
a: Initial Conditions 3
Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation using M-4
Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  Connect the signal source to the O-RU antenna 5
port and configure the source to transmit the required PRACH test signal upon receiving a trigger signal from 6
the CUSM-E.   7
Implicit in this Initial set up is statically configuring O-RU with a section of time/frequency resources for static 8
PRACH signals. 9
b: Procedure 10
• Set signal generator power by the following method: 11
d. Select SNR from the scenario with two RX antennas and AWGN propagation condition in table 8.4.1.5 -12
1, 8.4.1.5-2 or 8.4.1.5-3 TS 38.141-1 depending on the selected SCS and PRACH format. 13
e. Select the AWGN power level according to the configured SCS and channel bandwidth in table 14
8.4.1.4.2-1 TS 38.141-1and38.141-1and multiply by the PRACH signal bandwidth.  15
f. The output power will be given by the formula (SNR+Noise power – 3dB) rounded to the first decimal 16
digit. Extra 3dB are to compensate that SNR and noise power are selected from the two RX ports test 17
case and this test procedure requires only one O-RU port. 18
 19
For example, for the FR1 – SCS=30 KHz – BW=100MHz – Format A3 SNR is -13.5dB and noise level 20
is -70.1dBm/98.28MHz. signal generator power = -13.5dB -70.1dBm/98.28MHz*(139*30 KHz)-3dB 21
=-19.5dBm.  22
• Set signal generator frequency offset to the central carrier frequency. PRACH will be mapped 23
over frequency according to msg1-FrequencyStart ( ) parameter equal to 0. PRACH format is 24
set according to what TER has selected from the manufacturer declarations. 25
• Start PRACH waveform generation on the signal generator. 26
• TER will perform PRACH detection per each PRACH occasion and compare the result with the 27
expected preamble ID and the expected timing offset. Since the external AWGN and fading 28
generator are not present the time error tolerance should be low, TER will use the time error 29
tolerance in table 8.4.1.1-1 for AWGN case according to the corresponding PRACH format and 30
PRACH SCS. A counter of successful detections is incremented at every matching. The probability 31
of detection is given by the ratio between that counter and the number of the expected received 32
PRACH occasions within the test time. 33
• Repeat the test procedure by setting msg1-FrequencyStart ( ) parameter to the right edge of 34
the configured carrier bandwidth in order to exercise a different frequency offset number 35
  36
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  37
Test is pass if the probability of detection is 100%. 38
 39
 40
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming (BFM)  41
This section describes the beamforming conformance testing for ORAN fronthaul interface. The tests do not aim to test 42
the O-RU beamforming performance or capabilities but to test that the O-RU under test focuses the RF energy or 43
sensitivity into a specific direction and with a specific granularity following the O -DU emulator (i.e., O-RAN interface 44
of the TER described in section 2.1) C-Plane messages.  45
Unless stated otherwise in a test case, the following statements apply to all the test cases defined in this section: 46
• It is based on conducted testing with a setup such as described in Section 2.1 and it only applies to O-RU DUTs 47
that have conducted antenna ports or TAB connectors. 48
 49
start
RAn
start
RAn

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       207
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
• It applies to  Category A and  Category B O-RU DUTs. 1
 2
• It applies to LTE and/or 5G New Radio O-RU DUTs.  In both cases, precoding is not required in any test case.   3
 4
• If O-RU DUT supports Analog Beamforming (i.e. time domain beamforming), all the U-Plane test frames are 5
defined by segmenting the Stock Test A: 1 section per symbol.  The definition of this Stock Test A can be 6
found in Figure 3.2.1.1-2 and the description accompanying this Figure.  Each slot shall include multiple 7
sections (one per symbol within the slot) and only one beam at a time (i.e. one beamId at a time) and theref ore 8
only one beam can be tested per slot. 9
 10
• If O-RU DUT supports Digital Beamforming (i.e. frequency domain beamforming), all the U-Plane test frames 11
are defined by segmenting the Stock Test B: 2 sections per symbol definition as shown in Figure 3.2.1.1-2.  12
Each slot shall include multiple sections (two per symbol within the slot) and only one beam per section at a 13
time (i.e. one beamId at a time) and therefore up to two different beams can be tested per slot. 14
 15
• If O-RU DUT supports multiple polarizations, it is up to the TER to determine if the testing is carried out for 16
each polarization separately or multiple polarizations at the same time. In any case, it is important to guarantee 17
that the correct eAxC_ID for the correct polarization (or polarizations) is exercised.  18
 19
• For O-RU DUT that support TDD:  20
• The tests may use any combination of Downlink and Uplink standard 3GPP LTE test frames found in 21
Section 6.1.1.1 of TS 36.141-1. 22
• For example, the following TDD test waveform could be used for this test:  23
o 20MHz bandwidth with 100 RBs assigned 24
o Uplink/Downlink Configuration set to 3 25
o Special Subframe Configuration set to 8 26
o DwPTS Length set to 11 Symbols 27
o GP lengths set to 1 Symbol 28
o UpPTS Length set to 2 Symbols. 29
• The full test radio frame is shown in Figure 3.2.5.2-1. 30
 31
Figure 3.2.5.2-1 Combined DL and UL TDD 20 MHz 100 RB 32
If 20MHz is not supported by the O-RU DUT, then it will use the highest bandwidth supported by the O-33
RU DUT. 34
 35
• For O-RU DUT that support 5G NR:  36
o The tests will use a combination of Downlink and Uplink standard 3GPP 5G NR test frames. See 37
figure . 38
o The Downlink part of the radio frame will use a standard 3GPP NR-FR1-TM1.1 test frame for TDD in 39
[19] (Section 4.9.2 TS138.141-1) of the Conducted Transmitter Characteristic Test section (Section 6 40
TS138.141-1) as described in section 3.2.1.1. The test numerology will be preferably 30KHz 41
subcarrier spacing and 100 MHz Bandwidth. If not supported, then it will use any other supported 42
subcarrier spacing and the highest bandwidth of the O-RU DUT. 43
o The Uplink part of the radio frame will use a standard 3GPP Reference Sensitivity level definition 44
(Section 7.2 and Annex A TS138.141-1) of the Conducted Receiver Characteristic Test section 45
(Section 7 TS 38.141) and power levels at least 30dB above Reference Sensitivity power level as 46
described in section 3.2.1.1.  The test numerology will be preferably 30kHz subcarrier spacing and 100 47
MHz Bandwidth, if supported. Otherwise, it will use any available subcarrier space and the highest 48
bandwidth supported by the O-RU DUT. 49
o The Downlink symbols are allocated at slots 0 to 7 and 10 to 17.  50
o The Uplink symbols are allocated at slots 7 to 9 and 17 to 19. 51

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       208
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
o Note that slots 7 and 17 have symbols allocated for Downlink, symbols 0 to 5, some other symbols 1
assigned as Guard Period where no signal is transmitted or expected to be received, symbols 6 to 9, 2
and finally some other symbols allocated for Uplink, symbols 10 to 13. 3
 4
• The O-RU DUT must: 5
o support the default parameters in section 3.2.1.1.1 of this document. 6
o have installed current release of shipping software.  7
o have at least two conducted antenna ports (or TAB connectors) to be connected to a signal analyzer. 8
Likewise, it must have at least two conducted antenna ports or TAB connectors to be connected to a signal 9
generator. 10
o be fully calibrated up to the antenna ports or (TAB connectors) (if needed). It is expected to be calibrated 11
by O-RU vendor prior to testing.  12
 13
 14
• The TER must: 15
o be capable of carrying out any signal processing required to generate and demodulate 3GPP compliant 16
waveforms. 17
o be able to calculate or extract beamweights (or magnitude and phase relations) between antenna ports or 18
TAB connectors. Alternatively, and if the O-RU DUT manufacturer provides the list of beam directions 19
supported by the O-RU DUT, TER might calculate or extract the beam direction instead of the 20
beamweights. 21
o be able to generate and deliver signals with the required beamweights (or magnitude a nd phase relations) at 22
the antenna ports or TAB connectors.  23
o be fully calibrated up to the interfaces where is connected to the O-RU DUT antenna ports (or TAB 24
connectors). For that, a known test signal might be either injected by the TER into the O -RU DUT, or 25
internally generated by the O-RU DUT, and the O-RU DUT must not apply any digital or analog 26
beamweights to the known test signal.  One possible method to perform calibration uses injected C-Plane 27
and U-Plane signals from TER into the O-RU and using C-Plane messages with beamID=0.   28
 29
 30
• The O-DU emulator of the TER must: 31
o be capable of generating and sending U-Plane messages containing 3GPP test frames following the 32
corresponding Stock sectioning defined above, as well as be capable of capturing U-Plane messages and 33
extracting 3GPP test frames (i.e. IQ data) from the captured U-Plane messages. 34
o be capable of generating the C-Plane messages for, receiving, extracting and demodulating the 3GPP test 35
frames following the corresponding Stock sectioning defined above. 36
 37
• The TER might have less testing ports than the O-RU DUT conducted antenna ports (or TAB connectors) if 38
testing is carried out sequentially; or as many antenna ports as the number of conducted antenna ports (or TAB 39
connectors) under test if testing is carried out simultaneously. 40
 41
• It is up to the TER on how to extract the beamweights (or magnitude and phase relation) between the antenna 42
ports or TAB connectors, or the beam direction / properties, in order to match it with the manufacturer’s 43
declaration. 44
 45
• The user payload will be generated as PN23 with a seed of all ones. 46
 47
• It applies to the following CUS fronthaul specification sections: 48
• Section 5.4.2 for layout of C-Plane message, in particular Section Type 1 49
• Section 6.3.2 for U-Plane message layout 50
• Section 6.3.3 for coding of applicable Information Elements 51
• Section 10 for beamforming guidelines. 52
• Annex J for beamforming methods description.  53
 54
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – No Beamforming 55
A. Test Description and Applicability 56
This test is MANDATORY. 57
 58

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       209
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can transmit a basic 3GPP test frame with no beamforming 1
(beamId=0x000) and with one spatial stream (single eAxC). 2
 3
B. Test Entrance Criteria 4
• Manufacturers’ declaration that defines list of magnitude and phase relation (or beamweights) between 5
antenna ports or TAB connectors and/or beam directions with antenna array characteristics when O -RU DUT 6
is operating with no beamforming.  7
 8
C. Test Methodology 9
 10
a. Initial Conditions 11
• Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation 12
using M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  13
• Ensure that the RF connections and cables are calibrated so there is phase coherence between the antenna 14
ports (or TAB connectors) within acceptable tolerance.  15
• Connect the signal analyzer to the O-RU antenna ports or TAB connectors that belong to the beam under 16
test and configure the analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and demodulate the 17
transmitted signal.   18
• Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.  19
 20
b. Procedure 21
a. Build an appropriate IQ signal described above in the O-DU emulator.   22
b. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the 23
signal and the beam under test. Every symbol should be described by either one or two sections (DL-SCH 24
and DCI) using section type 1 messages.  Section type zero messages will be used to signal Guard Period 25
resources in the test waveform. 26
c. Encapsulate the IQ data in U-Plane messages. Play those messages to the O-RU respecting timing 27
windows described in section3.2.1.1.1.   28
d. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the signal analyzer and allow it to 29
demodulate and decode the test frame. 30
e. Extract either the beamweights, or magnitude and phase relation, or beam direction from the measured 31
signal. 32
 33
 34
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  35
1. The signal measured by the signal analyzer should satisfy a basic 3GPP signal performance requirement for 36
this radio category (i.e., EVM). 37
2. The test frame received by the signal analyzer should be the same as the signal described above and should 38
contain all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data. 39
3. The signal relation (i.e. beamweights, or magnitude and phase relation) between antenna ports or TAB 40
connectors, or the extracted beam direction, should match the expected relation, or beam direction, for the 41
expected no beamforming within a tolerance defined by the manufacturer.  42
 43
 44
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP UL – No Beamforming 45
A. Test Description and Applicability 46
This test is MANDATORY. 47
 48
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can receive a basic 3GPP test frame with no beamforming 49
(beamId=0x000) and with one spatial stream (single eAxC). 50
 51
B. Test Entrance Criteria 52
• Manufacturers’ declaration that defines list of magnitude and phase relation (or beamweights) between antenna 53
ports or TAB connectors and/or beam directions with antenna array characteristics when O -RU DUT is 54
operating with no beamforming.  55
 56
C. Test Methodology 57
 58
a. Initial Conditions 59

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       210
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
• Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation 1
using M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1. 2
• Ensure that the RF connections and cables are calibrated so there is phase coherence between the antenna 3
ports (or TAB connectors) within acceptable tolerance.  4
• Connect the signal source to the O-RU antenna ports or TAB connectors that belong to the beam under test 5
and configure the source with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and generate the test 6
signal.  7
• Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.   8
 9
b. Procedure 10
a. Build an appropriate test signal described above in the signal source of the TER.  11
b. Inject the test signal into the O-RU with the application of an initial set of beamweights, or equivalently 12
magnitude and phase relation, between all the TER ports connected to the antenna ports (or TAB 13
connectors) to emulate the phase and magnitude difference “seen” by the antenna elements under test . For 14
example, initial beamweights could be set to be “all equal” (i.e. no beamforming).  15
c. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the 16
signal and the beam under test. Every symbol should be described by either one or two  sections (UL-17
SCH) using section type 1 messages. Section type zero messages will be used to signal Guard Periods in 18
the test waveform. 19
d. Play the C plane messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows described in section 3.2.1.1.1. while 20
also triggering the signal source.   21
e. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the DUT, allow it to create and send the U 22
plane messages to the O-DU and for the O-DU to demodulate, decode and extract the payload. 23
f. Repeat the previous steps but now in step b apply a different set of beamweights or phase relation between 24
all the antenna ports (or TAB connectors) when injecting the test signal into the O-RU. For example, 25
repeating the process for a number of different beamweights will simulate the reception of the test signal 26
from different beam directions. This allows to determine if the O-RU is really focusing the sensitivity to 27
the correct beam direction. 28
 29
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  30
1. The test frame received by the TER/O-DU should be the same as the signal described above and should 31
contain all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data. 32
2. The beamweights or magnitude and phase relation at the antenna ports (or TAB connectors) of the test signal 33
that achieves the highest performance (i.e. best EVM, power, SNR, etc.) should match with the manufacturer’s 34
declaration of the phase relation expected for no beamforming. 35
 36
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Predefined-beam 37
Beamforming 38
A. Test Description and Applicability 39
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 40
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can transmit a basic 3GPP test frame with predefined -beams 41
beamforming (beamId≠0x000) and with one spatial stream (single eAxC). 42
The transmitted beam direction is measured for each indexed beam required in this measurement, see below. The 43
measured transmitted direction is compared to manufacturer-designated direction. Transmitted direction could be 44
defined by the phase relation between the antenna ports or TAB connectors under test, or directly by extracting the 45
beam direction. 46
Depending on the O-RU beamforming capabilities regarding the ability to generate “coarse”, “fine” and /or “beam 47
groups”, as defined in [2] Section 10.4.1.1. 48
 49
The elevation θ and azimuth Φ angles are defined as in [2] Section 10.4.1.1: 50
 51
The UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Predefined-beam Beamforming conformance test 52
might include multiple test that the O-RU must comply: 53
 54
a. “Coarse” beamIds test:  55

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       211
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
If O-RU supports and reports beamIds that are defined as coarse granularity (coarse beamIds) to the O -DU 1
emulator, the test should include the following beams: 2
1. A coarse beam with 0 degrees azimuth (Φ) and elevation (θ) angles. 3
2. A coarse beam with maximum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and maximum supported elevation angle (θ). 4
3. A coarse beam with maximum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and minimum supported elevation angle (θ).  5
4. A coarse beam with minimum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and maximum supported el evation angle (θ). 6
5. A coarse beam with minimum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and minimum supported elevation angle (θ).  7
 8
If the O-RU only supports one azimuth (Φ) or elevation angle (θ), fewer than 5 beam angles will be measured.  9
 10
b.  “Fine” beamIds test:  11
If O-RU supports and reports beamIds that are defined as fine granularity (fine beamIds) to the O-DU 12
emulator, the test should include the following beams: 13
1. A fine beam with 0 degrees azimuth (Φ) and elevation (θ) angles. 14
2. A fine beam with maximum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and maximum supported elevation angle (θ).  15
3. A fine beam with maximum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and minimum supported elevation angle (θ).  16
4. A fine beam with minimum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and maximum supported e levation angle (θ). 17
5. A fine beam with minimum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and minimum supported elevation angle (θ).  18
 19
If the O-RU only supports one azimuth or elevation angle, fewer than 5 beam angles will be measured.  20
 21
c.  “beam-group” beamIds test:  22
If O-RU supports and reports beamIds that belong to same and different beam-groups to the O-DU emulator, 23
the test should include the following beams: 24
1. All beams that belong to a beam-group with 0 degrees azimuth (Φ) or elevation (θ) angles. 25
2. All beams that belong to a beam-group with maximum supported azimuth angle (Φ). 26
3. All beams that belong to a beam-group with minimum supported azimuth angle (Φ). 27
4. All beams that belong to a beam-group with maximum supported elevation angle (θ). 28
5. All beams that belong to a beam-group with minimum supported elevation angle (θ). 29
 30
If the O-RU only supports one azimuth or elevation angle, fewer than 5 beam-groups will be measured. 31
 32
 33
B. Test Entrance Criteria 34
• Manufacturers’ defined list of beam indices and their associated magnitude and phase relation between antenna 35
ports or TAB connectors and/or beam directions with antenna array characteristics.  36
 37
C. Test Methodology 38
 39
a. Initial Conditions 40
• Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation using 41
M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  42
• Ensure that the RF connections and cables are calibrated so there is phase coherence between the antenna 43
ports (or TAB connectors) within acceptable tolerance.   44
• Connect the signal analyzer to the O-RU antenna ports or TAB connectors that belong to the beam under 45
test and configure the analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and demodulate the 46
transmitted signal.  47
• Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range. 48
   49
b. Procedure 50
a. Build an appropriate IQ signal described above in the O-DU emulator.   51
b. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the signal 52
and the beam under test. Every symbol should be described by either one or two sections (DL -SCH and 53
DCI) using section type 1 messages.  Section type zero messages will be used to signal Guard Period 54
resources in the test waveform. 55

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       212
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
c. Encapsulate the IQ data in U-Plane messages. Play those messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows 1
described in section 3.2.1.1.1.   2
d. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the signal analyzer and allow it to demodulate 3
and decode the test frame. 4
e. Extract either the beamweights, or magnitude and phase relation, or beam direction from the measured 5
signal. 6
 7
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  8
1. The signal measured by the signal analyzer should satisfy a basic 3GPP signal performance requirement for 9
this radio category (i.e., EVM). 10
2. The test frame received by the signal analyzer should be the same as the signal described above and should 11
contain all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data. 12
3. The signal relation (i.e. beamweights, or magnitude and phase relation) between antenna ports or TAB 13
connectors, or the extracted beam direction, should match the expected relation, or beam direction, 14
corresponding to the beam under test within a tolerance defined by the manufacturer.  15
 16
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP UL – Predefined-beam 17
Beamforming 18
A. Test Description and Applicability 19
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 20
 21
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can receive a basic 3GPP test frame with predefined -beams 22
beamforming (beamId≠0x000) and with one spatial stream (single eAxC).  23
 24
The same description and criteria for selecting the beams to be tested applies as in section 3.2.3.2.3 applies, but 25
instead it is related to the uplink direction.  26
 27
B. Test Entrance Criteria 28
 29
• Manufacturers’ defined list of beam indices and their associated magnitude and phase relation between antenna 30
ports or TAB connectors and/or beam directions with antenna array characteristics.  31
  32
C. Test Methodology 33
 34
a. Initial Conditions 35
• Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation using 36
M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1. 37
• Ensure that the RF connections and cables are calibrated so there is phase coherence between the antenna 38
ports (or TAB connectors) within acceptable tolerance.    39
• Connect the signal source to the O-RU antenna ports or TAB connectors that belong to the beam under test 40
and configure the source with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and generate the test 41
signal.  42
• Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.   43
 44
b. Procedure 45
a. Build an appropriate test signal described above in the signal source of the TER. 46
b. Inject the test signal into the O-RU with the application of an initial set of beamweights, or equivalently 47
magnitude and phase relation, between all the TER ports connected to the antenna ports (or TAB 48
connectors) to emulate the phase and magnitude difference “seen” by the antenna elements under test . For 49
example, initial beamweights could be set to be “all equal” (i.e. no beamforming).    50
c. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the 51
signal and the beam under test. Every symbol should be described by either one or two  sections (UL-52
SCH) using section type 1 messages. Section type zero messages will be used to signal Guard Period 53
resources in the test waveform. 54
d. Play the C plane messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows described in section 3.2.1.1.1. while 55
also triggering the signal source.   56

e. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the DUT, allow it to create and send the U 1
plane messages to the O-DU and for the O-DU to demodulate, decode and extract the payload. 2
f. Repeat the previous steps but now in step b apply a different set of beamweights or phase relation between 3
all the antenna ports (or TAB connectors) when injecting the test signal into the O-RU. For example, 4
repeating the process for a number of different beamweights will simulate the reception of the test signal 5

 8

all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data. 11
2. The beamweights or magnitude and phase relation at the antenna ports (or TAB connectors) of the test signal 12
that achieves the highest performance (i.e. best EVM, power, SNR, etc.) should match with the manufacturer’s 13
declaration of the beam under test. 14

 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Weight-based Dynamic 16
Beamforming 17
A. Test Description and Applicability 18
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 19
 20
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can transmit a basic 3GPP test frame with weight -based dynamic 21
beamforming with one spatial stream (single eAxC).  22
 23
The transmitted beam direction is measured for each weighted beam required in this measurement, see below. The 24
measured transmitted direction is compared to manufacturer-designated direction. Transmitted direction could be 25
defined by the phase relation between the antenna ports or TAB connectors under test, or by directly extracting the 26
beam direction. 27
The elevation θ and azimuth Φ angles are defined as in [2] Section 10.4.1.1: 28
 29
 30
The UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Weight-based Dynamic Beamforming conformance 31
test should evaluate the following beams for the O-RU to comply: 32
 33
a. A weight-based beam with 0 degrees azimuth (Φ) and elevation (θ) angles. 34
b. A weight-based beam with maximum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and maximum supported elevation 35
angle (θ). 36
c. A weight-based beam with maximum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and minimum supported elevation angle 37
(θ). 38
d. A weight-based beam with minimum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and maximum supported elevation angle 39
(θ). 40
e. A weight-based beam with minimum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and minimum supported elevation angle 41
(θ). 42
 43
If the O-RU only supports one azimuth (Φ) or elevation angle (θ), fewer than 5 beam angles will be measured.  44
 45
The UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Weight—based Dynamic Beamforming 46
conformance test should also evaluate the following compression methods for each of the supported beams 47
described above (a. to e.) for the O-RU to comply: 48
a. No compression method applied to the beamforming weights.  49
b. Block floating point compression method applied to the beamforming weights with 14 -bit mantissa. 50
c. Block scaling compression method applied to the beamforming weights with 14 -bit scaler. 51
d. μ-law compression method applied to the beamforming weights with 14-bit fixed width. 52
e. Beamspace compression method applied to the beamforming weights with 14 -bit scaler.  53
 54
If the O-RU does not support all the compression methods described above, fewer than 5 compression methods will 55
be measured. 56
 57

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       214
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
 1
B. Test Entrance Criteria 2
• Manufacturers’ defined list of frequency domain (ϕ) and or time domain (θ) weights for each supported beam, 3
or alternatively, list of gain and phase relation, or complex beam weights, between antenna ports or TAB 4
connectors for each supported beam . Also, the O-RU needs to report to the O-DU the antenna array 5
characteristics. 6
 7
C. Test Methodology 8
 9
a. Initial Conditions 10
• Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation 11
using M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1. 12
• Ensure that the RF connections and cables are calibrated so there is phase coherence between the antenna 13
ports (or TAB connectors) within acceptable tolerance.    14
• Connect the signal analyzer to the O-RU antenna ports or TAB connectors that belong to the beam under 15
test and configure the analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and demodulate the 16
transmitted signal.  17
• Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.   18
 19
b. Procedure 20
a. Build an appropriate IQ signal described above in the O-DU emulator.   21
b. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the signal 22
and the beam under test. Every symbol should be described by one or two sections (DL-SCH and DCI) 23
using section type 1 messages, the sections in the first symbol of the slot will contain section extension 24
extType=0x01 to convey the beam weights, it is not required that the next sections contain extension type 1 25
since the same beam IDs will not change along the slot. If O-RU does not support a field, then its value 26
should be 0x0. Section type zero messages will be used to signal Guard Period resources in the test 27
waveform. 28
c. Encapsulate the IQ data in U-Plane messages. Play those messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows 29
described in section 3.2.1.1.1.   30
d. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the signal analyzer and allow  it to 31
demodulate and decode the test frame. 32
e. Extract either the beamweights, or magnitude and phase relation, or beam direction from the measured 33
signal. 34
 35
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  36
1. The signal measured by the signal analyzer should satisfy a basic 3GPP signal performance requirement for 37
this radio category (i.e., EVM). 38
2. The test frame received by the signal analyzer should be the same as the signal described above and should 39
contain all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data. 40
3. The signal relation (i.e. beamweights, or magnitude and phase relation) between antenna ports or TAB 41
connectors, or the extracted beam direction, should match the expected relation, or beam direction, 42
corresponding to the beam under test within a tolerance defined by the manufacturer.  43
 44
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP UL – Weight-based Dynamic 45
Beamforming 46
A. Test Description and Applicability 47
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 48
 49
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can receive a basic 3GPP test frame with weight-based beamforming 50
and with one spatial stream (single eAxC).  51
 52
The same description and criteria for selecting the beams to be tested applies as in section 3.2.3.2.5 but applies to 53
the uplink direction.  54
 55
B. Test Entrance Criteria 56

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       215
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
• Manufacturers’ defined list of frequency domain (ϕ) and or time domain (θ) weights for each supported beam, 1
or alternatively, list of gain and phase relation, or complex beam weights, between antenna ports or TAB 2
connectors for each supported beam . Also, the O-RU needs to report to the O-DU the antenna array 3
characteristics 4
 5
C. Test Methodology 6
 7
a. Initial Conditions 8
• Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation 9
using M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  10
• Ensure that the RF connections and cables are calibrated so there is phase coherence between the antenna 11
ports (or TAB connectors) within acceptable tolerance.   12
• Connect the signal source to the O-RU antenna ports or TAB connectors that belong to the beam under test 13
and configure the source with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and generate the test 14
signal.  15
• Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.   16
 17
b. Procedure 18
 19
a. Build an appropriate test signal described above in the signal source of the TER.  20
b. Inject the test signal into the O-RU with the application of an initial set of beamweights, or equivalently 21
magnitude and phase relation, between all the TER ports connected to the antenna ports (or TAB 22
connectors) to emulate the phase and magnitude difference “seen” by the antenna elements under test . For 23
example, initial beamweights could be set to be “all equal” (i.e. no beamforming).    24
c. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the signal 25
and the beam under test. Every symbol should be described by one or two sections (UL-SCH) using section 26
type 1 messages, the sections in the first symbol of the slot will contain section extension extType=0x01 to 27
convey the beam weights, it is not required that the next sections contain extension type 1 since the same 28
beam IDs will not change along the slot. If O-RU does not support a field, then its value should be 0x0. 29
Section type zero messages will be used to signal Guard Period resources in the test waveform.  30
d. Play the C plane messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows described in section 3.2.1.1.1. while 31
also triggering the signal source.   32
e. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the DUT, allow it to create and send the U 33
plane messages to the O-DU and for the O-DU to demodulate, decode and extract the payload. 34
f. Repeat the previous steps but now in step b apply a different set of beamweights or phase relation between 35
all the antenna ports (or TAB connectors) when injecting the test signal into the O-RU. For example, 36
repeating the process for a number of different beamweights will simulate the reception of the test signal 37
from different beam directions. This allows to determine if the O-RU is really focusing the sensitivity to the 38
correct beam direction. 39
 40
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  41
1. The test frame received by the TER/O-DU should be the same as the signal described above and should contain 42
all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data. 43
2. The beamweights or magnitude and phase relation at the antenna ports (or TAB connectors) of the test signal 44
that achieves the highest performance (i.e. best EVM, power, SNR, etc.) should match with the manufacturer’s 45
declaration of the beam under test. 46
 47
 48
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Attribute-based Dynamic 49
Beamforming 50
A. Test Description and Applicability 51
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 52
 53
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can transmit a basic 3GPP test frame with attributed -based dynamic 54
beamforming with one spatial stream (single eAxC).  55
 56
If the O-RU DUT supports Attribute based Dynamic Beamforming, this test is mandatory for the O -RU DUT to be 57
O-RAN conformant.   58

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       216
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
The transmitted beam direction and attributes are measured for each attributed beam required in this measurement, 1
see below. The measured transmitted direction and attributes, i.e. pointing azimuth and elevation angles, 2
beamwidths and sidelobe suppression, is compared to manufacturer-designated direction and attributes. 3
Transmitted direction and beam attributes are defined by the magnitude and phase relation between the antenna 4
ports or TAB connectors under test, or by directly extracting the beam properties.  5
The elevation θ and azimuth Φ angles are defined as in Section 10.4.1.1  of [2]. 6
 7
 8
The UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Attribute-based Dynamic Beamforming 9
conformance test should evaluate the following beams for the O-RU to comply: 10
a. An attribute-based beam with 0 degrees azimuth (Φ) and elevation (θ) angles with any beamwidth and 11
sidelobe suppression supported by the O-RU under this beam direction. 12
b. An attribute-based beam with maximum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and maximum supported elevation 13
angle (θ) with the widest beamwidth and lowest sidelobe suppression supported for this specific beam 14
direction. 15
c. An attribute-based beam with maximum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and minimum supported elevation 16
angle (θ) with the narrowest beamwidth and highest sidelobe suppression suppor ted for this specific beam 17
direction. 18
d. An attribute-based beam with minimum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and maximum supported elevation 19
angle (θ) with the widest beamwidth and lowest sidelobe suppression supported for this specific beam 20
direction. 21
e. An attribute-based beam with minimum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and minimum supported elevation 22
angle (θ) with the narrowest beamwidth and highest sidelobe suppression supported for this specific beam 23
direction. 24
 25
If the O-RU only supports one azimuth (Φ) or elevation angle (θ), fewer than 5 beam angles and attribute 26
configurations will be measured. 27
 28
 29
B. Test Entrance Criteria 30
• Manufacturers’ defined list of supported beam directions (azimuth ϕ and elevation θ angles) attributes that are 31
supported by the O-RU and their associated gain and phase relation, or complex weight, between antenna ports 32
or TAB connectors and/or beam directions with antenna array characteristics. 33
 34
C. Test Methodology 35
 36
a. Initial Conditions 37
• Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation 38
using M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  39
• Ensure that the RF connections and cables are calibrated so there is phase coherence betw een the antenna 40
ports (or TAB connectors) within acceptable tolerance.   41
• Connect the signal analyzer to the O-RU antenna ports or TAB connectors that belong to the beam under 42
test and configure the analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and demodulate the 43
transmitted signal.  44
• Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.   45
 46
b. Procedure 47
a. Build an appropriate IQ signal describing the NR-FR1-TM1.1 signal described above in the O-DU 48
emulator.   49
b. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the signal 50
and the beam under test. Every symbol should be described by one or two sections (DL-SCH and DCI) 51
using section type 1 messages, the sections in the first symbol of the slot will contain section extension 52
extType=0x02 to convey the beam weights, it is not required that the next sections contain extension type 2 53
since the same beam IDs will not change along the slot.  If O-RU does not support a field, then its value 54
should be 0x0. Section type zero messages will be used to signal Guard Period resources in the test 55
waveform. 56
c. Encapsulate the IQ data in U-Plane messages. Play those messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows 57
described in section 3.2.1.1.1.   58
d. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the signal analyzer and allow it to 59
demodulate and decode the test frame. 60

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       217
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
e. Extract either the beamweights, or magnitude and phase relation, or beam properties from the measured 1
signal. 2
 3
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  4
1. The signal measured by the signal analyzer should satisfy a basic 3GPP signal performance requirement for this 5
radio category (i.e., EVM). 6
2. The test frame received by the signal analyzer should be the same as the signal described above and should 7
contain all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data. 8
3. The signal relation (i.e. beamweights, or magnitude and phase relation) between antenna ports or TAB 9
connectors, or the extracted beam properties, should match the expected beam properties corresponding to the 10
beam under test within a tolerance defined by the manufacturer.  11
 12
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP UL – Attribute-based Dynamic 13
Beamforming 14
A. Test Description and Applicability 15
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 16
 17
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can receive a basic 3GPP test frame with attribute -based 18
beamforming with one spatial stream (single eAxC). 19
 20
Same description and criteria for selecting the beams to be tested applies as in section 3.2.3.2.7 but considering 21
uplink direction.  22
 23
B. Test Entrance Criteria 24
• Manufacturers’ defined list of supported beam directions (azimuth ϕ and elevation θ angles) attributes that are 25
supported by the O-RU and their associated gain and phase relation, or complex weight, between antenna ports 26
or TAB connectors and/or beam directions with antenna array characteristics 27
 28
C. Test Methodology 29
 30
a. Initial Conditions 31
• Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation using 32
M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1. 33
• Ensure that the RF connections and cables are calibrated so there is phase coherence between the antenna 34
ports (or TAB connectors) within acceptable tolerance.    35
• Connect the signal source to the O-RU antenna ports or TAB connectors that belong to the beam under test 36
and configure the source with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and generate the test 37
signal.  38
• Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.   39
 40
b. Procedure 41
a. Build an appropriate test signal described above in the signal source of the TER.  42
b. Inject the test signal into the O-RU with the application of an initial set of beamweights, or equivalently 43
magnitude and phase relation, between all the TER ports connected to the antenna ports (or TAB 44
connectors) to emulate the phase and magnitude difference “seen” by the antenna elements under test . For 45
example, initial beamweights could be set to be “all equal” (i.e. no beamforming).    46
c. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the signal 47
and the beam under test. Every symbol should be described by one or two sections (UL-SCH) using section 48
type 1 messages, the sections in the first symbol of the slot will contain section extension extType=0x02 to 49
convey the beam weights, it is not required that the next sections contain extension type 2 since the same 50
beam IDs will not change along the slot. If O-RU does not support a field, then its value should be 0x0. 51
Section type zero messages will be used to signal Guard Period resources in the test waveform. 52
d. Play the C plane messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows described in section 3.2.1.1.1. while also 53
triggering the signal source.   54
e. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the DUT, allow it to create and send the U 55
plane messages to the O-DU and for the O-DU to demodulate, decode and extract the payload. 56

f. Repeat the previous steps but now in step b apply a different set of beamweights or magnitude and phase 1
relation between all the antenna ports (or TAB connectors) when injecting the test signal into the O -RU. For 2
example, repeating the process for a number of different sets of beamweights will simulate the reception of 3
the test signal from different beam directions. This allows to determine if the O -RU is really focusing the 4
sensitivity to the correct beam properties. 5

D. Test Requirement (expected result)  7
1. The test frame received by the TER/O-DU should be the same as the signal described above and should contain 8
all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data. 9
2. The beamweights or magnitude and phase relation at the antenna ports (or TAB connectors) of the test signal 10
that achieves the highest performance (i.e. best EVM, power, SNR, etc.) should match with the manufacturer’s 11
declaration of the beam under test. 12
 13
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Channel-Information-based 14
Beamforming 15
A. Test Description and Applicability 16
This Test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 17
 18
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can transmit a basic 3GPP test frame with channel -information-based 19
beamforming with multiple spatial streams from multiple users (i.e. MU -MIMO). 20
 21
For Category A radios, the test is for each polarization separately and consequently either different or same channel 22
models can be defined for each of the polarization. For Category B, same channel might be used for both 23
polarizations and the test might measure each polarization separately. 24
The transmitted beam direction is measured for each scenario required in this measurement .  The measured 25
transmitted direction is extracted from the decoded received signal in the TER. Transmitted direction is defined by 26
properly receiving a data transmission between the O-RU and the target User Equipment while destroying or 27
heavily attenuating the data transmission between the O-RU and the other User Equipment. 28
The UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Channel-Information-based Beamforming 29
conformance test should evaluate the following scenarios for the O-RU to comply and will rely on TER Channel 30
Emulation capabilities as shown in Figure 3.2.3.2-3.  31
 32
 33
Figure 3.2.5.2-2 TER with Channel Emulation Capability 34

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       219
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
 1
A scenario where two spatial streams, or eAxC flows, are generated for two users (one layer each) with M antenna 2
ports or TAB connectors. The O-DU will report to the O-RU via C plane messages an emulated channel estimate 3
𝐻 ≜  [ℎ1
1, . . . , ℎ1
𝑀, ℎ2
1, . . . , ℎ2
𝑀] ∈ ℂ2𝑥𝑀. The emulated channel  𝐻  shall model a static channel, with rank not lower 4
than the number of spatial streams, and it shall not be a block-diagonal channel. As an example, a Butler channel 5
model could be implemented as emulated channel. The O-RU will calculate and apply the beamweight matrix 𝐺 ≜6
 [𝑔1
1, . . . , 𝑔1
𝑀, 𝑔2
1, . . . , 𝑔2
𝑀]  ∈ ℂ𝑀𝑥2 in such that the received signal at the users is the same as the generated in the O -7
DU. It is up to the O-RU on how to calculate the beamforming weights, for example Zero-forcing, regularized 8
zero-forcing / MMSE, etc.   9
 10
If O-RU supports Analog Beamforming (Time Domain Beamforming), the test should not apply any analog 11
beamforming or time domain beamforming. In this case, M is not the number of antenna ports or TAB connecto rs 12
but the number of TRX channels supported by the O-RU. 13
 14
B. Test Entrance Criteria 15
 16
• The O-RU must have at least two TRX chains with conducted antenna ports (or TAB connectors) to be 17
connected to a signal analyzer. 18
• The TER equipment must either include a channel emulator between the O -RU antenna ports and the signal 19
analyzer or the signal analyzer be capable of applying the required channel matrix being emulated between the 20
O-RU and the users.  21
• Manufacturers’ defined list of number of TRX chains and what antenna ports or TAB connectors are 22
connected to each TRX chain.  23
 24
C. Test Methodology 25
 26
a. Initial Conditions 27
• Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation using 28
M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  29
• Ensure that the RF connections and cables are calibrated so there is phase coherence between the antenna 30
ports (or TAB connectors) within acceptable tolerance.   31
• Connect the signal analyzer to the O-RU antenna ports or TAB connectors that belong to the scenario under 32
test and configure the analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and demodulate the 33
transmitted signal.  34
• Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.   35
 36
b. Procedure 37
a. Build an appropriate IQ signal described above in the O-DU emulator.   38
b. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the signal 39
and the scenario under test. Every symbol should be described by either one or two  sections (DL-SCH and 40
DCI) using section type 5 and 6 messages. Section type zero messages will be used to signal Guard Period 41
resources in the test waveform. 42
c. Encapsulate the IQ data in U-Plane messages. Play those messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows 43
described in section 3.2.1.1.1. 44
d. Capture the test signals and pass them through a channel emulator or apply the signal processing required 45
to emulate the channel under test.   46
e. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the signal analyzer and allow it to 47
demodulate and decode the test frame. 48
 49
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  50
1. The signal measured by the signal analyzer should satisfy a basic 3GPP signal performance requirement for this 51
radio category (i.e., EVM). 52
2. The test frame received by the signal analyzer should be the same as the signal described above and shoul d 53
contain all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data. 54
 55
 56
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP UL – Channel-Information-based 57
Beamforming 58
A. Test Description and Applicability 59

This Test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 1
 2
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can receive a basic 3GPP test frame with channel-information-based 3
beamforming with multiple spatial streams from multiple users (i.e. MU -MIMO).  4
 5
Same description and criteria for selecting the beams to be tested applies as in se ction 3.2.3.2.10 but considering 6
uplink direction.  7

 9
• The O-RU must have at least two TRX chains with conducted antenna ports (or TAB connectors) to be 10
connected to a signal generator. 11
• The TER equipment must either include a channel emulator between the O -RU antenna ports and the signal 12
generator or the signal generator be capable of applying the required channel matrix being emulated between 13
the users and the O-RU.  14
• Manufacturers’ defined list of number of TRX chains and what antenna ports or TAB connectors are 15
connected to each TRX chain. 16
 17
C. Test Methodology 18
 19
a. Initial Conditions 20
• Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation 21
using M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  22
• Ensure that the RF connections and cables are calibrated so there is phase coherence between the antenna 23
ports (or TAB connectors) within acceptable tolerance.   24
• Connect the signal source to the O-RU antenna ports or TAB connectors that belong to the beam under test 25
and configure the source with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and generate the test 26
signal.  27
• Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.  28
  29
b. Procedure 30
a. Build an appropriate test signal described above in the signal source of the TER. 31
b. Inject the test signals through a channel emulator or apply the required signal processing to emulate the 32
channel under test.  33
c. Inject the resulting test signals into the antenna ports (or TAB connectors). 34
d. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the signal 35
and the beam under test. Every symbol should be described by either one or two  sections (UL-SCH) using 36
section type 5 and 6. Section type zero messages will be used to signal Guard Period resources in the test 37
waveform. 38
e. Play the C plane messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows described in section 2.4. while also 39
triggering the signal source.   40
f. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the DUT, allow it to create and send the U 41
plane messages to the O-DU and for the O-DU to demodulate, decode and extract the payload. 42
 43

The test frame received by the TER/O-DU should be the same as the signal described above and should contain all 45
the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data. 46

 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Compression (CMP) 48
Validate the correct implementation and interpretation of mandatory and optional IQ data compression formats 49
described in [2]. Also, evaluate the consistency in U-Plane signaling. 50
It applies to the following CUS fronthaul specification sections in [2]: 51
• Section 5.4.2 for layout of C-Plane message, in particular Section Type 1 52
• Section 5.4.4.10 for applicability of "udCompHdr" and "reserved" fields 53
• Section 6.3.3.15/16/17 for applicability of udCompParam 54
• Section 6.3.2 for U-Plane message layout 55
• Section 6.3.3 for coding of applicable Information Elements 56

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       221
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
• Table 8-2 for mandatory/optional capabilities. 1
• Annex A.6 Selective RE sending Compression 2
 3
The objective is primarily to test the protocol, prior to the compression algorithms performance.  4
Signalling: IQ Compression related fields in UC-Plane messages include:  5
• U-Plane IQ data field  6
• C-Plane udCompHdr (per section 5.4.4.10 of [2]) 7
• U-Plane udComphdr (per section 6.3.3.13 of [2]) 8
• U-Plane udCompParam (per section 6.3.3.15 of [2]) 9
• Modulation compression parameters used in the Section Extension Type =4 10
• csf (constellation shift flag)  11
• modCompScaler (modulation compression scaler value) 12
 13
Compression: Current specification includes 7 compression modes, including uncompressed mode (fixed point).  Tests 14
should cover each one of these modes   15
• fixed-point 16
• block floating-point 17
• block scaling 18
• mu-law 19
• modulation compression 20
• Block Floating Point + selective RE sending 21
• Modulation Compression + selective RE sending 22
 23
IQ Bit Width: For fixed-point, block floating point, block scaling and mu-law compression, IQ information can be 24
represented using different bit width (1-16 bits). To optimize test time, tests should be performed on a subset of bit 25
widths  26
• 9 bits 27
• 14 bits  28
 Overview of Compression Test Methodology 29
A common test methodology and structure will be used across all compression test cases. Each one of the test cases will 30
be defined with specific input parameters and expected output values.  31
To minimize influence of the Radio’s RF performance to the test results, the test methodology will be based on a 32
relative comparison between modulated signal measurements performed on a TDD test frame with uncompressed IQ 33
(fixed 16 bits) and measurements on the same test frame using compressed IQ. The test will verify that the difference 34
between measurements fits within an acceptable range for the test to pass. 35
For downlink test, the modulated signal measurement is performed by a signal analyzer on the antenna port of the O-36
RU.  37
For uplink measurement, the modulated signal measurement is performed with the IQ extracted from the Uplink U -38
Plane data sent by the O-RU on the O-RAN interface.  39
The following paragraphs in this overview section outline the details of these common test methodologies.  40
3.2.5.3.1.1 Test Frame 41
TDD test methodology for compression will combine similar downlink and uplink test patterns used for FDD test. The 42
main difference is that uplink and downlink tests are performed simultane ously for TDD.  43
The test frames used for compression conformance test will be referred in this document as “ NR-FR1-TDD-CMP-44
TST-DL” TDD Downlink Standard Compression Test frame and “NR-FR1-TDD-CMP-TST-UL” TDD Uplink 45
Standard Compression Test frame. They are 5G NR frames based on the description in section 3.2.1.1.3 For scenario #3 46
(Conducted TDD Tests for FR1 Radios) with specific attributes described below. 47

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       222
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
The Downlink UC-Plane test stimulus file includes the C-Plane and U-Plane messages that require the O-RU to 1
transmit on the downlink the NR-FR1-TDD-CMP-TST-DL test frame.  2
The Uplink C-Plane test stimulus file includes the C-Plane messages that require the O-RU to provide the uplink U-3
Plane messages according to the NR-FR1-TDD-CMP-TST-UL test frame received by the O-RU on its antenna port. 4
Signalling and IQ information will be based on various compression schemes  5
Stimulus File Name Description
NR-FR1-TDD-CMP-TST-ST-DL-UNC-16B Static Downlink Uncompressed (CU-plane)
NR-FR1-TDD-CMP-TST-ST-UL-UNC-16B Static Uplink Uncompressed (C-plane only)
NR-FR1-TDD-CMP-TST-ST-DL-FPF-9B Static Downlink Fixed Point 9 Bits (CU-plane)
NR-FR1-TDD-CMP-TST-ST-DL-FPF-14B Static Downlink Fixed Point 14 Bits (CU-plane)
NR-FR1-TDD-CMP-TST-ST-UL-FPF-9B Static Uplink Fixed Point 9 Bits (C-plane only)
NR-FR1-TDD-CMP-TST-ST-UL-FPF-14B Static Uplink Fixed Point 14 Bits (C-plane only)
NR-FR1-TDD-CMP-TST-ST-DL-BFP-9B Static Downlink Block Floating Point 9 Bits (CU-plane)
NR-FR1-TDD-CMP-TST-ST-DL-BFP-14B Static Downlink Block Floating Point 14 Bits (CU-plane)
NR-FR1-TDD-CMP-TST-ST-UL-BFP-9B Static Uplink Block Floating Point 9 Bits (C-plane only)
NR-FR1-TDD-CMP-TST-ST-UL-BFP-14B Static Uplink Block Floating Point 14 Bits (C-plane only)
NR-FR1-TDD-CMP-TST-ST-DL-BSC-9B Static Downlink Block Scaling 9 Bits (CU-plane)
NR-FR1-TDD-CMP-TST-ST-DL-BSC-14B Static Downlink Block Scaling 14 Bits (CU-plane)
NR-FR1-TDD-CMP-TST-ST-UL-BSC-9B Static Uplink Block Scaling 9 Bits (C-plane only)
NR-FR1-TDD-CMP-TST-ST-UL-BSC-14B Static Uplink Block Scaling 14 Bits (C-plane only)
NR-FR1-TDD-CMP-TST-ST-DL-MLW-9B Static Downlink Mu-Law 9 Bits (CU-plane)
NR-FR1-TDD-CMP-TST-ST-DL-MLW-14B Static Downlink Mu-Law 14 Bits (CU-plane)
NR-FR1-TDD-CMP-TST-ST-UL-MLW-9B Static Uplink Mu-Law 9 Bits (C-plane only)
NR-FR1-TDD-CMP-TST-ST-UL-MLW-14B Static Uplink Mu-Law 14 Bits (C-plane only)
NR-FR1-TDD-CMP-TST-ST-DL-MC Static Downlink Modulation Compression
NR-FR1-TDD -CMP-TST -ST-DL-UNC-BRE-
16B
Static Downlink Uncompressed (CU-plane) with both empty
and allocated RE in the same symbol
NR-FR1-TDD -CMP-TST -ST-UL-UNC-BRE-
16B
Static Uplink Uncompressed (C-plane only) with both empty
and allocated RE in the same symbol

NR-FR1-TDD-CMP-TST-ST-DL-BRE-9B Static Downlink Block Floating Point + Selective RE 9 Bits
(CU-plane)
NR-FR1- TDD-CMP-TST-ST-DL-BRE-14B Static Downlink Block Floating Point + Selective 14 Bits
(CU-plane)

 (C-plane only)

(C-plane only)

3.2.5.3.1.2 Test Frame Power  3
To ensure that the compressed IQ exponent value is properly tested, each symbol of the test frame will include 3 4
sections with different power levels.  The Power levels are relative powers to the first group of PRBs transmitted.  Any 5
valid 3GPP power level may be used for the first set of PRBs as long as the power levels of the remaining PRBs are 6
also valid.  Figure 3.2.3.3-1 below shows PRB power relative to the first set of PRBs. 7
•    0 dB for the bottom third of total PRBs in the symbol (referred as PDSCH0) 8
• -10 dB for the middle third of total PRBs in the symbol (referred as PDSCH1) 9
• -20 dB for the upper third of total PRBs in the symbol (referred as PDSCH2) 10
 11

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       224
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
The spectrum representation of the frame shown in Figure 3.2.3.3-1 below highlights the various power levels for each 1
group of PRBS within a symbol.  2
 3
Figure 3.2.5.3-1 PRB Spectrum Power Visualization 4
 5
3.2.5.3.1.3 Test Frame User data  6
To validate that user data has not been impacted by compression, the test payload for the 3 sections is based on a PN23 7
sequence that will be measured and compared by the test apparatus.   8
3.2.5.3.1.4 Test Frame Modulation Scheme 9
To maximise coverage on the compressed IQ mantissa value, the test frame will use the highest possible modulation 10
(256 QAM modulation for downlink).  An example measurement is show in Figure 3.2.3.3-2. 11
 12
Table 3.2.5.3-3 Example User Data Modulation Validation 13
 14
3.2.5.3.1.5 Summary of Required Measurements for Compression Tests 15
3 measurements types will be required for downlink tests and 4 measurements will be required for uplink tests.  16
• Power level:  Using the test frames (NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-DL and NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-UL) 17
sent twice with both compressed and uncompressed IQ data, power level measurements are performed to 18
validate compression algorithms influence on Exponent (udCompParam).  19
The Power level measurements are called: 20
For downlink 21
 22
o CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-Power-DL-PDSCH0 in dBm 23
o CMP-Compressed-Measured-Power-DL-PDSCH0 in dBm 24
o CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-Power-DL-PDSCH1 in dBm 25
o CMP-Compressed-Measured-Power-DL-PDSCH1 in dBm 26
o CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-Power-DL-PDSCH2 in dBm 27
o CMP-Compressed-Measured-Power-DL-PDSCH2 in dBm 28
 29
For Uplink 30
o CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-Power-UL-PDSCH0 in dBm 31
o CMP-Compressed-Measured-Power-UL-PDSCH0 in dBm 32
o CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-Power-UL-PDSCH1 in dBm 33
o CMP-Compressed-Measured-Power-UL-PDSCH1 in dBm 34
o CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-Power-UL-PDSCH2 in dBm 35
o CMP-Compressed-Measured-Power-UL-PDSCH2 in dBm 36
 37
For the test to pass, the difference between compressed and uncompressed measurements should be within an 38
acceptable range, called 39

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       225
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
o ACC_PWR_PDSCH0 = ± 1dB 1
o ACC_PWR_PDSCH1 = ± 1dB 2
o ACC_PWR_PDSCH2 = ± 1dB 3
o  4
• EVM:  Using a common test frame sent twice with both compressed and uncompressed IQ data, EVM 5
measurements comparisons between uncompressed IQ and compressed IQ will help validate acceptable 6
compression influence on signal quality.  7
 8
For downlink These 6 EVM measurements required: 9
o CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-EVM-DL-PDSCH0 in % 10
o CMP-Compressed-Measured-EVM-DL-PDSCH0  in % 11
o CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-EVM-DL-PDSCH1  in % 12
o CMP-Compressed-Measured-EVM-DL-PDSCH1  in % 13
o CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-EVM-DL-PDSCH2  in % 14
o CMP-Compressed-Measured-EVM-DL-PDSCH2  in % 15
 16
For uplink These 6 EVM measurements required: 17
o CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-EVM-UL-PDSCH0 in % 18
o CMP-Compressed-Measured-EVM-UL-PDSCH0  in % 19
o CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-EVM-UL-PDSCH1  in % 20
o CMP-Compressed-Measured-EVM-UL-PDSCH1  in % 21
o CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-EVM-UL-PDSCH2  in % 22
o CMP-Compressed-Measured-EVM-UL-PDSCH2  in % 23
 24
For the test to pass, the difference between the compressed and uncompressed measurements for the same 25
PDSCH signal must be within the following range: 26
o ACC_EVM_PDSCH0 ≤ 4 percentage points 27
o ACC_EVM_PDSCH1 ≤ 4 percentage points 28
o ACC_EVM_PDSCH2 ≤ 4 percentage points 29
 30
An example measurement showing both power and EVM is shown below in Figure 3.2.5.3-2 31
Example Compression EVM Measurement. 32
 33

Figure 3.2.5.3-2 Example Compression EVM Measurement 34
 35
• Payload Data Integrity:  comparing user data between the O-RAN test frame and the RF measurement to 36
validate that compression does not influence user data.  The User data measurements are called:  37
For Downlink 38
 39
o CMP-Uncompressed-BER-DL-PDSCH0  40
o CMP-Uncompressed-BER-DL-PDSCH1  41
o CMP-Uncompressed-BER-DL-PDSCH2  42
o CMP-Compressed-BER-DL-PDSCH0  43
o CMP-Compressed-BER-DL-PDSCH1  44
o CMP-Compressed-BER-DL-PDSCH2  45
 46
For Uplink 47

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       226
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
 1
o CMP-Uncompressed-BER-UL-PDSCH0  2
o CMP-Uncompressed-BER-UL-PDSCH1  3
o CMP-Uncompressed-BER-UL-PDSCH2  4
o CMP-Compressed-BER-UL-PDSCH0  5
o CMP-Compressed-BER-UL-PDSCH1  6
o CMP-Compressed-BER-UL-PDSCH2  7
 8
For the data integrity test to pass, the comparison between stimulus payload and the measured payload  should 9
be free of any errors (i.e. BER=0).  10
 11
• Presence/Absence of U-Plane Header measurements (uplink only): to validate that in the U-Plane PRB 12
header, the udCompHeader, “reserved” and udCompParam fields are correctly absent for Static compression 13
mode or present for other compression modes.  14
 15
Table 3.2.5.3-4 Measurements Required for Specific Downlink Compression Options below describes the 16
measurements required for each compression option in the downlink. 17

3.2.5.3.1.7 Results Analysis 2
In general, for each specific Compression Test in this conformance test document, the test will pass if the following 3
conditions are met: 4
• Power measurement differences between Uncompressed and Compressed are within acceptable range  5
• EVM measurement difference between Uncompressed and Compressed are within acceptable range  6
• Data integrity measurements show no data corruption 7
• Uplink U-Plane Header measurements exclude fields for static compression 8
 9
These test criteria and expected results are summarized below in Table 3.2.5.3-6 Compression Test Acceptance 10
Threshold Criteria. 11
