 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming (BFM)  1
This section describes the beamforming conformance testing for ORAN fronthaul interface. The tests do not aim to test 2
the O-RU beamforming performance or capabilities but to test that the O-RU under test focuses the RF energy or 3
sensitivity into a specific direction and with a specific granularity following the O -DU emulator (i.e., O-RAN interface 4
of the TER described in section 2.1) C-Plane messages.  5
Unless stated otherwise in a test case, the following statements apply to all the test cases defined in this section:  6
• It is based on Over-the-Air (OTA) testing with a setup such as described in Section 2.1 and it may be applied to 7
any O-RU DUTs, whether the O-RU DUTs have conducted antenna ports or TAB connectors or not.  8
• Section 3.2.1.1.2 for scenario #2 non-conducted OTA FDD FR1 radios contains a description of test setups, as 9
mentioned by 3GPP TS 37.843 defines various radiated test systems. If not explicitly mentioned, scenario #4 10
non-conducted OTA TDD tests for FR1 and FR2 radios will inherit those descriptions.  11
 12
• It applies to  Category A and  Category B O-RU DUTs. 13
 14
• It applies to LTE and/or 5G New Radio O-RU DUTs.  In both cases, precoding is not required in any test case.   15
 16
• If O-RU DUT supports Analog Beamforming (i.e. time domain beamforming), all the U -Plane test frames are 17
defined by segmenting the Stock Test A: 1 section per symbol.  The definition of this Stock Test A can be 18
found in Figure 3.2.1.1-2 and the description accompanying this Figure.  Each slot shall include multiple 19
sections (one per symbol within the slot) and only one beam at a time (i.e. one beamId at a time) and therefore 20
only one beam can be tested per slot. 21
 22
• If O-RU DUT supports Digital Beamforming (i.e. frequency domain beamforming), all the U -Plane test frames 23
are defined by segmenting the Stock Test B: 2 sections per symbol definition as shown in Figure 3.2.1.1-2.  24
Each slot shall include multiple sections (two per symbol within the slot) and only one beam per section at a 25
time (i.e. one beamId at a time) and therefore up to two different beams can be test ed per slot. 26
 27
• If O-RU DUT supports multiple polarizations, it is up to the TER to determine if the testing is carried out for 28
each polarization separately or multiple polarizations at the same time. In any case, it is important to guarantee 29
that the correct eAxC_ID for the correct polarization (or polarizations) is exercised.  30
 31
• For O-RU DUT that support LTE:  32
o Downlink tests will use a standard 3GPP E-TM1.1 test frame for TDD, based on uplink/downlink 33
configuration 3 and special subframe configuration 8  (Section 6.1.1.1 TS 36.141) with 20MHz bandwidth 34
(100 RB) as shown in Figure 3.2.3.2-1. 35
 36

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       259
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
Figure 3.2.6.2-1 E-TM1.1 TDD 20 MHz 100RB 1
If 20MHz is not supported by the O-RU DUT, then it will use the highest bandwidth supported by the O-2
RU DUT. 3
o Uplink test will use a standard 3GPP UL RMC Configuration definition for TDD (TS36.521 -1 Annex 4
A.2.3) and power levels at least 30dB above Reference Sensitivity power level with 20MHz bandwidth 5
(100 RB) as shown in Figure 3.2.3.2-2. 6
o  7
 8
Figure 3.2.6.2-2 UL RMC TDD 20 MHz 100 RB. TS 36.521-1 A.2.3.1.1 9
If 20MHz is not supported by the O-RU DUT, then it will use the highest bandwidth supported by the O-10
RU DUT. 11
 12
• For O-RU DUT that support 5G NR:  13
o NR FR1 test models described in TS 38.141-1 are also applicable for BS type 1-O conformance testing. 14
FR1 TDD downlink tests will use a standard 3GPP NR-FR1-TM1.1 test frame for TDD.  15
o FR2 TDD downlink tests will use a standard 3GPP NR-FR2-TM1.1 test frame for TDD in (Section 16
4.9.2 TS 38.141-2) of the Radiated Transmitter Characteristic Test section (Section 6 TS 38.141-2) as 17
described in section 3.2.1.1. The test numerology will be preferably 120KHz subcarrier spacing and 18
100 MHz Bandwidth, or lower depending on DUT capability. If not supported, then it will use any 19
other supported subcarrier spacing and the highest bandwidth of the O -RU DUT. 20
o NR FR1 test models described in TS 38.141-1 are also applicable for BS type 1-O conformance testing. 21
FR1 TDD uplink tests will use a standard 3GPP G-FR1_A1-5_SCS30kHz_51RB test frame for TDD.  22
 23
o FR2 TDD uplink tests will use a standard 3GPP Reference Sensitivity level definition (Section 7.2 and 24
Annex A TS 38.141-2) of the Radiated Receiver Characteristic Test section (Section 7 TS 38.141-2). 25
The O-RU manufacturer declares a minimum EIS level for the considered OTA sensitivity direction 26
declaration. The power levels inclining from the angle of arrival that should be tested (RoAoA) is at 27
least 30dB above the OSDD EIS Reference Sensitivity power level. The test numerology will be 28
preferably 120kHz subcarrier spacing and 100 MHz Bandwidth based on G-FR2-A1-3 in TS 38.141-2,  29
or lower depending on DUT capability. Otherwise, it will use any available subcarrier spac ing and the 30
highest bandwidth supported by the O-RU DUT. 31
 32
•  Radiated tests coordinate system is based on the coordinate system defined in section 10.5.1. of  [2]. 33
 34
 35
• The O-RU DUT must: 36
o support the default parameters in section 3.2.1.1.2 of this document. 37
o have installed current release of shipping software.  38

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       260
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
o be fully calibrated up to Radiated Interface Boundary (RIB) as defined in 3GPP TS 38.141 -2. It is expected 1
to be calibrated by O-RU vendor prior to testing.  2
 3
 4
• The TER must: 5
o be capable of carrying out any signal processing required to generate and demodulate 3GPP compliant 6
waveforms. 7
o be able to calculate or extract the spherical beam direction via OTA measurements. 8
o be able to generate and deliver signals with the required beam direction at the RIB point.  9
o be fully calibrated up to the interface where it interacts with the DUT’s RIB. For that, a known test signal 10
might be either injected by the TER into the O-RU DUT, or internally generated by the O-RU DUT, and 11
the O-RU DUT must not apply any digital or analog beam forming to apply a directional characteristic to 12
the known test signal.  One possible method to perform calibration uses injected C -Plane and U-Plane 13
signals from TER into the O-RU and using C-Plane messages with beamID=0.  Alternatively, calibration 14
methods for radiated test setups that are described in 3GPP TR37.941 can be used. 15
o    16
o  17
 18
 19
• The O-DU emulator of the TER must: 20
o be capable of generating and sending U-Plane messages containing 3GPP test frames following the 21
corresponding Stock sectioning defined above, as well as be capable of capturing U-Plane messages and 22
extracting 3GPP test frames (i.e. IQ data) from the captured U-Plane messages. 23
o be capable of generating the C-Plane messages for, receiving, extracting and demodulating the 3GPP test 24
frames following the corresponding Stock sectioning defined above. 25
 26
• The TER might have a single test antenna if a single beam direction and polarization is measured and an 27
optional positioning method to perform directional radiation measurements s equentially, or multiple test 28
antennas to perform directional radiation measurements and/or polarizations at the same time.  29
 30
• It is up to the TER on how to extract the beam direction and beam properties at the DUT’s RIB in order to 31
match it with the manufacturer’s declaration. 32
 33
• The user payload will be generated as PN23 with a seed of all ones. 34
 35
• It applies to the following CUS fronthaul specification sections: 36
• Section 5.4.2 for layout of C-Plane message, in particular Section Type 1 37
• Section 6.3.2 for U-Plane message layout 38
• Section 6.3.3 for coding of applicable Information Elements 39
• Section 10 for beamforming guidelines. 40
• Annex J for beamforming methods description.  41
 42
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – No Beamforming 43
A. Test Description and Applicability 44
This test is MANDATORY. 45
 46
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can transmit a basic 3GPP test frame with no beamforming 47
(beamId=0x000) and with one spatial stream (single eAxC). 48
 49
B. Test Entrance Criteria 50
• Manufacturers’ declaration that defines list of beam directions when O-RU DUT is operating with no 51
beamforming. This list serves as indication of the expected transmitted beam direction in below evaluation.   52
 53
C. Test Methodology 54
 55
a. Initial Conditions 56
• Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation using 57
M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  58

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       261
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
• Ensure that the test antenna/s and TER equipment is calibrated within acceptable tolerance.  1
• Place the test antenna/s to a defined position within the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1. 3.2.1.1.4 and 2
configure the analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and demodulate the 3
transmitted signal. 4
• Place the O-RU into a test calibrated point within the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.3.2.1.1.4. 5
• Align the O-RU to a default initial position, i.e. align the O-RU to the origin of coordinates of the declared 6
coordinate reference point and orientation in the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.3.2.1.1.4.  7
• Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.  8
 9
b. Procedure 10
f. Build an appropriate IQ signal describing the NR-FR1-TM1.1 or NR-FR2-TM1.1 signal described above 11
in the O-DU emulator.   12
g. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the 13
signal and the beam under test. Every symbol should be described by either one or two  sections (DL -SCH 14
and DCI) using section type 1 messages. No section type zero messages will be used for this test. 15
h. Encapsulate the IQ data in U-Plane messages. Play those messages to the O-RU respecting timing 16
windows described in section 3.2.1.1.3.2.1.1.4.   17
i. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the signal ana lyzer and allow it to 18
demodulate and decode the test frame. 19
j. Measure any metric/s that allows for extracting the transmitted beam direction from a single measurement, 20
i.e. transform-based techniques, or take as many measurements of any metric/s from multiple angles, by 21
for example rotating the O-RU, that allows for extracting beam direction from multiple measurement, i.e. 22
beam scanning. 23
 24
 25
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  26
1. The signal measured by the signal analyzer at the contemplated transmitted beam direction should satisfy a 27
basic 3GPP signal performance requirement for this radio category (i.e., EVM).  28
2. The test frame received at the contemplated transmitted beam direction by the signal analyzer should be the 29
same as the signal described above and should contain all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 30
data. 31
3. The extracted or measured beam direction is defined as the direction where the best metric/s were measured (i.e. 32
best EVM, power, SNR, etc.) and should match the expected transmitted beam direction for the expected no 33
beamforming within a tolerance defined by the manufacturer.  34
 35
 36
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP UL – No Beamforming 37
A. Test Description and Applicability 38
This test is MANDATORY. 39
 40
 41
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can receive a basic 3GPP test frame with no beamforming 42
(beamId=0x000) and with one spatial stream (single eAxC). 43
 44
 45
B. Test Entrance Criteria 46
• Manufacturers’ declaration that defines list of beam directions when O-RU DUT is operating with no 47
beamforming. This list serves as indication of the expected receive beam direction in below evaluation.   48
  49
 50
C. Test Methodology 51
 52
a. Initial Conditions 53
• Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation using 54
M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  55
• Ensure that the test antenna/s and TER equipment is calibrated within acceptable toleranc e.  56
• Place the test antenna/s to a defined position within the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1. 3.2.1.1.4 and 57
configure the signal source with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and generate the test 58
signal. 59

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       262
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
• Place the O-RU into a test calibrated point within the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.3.2.1.1.4. 1
• Align the O-RU to a default initial position, i.e. align the O-RU to the origin of coordinates of the declared 2
coordinate reference point and orientation in the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.3.2.1.1.4.  3
• Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.  4
 5
b. Procedure 6
a. Build an appropriate test signal described above in the signal source of the TER.  7
b. Inject the test signal into the O-RU with the application of an initial beam direction. This initial beam 8
direction could be the boresight direction of the receiver antenna array, corresponding to the 9
manufacturers declaration of the expected receive direction. 10
c. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the 11
signal and the beam under test. Every symbol should be described by either one or two  sections (UL -12
SCH) using section type 1 messages. No section type zero messages will be used for this test.  13
d. Play the C plane messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows described in section 3.2.1.1.3.2.1.1.4 14
while also triggering the signal source.   15
e. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the DUT, allow it to create and send the U 16
plane messages to the O-DU. 17
f. Allow the O-DU to demodulate, decode and extract the payload and to measure and extract any required 18
metric/s from the received signal that will be used later to determine what is the best received direction.  19
g. Repeat the previous steps but now in step b apply a different beam direction when injecting the test signal 20
into the O-RU. Repeating the process for a number of different beam directions will exercise the reception 21
of the test signal from different receive beam directions. This allows to determine if the O-RU is really 22
focusing the sensitivity to the correct expected receive beam direction. 23
 24
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  25
1. The test frame received at the contemplated receive beam direction by the TER/O -DU should be the same as the 26
signal described above and should contain all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data.  27
2. The extracted or measured receive beam direction is defined as the direction where the best metric/s were 28
measured (i.e. best EVM, power, SNR, etc.) and should match the expected receive beam direction for the 29
expected no beamforming within a tolerance defined by the manufacturer.  30
 31
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Predefined-beam 32
Beamforming 33
A. Test Description and Applicability 34
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 35
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can transmit a basic 3GPP test frame with predefined -beams 36
beamforming (beamId≠0x000) and with one spatial stream (single eAxC).  37
The transmitted beam direction is measured for each indexed beam required in this measurement, see below. The 38
measured transmitted direction is compared to manufacturer-designated direction. Transmitted beam direction is 39
defined by extracting the beam direction from directional measurement samples. , e.g. spherical scan. 40
Depending on the O-RU beamforming capabilities regarding the ability to generate “coarse”, “fine” and/or “beam 41
groups”, as defined in [2] Section 10.4.1.1. 42
 43
The elevation θ and azimuth Φ angles are defined as in [2] Section 10.4.1.1: 44
 45
The UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Predefined-beam Beamforming conformance test 46
might include multiple test that the O-RU must comply: 47
a. “Coarse” beamIds test:  48
If O-RU supports and reports beamIds that are defined as coarse granularity (coarse beamIds) to the O -DU 49
emulator, the test should include the following beams: 50
1. A coarse beam with 0 degrees azimuth (Φ) and elevation (θ) angles. 51
2. A coarse beam with maximum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and maximum supported elevation angle (θ).  52
3. A coarse beam with maximum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and minimum supported elevation angle (θ). 53
4. A coarse beam with minimum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and maximum supported elevation angle (θ).  54
5. A coarse beam with minimum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and minimum supported elevation angle (θ). 55
 56

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       263
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
If the O-RU only supports one azimuth (Φ) or elevation angle (θ), fewer than 5 beam angles will be measured.  1
 2
b.  “Fine” beamIds test:  3
If O-RU supports and reports beamIds that are defined as fine granularity (fine beamIds) to the O -DU 4
emulator, the test should include the following beams: 5
1. A fine beam with 0 degrees azimuth (Φ) and elevation (θ) angles. 6
2. A fine beam with maximum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and maximum supported elevation angle (θ).  7
3. A fine beam with maximum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and minimum supported elevation angle (θ). 8
4. A fine beam with minimum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and maximum supported elevation angle (θ).  9
5. A fine beam with minimum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and minimum supported elevation angle (θ).  10
 11
If the O-RU only supports one azimuth or elevation angle, fewer than 5 beam angles will be measured.  12
 13
c.  “beam-group” beamIds test:  14
If O-RU supports and reports beamIds that belong to same and different beam-groups to the O-DU emulator, 15
the test should include the following beams: 16
1. All beams that belong to a beam-group with 0 degrees azimuth (Φ) or elevation (θ) angles. 17
2. All beams that belong to a beam-group with maximum supported azimuth angle (Φ). 18
3. All beams that belong to a beam-group with minimum supported azimuth angle (Φ). 19
4. All beams that belong to a beam-group with maximum supported elevation angle (θ). 20
5. All beams that belong to a beam-group with minimum supported elevation angle (θ). 21
 22
If the O-RU only supports one azimuth or elevation angle, fewer than 5 beam-groups will be measured. 23
 24
 25
B. Test Entrance Criteria 26
• Manufacturers’ defined list of beam indices and their associated beam directions with antenna array 27
characteristics. This list serves as indication of the expected transmitted beam direction in below  evaluation.   28
 29
C. Test Methodology 30
 31
a. Initial Conditions 32
• Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation using 33
M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  34
• Ensure that the test antenna/s and TER equipment is calibrated within acceptable toleranc e.  35
• Place the test antenna/s to a defined position within the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1. 3.2.1.1.4 and 36
configure the analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and demodulate the 37
transmitted signal. 38
• Place the O-RU into a test calibrated point within the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.3.2.1.1.4. 39
• Align the O-RU to a default initial position, i.e. align the O-RU to the origin of coordinates of the declared 40
coordinate reference point and orientation in the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.3.2.1.1.4.  41
• Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.  42
   43
b. Procedure 44
a. Build an appropriate IQ signal describing the NR-FR1-TM1.1 signal described above in the O-DU 45
emulator.   46
b. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the 47
signal and the beam under test. Every symbol should be described by either one or two  sections (DL-SCH 48
and DCI) using section type 1 messages. No section type zero messages will be used for this test.  49
c. Encapsulate the IQ data in U-Plane messages. Play those messages to the O-RU respecting timing 50
windows described in section 3.2.1.1.3.2.1.1.4.   51
d. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the signal analyzer and allow it to 52
demodulate and decode the test frame. 53
e. Measure any metric/s that allows for extracting the transmitted beam direction from a single measurement, 54
i.e. transform-based techniques, or take as many measurements of any metric/s from multiple angles, by 55
for example rotating the O-RU, that allows for extracting beam direction from multiple measurement, i.e. 56
beam scanning. 57

Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       264
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
 1
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  2
The signal measured by the signal analyzer at the contemplated transmitted beam direction should satisfy a basic 3
3GPP signal performance requirement for this radio category (i.e., EVM).  4
1. The test frame received at the contemplated transmitted beam direction by the signal analyzer should be the 5
same as the signal described above and should contain all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 6
data. 7
2. The extracted or measured transmit beam direction is defined as the direction where the best metric/s were 8
measured (i.e. best EVM, power, SNR, etc.) and should match the expected transmit beam direction for the 9
beam under test within a tolerance defined by the manufacturer.  10
 11
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP UL – Predefined-beam 12
Beamforming 13
A. Test Description and Applicability 14
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 15
 16
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can receive a basic 3GPP test frame with predefined -beams 17
beamforming (beamId≠0x000) and with one spatial stream (single eAxC).  18
 19
The same description and criteria for selecting the beams to be tested applies  as in section 3.2.6.2.3 applies, but 20
instead it is related to the uplink direction.  21
 22
B. Test Entrance Criteria 23
 24
• Manufacturers’ defined list of beam indices and their associated beam directions with antenna array 25
characteristics. This list serves as indication of the expected receive beam direction in below evaluation.   26
  27
C. Test Methodology 28
 29
a. Initial Conditions 30
• Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation using 31
M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  32
• Ensure that the test antenna/s and TER equipment is calibrated within acceptable tolerance .  33
• Place the test antenna/s to a defined position within the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1. 3.2.1.1.4 and 34
configure the signal source with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and generate the test 35
signal. 36
• Place the O-RU into a test calibrated point within the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.3.2.1.1.4. 37
• Align the O-RU to a default initial position, i.e. align the O-RU to the origin of coordinates of the declared 38
coordinate reference point and orientation in the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.3.2.1.1.4.  39
Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range 40
b. Procedure 41
a. Build an appropriate test signal described above in the signal source of the TER.  42
b. Inject the test signal into the O-RU with the application of an initial beam direction. This initial beam 43
direction could be the boresight direction of the receiver antenna array, corresponding to the 44
manufacturers declaration of the expected receive direction. 45
c. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the 46
signal and the beam under test. Every symbol should be described by either one or two  sections (UL -47
SCH) using section type 1 messages. No section type zero messages will be used for this test.  48
d. Play the C plane messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows described in section 3.2.1.1.3.2.1.1.4 49
while also triggering the signal source.   50
e. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the DUT, allow it to create and send the U 51
plane messages to the O-DU. 52
f. Allow the O-DU to demodulate, decode and extract the payload and to measure and extract any required 53
metric/s from the received signal that will be used later to determine what is the best received direction.  54
g. Repeat the previous steps but now in step b apply a different beam direction when injecting the test signal 55
into the O-RU. Repeating the process for a number of different beam directions will exercise the reception 56

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       265
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
of the test signal from different beam directions. This allows to determine if the O-RU is really focusing 1
the sensitivity to the correct beam direction. 2
 3
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  4
1. The test frame received at the contemplated receive beam direction by the TER/O -DU should be the same as 5
the signal described above and should contain all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data.  6
2. The extracted or measured receive beam direction is defined as the direction where the best metric/s were 7
measured (i.e. best EVM, power, SNR, etc.) and should match the expected beam direction for the beam under 8
test within a tolerance defined by the manufacturer.  9

 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Weight-based Dynamic 11
Beamforming 12
A. Test Description and Applicability 13
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 14
 15
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can transmit a basic 3GPP test frame with weight -based dynamic 16
beamforming with one spatial stream (single eAxC).  17
 18
The transmitted beam direction is measured for each weighted beam required in this measurement, see below. The 19
measured transmitted direction is compared to manufacturer-designated direction. Transmitted beam direction is 20
obtained by directly extracting the beam direction from the directional samples.  21
The elevation θ and azimuth Φ angles are defined as in [2] Section 10.4.1.1: 22
 23
 24
The UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Weight-based Dynamic Beamforming conformance 25
test should evaluate the following beams for the O-RU to comply: 26
a. A weight-based beam with 0 degrees azimuth (Φ) and elevation (θ) angles. 27
b. A weight-based beam with maximum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and maximum supported elevation ang le 28
(θ). 29
c. A weight-based beam with maximum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and minimum supported elevation angle 30
(θ). 31
d. A weight-based beam with minimum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and maximum supported elevation angle 32
(θ). 33
e. A weight-based beam with minimum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and minimum supported elevation angle 34
(θ). 35
 36
If the O-RU only supports one azimuth (Φ) or elevation angle (θ), fewer than 5 beam angles will be measured.  37
 38
The UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Weight—based Dynamic Beamforming 39
conformance test should also evaluate the following compression methods for each of the supported beams 40
described above (a. to e.) for the O-RU to comply: 41
a. No compression method applied to the beamforming weights.  42
b. Block floating point compression method applied to the beamforming weights with 14-bit mantissa. 43
c. Block scaling compression method applied to the beamforming weights with 14 -bit scaler. 44
d. μ-law compression method applied to the beamforming weights with 14-bit fixed width. 45
e. Beamspace compression method applied to the beamforming weights with 14 -bit scaler.  46
 47
If the O-RU does not support all the compression methods described above, fewer than 5 compression methods will 48
be measured. 49
 50
 51
B. Test Entrance Criteria 52
Manufacturers’ defined list of frequency domain (ϕ) and/or time domain (θ) weights and their associated beam 53
directions with antenna array characteristics 54
 55
C. Test Methodology 56
 57

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       266
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
a. Initial Conditions 1
• Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation 2
using M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1. 3
• Ensure that the test antenna/s and TER equipment is calibrated within acceptable tolerance.  4
• Place the test antenna/s to a defined position within the OTA chamber a s defined in 3.2.1.1.3.2.1.1.4 and 5
configure the analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and demodulate the 6
transmitted signal. 7
• Place the O-RU into a test calibrated point within the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.3.2.1.1.4. 8
• Align the O-RU to a default initial position, i.e. align the O-RU to the origin of coordinates of the declared 9
coordinate reference point and orientation in the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.3.2.1.1.4.  10
• Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.   11
 12
b. Procedure 13
a. Build an appropriate IQ signal describing the NR-FR1-TM1.1 or NR-FR2-TM1.1 signal described above in 14
the O-DU emulator.   15
b. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the signal 16
and the beam under test. Every symbol should be described by one or two sections (DL -SCH and DCI) 17
using section type 1 messages, the sections in the first symbol of the slot will contain section extension 18
extType=0x01 to convey the beam weights, it is not required that the next sections contain extension type 1 19
since the same beam IDs will not change along the slot. If O-RU does not support a field, then its value 20
should be 0x0. No section type zero messages will be used for this test. 21
c. Encapsulate the IQ data in U-Plane messages. Play those messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows 22
described in section 3.2.1.1.1.   23
d. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the signal analyzer and allow it to 24
demodulate and decode the test frame. 25
 26
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  27
1. The signal measured by the signal analyzer should satisfy a basic 3GPP signal perform ance requirement for this 28
radio category (i.e., EVM). 29
2. The test frame received by the signal analyzer should be the same as the signal described above and should 30
contain all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data. 31
3. The extracted or measured transmit beam direction is defined as the direction where the best metric/s were 32
measured (i.e. best EVM, power, SNR, etc.) and should match the expected beam direction for the beam under 33
test within a tolerance defined by the manufacturer  34

and with one spatial stream (single eAxC).  42

C. Test Methodology 52
 53
a. Initial Conditions 54
• Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation 55
using M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  56

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       267
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
• Ensure that the test antenna/s and TER equipment is calibrated within acceptable tolerance.  1
• Place the test antenna/s to a defined position within the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1. 3.2.1.1.4 and 2
configure the analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and demodulate the 3
transmitted signal. 4
• Place the O-RU into a test calibrated point within the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.3.2.1.1.4. 5
• Align the O-RU to a default initial position, i.e. align the O-RU to the origin of coordinates of the declared 6
coordinate reference point and orientation in the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.3.2.1.1.4.  7
• Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified r ange.   8
 9
b. Procedure 10
 11
a. Build an appropriate test signal related to either FR1 or FR2 described above in the signal source of the 12
TER.  13
b. Inject the test signal into the O-RU with the application of an initial beam direction as fulfilling the 14
expected spherical  RoAoA .For example, initial beam direction could be the boresight of the receive 15
antenna array.   16
c. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the signal 17
and the beam under test. Every symbol should be described by one or two sections (UL-SCH) using section 18
type 1 messages, the sections in the first symbol of the slot will contain section extension extType=0x01 to 19
convey the beam weights, it is not required that the next sections contain extension type 1 since the same 20
beam IDs will not change along the slot. If O-RU does not support a field, then its value should be 0x0. No 21
section type zero messages will be used for this test. 22
d. Play the C plane messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows described in section 3.2.1.1.1. while 23
also triggering the signal source.   24
e. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the DUT, allow it to create and send the U 25
plane messages to the O-DU and for the O-DU to demodulate, decode and extract the payload. 26
f. Repeat the previous steps but now in step b apply a different inclining beam direction or RoAoA. For 27
example, repeating the process for a number of different beam directions. This allows to determine if the O-28
RU is really focusing the sensitivity to the correct beam direction. 29
 30
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  31
1. The test frame received by the TER/O-DU should be the same as the signal described above and should contain 32
all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data. 33
2. The extracted or measured receive beam direction is defined as the direction where the best metric/s were 34
measured (i.e. best EVM, power, SNR, etc.) and should match the expected receive beam direction for the beam 35
under test within a tolerance defined by the manufacturer 36

 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Attribute-based Dynamic 39
Beamforming 40
A. Test Description and Applicability 41
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 42
 43
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can transmit a basic 3GPP test frame with attributed -based dynamic 44
beamforming with one spatial stream (single eAxC).  45
 46
If the O-RU DUT supports Attribute based Dynamic Beamforming, this test is mandatory for the O-RU DUT to be 47
O-RAN conformant.   48
The transmitted beam direction and attributes are measured for each attributed beam required in this measurement, 49
see below. The measured transmitted direction and attributes, i.e. pointing azimuth and elevation angles, 50
beamwidths and sidelobe suppression, is compared to manufacturer-designated direction and attributes. 51
Transmitted direction and beam attributes are defined by the magnitude and phase relation between the antenna 52
ports or TAB connectors under test, or by directly extracting the beam properties. 53
The elevation θ and azimuth Φ angles are defined as in Section 10.4.1.1 of [2]. 54
 55
 56

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       268
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
The UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Attribute-based Dynamic Beamforming 1
conformance test should evaluate the following beams for the O-RU to comply: 2
a. An attribute-based beam with 0 degrees azimuth (Φ) and elevation (θ) angles with any beamwidth and sidelobe 3
suppression supported by the O-RU under this beam direction. 4
b. An attribute-based beam with maximum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and maximum supported elevation angle 5
(θ) with the widest beamwidth and lowest sidelobe suppression supported for this specific beam direction.  6
c. An attribute-based beam with maximum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and minimum supported elevation angle 7
(θ) with the narrowest beamwidth and highest sidelobe suppression supported for this specific beam direction. 8
d. An attribute-based beam with minimum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and maximum supported elevation angle 9
(θ) with the widest beamwidth and lowest sidelobe suppression supported for this specific beam direction. 10
e. An attribute-based beam with minimum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and minimum supported elevation angle 11
(θ) with the narrowest beamwidth and highest sidelobe suppression supported for this specific beam direction.  12
 13
If the O-RU only supports one azimuth (Φ) or elevation angle (θ), fewer than 5 beam angles and attribute 14
configurations will be measured. 15
 16
 17
B. Test Entrance Criteria 18
Manufacturers’ defined list of frequency domain (ϕ) and/or time domain (θ) weights and their associated beam 19
directions with antenna array characteristics. 20

C. Test Methodology 22
 23
a. Initial Conditions 24
• Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation using 25
M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  26
• Ensure that the test antenna/s and TER equipment is calibrated within acceptable tolerance.  27
• Place the test antenna/s to a defined position within the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1. 3.2.1.1.4 and 28
configure the analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and demodulate the 29
transmitted signal. 30
• Place the O-RU into a test calibrated point within the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.3.2.1.1.4. 31
• Align the O-RU to a default initial position, i.e. align the O-RU to the origin of coordinates of the declared 32
coordinate reference point and orientation in the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.3.2.1.1.4.  33
• Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.   34
 35
b. Procedure 36
a. Build an appropriate IQ signal describing the NR-FR1-TM1.1 or NR-FR2-TM1.1 signal described above in 37
the O-DU emulator.   38
b. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the signal 39
and the beam under test. Every symbol should be described by one or two sections (DL -SCH and DCI) 40
using section type 1 messages, the sections in the first symbol of the slot will contain section extension 41
extType=0x02 to convey the beam weights, it is not required that the next sections contain extension type 2 42
since the same beam IDs will not change along the slot.  If O-RU does not support a field, then its value 43
should be 0x0. No section type zero messages will be used for this test. 44
c. Encapsulate the IQ data in U-Plane messages. Play those messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows 45
described in section 3.2.1.1.1.   46
d. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the signal analyzer and allow it to 47
demodulate and decode the test frame. 48
a. Extract either the beamweights, or magnitude and phase relation, or beam pr operties from the measured 49
signal. the beam direction from the measured samples. Measure any metric/s that allows for extracting the 50
transmitted beam attributes from a single measurement, i.e. transform -based techniques, or take as many 51
measurements of any metric/s from multiple angles, by for example rotating the O -RU, that allows for 52
extracting beam attributes from multiple measurement, i.e. beam scanning. 53
 54
 55

1. The signal measured by the signal analyzer should satisfy a basic 3GPP signal performance requirement for this 57
radio category (i.e., EVM). 58
2. The test frame received by the signal analyzer should be the same as the signal described above and should 59
contain all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data. 60

 4
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Channel-Information-based 5
Beamforming 6
A. Test Description and Applicability 7
This Test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 8
 9
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can transmit a basic 3GPP test frame with channel -information-based 10
beamforming with multiple spatial streams from multiple users (i.e. MU -MIMO). 11
 12
For Category A radios, the test is for each polarization separately and consequently either different or same channel 13
models can be defined for each of the polarization. For Category B, same channel might be used for both 14
polarizations and the test might measure each polarization separately. 15
The transmitted beam direction is measured for each scenario required in this measurement.  The measured 16
transmitted direction is extracted from the decoded received signal in the TER. Transmitted direction is defined by 17
properly receiving a data transmission between the O-RU and the target User Equipment while destroying or 18
heavily attenuating the data transmission between the O-RU and the other User Equipment. 19
The UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Channel-Information-based Beamforming 20
conformance test should evaluate the following scenarios for the O-RU to comply and will rely on TER Channel 21
Emulation capabilities as shown in Figure 3.2.6.2-3.  22
 23
 24
Figure 3.2.6.2-3 TER with antennas representing multiple UEs 25
 26
c. A scenario where two spatial streams, or eAxC flows, are generated for two users (one layer each) with M 27
antennas ports or TAB connectors. The O-DU will report to the O-RU via C plane messages the channel 28
estimate 𝐻 ≜  [ℎ1
1, . . . , ℎ1
𝑀, ℎ2
1, . . . , ℎ2
𝑀] ∈ ℂ2𝑥𝑀, which is the effective channel as seen by the antennas 29
representing the multiple UEs, which are spaced sufficiently such that the O-RU can effectively equalize out 30
the interference between the users. The O-RU will calculate and apply the beamweight matrix 𝐺 ≜31
 [𝑔1
1, . . . , 𝑔1
𝑀, 𝑔2
1, . . . , 𝑔2
𝑀]  ∈ ℂ𝑀𝑥2 in such that the received signal at the users is the same as the generate d in the 32
O-DU. It is up to the O-RU on how to calculate the beamforming weights, for example Zero-forcing, 33
regularized zero-forcing / MMSE, etc.   34
 35

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       271
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
If O-RU supports Analog Beamforming (Time Domain Beamforming), the test should not apply any analog 1
beamforming or time domain beamforming. In this case, M is not the number of antenna s ports or TAB connectors 2
but the number of TRX channels supported by the O-RU. 3
 4
B. Test Entrance Criteria 5
 6
• The O-RU must have at least two TRX chains with radiating antennas  7
• The TER equipment must include 2 antennas with sufficient separation to emulate the 2 users such that the O-8
RU can equalize out the mutual interference of the users due to the effective MU -MIMO channel. 9
• Manufacturers’ defined list of number of TRX chains and what antennas are connected to each TRX chain 10
 11
C. Test Methodology 12
 13
a. Initial Conditions 14
• Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation using 15
M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  16
• Ensure that the test antennas and TER equipment are calibrated within acceptable tolerance.  17
• Place the test antennas within the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.4  with sufficient separation for 18
effective MU-MIMO beamforming and configure the analyzer ports with any setup information needed to 19
synch and demodulate the MU-MIMO transmitted signal 20
• Place the O-RU into a test calibrated point within the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.4. 21
• Align the O-RU to a default initial position, i.e. align the O-RU to the origin of coordinates of the declared 22
coordinate reference point and orientation in the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.4.  23
• Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.   24
 25
b. Procedure 26
a. Build an appropriate IQ signal describing the NR-FR1-TM1.1 signal described above in the O-DU 27
emulator, with the data symbols for user 1 and user 2 fully overlapping in time and frequency, but with user 28
data initialized using different seeds for the PN23 sequence.   29
b. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the signal 30
and the scenario under test. Every symbol should be described by either one or two  sections (DL -SCH and 31
DCI) using section type 5 and 6 messages. No section type zero messages will be used for this test.  32
c. Encapsulate the IQ data in U-Plane messages. Play those messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows 33
described in section 3.2.1.1.1. 34
d. Capture the test signals and pass them through a channel emulator or apply the signal processing required 35
to emulate the channel under test using the 2 test antennas.   36
e. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the signal analyzer and allow it to 37
demodulate and decode the test frames for the 2 users. 38
 39
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  40
1. The signal measured by the signal analyzer should satisfy a basic 3GPP signal performance requirement for this 41
radio category (i.e., EVM). 42
2. The test frame received by the signal analyzer for the 2 users should be the same as the signal described above 43
and should contain all the same PRB assignments and all the respective  PN23 data. 44
 45
 46
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP UL – Channel-Information-based 47
Beamforming 48
A. Test Description and Applicability 49
This Test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 50
 51
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can receive a basic 3GPP test frame with channel -information-based 52
beamforming with multiple spatial streams from multiple users (i.e. MU-MIMO).  53
 54
Same description and criteria for selecting the beams to be tested applies as in section 3.2.3.2.103.2.6.2.9 but 55
considering the uplink direction.  56
B. Test Entrance Criteria 57
 58

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       272
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
• The O-RU must have at least two TRX chains with radiating sensing antennas  1
• The TER equipment must include 2 antennas with sufficient separation to emulate the 2 users  such that the O-2
RU can equalize out the mutual interference of the users due to the effective MU -MIMO channel. 3
• The O-RU must have at least two TRX chains with conducted antenna ports (or TAB connectors) to be 4
connected to a signal generator. 5
• The TER equipment must include 2 antennas with sufficient separation to emulate the 2 users the O -RU need 6
to be able to equalize out the mutual interference of the users due to the effective MU -MIMO channel. 7
Manufacturers’ defined list of number of TRX chains and what antennas are connected to each TRX chain. 8
 9
C. Test Methodology 10
 11
a. Initial Conditions 12
• Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation 13
using M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  14
• Ensure that the test antennas and TER equipment are calibrated within acceptable toleranc e.  15
• Place the test antennas within the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.4 with sufficient separation for 16
effective MU-MIMO beamforming and configure the generator ports with any setup information needed to 17
transmit the signals from the 2 UEs 18
• Place the O-RU into a test calibrated point within the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.4. 19
• Align the O-RU to a default initial position, i.e. align the O-RU to the origin of coordinates of the declared 20
coordinate reference point and orientation in the OTA chamber as d efined in 3.2.1.1.4.  21
• Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.  22
  23
b. Procedure 24
a. Build the appropriate test signals for each of the 2 users as described above in the signal source of the TER 25
using a different seed to initialize the PN23 data for each user. 26
b. Transmit the test signals over the air with sufficient transmit power according to  3.2.1.1.4 27
c. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the signal 28
and the beam under test. Every symbol should be described by either one or two  sections (UL -SCH) using 29
section type 5 and 6. No section type zero messages will be used for this test. 30
d. Play the C plane messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows described in section 2.4. while also 31
triggering the signal source.   32
e. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the DUT, allow it to create and send the U -33
plane messages to the O-DU and for the O-DU to demodulate, decode and extract the payload for each of 34
the users. 35
 36
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  37
The test frames received by the TER/O-DU should be the same as the signals described above and should contain all the 38
same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data of the 2 users. 39
 40
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Compression (CMP) 41
The compression tests for FR1 and FR2 TDD Non-conducted OTA are the same as the tests described in section 3.2.5.3 42
for FR1.  For FR2, similar test frames with 120 KHz SCS shall be used in the test   Only the setup for the tests are 43
different reflecting the difference between non-conductive and conductive mode testing.  44
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Delay Management (DLM) 45
The delay management tests for FR1 and FR2 TDD Non-conducted OTA are the same as the tests described in section 46
3.2.5.4 for FR1.  For FR2, similar test frames with 120 KHz SCS shall be used in the test.  Only the setup for the tests 47
are different reflecting the difference between non-conductive and conductive mode testing.  48
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Transport (TRN) 49
This test is for future study. 50
 51

                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class LAA (LAA) 1
The LAA tests for FR1TDD Non-conducted OTA are the same as the tests described in section 3.2.5.6.  Only the setup 2
for the tests are different reflecting the difference between non-conductive and conductive mode testing.  Note that 3
LAA tests are not applicable for the FR2 spectrum.  4
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class LTE (LTE) 5
This test is for future study. 6
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Section Type 3 (ST3) 7
The Section Type 3 tests for FR1 and FR2 TDD Non-conducted OTA are the same as the tests described in section 8
3.2.5.8 for FR1.  For FR2, similar test frames with 120 KHz SCS shall be used in the t est.  Only the setup for the tests 9
are different reflecting the difference between non-conductive and conductive mode testing.  10
 11
 12
3.3 S-Plane Conformance Tests 13
This section describes tests that are used to validate S-Plane functional and performance conformance of network 14
elements using the O-RAN WG4 fronthaul interface defined in [2] and the O-RAN WG4 M-Plane interface defined in 15
[3].  This version of the conformance specification defines both O-DU and O-RU conformance tests.  Future versions of 16
this specification will describe additional S-Plane functional and performance conformance tests of other clocks used in 17
the front haul, e.g. PRTC/T-GM, etc.  18
S-Plane functionality of the O-RU is determined based on status retrieved from the O-RU using the M-Plane or SMO as 19
appropriate, whereas, S-Plane performance is determined by over-the-air (OTA) or conductive (i.e. a cabled electrical 20
connection to the DUT’s radio interface) measurements of O-RU synchronization signal.  21
S-Plane functionality of the O-DU is determined based on status retrieved from the O-DU using the SMO. As M-plane 22
specification in WG5 become available, retrieval of O-DU status based on M-plane will be considered for functional 23
tests, as well.  24
The performance of O-DU is determined by time/frequency error measurements on output signals (such as 1PPS, or 25
fronthaul SyncE+PTP master ports in LLS-C1 and LLS-C2).  When applicable, O-DU tests are based on ITU-T 26
G.8275.1 profile. ITU-T G.8275.2 is not specifically supported in this document version because this standard does not 27
specify performance criteria and is left for further study.   28
O-DU tests consider both local and remote PRTC connections, as shown in Figure 3.3.1 -1. The connection type is 29
relevant for performance tests because the input conditions applied to DUT depends on connection types supported:  30
•  An embedded PRTC (e.g. using embedded GNSS receiver, Figure 3.3.1-1a) has no exposed direct O-DU 31
interface, so test stimulus is applied to the Time Reference input (e.g. GNSS RF).  32
•  A local PRTC is collocated with the O-DU and may communicate to O-DU via either a 1PPS and serial link 33
(e.g. ITU-T G.8271 or similar interface), Figure 3.3.1-1b, or an Ethernet interface (PTP and PLSF, Figure 34
3.3.1-1c).  35
• A remote PRTC is located anywhere in the network (backhaul or fronthaul) and communicates to O -DU via an 36
Ethernet interface (PTP and PLSF, Figure 3.3.1-1d). 37
 38

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       274
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
 1
Figure 3.3.1-1 Methods to connect PRTC to O-DU  2
 3
Both functional and performance tests require the provision of a test equipment i.e. provision of a test setup that 4
includes a CUSM-E which delivers the necessary stimuli as described in section 3.31. 5
The S-Plane conformance test suite assumes that the vendor’s equipment is conformant and has been tested to meet the 6
requirements of G.8275.1 and IEEE1588v2 and other relevant S-Plane standards. Therefore, this document does not 7
attempt to duplicate tests for these standards.    8
The below sections of bullets summarize the test scope in order to validate conformance to the synchronization plane 9
specification referenced by [2] section 9.  10
• General points which apply to testing of both functional and performance aspects of the O-DU and O-RU: 11
• The tests apply to both 4G (LTE/E-UTRA) and 5G (NR) and are applicable to all O-RAN IOT profiles listed 12
in Annex A 13
• A CUSM-E is needed to generate the necessary M-plane or SMO and S-Plane traffic that includes PTP and 14
possibly SyncE SSM over ESMC. It is synchronized to a time reference. For the O-RU testing a CUSM-E 15
must also generate CU-Plane background traffic. 16
• Shall be done in the lab at constant temperature  17
• The CUS specification [2] may in the future support different kinds of Physical Layer Frequency Support 18
(PLSF), however the only fully specified PLFS by the current edition of [2] is SyncE. Thus, these S-Plane tests 19
are defined to include SyncE when required. 20
• Testing of SyncE is optional and is only valid when the SyncE device which can be driven by a  master (e.g. O-21
RU) makes use of it. Therefore, the related SyncE test cases are optional. 22
 23
• The following bulleted points apply specifically to functional tests of the O-RU in addition to the general points 24
above, 25
• For validation of S-Plane, the following are used: 26
o A CUSM-E sends and receives synchronization information over the fronthaul interface.  27
o A Measurement Equipment to perform frequency/phase/time measurements from any available 28
synchronization interface.  29
o DUT’s S-Plane reports its state over M-Plane. 30
• The acceptance criterion for these tests is to comply with specification [2]. 31
 32
• The following bullets points apply specifically to functional test of the O-DU in addition to the general points 33
above: 34
• On its input ports, O-DU end application like O-RU may optionally use SyncE along with PTP. However, in 35
the case of an LLS-C1/C2 O-DU acting as G.8275.1 SyncE+PTP master, SyncE emission is mandatory on the 36
fronthaul for validation of S-plane: 37

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       275
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
o DUT reports its S-Plane state over SMO (and in future WG5 M-plane). 1
• The acceptance criterion for these tests is to comply with specification [2]. 2
• The CUSM-E also provides local time source input signals to the O-DU: 3
o GNSS RF signals, delivered by a GNSS generator referenced to the local time reference  4
o PRTC output signals (1PPS + serial link)  5
• The following bulleted points apply specifically to performance tests for O-RU and O-DU in addition to the general 6
points above. 7
• These tests are not defined to fully stress the DUT. Rather they are intended to stress the DUT enough to 8
determine that it can properly operate via the defined front haul protocol.    9
o The thermal profile is not defined. The tests are defined to be run at a constant temperature, but the 10
thermal profile choice and range is left as a decision for the vendor.  11
o The variable C/U-Plane profile (for example similar to test case 13 shown in figure VI.11 of ITU-T 12
G.8261 [10]) will be defined as part of the work on the future performance tests.  13
o All performance tests described in this section assume the following two components in the procedure (test 14
methodology sections): 15
o Establishing the necessary M-plane session to bring up the O-RU or O-DU and make it ready for 16
transmission of a measurement signal. For the O-DU, the establishment of an M-plane session can be done 17
when the WG5 M-plane is available. In the interim, the O-DU shall be configured using SMO.  18
o For the O-RU in addition to the M-plane session, the transmission of a test signal necessitates the 19
provision of a CU plane test vector. The test vector needs to have enough information to set up a 20
synchronization channel within the radio frame transmitted over the air.  21
o For O-DU performance tests the test cannot be executed unless the O-DU provides an Ethernet port with 22
sync master function and/or a 1PPS output signal.  23
• The acceptance criterion for the performance tests is to satisfy the 3GPP OTA TAE limits specified in 3GPP 24
TS 36.141 [18] for 4G (LTE) and 38.141-2 [20] for 5G (NR), and summarized in eCPRI [11] and ITU-T 25
G.8271 [7]. The conditions applicable to each test will be set out in the relevant sections  below (future work 26
item). OTA TAE limits for MIMO/Tx Diversity is outside the scope of this document because they apply 27
between endpoints belonging to the same O-RU. 28
• The CUS Specification [2] which follows eCPRI and IEEE802.1 CM recommendation, defines two examples 29
of O-RU types, but these are not strict classes like the T-BC classes specified in ITU-T G.8273.2. 30
3.3.1 Test Environment 31
The following describes the necessary functions and capabilities of the test equipment in order to perform O-RU or O-32
DU conformance tests. A diagram of the O-RU test set up shown in Figure 3.3.1-2, and a similar diagram of the O-DU 33
test set up is shown in Figure 3.3.1-3.  34
Referring to Figure 3.3.1-2, the stimulus is applied to the O-RU via an Ethernet interface which simulates an ORAN 35
CUS-Plane protocols by using equipment to generate an O-DU and/or front haul time reference. This interface carries 36
the PTP and SyncE stimulus to test the O-RU and carries M-Plane information to configure DUT and as needed C-37
Plane and U-Plane information to generate a test signal to measure time accuracy.  Performance measurements are 38
made at the radio output.  These measurements can be made either over the air (called a non-conductive measurement), 39
or via a cable connection from the radio interface (called conductive measurement).  If the O -RU has a 1PPS (One 40
Pulse Per Second) output, which has been correlated to the radio output , the measurements can be made using the 1PPS 41
output.  42
Figure 3.3.1-2 applies to LLS-C1/C2/C3 topologies.  LLS-C4 topology is for further study. 43
 44

Figure 3.3.1-2 O-RU C1/C2/C3 Conformance Test Set Up 2
As shown in Figure 3.3.1.3, the O-DU the setup is similar to the O-RU. In addition to the option to supply timing using 3
PTP via Ethernet (like the O-RU), the input stimulus may be applied to the DUT from a directly connected Time 4
Reference which delivers frequency (e.g. SyncE, 10MHz, 1PPS), phase (e.g.1PPS, 10ms frame boundary) and time 5
(e.g. ToD, PTP) signals.  Directly connecting the Time Reference time via a Local Sync Port simulates topology with 6
an O-DU using a Local PRTC Time Reference. Using PTP via an Ethernet Test Port simula tes a topology using a 7
Remote PRTC. 8
For the O-DU performance tests the quality of the DUTs timing output is measured via the DUT’s Master Ethernet Port 9
(again, if available) which propagates the time and optionally frequency information from the DUT using PTP, and 10
optionally SyncE, or 1PPS output (if available). If no master ethernet port or 1PPS output are available, then 11
performance test cannot be executed. 12
• Typically, in LLS-C1/C2, using a spare Ethernet Master Port offers the most accurate interface 13
• Typically, in LLS-C3/C4, using a 1PPS measurement interface may avoid having to configure an Ethernet port 14
as PTP master for measurement purpose. 15

Figure 3.3.1-3 O-DU C1/C2/C3/C4 Conformance Test Set Up with an a) Embedded PRTC, b) Local Sync Port 2
PRTC, c) PRTC over PTP/SyncE 3
 4
CUSM-Plane Emulator: This function implements various planes (C, U, S, M) to simulate a front haul/transport 5
network connecting to DUT (i.e. O-RU, O-DU). It should be capable of testing S-Plane performance under stress with 6
various noise profiles. S-Plane signals sent to DUT and measurement equipment are traceable to reference signals 7
received from the master time reference. Emulator should generate noise free reference signal for Measurement 8
Equipment and (when required) a noise profile for the DUT. The CUSM-Plane emulator may be composed of multiple 9
components or could be a single component containing all the capabilities listed below. When O -RU is the DUT UC-10
Plane is needed for O-RU to generate a radio information required to measure timing.  For O-DU, CU-Plane 11
functionality is not used since timing is measured directly from an Ethernet or 1PPS test port.  12
• Time Reference/S-Plane: This equipment is the frequency and time reference. It delivers frequency (e.g. 13
SyncE, 10MHz, 1PPS), phase (e.g.1PPS, 10ms frame boundary) and time (e.g. ToD, PTP) signals to the Sync 14
Tester equipment and to the various simulators/generators listed below. PRTC specified by ITU -T G.8272 is 15
one example in terms of performance. The level of performance for these reference signals should be 16
significantly (by an order of magnitude) better than the 3GPP synchronization requirements, when absolute 17
limits are measured against the reference clock. The time reference function with t he CUSM-Plane emulator is 18
traceable to UTC. The time output is used to synchronize the Signal Analyzer or Test Equipment performing 19
time error measurements. The phase output is used to synchronize the Signal Analyzer or Test Equipment 20
performing time error measurements. 21

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       278
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
• PRTC/T-GM: for testing an O-DU from either local or remote PRTC over Ethernet. It includes a PTP master 1
clock and, when applicable, a SyncE master function that propagate the Time reference and allow adding 2
configured noise patterns. 3
• GNSS Emulator: for testing an O-DU with integrated local PRTC. The GNSS emulator will provide an RF 4
signal to the O-DU. The RF signal emulates a signal received by a GNSS antenna and allows adding 5
configured noise patterns. As an alternative to a GNSS emulator fo llowing case is acceptable: the test 6
environment provides the capability to access a GNSS antenna mounted at a suitable location inside the 7
building with line of sight to sufficient number of GNSS satellites (>4).  8
• PRTC Emulator: for testing an O-DU with integrated T-GM, but without an integrated local PRTC: in this 9
case, the test setup needs to provide the following signals to the O-DU: 1PPS (according to ITU G.703), 10
10MHz, and serial link carrying ToD and PRTC status. There are different ToD formats such as ITU-T G.8271 11
Annex A and NMEA. The ToD format of the test setup needs to deliver the ToD format supported by the O -12
DU. This interface allows adding configured noise patterns. 13
• SMO: Responsible for configuring CUSM Plane emulator to send configuration to DUT for the defined 14
conformance tests. 15
• M-Plane: Translate the SMO configuration into the proper M-Plane messages to correctly configure and 16
report status from the DUT.  For O-RU testing this is implemented using WG4 M-Plane protocol.  For O-DU 17
this is implemented by either using a Network Management System (SMO) which is compatible with the DUT 18
or using a WG5 M-Plane emulator. 19
• UC-Plane: S-Plane tests require the transmission of UC-Plane traffic over the fronthaul, the emulator shall 20
implement the O-RAN UC-Plane protocol and shall send a stock data frame defined in Section 2.3.5 and 21
shown in Figure 2-3 as UC-Plane messages to DUT O-RU. 22
The emulator shall merge all traffic types for transmission over the fronthaul without degrading performance of S-23
Plane. 24

Table 3.3.1-3.2.6.8-1 O-DU C1/C2/C3 Input Source and Output Source Options  25
Measurement Equipment: This equipment is responsible for extracting the desired synchronization information from 26
the test signal transmitted by the DUT, and then measuring this information to determine if the performance is within 27
limits. This could be a single piece of test equipment containing all the capabilities listed below, or it may be created  by 28
interconnecting a separate signal analyzer and performance measurement system.   29
For O-RU testing the following measurement equipment is needed. 30
• Signal Extractor/Analyzer: This equipment demodulates the time reference signal from the O-RU’s 31
downlink radio interface. It receives RF signals from the DUT’s air or preferably coaxial interface. This 32
equipment should be connected to Synchronization/Reference Clock to be able to lock on the correct 33
synchronization channel of the O-RU RF output signal. 34
• Performance Measurement Equipment: This equipment performs error measurements of the 1pps and 35
10MHz signals from DUT or from Signal Extractor.  It uses standard metrics to validate if measured signal 36
meets the defined limits. It is recommended to use a ≥2 GHz sampling on 1pps signals (for 1 ns sampling 37
accuracy)  38
For O-DU testing the following measurement equipment is used. 39
• PTP/SyncE/1pps Measurement Equipment: This equipment is responsible for extracting the desired 40
synchronization information from the master Ethernet port (e.g. decoding the PTP and/or SyncE sent from 41

________________________________________________________________________________________________
Copyright © 2021 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       279
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
DUT’s master port) or 1PPS output from the DUT. Then measuring this information to determine if the 1
performance of the DUT is within limits. 2
3.3.2 Functional test of O-RU using ITU-T G.8275.1 profile (LLS-C1/C2/C3) 3
A. Test Description and Applicability 4
This test is MANDATORY. 5
The purpose of this test is to validate that an O-RU is correctly synchronizing to a CUSM Emulator delivering both 6
PTP and (optionally) SyncE using ITU-T G.8275.1 [5] profile and that the O-RU correctly reports its status to the 7
CUSM Emulator based on the nominal or degraded synchronization conditions generated by CUSM Emulator .  8
B. Test Entrance Criteria 9
O-RU is connected to CUSM Emulator directly.  10
O-RU must be operating with the respective SMO or M-Plane properly. (as defined in 3.2.1.1.53.2.1.1.5). 11
C. Test Methodology 12
a. Initial Conditions 13
This test uses the O-RU (DUT), a CUSM-Plane emulator with SMO features to generate stimulus for the O-14
RU (DUT) and signal analyzer to measure the radio interface timing. 15
b. Procedure 16
Three conditions must be tested: 17
Startup: CUSM-Plane Emulator is configured to act as a clock, with PTP and SyncE ports in passive state (no 18
messages sent) 19
Nominal: CUSM-E is configured to start acting as a PTP master compliant with the ITU-T G.8275.1 [5] 20
profile advertising LOCKED status with nominal clockClass and clockAccuracy. If SyncE is to be tested 21
CUSM-Plane Emulator is configured to act as a clock, with SyncE ports in master state, compliant to ITU -T 22
G.8264 profile advertising nominal SSM value as specified by ITU-T G.8275.1 [5]. 23
Degraded: There are two levels of degraded conditions for both PTP and SyncE that can be configured to the 24
CUSM-Emulator. 25
• The first degradation level is where the CUSM-E is configured to act as a clock, with PTP and SyncE 26
ports in master state, compliant to ITU-T G.8275.1 profile, and sending configured clockClass and/or 27
SSM values within the O-RU’s configured accepted limits via the M-plane.  28
• The second degradation level is where the same clockClass and/or SSM values are sent by CUSM-E 29
outside the O-RU’s configured accepted limits via the M-plane. 30
To cover the all the relevant scenarios the test sequence listed in Table 3.3.2-3.2.6.8-1 steps through the 31
Startup/Nominal/Degraded states in a sequence. The steps in this table and Table 3.3.2-2 are intended to be 32
exercised in sequential order.  Since SyncE is optional, there are two columns, one for PTP status and a second 33
for SyncE.  Each of the status items corresponds the conditions defined above. 34
 35

________________________________________________________________________________________________

Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       280
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v03.00
Step PTP Status:  SyncE Status (if applicable): SSM
1. Startup: no clockclass Startup: no SSM/QL
2. Nominal clockclass=6 Nominal QL= (see Note 1)
3. Degraded clockclass but within the O-RU’s
configured accepted range.
Nominal QL= (see Note 1)
4. Degraded clockclass outside the O-RU’s
configured accepted range.
Nominal QL= (see Note 1)
5. Degraded clockclass outside the O-RU’s
configured accepted range.
Degraded QL outside the O-RU’s configured accepted
range.
6. Nominal clockclass=6 Nominal QL= (see Note 1)
7. Nominal clockclass=6 Degraded QL but within the O-RU’s configured
accepted range.
8. Nominal clockclass=6 Degraded QL outside the O-RU’s configured accepted
range.
9. Nominal clockclass=6 Nominal QL = (see Note1)
10. S-Plane lost, no message S-Plane lost, no message
Note 1: For SyncE, Nominal QL is what is determined as the best acceptable configured value by the O-RU 1

D. Pass Fail Criteria (expected results) 3
The acceptance criterion is that the status reported by the O-RU for the steps defined in above procedure matches 4
the results described in Table 3.3.2-.   The left column indicates the steps defined in Table 3.3.2-3.2.6.8-1. The 5
second column summarizes the O-RU status from Table 3.3.2-3.2.6.8-1.  The right two columns list the M-plane 6
clock status parameters that are queried from the test O-RU and their desired value. For PTP clockClass and 7
optional SyncE SSM quality level, the “Received Value” is the one received by the O-RU (except in Startup mode 8
when there is no such received value and the default one is reported).  9
The O-RU Sync-state, PTP lock state, PTP state, PTP clock-class, SyncE lock-state, SyncE state, SyncE quality-10
level are defined in the M-Plane specification [3] (chapter 10) and relevant YANG models.  11
